column2: BERGEN--Benjamin Eric. 12/7/1977 - 6/14/1995 It's been 20 years since we have lost you. We think about you every day. We will always love you. Dad, Mom and Sarah 1/3

GRIFFIN--James Q. The Board of Governors of The Ivy Club and the Trustees of the Ivy 1879 Foundation mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our friend, James Q. Griffin, Princeton Class of 1955. Jim was elected president of The Ivy Club in 1982, and he led the Club for over three decades, overseeing changes including the admission of women and the establishment of the Foundation to further the Club's educational role. He conceived of and led the effort to build a splendid addition to Ivy's Clubhouse, named by the Board the Griffin Wing despite the reluctance born of Jim's characteristic modesty. He nurtured the undergraduate members in the Club's culture by his unassuming example in word and deed, and by his endearing sense of humor. Thanks to his irresistible charm and wisdom, Jim exercised his leadership through the creation of a willing consensus in the board and the membership as a whole. His vision advanced the quality of the Club's life and enhanced its educational mission. Jim's legacy, in spirit and in stone, will always be an important part of Ivy. Jim Griffin was a natural and complete gentleman, a loyal Princetonian and a man utterly devoted to his family and his friends. The values by which he lived, and the standards he set, inspired all those whose lives he touched. We shall miss him greatly. The Trustees of the Foundation join the Governors of Ivy in extending to Jim's wife, Barbie, and to his entire family, our heartfelt condolences. The Ivy Club Corbin R. Miller, Treasurer Robert A. Engel, Secretary Ivy 1879 Foundation John F. Cook, President Frances P. Jain, Secretary 1/3

GREEN--Charles P. III, "BC," 32, died Sunday, May 31, 2015 at home in Albany, NY. Born in Manhattan, he is the beloved son of Marianna Reges and Charles P. Green. He was the cherished father of Alivia Alice DeGeorge Green; brother of Rebecca Reges Green; survived by aunts, uncles, cousins, wonderful friends and his beloved dog, Ramona. Memorial services will be held on Monday, June 15, 2015 at 5:30pm in the sanctuary of the First Presbyterian Church, NYC, on Fifth Avenue (12 West 12th St.), followed by a Celebration of Life from 6-9pm, in the church parlor. 1/3

SHACK--Barbara. A bright star went out the morning of June 9th when we lost our dear and precious friend, Barbara Shack. Barbara was a most unusual woman. She was our hero. A fighter for civil rights, women's rights, gays, people of color, immigrants and children. Where there was darkness, she was a glowing star. Barbara valued the Constitution, she loved our country and tried to make it better for everyone. She was a true Citizen and a great New Yorker. To say we will miss this incredible loving woman is an understatement. Our condolences to Donald, her children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren. So long Barbara, we'll miss you always. Marsha, Nora, Roger & Seymour. 1/3

ABRAMS--Larry H.,died June 10th of cancer at the age of 61. Real estate manager, lawyer, longtime trustee at Gould Farm, he touched the lives of all who knew him. Until his final days he made new friends and lived life to the fullest. He is survived by his beloved son Justin, devoted partner Betty Sheets, sister Judith Abrams - McCarthy (Tom McCarthy), ex-wife Janet West and his many, many friends. We were not ready to see him go. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contact jlkainen@gmail.com for details. Contributions in his memory can be made to Gould Farm. www.gouldfarm.org. 1/3
FIALKOFF--Frank. Dearest nephew. You and yours are forever in our hearts. Aunt Roberta, Uncle Edgar and family 1/3

MATISON--Sumner Eliot, June 12, 2015, 94. Harvard and Columbia University Grad, Clinical Social Worker. Sumner's kindness and generosity, wisdom and humor, will live on in the hearts of his friends and family. He leaves behind his devoted daughters Rena Greenblatt and Lisa Garrigues; his adoring grandchildren Daniel, David, Colette, and Miles; and the loving memory of his wife Shirley and son Jason. Private Memorial Sunday. Shiva Monday 5-8pm. 1/3

ROSEN--Arthur, on June 10. World War II Veteran. Beloved husband of Harriet. Father of Jeffrey and Donald. Grandfather and great-grandfather. A member of the Greatest Generation. Lovingly, Mike, Regina, Eric, Jamie and Families. 1/3

BILLER--Abraham. Park East Synagogue and Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourn the passing of our devoted member, Abraham Biller, generous supporter of Jewish Education and the State of Israel, beloved brother of Miriam Biller, uncle of Rachel (Yitzchok) Zimmerman. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President 1/3
ALLISON--Clyde H. (Skip) April 12, 1959 - June 13, 1990. Cherished forever. Please honor this wonderful man by letting the people you love know how you feel. 1/3

LONDON--Mel, an award-winning filmmaker, television director and author died on Monday, May 18, 2015 at his home in Manhattan's East Village. The cause was heart failure said his wife of 69 years, Sheryl. Mel produced many documentary and corporate films, earning over 250 awards, among them an Academy Award nomination in 1963 for the film "To Live Again". Mel and Sheryl also collaborated on 16 food and lifestyle books. They were winners of the James Beard Cookbook award for "A Seafood Celebration" and 1st place Tastemaker award for "Fish Lovers Cookbook". Mel also taught at NYU film school and wrote the popular film textbooks, "Making it in Film" and "Getting Into Film". He authored a travel book "Easy Going", and one on success in life's middle years, "Second Spring". Born and raised in the Bronx he attended CCNY before enlisting in the US army where he rose to the rank of 2nd Lieutenant. He served in Germany in WWII with African-American troops before the army was integrated. When the war ended he and his wife went to Berlin, during the "occupation", where they lived while Mel worked for the "Armed Forces Network" as a sport caster and disc jockey for the troops. Upon his return to the U.S. he joined "On Film" an avant-garde company based in Princeton, NJ. He was spirited away by the burgeoning young television industry where he directed "Play of the Week", a syndicated series featuring top Broadway talent. He then joined David Wolper Association, a California company where he was a vice-president. He refused to move to California and left to form a partnership with Lee R. Bobker and "Vision Associates" in New York. From there Mel and Sheryl formed their own company "Symbiosis" a name selected to illustrate their interactive skills. At Symbiosis, they traveled to 66 countries producing films and making life-long friends. From their vacation home in Saltaire, Fire Island they wrote, created and tested their cookbooks. Mel was an avid fisherman and Sheryl developed a "green thumb" in the garden. Mel is survived by his wife, his brother Stanley, his sister-in-law Elaine and his niece Leslie and her children Daniel and Alexandra. No services are planned, a donation can be made in his name to the American Heart Association. 1/3

BRENNER--Miriam, nee Spierer. Born March 9th 1925; died June 11th 2015. Beloved mother, sister, grandmother, aunt, and mother-in-law. You were blessed with a wonderful marriage, loving family and many friends who will miss your laughter and zest for life. Services to be held at "The Riverside," on 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday, June 14, 2015 at 12pm. 1/3

MAYER--Mary Joan. Beloved wife of Lawrence A, died June 4th 2015 at age 90. Her children, David and Elizabeth (Raleigh), son-in-law Michael Keohane, granddaughter Maud, and sisters Ruth Newton and Nancy Simon survive her. Born in Manhattan to Joseph and Winifred (nee Schruers) Levy, she graduated cum laude from Mt. Holyoke College in 1945. A career in economic and social research included positions at the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and the Girl Scouts of America. She later became Director of Research, Planning and Policy and then Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Department for the Aging. In retirement, she was an NGO representative of the International Federation on Aging at the U.N. and a board member of Selfhelp Community Services Inc. A private celebration of her life will be held this fall. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Young People's Chorus of New York City (www.ypc.org). 1/3

ST. GEORGE--Judith Alexander, passed away peacefully in Bloomfield, CT with her husband at her side on June 10, 2015. Judith was 84 years old. She authored more than 40 books. In 2001, her book So You Want to be President was awarded the Caldecott Medal. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, David St. George; her children: Peter St. George; James St. George; Philip St. George; Sarah St. George; and five grandchildren. 1

BRENNINKMEIJER--Wendy. Wendy Phelps West Brenninkmeijer, May 8, 1959 -- May 1, 2015. Wendy was born on May 8, 1959 in New Jersey. After prolonged complications with bone cancer, she passed away peacefully in her Santa Barbara home on May 1, 2015 with her beloved husband and three children present. Wendy grew up with her four siblings in Bernardsville, New Jersey. She attended Ethel Walkers boarding school (Class of '77) in Simsbury, Connecticut and subsequently Boston College (Class of '82) where she received a Bachelor of Arts in History. Later on, Wendy received a Master of Arts degree in Counseling from Pacifica Graduate Institute (Class of '04) in Carpinteria as well as a Health Coaching and Integrative Therapies certificate from the University of Minnesota (Class of '13). In 2007, Wendy founded Healers West with the mission to create a unified global network of healers and to provide an educational community resource for expanding public awareness of complementary and alternative therapies as related to integrative medicine. During her years at Boston College, Wendy met Titus Brenninkmeijer whom she married in 1986 and together they raised three children - Ian (25), Sophie (24) and Miles (21). Wendy lived in a number of countries with her family including Spain, Germany and Brazil. Wendy will be remembered by her closest family and friends as a person who lived to serve others. Following college, Wendy worked with refugees from El Salvador and Vietnam while serving as an in home trainer for the Refugee Women's Program in San Francisco. She also worked with North African and Romani refugees in Spain, rural development and family planning programs in Mexico and volunteered among the street children of Sao Paulo's infamous favelas in Brazil. It was while Wendy was living in Brazil that her husband's near death experience transformed her life, eventually leading to her training as a Flower Essence Practitioner/Reiki Master. She was a member of the Brazilian flower essence organization Gotas de Flor com Amor and prepared flower essences from her home for family and friends. Wendy cultivated a unique understanding and outlook on her medical situation and treatment. To her, personal healing was not defined by the outcome yet characterized as a spiritual journey and an opportunity to learn not only about herself but also the healing powers of alternative health practices with integrated medicine. A memorial service will be held on June 20th at 1:30pm in the Chapel at Ethel Walker School, 230 Bushy Hill Rd. Simsbury, CT 06070. There will be a reception following the service at the "Living Room" at Ethel Walker School. In lieu of flowers, friends can remember Wendy by donating to the Women's Wisdom Initiative, a cause very close to Wendy's heart, and started by her childhood friend. womenswisdominitiative.org/donate. Services entrusted to McDermott-Crockett Mortuary, Santa Barbara, CA . 1/3

STEINBERG--Eugene, age 88, died peacefully from a long battle with cancer, on June 11, 2015. He is survived by his devoted wife of 63 years Estelle, his children Sandy and Martin Pollock, Arthur and Ninette Steinberg, Norman Steinberg and Amy Davidson, his grandchildren Erica and Mike Distenfeld and great granddaughter Lucy, Brad and Shana Pollock, Jaclyn and Dave Cooper, Lauren, Alyx, Jason Steinberg and his fiance Alanna, Brian and Jonathan Steinberg. His father came to the United States from Pinsk Belarus and then brought over his mother, two brothers and two sisters. He grew up in Brownsville Brooklyn and went to Tilden High School. From those humble beginnings, Eugene founded two successful businesses, Largene Press and Bell Vending. He was an active synagogue member in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, Long Beach Island New Jersey, Del Ray Florida, and Monroe New Jersey. A devoted uncle and cousin, an active supporter of Israel and Jewish causes, Eugene understood people and was a generous soul with a loving heart. A true "mensch." He will always be with us. 1/3

CHARTOFF--Robert. I mourn the passing of my friend Bob. He will live on in our memories and his accomplishments and philanthropies will endure. His films have already become classics. My heart goes out to his family especially to his loving wife Jenny whose courage during his last illness matched his own. We became friends and fraternity brothers at Union College in 1951. Our friendship grew and became closer with age. I will miss him. Mort Silver 1/3

RUTSCHMANN--Jakob (aka Jacques), Ph.D.,90, of Manhattan, NY, died on June 4, 2015, in Palo Alto, CA. Born in Zurich in 1925, Dr. Rutschmann was educated in Switzerland, then spent his career as a psychology professor at Columbia University. He was optimistic, intellectually curious and full of humor. He is survived by two children, two grandchildren and by extended family and friends. Donations to Natural Resources Defense Council. 1/3

TURK--Anita. 1931-2015. Predeceased by loving husband Norman. Adored mother of Merri and Lewis; mother-in-law of Stuart. Cherished grandmother of Bari and Jared. Devoted sister of Marilyn Starr. Loving aunt, cousin, and friend. She will be greatly missed. 1/3
RACHLIN--Dr. Edward. Dr. Edward Rachlin Memorial Service 5pm, June 18 at Carnegie Hall, Rohatyn Room. 57th St. Weill Hall Entrance 1/3
SCHWARTZ--Dr. Morton. To my dearest friend and roommate. Part of me will always be with you. Good night sweet prince. We will miss and always love you. Gloria and Larry 1/3

WARTELS--Penelope "Penny" Johnson--on February 13, 2015. She is survived by her husband David E. Wartels; and her son's Wyatt and Edward, their wive's and three granddaughters. A memorial service will be held at The Weekapaug Chapel, Weekapaug, RI on June 27th at 11am. 1

APPELMAN--Shirley, on June 5, 2015 at age 95; passed away peacefully after a long and healthy life. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David H. Appelman, father of Eleanore (Eugene) Schloss, Robert (Louise) Appelman, grandmother of Sima Schloss and Henry (Betsy) Schloss, great-grandmother of Oliver Schloss. A funeral service and burial was held on June 7, 2015 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Morton MD, "Matza", was a star football player at Far Rockaway High School and Rutgers University. Following military service he went into private medical practice. He completed 60 years as an Internist and Gastroenterologist. He recognized Endoscopy as a useful diagnostic procedure and privately trained with guidance from Dr. Jerome Waye. He was an old fashioned caring doctor and a brilliant diagnostician. Next to his family, it was his primary motivation in life. Dr. Schwartz was a devoted husband to Elaine. He was a most caring father to Dr. Stewart (Edith), Melissa (Michael) Chambers, Dr. Jeffrey (Ingrid), Betsy and the late Steven Hornstein, Dr. Melanie (Dr. David) Hecker, Dr. Douglas, and Jessica (Ronald) Lanzilotta. His grandchildren include Veronica, Anthony, Jeffrey Jr., Jarred, Alec, Franklin, Marissa, Fiona, Phoebe, Madison, Rylie, Codie, Ronald and Joseph. They all adored him. Special thanks to Ellen, Tom, and Claire for their loyalty. Most appreciation to Doriel Butcher who gave unreserved devotion to his care and comfort. He will always be loved and missed by his family and all who knew him. Services from Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Today, 2pm. 1/3

BELEFANT--Eva T.,passed away on June 12, 2015. Eva was predeceased by Marty, her beloved husband of 59 years and is survived by her devoted son Peter, her sister Margot Cranley, and many dear and numerous lifelong friends. She was ahead of her time in her actions and thoughts. Exceedingly capable, living life with vitality and genuineness she took special pleasure in her family, friends, gardens and pets. Services Monday, June 15, 12 noon at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583 As she lives in our hearts, in lieu of a donation, please plant a flower, shrub or tree as a living memory to Eva. 1/3

BREWSTER--Alison Folliss, long time resident of New York and Wilton, CT died peacefully on May 27th in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL at the age of 90. She is survived by two daughters, Katherine Folliss Burley of Scottsdale, AZ and Ann Folliss Jeffery of New York; as well as two grandchildren, Chester Charles Burley IV and Sabrina Ann Burley, and five great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Alzheimer's Association http://www.alz.org/ join--the--cause--donate.asp 1/3

LEDERER--Inge Miriam, (formerly Gibel), passed away on June 9th in Des Moines, IA at the age of 84. Family and friends are committed to continue the legacy of activism pioneered by this civil rights and progressive Jewish Socialist Zionist. The funeral was at Eretz HaChaim Cemetery, in Israel on Monday 15 June at 3pm. She is survived by daughter Prof. Katya Gibel Mevorach, son Maurice Gibel, six grandchildren, and one great-grandson 1/3
MODELL--Paula. We love you deeply. You were a fantastic woman. Your spirit will always be in our hearts. All our love, Janellen & David Gerstein 1/3
GILBERT--Ronnie. Ronnie lived a big, passionate life for 88 years which came to a peaceful end on June 6, 2015. She will be loved and missed always by Lisa Weg, Zoe Weg, and Donna Korones. 1/3

SHAH--Sumitra. Death cannot take away what you gave us in your lifetime. We received more than we could give, now all bundled up in sweet memories. We love you always. Love and peace. Sanjit, Mary, Mina, Vikram, Shashi Shah and family 1/3

FIALKOFF--Frank, of Alpine, NJ and Crested Butte, CO, died peacefully Monday, June 8th after a brave battle with cancer at the age of 70. Known for his big personality and mischievous smile, he lived a full life that made an impact on so many. An adored husband of 50 years to wife Linda, father to Brett and Gabrielle, father-in-law to Heather, grandfather to Andie, Hannah, Jack and Thea and friend and mentor to countless individuals. He was the Chief Executive Officer of Haskell Jewels, LLC, the leading fashion jewelry company in the U.S. Fialkoff was raised in the Bronx and began his storied career in the accessories industry at the age of sixteen. He purchased his first company, jewelry manufacturer Albert Weiss, in 1970. Fialkoff joined Swank in 1975 as President where he founded the women's division. He joined Victoria Creations in 1980 as President, and later, CEO. In 1990, Fialkoff, together with wife, Linda, founded Haskell Jewels. Fialkoff was known throughout his career for his charm and tenacity. His charismatic leadership guided the fashion jewelry industry for decades. Fialkoff received the Fashion Accessories Benefit Ball (FABB) Achievement Award in 2009 and, in 2011, was honored with the Business Visionary Award by the Accessories Council. He was deeply involved with the Adaptive Sports Center (ASC) of Crested Butte, Colorado. He was an avid mountain biker, hiker and skier but what he enjoyed most was spending time with his family. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 16th, 2:00pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made in his name to the Adaptive Sports Center of Crested Butte, CO. 1/3

EGENER--Stanley. March 31, 1934 - May 30, 2015. "Stan the Man" as he was commonly referred to, was truly beloved by family, friends and business associates. He is survived by his brother George, his two sons Mark and Todd, his wife Jennifer, his five grandchildren Daniel, Matthew, Sarah, Caroline and Elizabeth and his companion of many years, Aline Delbray. Stanley Egener was in the first class of men to graduate from Hunter College in New York. He served as an aviator in the U.S. Navy where he was stationed on the USS Intrepid, now a museum docked in New York. He was an exceptional athlete who played semi-pro football, golf and tennis. He was also an accomplished downhill skier. Stan began his career in finance in 1960 with Dreyfus Corporation and later worked with Oppenheimer. & Co. In 1972 Stan and two colleagues, Arthur Scherl and Richard Bassuk formed "Scherl, Egener & Bassuk" where they created a revolutionary new type of mutual fund called the "Side Fund". The Side Fund was eventually acquired by Neuberger Berman and later renamed the "Partners Fund". Stan joined Neuberger Berman and was instrumental in building their mutual fund business. In 1982, he was elected President of Neuberger Berman Management, Inc. and ultimately became a Partner in Neuberger Berman, LLC. Stan served for many years on the board of the Investment Company Institute and was President of the No-Load Mutual Fund Association. Considered a maverick both professionally and personally, Stanley's genius was his creativity and focus. He will be sorely missed and his life accomplishments will be an inspiration for all of the generations of family that will succeed him. Contributions in his memory to the Taub Alzheimer's Disease Research Institute 630 W. 168th St., PH 19, New York, NY 10032 would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Arthur (Abe), passed away June 10th, 2015 in Pembroke Pines, FL at the age of 99. Beloved husband of Etta. Dear father of Eugene (Karin) and Donna Lee Goldin (Philip). Adoring grandfather of Gabrielle, Bret (Kim), Douglas, Jason and Nicole. Proud great-grand-father of Sadie, Lucy, and Mia. After a life of hard work for his family in the garment industry, he spent the last 35 years happily retired in Florida with his loving wife. Arthur and Etta recently celebrated their 75th wedding anniversary. Service Today, 11am, at "The Riverside", 76th Street. and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3
CANALE--Peter Alfred. My dear son, may you now rest in peace with J.M.J. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Professor Sheri P.,passed away on May 22, 2015 at her home in Philadelphia at the age of 48. Sheri was a loving mother to Markus, Maurice, and Margaux, and a wonderful wife to Gregg Kanter. She was devoted to her extended family, particularly her late sister Margot Pulitzer's children whom she loved and cared for as if they were her own. She treated others as if they were family, and many count her as a close friend. Sheri was committed to strengthening Jewish institutions in Philadelphia. She supported Temple Beth Zion-Beth Israel by founding Bonim, a weekly program for young children, and serving on its Rabbi Search Committee. She initiated programs to improve the Perelman Jewish Day School, and served on the Board of HIAS Pennsylvania. Sheri was the founder and Director of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law's Human Rights and Atrocity Prevention Clinic. The Clinic won landmark victories, including persuading the Grand Chamber of the European Court of Human Rights that the Bosnian Constitution violated the European Convention of Human Rights by excluding ethnic minorities from Bosnia's Presidency. The Clinic partnered with the U.N. Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide to assess early warning signs of genocide, and worked with the International Criminal Court's Trust for Victims to develop a field manual for identifying victims of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide. Sheri also founded and developed the Clinic's Refugee Representation Project for asylum seekers. Sheri was the Faculty Director of the Cardozo Law Institute in Holocaust and Human Rights, a leading global center dedicated to strengthening laws, norms, and institutions to prevent mass atrocities, and she co-founded its predecessor, Cardozo's Holocaust, Genocide and Human Rights Program. As an Associate Clinical Professor at Cardozo, Sheri taught international human rights law and inspired students to pursue careers in genocide prevention. Sheri lectured worldwide. She served on the Board of the Auschwitz Institute for Peace and Reconciliation and regularly presented at its Raphael Lemkin Seminar for Genocide Prevention in Oswiecim, Poland. Sheri was a Consultant to the U.N. Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide and authored the genocide prevention chapter in the U.N. training manual. She produced an award-winning documentary, Nuremberg: Reflection and Resonance, which traced Nuremberg's influence on modern international tribunals. Sheri published extensively and is co- editor of the forthcoming book Reconstructing Atrocity Prevention. Cardozo presented Sheri with the Telford Taylor Award and the Inspire Award; Yeshiva University presented her with the Point of Light Award; The Center for Peacebuilding (CIM) named her a 2015 Peace Ambassador; and the Anne Frank Center USA announced that Sheri would receive its Outstanding Educator Award. Before joining the Faculty at Cardozo, Sheri worked in Sarajevo as the Panel-Registrar and Judicial Law Clerk for the Human Rights Chamber of Bosnia & Herzegovina. In every area of her life, when Sheri noticed an injustice or a person or institution in need of help, she acted and achieved results, without drawing attention to herself. She was generous, warm, talented and, above all, humble. She lived her dreams by doing the work she loved. By combining brilliance and intellectual honesty with a tenacious work ethic, Sheri made the world a better place and inspired international human rights students and colleagues. She has a place among the righteous. Sheri's devotion to family, Jewish institutions, and combating ethnicity-based injustice was influenced by her parents, Ann Pappenheim Rosenberg and the late Marcus Rosenberg. They cherished extended families and built the Dallas Jewish community by founding Congregation Shaare Tefilla and Akiba Academy of Dallas, the city's first Orthodox day school. Their childhood experiences during the Holocaust -- Ann escaped from Vienna in November 1939, and Marcus lived under Nazi occupation in Bardejov, Czechoslovakia, before being sent to Auschwitz -- motivated Sheri to become a leading scholar of international human rights and genocide prevention. Those wishing to honor Sheri's memory can support the institutions that were important to her: the Cardozo Law Institute in Holocaust and Human Rights, Temple Beth Zion-Beth Israel, and Perelman Jewish Day School. 1/3

CHAIT--Allan. The National Antique and Art Dealers Association of America mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague Allan S. Chait of Ralph M. Chait Galleries, one of the founding firms of our organization. He was a man of great integrity and knowledge, and a distinguished presence in the world of Chinese porcelain and works of art. He was highly respected for his wise counsel and great character, and loved for his warmth and generous spirit. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

OSBORN--Dr. Harold Holmes "Oz," 71, passed away on April 30th in New Rochelle, NY. He was the son of Florence and Harold Osborn and caretaker and brother to Lucille Osborn, all of Connecticut. A graduate of the Kent School '62, Yale University '66 and Columbia University Medical School '70, he was a scholar and an athlete. As a politically radicalized medical student, Oz did his residency at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx. It was there that he helped found the Lincoln Collective: a grassroots effort devoted to community-oriented medicine. He helped create The People's Drug Program, one of the first detox clinics in the South Bronx; pioneered the use of holistic medicine in inner city hospitals; and developed a relief system for medical interns. For thirty years he was devoted to improving the health of the people of the Bronx by blending medical practice and community activism. In 1984, he served as the medical witness in the wrongful death case of Eleanor Bumpurs, who was killed while being forcibly evicted by the NYPD. In 1997, Oz was a leader in the movement that shut down a polluting medical waste incinerator in the South Bronx. Two years later, he founded The New Dawn Foundation, turning a large waterfront property into a space for holistic wellness treatment and a retreat for inner-city youth. He is survived by a great many loving friends, two grandchildren, Fergus and Charles, and his three children, Kyre, Jesse and Kate Osborn. 1/3

ISAACSON--Thelma Rabinowitz, on June 2 in Brooklyn where she lived and thrived all her life. A devoted and beloved mother to Jane, Matthew, and Lawrence, grandmother to Joshua (and Denise), Nina (and Alex), Sarah (and Jacob), Anna (and David), Jess (and Jane), Mollie (and Eric) and Cora and great-grandmother to Asher, Phoebe and Dean, mother-in-law to Warren, Helaine and Michele. During her 100 years of life, Thelma was a good friend to many, active in her synagogue and involved in raising money for charities. She was the family matriarch, looking out for everyone, caring about them and advising them about the vicissitudes of life. We were blessed to have her in our lives for so many years and we will miss her very much. 1/3

MULHOLLAND--James S.,II. The Officers and The Board of Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home mourn the loss of a dear friend and passionate supporter, James Mulholland. A devoted husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather, Jim was a generous man who alongside his beloved wife Claire helped to transform the Fresh Air Home into a modern facility serving physically challenged children. Through his beneficence, he helped to better the lives of countless, less fortunate children. His legacy will live on at the Home for many years to come. We extend our deepest sympathy to Claire and the entire Mulholland Family. The Officers and Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home 1/3

TAYLOR--Dwight D.,Jr. For 94 years, Dwight found the best in himself, in his friends, and in life. He will be dearly missed and fondly remembered by all those whose lives he has touched for the better. He passed away peacefully at his home on the morning of Monday, May 18th 2015. Dwight was born on November 25, 1920, Minneapolis, MN and grew up on Lake Minnetonka, near the town of Excelsior. An only child, he left home in the fall of 1937 and boarded a train headed for Harvard at age 16. Dwight played basketball at Harvard and lived at Lowell House. He was awarded a B.A. in '41, Phi Beta Kappa. He received a law degree at the Harvard Law School, nominally the class of '44 which was delayed to '49 due to the War. He earned an A.M.P. from the Harvard Business School, 1972. During WWII, he joined Pan Am's ground support services group as station manager at Noumea, New Caledonia. Dwight entered private legal practice from 1949 to 1952. From 1952 to 1953 he was the Assistant to the President of the State University of New York in Albany. From 1954 to 1955 he worked for the Carnegie Corporation in New York, then joined American Airlines as Vice President of governmental affairs from 1955 to 1964. He was a Senior Vice President of Eastern Airlines from 1965 until 1974. That year, he moved to San Francisco as Senior Vice President of Crown Zellerbach, where he retired in 1985. He married Dorothy Virginia Bennett in Alexandria, VA on April 11, 1975. They lived in Pacific Heights, San Francisco and traveled the world together. Dwight possessed a deep, life-long love of learning, an incredible memory, and a passion for clarity and wit in language. His reverence for Shakespeare led him to make a New Year's resolution of re-reading all the plays this year. He completed 15 of them. Mr. Taylor is preceded by his wife, Dorothy Bennett Taylor. He is survived by Nancy Northrup of Cooperstown, NY, Donald Prather of Alexandria, VA and numerous grandchildren and great- grandchildren. Donations can be made on Dwight Taylor's behalf to the college scholarship charity 10,000 Degrees. A memorial service will be held at 10:30am on June 18th, 2015 at the Olympic Club, 524 Post Street, San Francisco, CA. 1/3

GRIFFIN--James. James Quigley Griffin, of Hopewell, NJ died peacefully on June 2nd after a brief illness. A revered husband, father, grandfather, farmer, sportsman and friend to countless individuals, Mr. Griffin had a diverse and inspiring career in banking, museum administration, finance, and as a trustee of numerous cultural institutions. Son of Helen Quigley and Donald Worner Griffin, Mr. Griffin was born in Lock Haven, PA on August 23, 1932. He grew up on the Princeton University campus where his father was General Secretary of the Alumni Association. He was a graduate of the Gilman School of Baltimore, MD and earned an AB in history from Princeton University in 1955. After serving as Captain in the US Army, he began a 25 year career at First National City Bank where he rose to be a Vice President and Head of Personnel for Citibank's International Division. In 1979 Mr. Griffin joined the Metropolitan Museum of Art as Treasurer and Vice President for Finance. Upon leaving the Metropolitan Museum he joined Patterson, Belknap, Webb and Tyler LLP as Treasurer. After 35 years commuting to New York City, Mr. Griffin chose to work closer to home and his family, and joined Wilmerding, Miller & Co., Inc., an investment advisory firm in Princeton, NJ as Vice President and Secretary from 1992 until the present. Mr. Griffin served as Treasurer on the Boards of the New York Historical Society, the New York Society Library, International School Services (ISS), AMIDEAST (America- Mideast Educational and Training Services, Inc.), and as a trustee at Morven Museum and Garden. Mr. Griffin was deeply committed to The Ivy Club in Princeton, where he served as the Graduate Board President from 1982 until his death. He was a longstanding member of the Century Association, the Anglers Club of New York, and Pretty Brook Tennis Club. Mr. Griffin is survived by his wife of 56 years, Barbara Moorehead Griffin; his three daughters, Barbara Griffin Cole, Cynthia Griffin Ferris, and Sarah Griffin Thompson; his sons-in-law, Christopher A. Cole, Timothy G. Ferris, Newell M. Thompson; and nine grandchildren. He and his wife lived on a working sheep farm in Hopewell, NJ where he was a passionate amateur stonemason. When not working on his legendary argillite stonewalls, he could be found in the vegetable garden or on his tractor mowing the fields. He loved nothing better than to prepare a homegrown feast for his family and friends in their warm, welcoming kitchen. In the winter, after the first cold snap, the call went out, "Ice at Jimmy's!" Skaters of all ages joined with him to play fast and furious shinny hockey on the Griffin's pond. He was widely known for his gentle, gracious and selfless manner, his work ethic, and his unwavering values. An optimist with a keen appreciation for individual talent in all walks of life; he was a rare person who inspired others to be better. A Memorial Service celebrating the Life of James Q. Griffin will be held at the Princeton University Chapel on June 22 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, friends may contribute to the James Q. Griffin Memorial Fund at the Princeton Area Community Foundation (15 Princess Road, Lawrenceville, NJ 08525) which will support education, leadership, and Jim's other charitable interests. 1/3
COLEMAN--Ornette. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, a classic modern composer who revolutionized mid-century American Jazz. 1/3

DUBOFF--Elizabeth Epstein, passed away peacefully on June 8th at 96 years old. Beloved wife of the late Samuel; devoted mother to Judy (Bill McDonnell), Robert (Janet Berkeley), and David (Cheryl Wurzburger); grandmother to Ryya, Josh, Sam, Brett, Graeme, Suzie; great-grandmother to Willow and Twila. She is survived by her siblings Richard Epstein (Judy) and Margaret Weinstock and fabulous caregiver Marline. She lived in Valhalla, NY and Springs, East Hampton. She was a big-hearted woman who graduated from Smith College and NYU School of Social Work. Donations can be sent to the Fund for Modern Courts, 28 West 39th Street, 4th floor, NYC, NY 10018 to be used for the Duboff Award Fund, to recognize non-lawyers who volunteer to improve justice for all. 1/3

GREGUS--Rudolph L.,passed away peacefully in his daughter's home in New York City on May 23rd at the beautiful age of 90. Born on the Lower Eastside, raised in Slovakia and later escaped after WWII and immigrated back to the United States. He was a graduate of Ohio State University in political science. Devoted husband of Ellen, loving father to Luba and Ruzena and proud grandfather of Grant, Caitlin and Caroline, Rudolph was a leader, teacher and columnist in spreading the Slovak culture in the U.S. Contributions in his memory can be made to: Slovak American Cultural Center (SACC), P.O. Box 5395, New York, NY 10185. 1/3

MODELL--Paula. Our darling friend Paula has left this world but such a beautiful and strong spirit lives on eternally. We loved her dearly and will always remember the many joyous times together. Our hearts break for her loves Jerry, Eric, Natalie, Rhea, Jillian, Hudson, Eden, and Rebecca. With love, Andrea and Marty Schlossberg and Debra, Darian and Richard 1/3

RABINOVE--Anna Schenkelbach, age 91, died at home on June 9th. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving and devoted mother of Beth (Stephen), Amy (Dave), David (Cathie), Ellen (Barry). Proud grandmother of Brian, Daniel, Justin, Zachary, Benjamin, Alex and Paul. Lovingly cared for by Lia Jorbenadze and Elena Olshevska for many years. An avid read and devoted teacher, she will be deeply mourned and forever remembered for her boundless love for her family. Contributions in her memory may be sent to The Fresh Air Fund or Save the Children. 1/3

CHASIN--Helen S.,was born in New York on July 23, 1938, and attended Midwood High School in Brooklyn and Radcliffe College. Her first book of poetry won the Yale Younger Poets prize in 1968. Ms. Chasin was an inspiring and impassioned teacher of writing, co-founding The Writers Community in Manhattan in 1976. In her later years, she split her time between Rockport, Massachusetts and New York City. Chasin loved food, art and literature, travel, gardening, and her friends--and she loved to hate Nixon and the subway system. She died in her Manhattan home in early June, and is survived by Dana James Chasin and Alexandra Chasin. Please contact them for information about a private memorial gathering. 1/3

SUSSER--Doris. After a long illness died peacefully at home on June 12. Devoted wife of Herbert Susser for 59 years. Loving mother of Loren Palmer (Brandon) and Mitchell Susser. MAUSKOPF--Amy Udell. "A woman of valor, who can find? Her worth is far above jewels." Amy, you were the jewel in the crowns of your loving family and friends and community. You taught us about love, kindness and inclusion. We would all sit, as deeply honored guests, at your heavenly table. You nourished all of us, as we would gather, in joy and love. There, we were whole because of you. "Wherever people gather, her deeds speak her praise." You fed us with wisdom; you showed us beauty; and you dignified us in your sight, and in your light. You nurtured us, and in nurturing us, we not only felt connected to you, but as well to each other, and indeed to ourselves. You are blessed, and through you, your family and friends will be blessed and those whom you loved will continue to bless others. Amy, your memory will be everlasting for a blessing. Go gently now in peace and love. We are all with you, as you are with us. It is thus with heavy hearts that we mourn the passing of our beloved mother, wife, daughter, sister and sister-in-law--Amy. Amy's funeral will take place at Park East Synagogue at 12:00pm on Monday, June 15th (163 East 67th Street). "She is precious far beyond rubies". Tom, Ilana and Eli Mauskopf. Evlynn and Arthur Udell. Patricia and Mitchell Udell. 1/3

SIEGEL--Adrienne, a long- time resident in the Riverdale community, passed away on June 5, 2015 surrounded by family and friends at the Block Hospice Residence of KittayHouse. Adrienne, the daughter of the late Mac and Sally Newman, was born in the Bronx on August 22, 1941. She grew up on Burnside Ave and graduated from Evander Child High School. In 1968 she moved to West 235th Street where she raised her three children Shari, Jolie and Erik. Adrienne will be dearly missed by her children and their spouses, Shari (Anne), Jolie (Murray), and Erik (Gabriella); grandchildren, Olivia, Ethan, Sabrina, Max, Sophie, Drew and Ella; her brother Robert (Debbie), and sister- in-law Roberta; as well as her numerous nieces and nephews. Adrienne's roots and heart remained in the Bronx as she worked for many years as the admissions and medical billing coordinator at the Jewish Home and Hospital on Kingsbridge Rd. While there, she was a true advocate for the residents, volunteering her time and energy beyond her work schedule, even adopting the Home's service dog "Magic" when he was retired from working on the Alzheimer's unit. She also routinely visited her mother-in-law Dorothy Siegel 3-5 times every week. After retirement, she continued to contribute to the fabric of her community by working part time at Riverdale Sports Physical Therapy. She eventually retired full time. She joined a knitting group and participated in the Friends and Family organization of the Jewish Home and Hospital. But most of her focus and energy was toward her seven grandchildren and their families. Adrienne loved showering them with gifts, hosting holiday dinners and sharing in all the accomplishments and activities of all those in her life. Adrienne was a great friend and neighbor to all those around her. Kind in her heart and generous in her ways. Donations in her memory can be made to Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital, or to the Red Dog Fund. 1/3

BROWN--Robert D.,of Needham, MA, formerly of Weston, MA passed away at home after a brief illness on June 13, 2015. He was 92. Bob is survived by his wife, Carol, his three sons, Doug (Jeanne), Steve (Lisa) and Nat and by six grandchildren. Bob was an engineer and city planner whose life work was to create beautiful cities and inclusive communities. Graduate of Middlebury College and M.I.T. He was the first Director or the Capital Region Planning Agency in Hartford, CT and later was Director of the New England River Basins Commission. Active member of the Weston, MA Planning Board and founder of the Weston Affordable Housing Foundation. Tennis player from age 8 to 81. His legacy will be the deep sense of integrity and fairness that he instilled in all who had the joy of living, working or playing with him. Memorial service at First Parish Church, Weston, MA, 2:00pm, Wednesday, June 17. Details and full obituary at www.eaton funeralhomes.com. Memorial donations may be made to the Weston Affordable Housing Foundation. 1/3

Funeral at Gutterman's Funeral Home, June 15, noon, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY, Donations can be made to: Hospice Care of Long Island, Woodbury, NY and Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

WILFORD--Ronald A. IMG Artists mourns the passing of Ronald A. Wilford, a monumental figure in the classical music industry, and Chairman/CEO of Columbia Artists Management Inc. MOORE--George B. It is with heavy heart that we mourn the passing of this wonderful man. He was a terrific son, husband, father and grandfather. There will never be another quite like him. We send all our love to his wife, Kathie Moore, his daughter Tanya Moore Jessop and her family, and our own beloved son-in-law George B. Moore. Jordan & Tom Saunders 1/3

KATSAROS--Peter. Pete, I know you wouldn't like this but I have to do it. Pete Katsaros shunned celebration and avoided the commemoration of any formal event. He lived frugally in a house in the woods near Spring Lake, NY. Through diligent self-study he became an expert mycologist, naturalist, photographer, and amateur astronomer. He was the most intellectually gifted man I have ever known and had the most acute scientific intelligence. Though reclusive, he had a great capacity for friendship. He did not have a college degree, having dropped out after a year to work as a court reporter for the First Army on Governor's Island. Neither of us, growing up in Astoria in the 1950s, had any money, yet he took ten exquisite photographs in Central Park of the woman I was engaged to marry, had them enlarged to 8x10 size, and sent them to me in Iowa where I was in graduate school. In 1959 he lent me $300, an enormous sum, to buy a suit to get married in. After he died, my daughter gave me a framed picture of him. I cannot look at it. Sidney Landau 1/3

KESSLER--Claire, passed away on June 14, 2015, at age 90. Claire is the beloved wife of the late Milton Kessler. She is survived by her daughter, Joan Kessler, son-in-law, Vincent Kruskal, grandsons, Michael and Elliot, nieces and nephews, Joseph Sherman, Amy Lilley, Jeffrey Hecht, Jennifer Rothenberg, and Eric Hecht and great nieces and great nephews. www.zionchapel.com 1/3

MAUSKOPF--Amy Udell. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community deeply mourns the untimely passing of Amy Udell Mauskopf; beloved wife of Tom, cherished mother of Ilana (AJHS'09) and Eli (AJHS' 15). Amy's love, joy and kindness started with her ready smile on entering any room. She always made everyone feel better after being in her presence. She was truly a Woman of Valor and there will be a hole in our community without her. She was devoted to our school and community for over twenty years and used her professional skills to help make any major event the best it could possibly be. We send our love and condolences to Tom, Ilana, Eli, Evlynn, Arthur, Mitchell, Patricia and the entire Mauskopf and Udell families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joel Citron, President Board of Trustees Ariela Dubler, Head of School 1/3

MAUSKOPF--Amy. It's not supposed to happen but when it does, it's tragic and the world stops for a moment. TARNOWER--Leonard R. Born July 29, 1928, passed away June 14, 2015. Beloved husband of Myrna Brokaw Tarnower. Loving son of the late Gertrude and Charles. Devoted brother to the late Barbara. WILFORD--Ronald. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Ronald Wilford, Maestro Levine's manager for his entire career at the Met and an extraordinary force in classical music for the past half-century who engineered some of the most memorable performances in Met history. Besides bringing Maestro Levine to the Met, he orchestrated the Met debuts of Carlos Kleiber and Herbert von Karajan, and helped shape the careers of many of the most important singers on our stage, including Leontyne Price, Kathleen Battle, and Marilyn Horne. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family and friends, and to the millions of opera lovers whose lives were enriched by his work. He was our beloved colleague and friend. Peter Gelb, General Manager 1/3
EIGENFELD--Stan. 6/16/1930 - 11/11/2013 My darling, I celebrate your life. Your "Annie Beloved" 1/3
WEISSMAN--Seth Ian, 8/19/77 You are remembered. You are missed. You are loved--Mom/Estelle 1/3

WILFORD--Ronald Andrew. Died peacefully at home on June 13th, 2015, cared for by loving family and friends. He embraced life with gusto and enthusiasm, and left this life in the same philosophical frame of mind with which he relished it. A devout believer in psychoanalysis, he treasured the combination of love and work. Beloved by the artists he managed, his approach was always to probe for what they needed in order to reach their goals. He brought this same approach to everyone whose life he touched. Each member of his family will miss him terribly: his beloved wife Sara and son Christopher; daughter-in-law Meredith and beautiful granddaughter Addison; his daughter Diane; his step children for over 40 years-- Chris, AZ, Peter, Sarina, Betsey, and their children whom he also loved and inspired. A memorial service will be held in the fall. 1/3

WILFORD--Ronald A. Opus 3 Artists joins the entire performing arts community in mourning Ronald A Wilford, long time leader of Columbia Artists Management. Under Mr. Wilford's aegis, CAMI was an acknowledged leader in the management of classical musicians and boasted one of the finest rosters of performing artists in the world. Many of us at Opus 3 spent time working at CAMI and experienced personally his strong and often challenging leadership style, but more importantly we were touched by, and benefited from, his keen intellect and insights. Individually, as a company and not least on behalf of Opus 3's roster of artists, we mourn his loss, and send our sympathies and condolences to his wife Sara, and his entire family. David V. Foster, President Jonathan Brill, Executive Vice President 1/3

SKIDMORE--Philip Murray, died peacefully on June 13th, 2015, in Stamford, CT, at the age of 75. Beloved husband of Sarah Skidmore, wonderful father to Gregory and Anne Skidmore, and devoted grandfather to Brady, Tucker, and Harper Skidmore. Born in Manhattan, he obtained degrees from the Buckley School, Georgia Institute of Technology and NYU Business School. After leading roles at Lehman Brothers, Kuhn, Loeb & Co. and Advest, he joined his son's company, Belpointe Asset Management, as Chairman. Phil was the son of Louis Skidmore, co-founder of the architectural firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and the former Eloise Owings Skidmore. An avid sportsman, he was also committed to many civic organizations and a longtime usher at St. Paul's Church, Riverside, CT. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Church, Riverside, CT on Thursday, June 18th, at 2pm. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Ellen Kay. Ellen Kay Schwartz of New York, NY died Tuesday, June 16, 2015 at home with her loving husband, Edward M. Spiro, of 38 years by her side. Ellen was born in NYC on Jan. 23, 1952, graduated from Hunter College H.S., Vassar and Boston University School of Law, where she met her husband, Ed. A staunch believer in both public service and the need for fair application of the law to all, Ellen served as an attorney for the Legal Aid Society, Inspector General for various NYC agencies, an Asst. Deputy Commissioner for the NYPD, and the Head of Internal Affairs for the Baltimore Police Dept. For the last eight years, Ellen served the people of the State of New York, first as Executive Deputy Chief of Staff in the Attorney General's Office and then as Assistant Executive Deputy Secretary to the Governor. But no people in New York were better served by Ellen than her family. In addition to being a loving mother to her daughter, Sara (Spiro) Abramson, and son, Matthew H. Spiro, she was a wonderful mother-in-law to her children's respective spouses, Brett and Eileen, a loving and doting grandmother to Ilana and Vivian Abramson, supportive sister to Chuck Schwartz, and a caring daughter to Shirley Dinitz and Murray Schwartz and step-daughter to Leon Dinitz. Beyond her immediate family, Ellen was the core of her extended family, hosting large holiday dinners over the years that will be remembered fondly by all. Services will be held on Friday, June 19 at 11am at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., New York, NY. 1/3

MOORE--George B. It is with great sorrow that the members of the Board and staff of The Hispanic Society of America mourn the loss of our dear friend, esteemed colleague, and dedicated Trustee (1995-2015) and Chairman (2004-2015). He was a vibrant enthusiast of the Hispanic Society and will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Kathie and the entire Moore family. To commemorate his service, the Moore family has requested donations to be made to the George B. Moore Memorial Fund at The Hispanic Society of America (613 W. 155th St. New York, NY 10032). Mitchell Codding, Executive Director Philippe de Montebello, Chairman The Hispanic Society of America 1/3

WILFORD--Ronald A. Opus 3 Artists joins the entire performing arts community in mourning Ronald A Wilford, long time leader of Columbia Artists Management. Under Mr. Wilford's aegis, CAMI was an acknowledged leader in the management of classical musicians and boasted one of the finest rosters of performing artists in the world. Many of us at Opus 3 spent time working at CAMI and experienced personally his strong and often challenging leadership style, but more importantly we were touched by, and benefited from, his keen intellect and insights. Individually, as a company and not least on behalf of Opus 3's roster of artists, we mourn his loss, and send our sympathies and condolences to his wife Sara, and his entire family. David V. Foster, President Jonathan Brill, Executive Vice President 1/3

SHAPOFF--Matthew F.,died at age 43 on May 19, 2015. Mr. Shapoff, a Long Island native and artist, was an innovator in the field of cyanotype photography. Known for his kindness and generosity, he was a man of rare quality and commitment. He is survived by his loving wife, Cynthia Rybakoff. 1/3

AMANN--Gloria (Drucker), 69, of New York City passed suddenly in her sleep in the early morning of Monday, June 15. Born to two Germanborn Jewish parents who escaped the Holocaust to New York City, Gloria was the only child of Eva (Auerbach) Drucker and Siegfried Drucker. She is survived by her loving husband, Helmut Amann, and two daughters, Althea Azeff and Judy Misbin. Gloria earned two Masters and worked her entire adult life as an educator and librarian for inner-city New York children. She was fond of music, literature, art, and engaged in writing poetry, short stories and Art Criticism in her free time. Memorial services will be held at R. G. Ortiz Funeral Homes, 4425 Broadway (190 Street and Broadway) on June 18, 2015. Viewing will be from 3:00 to 9:00pm. Burial will be on June 19, 2015 TBD. 1/3

RIVERS--Margaret. November 7, 1951, died June 8, 2015. She was the cherished mother of Iasha and Wali Rivers. Services, 6pm Thursday, Benta Funeral Home in Harlem. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to Global Colon Cancer Association. Sleep in Peace 1/3

NAGER--Lenore, beloved wife of Harvey. Devoted mother to Cathy, Richard and Goldi. Cherished grandmother of Max. Dear sister of Allan and Ruthlee. Genuine friend to many with a generous heart and filled with beauty inside and out. Funeral services: Thursday, 10am at Gutterman's Inc. 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, Long Island. 1/3

MOORE--George B. The Saunders Family has lost a great friend. He was a devoted father and grandfather, Happily married to the beautiful, Kathie Moore. He was a gentleman, and great fun to be around. He made a deep and lasting impression on all who knew and loved him. I will always remember and miss him. I send my deepest condolences and love to the entire Moore family. Taz Saunders 1/3

COHEN--Alan, MD, June 16, 2015. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Hunter and Lindsey. Cherished son of Rita and the late Martin L. Devoted brother of Jason and Diane and the late Steven, Joanne and Kirsten. Services 12:30pm Friday at Temple Judea of Manhasset, 333 Searingtown Road, Manhasset, NY. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Sanford. February 19, 1934 - June 16, 2015, passed away peacefully. Survived by his long-time loving partner, Hon. Elaine Jackson Stack and his four children, Lauren Saverino, Bruce (Lorraine) Goldsmith, Barry Goldsmith and Jennifer (Lewis) Biblowitz; along with his eight grandchildren: Danielle, Dylan, Kathleen, Joshua, Alexa, Bryan, Jonah and Nathan and his three great- grandchildren: Zackary, Michael, Thomas; as well as the Stack children and 20 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Funeral Services: Friday, 10am at Gutterman's, Inc., 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, L.I. 1/3
KAUFMAN--Dr. Herman S.,March 31, 1922 - June 18, 1988. He gave of his head and his heart. With us, always. Hiltzik and Kaufman families. 1/3

SOBEL--Lionel, of Syosset, NY and Delray Beach, FL passed away June 15 at age 89. Affectionately nicknamed "the Chief," Lionel had a big personality and even bigger heart. A Bronx native and NYU graduate, he served in the US Navy during WW II and founded LNL Electronics in 1965. He was devoted to and beloved by wife Rita Lazoff Sobel, daughter Doryann (and Thomas) Mele, son Theodore (and Mary) Sobel and grandchildren Adam, Lucy, Julia, Rebecca and Louis. Services are at noon on June 18 at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY. Donations may be sent to Midway Jewish Center in Syosset, NY. 1/3

MOORE--George B. It is with heavy heart that we mourn the passing of this wonderful man. He was a terrific son, husband, father and grandfather. There will never be another quite like him. We send all our love to his wife, Kathie Moore, his daughter Tanya Moore Jessop and her family, and our own beloved son-in-law George B. Moore. Jordan & Tom Saunders 1/3

MANGUM--Richard H.,Esq. 69, passed away on June 13, 2015 from a sudden illness, seven years after suffering a traumatic brain injury. He devoted his life to civic leadership through social work and the law. He is survived by his wife Karol, two sons, and four grandsons. 1/3

SCOFIELD--G. Rolfe, 98, died in his hometown, Rochester, NY, on June 12, 2015. A graduate of Princeton and Harvard Law, he served in WW II as a navigator in the Army Air Force. His wife Whitney Smith died in 2002. He is survived by his four children, Whitney Bagnall, Sylvia Scofield, Giles Scofield, and Judy Rinere, and by four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. 1

LEICHMAN--Gil, of Bayside, NY, passed away in Israel at 94 years old on June 16, 2015. Gil is the beloved husband of his late wife Alice. He is survived by his children Judy (Marc), David (Miri), and Hindy (Walter) and eight grandchildren. Memorial Service on Monday at 10am at Temple B'nai Torah, 2900 Jerusalem Avenue, Wantagh, NY. He will be remembered as Saba Dolly by all who knew and loved him. 1/3
GEHRING--Francis P. Jr.,83 died May 21 after a long battle with Parkinson's. Service will be held on July 1st at 10am, Christ Episcopal Church, Charlottesville, VA 1/3

RUBENSTEIN--Paul. In loving memory of our dear friend and business partner Paul Rubenstein who we have loved and admired for more than 45 years. With deepest sympathy to his wife Betty, son Chett and three granddaughters. Forever in our hearts, Alan and Susan Weiner 1/3

BOXENBAUM--Bernard, 82, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed away on June 13th, 2015. He was a selfless and devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather to his late wife Gloria; daughter Abby (Jonathan) Rubin; late son Steven; grandchildren Chaya Leah (Yehoshua) Sova, Josh (DIna), Zachary (Shoshana) and Benjamin (Rivka); and great-grandchildren Aryeh, Racheli, Asher, Tovi, Motti, Rachel, Gittel and Ezra. His family was his life. 1/3

DOUBLEDAY--Nelson, Jr.,passed peacefully on June 17, 2015 surrounded by his family. He was born July 20, 1933 and was the son of Nelson and Ellen Doubleday of Oyster Bay, NY. Mr. Doubleday was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Princeton University. Upon graduation, he joined the Air Force where he was stationed at Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. He later joined the family publishing business in 1958 rising to become President and then Chairman until it was sold in 1986. Mr. Doubleday was an avid sportsman. He owned the New York Mets from 1986 to 2002 during which time they won several National League titles and the 1986 World Series. He also was an owner of the New York Islanders Hockey Team winning the Stanley Cup in 1983. Mr. Doubleday was an accomplished golfer, loved sailing the world on Mandalay, shooting at his plantation in South Carolina and the valleys of England. He thrived on having his family and friends enjoy his passions with him. Mr. Doubleday was a retired trustee of Deerfield Academy, The Green Vale School and the New York Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children. He is survived by his wife of forty-one years, Sandra Pine Doubleday, his sisters Ellen Violett, Neltje and the late Madeleine Martin, his daughters Wendy Havens (John), Lillian Woodworth, Nanki Doubleday, Phoebe Timpson (Bill), his step children Duke Barnett (Lindsey) and Alexis Barnett, thirteen grandchildren, one great grandson and his beloved dogs, Max and Moby. Services will be held at 10:30am Saturday, June 20, 2015, St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to Locust Valley Fire Department, 228 Buckram Rd, Locust Valley, NY 11560; Boys & Girls Clubs of Martin County, P.O. Box 910, Hobe Sound, FL 33475; or the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, 161 William Street, 9th Floor, New York, NY 10038. Further information Whitting Funeral Home, www.whitting.com 1/3

HAUSMAN--Esther Jean Karnes, beloved wife of the late Sidney Hausman, dear sister of Ruth Karnes, loving mother of Dr. Michael Hausman, adoring and adored grandmother of Sydney, Laura and Richard Hausman, and cherished aunt, cousin and friend to many. DOUBLEDAY--Nelson. The Board of Directors and staff of The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (The NYSPCC) mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Nelson Doubleday. A dedicated member of the Board of Directors for over 55 years, Nelson maintained a passionate commitment to the safety and well-being of New York City's children throughout his tenure. He was unanimously elected to the Board in 1960, and became an Honorary Director in 2006. Nelson's compassion, generosity of spirit and five decade commitment to The NYSPCC were an inspiration to us all. We extend our deepest condolences to Sandra and the entire Doubleday family. 1/3

LEE--James B.,Jr. The New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund mourns the passing of James B. Lee, Jr. Jimmy was a generous supporter of our organization for decades. He was our 1997 Honoree and then he continued to serve as a valued member of our Honorary Board. Founder Daniel J. "Rusty" Staub stated, "Jimmy will always be remembered for his altruistic spirit. He was a believer in our work and genuinely cared for the families that we serve." Chairman Stephen J. Dannhauser added, "Jimmy was a true friend. He always stepped up to 'answer the call' for the families of our fallen first responders. He will be greatly missed by everyone at our organization and by all who knew him." We send our sincerest condolences to his family and friends. 1/3

LEIGHTON--Glorya. We mourn the passing of this beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend. We all know that Glorya had a tremendous heart. There will never be another quite like her. Our sincere condolences and love to the entire Leighton family. Jeffrey and Nancy Haber 1/3

DANA--Nick. Douglas Elliman mourns the loss of Nick Dana who for over fifty years served the company and New York real estate industry with honor and distinction. Nick joined Douglas Elliman in 1954 and began its retail commercial division specializing on Madison Avenue. Our condolences go out to the entire Dana family especially to his sons Gary and Rick who continue their father's work at Douglas Elliman today. 1/3

LEE--James B. Jr. James B. Lee Jr.,on June 17, 2015. Beloved husband of Beth, and loving father of Lexi, Jamie, Izzy, and grandfather to Bobby and JoJo. Known as Jimmy, he was tenaciously loyal, and a source of inspiration to many who knew him as a mentor, colleague, and friend. He was a proud champion of Williams College and cared deeply about education and providing opportunities for those in need. A world- class fly fisherman, he lived for being outdoors and cherished time with his family. He was a larger-than-life personality who loved rock-and-roll, the thrill of the deal, his firm J.P. Morgan Chase, and his clients who he considered friends. The family invites friends to Memorial Mass on Monday, June 22nd at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund. 1/3
DOUBLEDAY--Nelson, Jr. The members of The Skeeters mourn the loss of their colleague and friend, Nelson Doubleday, Jr., and send their condolences to his family. 1/3

LEIGHTON--Glorya. Beloved wife and treasured mother died peacefully at home on June 16th, 2015 at the age of 83. TUTHS--Joseph James. At age 69. Six months gone but not forgotten. "Simply the best" husband of Diane Padovano-Tuths. Adored brother of Marie Luisi. Columbia BA ('67) MBA ('73): Sacred Heart College (Newton, MA) MA Education ('72). Columbia College RFC '63 - 67. Columbia Football, three letters, Lineman, Offensive Captain. Houston Oilers camp '67. New York Giants camp, '68. Captained Westchester Bulls, Giants farm team of ACFL. Touched many, missed and loved by all. 1/3

RUBENSTEIN--Paul. In loving memory of our dear friend and business partner Paul Rubenstein who we have loved and admired for more than 45 years. With deepest sympathy to his wife Betty, son Chett and three granddaughters. Forever in our hearts, Alan and Susan Weiner 1/3

BLOCH--Judith, LCSW, pioneer and activist in the fields of special education and early childhood education, died on Monday, June 15, 2015. Founder and Chief Executive Officer of Preschooler's Workshop, later called the Variety Child Learning Center, from 1966 to 2008. She grew the institution from a single classroom to a full service agency providing special education, evaluation, early intervention, therapeutic services, recreational and enrichment programs to thousands of children with developmental disabilities and their families. An early advocate of early intervention, Bloch began working with three-year-old developmentally disabled children when such services were all but nonexistent. In the 1960's mothers were often blamed for their children's autism. By contrast, Bloch viewed mothers as part of the solution and enlisted their aid as part of her curriculum. She later elaborated this philosophy into the Home/School Collaborative Model. To help children, she became a teacher of teachers, a writer, filmmaker, innovator in early assessment, and tireless public advocate. Her many awards include the Thirteen/WNET NY & WLIW21's Community Hall of Fame, and the National Association of Social Workers NY Chapter Lifetime Achievement Award. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Milton Bloch; by daughters Deena Bloch Schaffert (and Stephan Cohen), Natalie Bloch Langner (and David Langner), and Susan Bloch Leach (and John Leach); by brother David Simon (and Suzanne Cohn Simon) and sister Miriam Forman (and John Koller); and by seven grandchildren, Emily, Nathan, Rebecca, Hannah, Sophia, Geoffrey and Levi. 1/3

LEE--James B. Jimmy, To a dear friend and mentor; Wall Street has lost a great banker, but for every one of us who had the honor of working with you, we have all lost a great friend. Alexandra Lebenthal 1/3

SONNEBORN--Walter M. passed peacefully after 73 years of blissful marriage with his beloved Babette, 45 years of family practice in White Plains, and a 103-year love affair with the outdoors. He also leaves three sons, David, Jonathan and Henry and their spouses, 11 grand and 11 great-grandchildren. We will miss his humor, insights and all-abiding zest for life. Services Kol Ami White Plains, June 21, 11am. 1/3

KENNEDY--Doris. Passed away on June 18, 2015 at the age of 91. Funeral services will be held at St. Michaels Cemetery, Astoria, NY on Saturday at 11am. Services made by Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue, New York. 1/3

FRANK--Deborah. Fenway Golf Club expresses profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Deborah Frank, and extends sincere condolences to her husband, Matthew and the entire family. Bruce Haber, President 1/3
LEVIN--Vivian. You'll always be our sunshine. We miss you and honor your memory everyday. Love you to the sky! 1/3

ARVANITIS--Ernest A.,of Somers, NY. Retired Chief Actuary and Officer of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Survived by his wife, Helen (nee Christ) Arvanitis; son, Robert (wife, Celeste; children, Alexandra and Zachary); daughter, Allison, (husband, John Savage; children, Christian and Nikolas); sister, Sophie Demitrack (husband George) and nieces and nephews. Rite of Burial, Monday, June 22nd, 11am, Assumption Greek Orthodox Church, 30 Clapboard Ridge Rd., Danbury, CT. Entombment to follow. Visitation, Sunday, 4pm-7pm, Jowdy-Kane Funeral Home, 9-11 Granville Ave., Danbury, CT and Monday, 9am-10:45am at the Assumption Church. Contributions to the Wounded Warrior Project, P.O. Box 75841, Topeka, KS 66675 or Assumption Greek Orthodox Church, Danbury. 1/3

ARRABACA--Mary Anne Aseniero, on June 18th, 2015 of Forest Hills, NY. Devoted wife of Perfecto Arrabaca and loving mother to Andrew. Joy was a Psychiatrist with SCO Family Services and loved her work. Visiting hours at Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 98-07 Ascan Ave. corner Metropolitan Avenue in Forest Hills on Saturday June 20th and Sunday, June 21st, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mercy Church 70-01 Kessel St. Monday, June 22nd 9:45am, disposition at Fresh Pond Crematory. 1/3

COLLINS--Edna Wilde, of Freeport, NY on June 18, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Thomas F. Sr. Devoted mother of Thomas Jr., John (Patricia) Frank (Francine), Brian (Jenny), and Catherine "Katie" (the late David Lerner). Grandmother of 11 and great- grandmother of five. Raised in Forest Hills, NY. Daughter of the late Anne and Francis X. Wilde, and sister of the late Jean (James Neville). Registered Nurse, graduate of Mary Immaculate Nursing School and former employee of Long Beach Memorial Hospital, Lydia E. Hall Hospital and South Nassau Community Hospital. Reposing at Hungerford & Clark Inc Funeral Home, 110 Pine St (Corner So. Ocean Ave.) Freeport. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:30am at Our Holy Redeemer R.C. Church Freeport. Interment Long Island National Cemetery. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. 1/3

SUBOTNICK--Anita, passed away on June 18th. She loved her family, above all else, and was devoted to them. Grandchildren Ian, Livia, Maya and Charli and children, son, Bryan, and his wife, Heather, and daughter, Paula, and her husband, Adam, filled her life. However, she was never far apart from her husband of 52 years, Stuart Subotnick. Together, they worked to benefit society through their foundations and generous contributions to charitable organizations which they sponsored, often anonymously, for many years. Anita's love for life could be seen through her passion for thoroughbred horses. She enjoyed racing, a sport she became aware of through her beloved father, Irving. She met Stuart while they were both in high school, in Brooklyn, and was with him through many years of hard work and lucky breaks. Over the course of their lives, together, they lived as one. She will be deeply missed by all. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 21st at 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th Street, New York, NY. Donations can be made to Autism Speaks, 1 E. 33rd Street, 4th Floor, New York, NY 10016 www.autismspeaks.org. 1/3

LEE--James B. Jr. James B. Lee Jr.,on June 17, 2015. Beloved husband of Beth, and loving father of Lexi, Jamie, Izzy, and grandfather to Bobby and JoJo. Known as Jimmy, he was tenaciously loyal, and a source of inspiration to many who knew him as a mentor, colleague, and friend. He was a proud champion of Williams College and cared deeply about education and providing opportunities for those in need. A world- class fly fisherman, he lived for being outdoors and cherished time with his family. He was a larger-than-life personality who loved rock-and-roll, the thrill of the deal, his firm J.P. Morgan Chase, and his clients who he considered friends. The family invites friends to Memorial Mass on Monday, June 22nd at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund. 1/3

SAKOLSKY--Howard M.,lived life on his terms -bestowing unconditional love for his children Tony (1957-1973), Stephanie, Tanya, David; sister Marcy and as Papa Howard to Brandy and to his beloved companion Joy. Tall in stature and character, King of the road and his "coach," boundless curiosity for people and places. He was at home anywhere in the world. Our dear Jewish Cowboy has ridden gracefully into his sunset. 1/3

ADLINGTON--Christopher. Died peacefully on 13th June. Much loved and missed by family and friends. Funeral Service at2pm on 22nd June at St. Mary's Church, 145 W. 46th Street, New York, NY. Donations, if desired, to the Brooklyn Botanical Garden. 1/3

SADOWSKY--Dr. Donald. June 13, 1929 - June 12, 2015. A clinical dentist with advanced degrees in public health and sociomedical sciences, Donald Sadowsky obtained substantial federal research grants over many years, with extensive data reported at both national and international meetings. He was a professor emeritus at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and taught at Columbia University until he retired at the age of 75. He passed away the day before his 86th birthday, over six years after being diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Dr. Sadowsky grew up in New York City and eventually settled with his young family in Yorktown Heights, New York. His special interests were hiking, fishing, and gardening; nature provided renewed well-being for this "street kid from the Bronx." He is survived by his wife, Rosalie Landres; his children, Ann Mia and Jacob; and his grandchildren, Alyssa and Evan Haning. "When the music's over, turn out the lights." 1/3
PERLSTEIN--Harvey L. You are always thought of with love. Audrey and Suzanne 1/3

DOUBLEDAY--Nelson. The Board of Directors and staff of The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (The NYSPCC) mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Nelson Doubleday. A dedicated member of the Board of Directors for over 55 years, Nelson maintained a passionate commitment to the safety and well-being of New York City's children throughout his tenure. He was unanimously elected to the Board in 1960, and became an Honorary Director in 2006. Nelson's compassion, generosity of spirit and five decade commitment to The NYSPCC were an inspiration to us all. We extend our deepest condolences to Sandra and the entire Doubleday family. 1/3

jampires By Sarah McIntyre. Illustrated by David O’Connell. 32 pp. David Fickling/Scholastic. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7)
 
When Sam finds that someone has “sucked out the jamminess” of his doughnut — and really, what could be worse? — he puts ketchup inside to trap the culprit. Luckily the perpetrators are two “jampires,” batlike creatures more cute than scary. Even luckier, they fly him to a land of cake castles, tart flowers and an ice cream moon. With rounded shapes, soft colors and pops of jam-bright red, O’Connell’s art works delightfully with McIn­tyre’s supple rhymes to spread a silly, sweetly escapist mood.
BENNETT--Solomon, on June 14, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Bette. Loving father of Candi and Richard, Melanie and Jeff. Cherished grandfather of Brandon, Elizabeth, Caroline and Margaux. 1/3

NORWALK--Perle R.,formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on June 19, 2015. Perle was pre-deceased by her loving husband, Seymour. She was the beloved mother of Charles and Barbara Norwalk, and Carole and Irving Friedman. Loving grandmother of Danielle and Lance Burns, Samantha and Richard Michaelson, and Scott and Allie Norwalk. Great-grandmother of Justin, Shawn, Alex, Taya and Brody. SCHWARTZ--Ellen Kay. Ellen Kay Schwartz of New York, NY died Tuesday, June 16, 2015 at home with her loving husband, Edward M. Spiro, of 38 years by her side. Ellen was born in NYC on Jan. 23, 1952, graduated from Hunter College H.S., Vassar and Boston University School of Law, where she met her husband, Ed. A staunch believer in both public service and the need for fair application of the law to all, Ellen served as an attorney for the Legal Aid Society, Inspector General for various NYC agencies, an Asst. Deputy Commissioner for the NYPD, and the Head of Internal Affairs for the Baltimore Police Dept. For the last eight years, Ellen served the people of the State of New York, first as Executive Deputy Chief of Staff in the Attorney General's Office and then as Assistant Executive Deputy Secretary to the Governor. But no people in New York were better served by Ellen than her family. In addition to being a loving mother to her daughter, Sara (Spiro) Abramson, and son, Matthew H. Spiro, she was a wonderful mother-in-law to her children's respective spouses, Brett and Eileen, a loving and doting grandmother to Ilana and Vivian Abramson, supportive sister to Chuck Schwartz, and a caring daughter to Shirley Dinitz and Murray Schwartz and step-daughter to Leon Dinitz. Beyond her immediate family, Ellen was the core of her extended family, hosting large holiday dinners over the years that will be remembered fondly by all. Services will be held on Friday, June 19 at 11am at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., New York, NY. 1/3

GROSSMAN--Solomon. June 26, 1928 - May 17, 2015. As a child Sol was so drawn to music that although told to stay in the car when his father went to run an errand, he was compelled to follow the strains of gospel music spilling from a church. When found by police who asked why he ran away, young Sol said "I thought I heard angels, and wanted to see them!" His father said, "We have music at home." He responded "Not like that!" Sol received a BA in philosophy from William and Mary College and remained a life-long learner, reading biographies weekly. His father Irving died young. Sol and his brother Ivan needed to take over the family dry cleaning business in New Jersey. Their main goal was to provide for their mother Rose and younger sister Florence. They later expanded into real estate in New York and New Jersey. Sol lived with his partner, Ron Kane in New York and spent summers in the Hamptons. Every autumn they went to Paris. Sol and Ron were committed philanthropists whose donations live on at the Met, Gracie Mansion and the White House. They hosted classical concerts in their homes, and walked their German Shepherds in Central Park. Sol loved spending time with his nieces and nephews; he taught them to drive, took them to concerts and shared his passion for the arts and history. Sol had a massive stroke in 1982, but with tenacity and courage managed to recover and live a full life. As his condition worsened, he made Palm Desert his winter home, spending time with friends and family there. His superb caregivers Ray Lopez and Jason Marbella kept Sol healthy and strong for many years. He will be dearly missed by many, including his longtime assistant, Cathy Sakalian, his caregivers, innumerable friends, and nieces, and nephews Dian, Nancy, Laurie and Jane Grossman, Nina Rosen, Johnny Platzer, Ariel and Perrin Wright, Sarah Samuel, and Kenny and Elizabeth Rosen. 1/3
