On behalf of our faculty, students, staff, the Penn Medicine Board of Trustees on which he served, and the countless patients treated at the Roberts Proton Therapy Center established by the Roberts family, we salute his memory. Ralph's exceptional commitment to our University, the City of Philadelphia and our nation was nothing short of inspirational. His legacy is a world made better by his time in it. David L. Cohen, Board Chair, and Amy Gutmann, President, University of Pennsylvania; Mark O. Winkelman, Chair, Penn Medicine Board; J. Larry Jameson, Dean, Perelman School of Medicine; and Ralph W. Muller, CEO, University of Pennsylvania Health System 1/3

Radloff, of Boston; by her grandchildren Mary Alice Teti (and husband J. Leonard), James J. Beha (and wife Alyson), Christopher R. Beha (and wife Alexandra), Macy E. Radloff, and Allison V. Radloff, nine great-grandchildren, numerous nieces and nephews, and her youngest sister, Madeline Reilly Bailey. Sanny was a committed parishioner of Church of the Resurrection in Rye and a long- time member of the Colony Club, the American Yacht Club and the Rye Garden Club. Of her many volunteer activities Sanny was particularly proud of her work at Bird S. Coler Hospital on Welfare (now Roosevelt) Island. She was a member of the Ladies of Charity and a Dame of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta and the Order of the Holy Sepulchre. One of seven children of John S. and Estelle Mulqueen Reilly, Sanny was a "Reilly girl" to her core: a model of faith, loyalty, spunk, service to others, and good spirits all her life. Her life was filled with family, prayer, bridge, service, and conversation. She was dearly loved as mother, aunt and "Granny Sanny," hugely enjoyed by her many friends, and much appreciated by her North Manursing neighbors (especially in the garden and at her Halloween receptions). A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, at 10am on June 24. CLYMA--Gail D. September 2, 1935 to June 15, 2015. Gail was born and raised in Yonkers, New York, and graduated from Roosevelt High School. She graduated from Syracuse University in 1957 with degrees in journalism and home economics. Her first job was with the advertising agency J. Walter Thompson in New York City. For most of her career she worked at Time Inc. with her last position there being Director of Market Research for Fortune Magazine. During her retirement she enjoyed gardening at her second home in Westhampton, and worked tirelessly for the International Dark Sky Association, an anti-light pollution organization. She was a long time volunteer for the New York City Parks Department. She was predeceased by her parents Edmund Ramon Clyma and Cecil Chase Clyma and her sister Nancy Clyma. She is survived by her sister Jane C. McGinnis, nephews Kim Harwood and Christopher Harwood, and five great nephews, Kai, Luca, Galen, Jachym and Vincent Harwood. The time and place of her memorial service will be announced. 1/3

BERNHARD--Sandra. With profound sadness, we say farewell to our colleague and friend Sandra Bernhard, who passed away June 18. Sandy was a brilliant, empathic, compassionate, passionate, and exhaustive force for arts education in the United States. As the founding director since 2007 of HGOco, our company's community and education initiative, she spearheaded a wide range of innovative programming and forged powerful collaborative relationships with colleague organizations throughout the city and the nation. Born February 3, 1959, prior to coming to Houston Sandy was Department Chair, Associate Professor, Artistic Director, and J. Ralph Corbett Distinguished Chair of Opera at Cincinnati College- Conservatory of Music. At San Francisco Opera from 1990 for more than 15 seasons, she served as assistant director for over 40 productions, educational director from 1994-96, and as an acting coach and instructor for the Merola Opera program. She earned a BM from the University of Illinois. Sandy faced her long illness with incredible courage and grace, teaching all of us how to be at peace with loss. She leaves a powerful legacy at Houston Grand Opera, one that even in this time of incredible sadness, we celebrate with great joy, both in her memory and in looking forward. Our deep sympathies go out to her partner, Lisa Long; her parents, Walt and Mandy Sachwitz, of Huntington Beach, CA; her brother Steve Sachwitz, his wife Debbie and their son Drew of Walnut Creek, CA. We will hold a memorial for Sandy in the fall. Contributions in her memory may be made to Omega House, 602 Branard St., Houston, TX 77006. John Mendelsohn, Chairman Patrick Summers, Artistic & Music Director Perryn Leech, Managing Director Houston Grand Opera 1/3

ZIMMERMAN--Ruth Olshan. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Edward Zimmerman. Adored mother of Karen and Jon, Ellen and Bob. Cherished grandmother of Danielle and Eric, David, Jenny, Jonathan, Matthew and Laurel. Proud great-grandmother. Dear sister of Morton and Carole, Gladys and Steve, and the late Roz and Isaac. Service Monday 12:30pm at Larchmont Temple. 1/3

JOHNSON--Mary. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Alfred Arkay Johnson passed away peacefully at the age of 91 on June 20, 2015. Surrounded by her loving children Lillian and Irene. She will be remembered as a loving devoted Wife, Mother, Grandmother. A true Philanthropist for numerous charities dear to her heart. She will be deeply missed by many. Visitation will be on Tuesday 4pm-8pm at Frank E Campbell 81st St. and Madison. Mass will be at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity 340 East 74th Street on Wednesday at 11am. Interment to follow at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, NY. 1/3

SCHAEFER--Molly, former Publisher of Town and Country, died suddenly on June 17 of a horse riding accident at her farm in Pine Plains, NY. Born in Wauseon, Ohio, on October 14, 1944, a graduate of Michigan State '66, the young idealist taught English Lit to high schoolers in Detroit. She broke into the magazine world when, in the early 70's, she convinced LIFE magazine that she could land an interview with Jimmy Hoffa. She did, by actually sticking her tiny foot in his door. Her determination, insatiable curiosity and zest for life led her to New York. She worked in advertising for the New Yorker and W, was Associate Publisher of Cosmopolitan magazine, culminating her career as Publisher of Town and Country, from which she retired in 2000. An avid horsewoman and conservationist, she ran her farm while being an active Board member of The Dutchess Land Conservancy, Executive Vice President of Historic Hudson Valley, a member of Pine Plains United and Board of Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation. Molly's dedication to land preservation, family and friends will never be forgotten. She leaves her devoted husband, Dan Slott and loving son, Johnny, from her first marriage and her sister, Melissa Moll of Apple Creek, Ohio. She leaves the world a better place. A tribute to her life will be held at Mashomac Preserve in Pine Plains on Sunday, June 28, 2015 at 2pm. In memory of Molly, please send contributions to Dutchess Land Conservancy and/or Historic Hudson Valley. 1/3

SALTER--James 1925-2015. Jim died unexpectedly on Friday, June 19, 2015. A combat pilot, sportsman, epicure and author, he was the beloved husband of Kay Eldredge and the adored father of Allan (died 1980), Nina, Claude, James, and Theo and grandfather of Nile, Teagan, Elizabeth, and Sylvan. Among his fellow writers, he was regarded as incomparable, and his friendship was a prize beyond price. His voice, presence and personality will be terribly missed. At a later date there will be a memorial service celebrating Jim's life and work. 1/3
SUBOTNICK--Anita. One-half of a wonderful couple. We will miss you. Susan and Jim 1/3

LEE--James B.,Jr. His Eminence, Timothy Michael Cardinal Dolan, Chairman, Peter T. Grauer, President, and the entire Board of Trustees of Inner-City Scholarship Fund mourn the loss of our trustee and friend, James B. "Jimmy" Lee, Jr. Jimmy's passion for business was equaled by his commitment to helping others in need. He touched countless young lives through his support of Inner-City Scholarship Fund's mission to make a Catholic education possible for low-income children in New York City. His kindness will be forever remembered through the lives of the students for whom he made a difference. We offer our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Beth and their children. 1/3

COSTIKYAN--Harriet, age 87, daughter of the late Clarke and Leicester Costikyan, passed away peacefully on May 18, 2015. She is survived by her sister June Cronin, niece, Priscilla and three nephews, Peter, Phillip and Clarke. A memorial service will be held on June 25th at 11:00am at The Church of the Heavenly Rest. Located at 5th Avenue and 90th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory should be sent to Health Advocates for Older People, 708 Third Avenue, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

STINCHCOMB--Martha, 77, died on Sunday, June 14, 2015 at her home in Scotch Plains, NJ. Surviving are her daughter, Laura Stinchcomb and two grandchildren, Alexandra and Jack Mossawir. Private services are by Memorial Funeral Home, Fanwood, NJ. www.fanwoodmemorial.com 1/3

ZIMMERMAN--Ruth. Loving sister, sister-in-law, aunt, and great-aunt. Your warmth, generosity of spirit and loving commitment to the family will be deeply missed. Mort, Carole and Michael Olshan and Andrea & Michael Odell 1/3

SCHAEFER--Molly B. The Board and staff of Historic Hudson Valley mourn our Vice Chair, Nominating Chair, Executive Committee member, and Trustee since 1999. Molly was a peerless booster, board builder, and source of goodwill and glue binding our governing body. Her discerning selection of Trustees and awardees shaped the character of who we are and whom we honored. Molly radiated style and irresistible warmth. We admired her roles at Dutchess Land Conservancy, Mashomack Preserve, and Pine Plains United. For her unique gifts, we give enduring thanks. Michael Hegarty, Chairman Mark F. Rockefeller, Executive Committee Chair Waddell Stillman, President 1/3
MILLER--Muriel Sholin on June 13th, 2015. Loving wife of the late Leonard. Mother of the late Tammis and Terran (Lisa). Grandmother of Haley and Liam. The color purple will never be the same. 1/3

MILLER--Donald L. On June 20, 2015, Donald L. Miller died at the age of 83. He lived in Manhattan and Pine Grove, CT. Donald was a loving husband to Joan for 57 years; a cherished brother to Peggy; supportive and adventurous father to his daughters Susan Cohen and Amanda Miller; an enlightening grandfather to Danny and Timmy Cohen and Maxwell and Quinn Silva, all of whom survive him. Donald was an Air Force photographer during the Korean War, who continued to earn his living as a photographer in New York after the Air Force. Donald was also a writer, politician, painter, sculptor, furniture maker, cook, collector of tea bag tags, stamps and stories. Never idle, never bored. He will be greatly missed and forever remembered by family and friends around the world. 1/3

PASTOR--Frank M.,55, of New York City died peacefully on June 17, 2015. Born July 5, 1959 in Perth Amboy, NJ, he graduated Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School ('77). Frank graduated from Harvard University ('81). He was a resident of Adams House and a member of the Hasty Pudding Club where he performed in their annual theatricals. Following graduation, Frank moved to New York City and began his long career in advertising. In 1992, he moved to Paris, France to an international advertising agency. Eventually, he created his own company, Fresh Marketing Perspectives. In 2010, Frank completed the New York City Teaching Fellows Program and taught earth science at Harlem Renaissance High School. Frank's passion for the arts was central to his life as were his frequent international jaunts and the pursuit of picture perfect beach weather. Frank is survived by his mother Joyce Adamusik Pastor of Garnet Valley, PA, sister Lori Koelsch and her husband Eric of Wilmington, DE, and his niece, Elizabeth Niedringhaus, her husband Mark and their toddler son Cody of Chapel Hill, NC. Frank was predeceased by his father, Ambrose who passed away in 1987. Frank is also survived by Daniel Burguet of Madrid, Spain and Roy Kogan, of New York City whose love and devotion were so important, especially during Frank's final days. Donations can be made in his honor to the LIVESTRONG Foundation (www.livestrong.org). 1/3

BEHA--Macy Ann (nee Reilly), "Sanny" to all, passed from this life on June 18, 2015, in Rye, NY. She was 92. Her devoted husband, James. J., predeceased her in 1999; Jim and Sanny had been married for more than 50 years. She is survived by her son, James A., and his wife, Nancy, of New York City; her daughter, Ann Macy, and her husband, Robert A. Radloff, of Boston; by her grandchildren Mary Alice Teti (and husband J. Leonard), James J. Beha (and wife Alyson), Christopher R. Beha (and wife Alexandra), Macy E. Radloff, and Allison V. Radloff, nine great-grandchildren, numerous nieces and nephews, and her youngest sister, Madeline Reilly Bailey. Sanny was a committed parishioner of Church of the Resurrection in Rye and a long- time member of the Colony Club, the American Yacht Club and the Rye Garden Club. Of her many volunteer activities Sanny was particularly proud of her work at Bird S. Coler Hospital on Welfare (now Roosevelt) Island. She was a member of the Ladies of Charity and a Dame of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta and the Order of the Holy Sepulchre. One of seven children of John S. and Estelle Mulqueen Reilly, Sanny was a "Reilly girl" to her core: a model of faith, loyalty, spunk, service to others, and good spirits all her life. Her life was filled with family, prayer, bridge, service, and conversation. She was dearly loved as mother, aunt and "Granny Sanny," hugely enjoyed by her many friends, and much appreciated by her North Manursing neighbors (especially in the garden and at her Halloween receptions). A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, at 10am on June 24. Family will receive visitors at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, on June 23 from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm. FIDERER--Martin, of Longboat Key, FL and formerly of Scarsdale, NY and Rye Brook, NY, died peacefully on June 18, 2015 after a short illness. Born in Brooklyn in 1927, he joined the Navy at age 18 and was later educated at the University of Missouri and the University of Michigan. Mr. Fiderer began a long career in health care communications with Pfizer Inc., then joined Sudler & Hennessey in New York and later founded his own pharmaceutical advertising agency, Martin Fiderer Associates. After retiring in 1992, he volunteered as a guide at the Norwalk Aquarium in Connecticut and at the Mote Marine Aquarium in Sarasota, FL. He was a ranked bridge player, an avid tennis player and an occasional playwright. He is survived by son David, daughter-in-law Laura, grandsons Ray, Jason, Jordan and granddaughter Haley. Adele, his beloved wife of nearly 65 years, and daughter Beth predeceased him. Funeral services will be held at 11:00am on June 22 at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

GAGARIN--Serge. Prince Serge Serge Gagarin, of Southport, CT died peacefully on June 20, 2015 at age 96. He was predeceased by his wife Frances Moore Gagarin. He is survived by two sons Andrew and Charles. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Serge Gagarin Memorial Fund, Southport Congregational Church, PO Box 366, Southport, CT 06890. Services will be at eleven on Thursday, June 25 at the Southport Congregational Church, 524 Pequot Ave, Southport, CT. 1/3

STUKANE--Eleanor, of Toms River, NJ, formerly of S. Plainfield, NJ and New York City, left us too early at age 93. A woman of grace and dignity, the beloved wife of Edward A. Stukane, who predeceased her, the loving mother of Eileen, Ellen, Ed, Tom, mother-in-law of Jim Black, Kimberly Lyons, David Puchkoff, the cherished grandmother of Ken and Doug Black, Cole and Quinn Stukane, Micki and Jeremy Stukane, and Masha Puchkoff, passed away peacefully in her home on June 20th. She was dearly loved by her family and friends and will be deeply missed. Funeral June 25th, contact Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, Toms River, NJ. Gifts in her memory may be sent to Noah's Ark of Central Florida, PO Box 92221, Lakeland FL 33804-2221. 1/3

ZIMMERMAN--Ruth. UJA- Federation of New York mourns the passing of Ruth Zimmerman, beloved wife of the late Dr. Edward Zimmerman who leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend deepest condolences to Ruth's siblings, Morton and Carole, Gladys and Steve, and the late Roz and Isaac; her children, Karen and Jon and Ellen and Bob; her grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

STRAUB--Chester J.,Jr., Of Bronxville, NY, passed away peacefully with his family by his side, on Sunday, June 21, 2015, after fiercely and courageously, but with admirable composure, battling metastatic melanoma. He is lovingly survived by his wife, Jennifer; three stepchildren, Jonathan, Amanda and Mallory, and two step-grandchildren. Born October 4, 1960, Mr. Straub grew up in Brooklyn and Bronxville, NY. He was the eldest son of Chester J. and Patricia Straub, brother of Michael (wife Rachel), Christopher (wife Ann) and Robert (wife Dorothy), and uncle to seven nephews and nieces. Mr. Straub enjoyed some 30 years of progressively responsible executive positions in the public, private and non-profit sectors; with a focus on business, community, economic and real estate development in the states of New York and Florida; numerous urban and rural communities nationwide and in the British Virgin Islands. He had served in the Clinton Administration as Deputy Assistant Secretary, then Acting Assistant Secretary for Economic Development, Washington, DC; Executive Director of Technological Research and Development Authority, Florida; President of Ulster County Development Corporation, New York; Managing Director of Latitude 18 Associates LLC; Chief Executive Officer of Bougainvillea Hospital, British Virgin Islands; Corporate Secretary of Battery Park City Authority, New York; Executive Director, New York State Democratic Party; and various campaign roles for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Governor Mario M. Cuomo, as well as the New York presidential campaigns of Bill Clinton and Walter Mondale. He was educated at Xavier High School, Tufts University and St. John's Law School. Mr. Straub had a deep love for all his family, the centerpiece of his life, and was kind, caring, deeply ethical, and fiercely loyal. He practiced his belief in one's obligation to participate in public and political life, and made the world a better place. He will be sorely missed. Family and friends will gather at Fred H. McGrath & Son, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY on Thursday, June 25, 2015 from 2pm to 4pm and 6pm to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church on Friday, June 26, 2015 at 9:45am, directly across from the McGrath Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. May God have him rest in peace and save his soul. 1/3

HOERR--John P.,III, 84, of Middleboro, MA, died June 21. He was a journalist who specialized in labor - management relations and labor history. He was the author of "And The Wolf Finally Came: The Decline of the American Steel Industry," "We Can't Eat Prestige: The Women Who Tamed Harvard," and "Harry, Tom, and Father Rice: Accusation and Betrayal in America's Cold War." He also wrote "Monongahela Dusk," a historical novel. He had been a labor reporter and editor for Business Week magazine. He was born in McKeesport, PA, and was a graduate of Penn State University. A memorial will be held in Pittsburgh. 1/3

MANCUSO--Mary J.,90, Joined her beloved husband, Jack, in heaven on June 20, 2015. Loving Mother of four and grandmother of eight, she was a gentle soul who was deeply loved and will be forever missed. Services in Astoria: Wake on June 23, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm at Farenga Funeral Home; funeral, June 24, 9:45am, at Immaculate Conception Church. Donations in her memory can be sent to VNSNY Hospice Care. 1/3
DREIER--Jacob Leon, died at home on June 17. Memorial service July 1st, 3pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. 1/3
SHEEHY--Timothy, my beautiful son, on his birthday, who is loved, cherished and remembered every day. 1/3

ROLLINS--Jack, 100, of New York, NY, passed away on June 18th, 2015. Born Jacob Rabinowitz, on March 23rd, 1915, in Brooklyn to Sarah and Louis Rabinowitz, he was the oldest of three children. He graduated from Jefferson High in 1933 and The City College of New York in 1937, served in World War II, and in 1948, married the love of his life, Jane Martin (born Pearl Rose Levine, died 2012). Mr. Rollins was personal manager to numerous influential performers including Harry Belafonte, Woody Allen, Robin Williams, Billy Crystal, David Letterman, Robert Klein, Mike Nichols and Elaine May, Dick Cavett and Joan Rivers. With business partner Charles H. Joffe, he executive produced Woody Allen's films, receiving an Oscar for Best Picture for "Annie Hall" in 1977. He was also the executive producer of Late Night with David Letterman. He is survived by his daughters, Susan Rollins of New York, Hillary Rollins of Santa Monica, and Francesca Rollins of Los Angeles, as well as four grandchildren and great nieces, nephews and cousins. "The Gentleman Manager" will be memorialized on Wednesday, June 24th, at 4pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to either St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital or Comic Relief, Inc. 1/3

MILLER--Donald L. On June 20, 2015, Donald L. Miller died at the age of 83. He lived in Manhattan and Pine Grove, CT. Donald was a loving husband to Joan for 57 years; a cherished brother to Peggy; supportive and adventurous father to his daughters Susan Cohen and Amanda Miller; an enlightening grandfather to Danny and Timmy Cohen and Maxwell and Quinn Silva, all of whom survive him. Donald was an Air Force photographer during the Korean War, who continued to earn his living as a photographer in New York after the Air Force. Donald was also a writer, politician, painter, sculptor, furniture maker, cook, collector of tea bag tags, stamps and stories. Never idle, never bored. He will be greatly missed and forever remembered by family and friends around the world. 1/3

KONAR--William. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of William Konar, a Holocaust survivor from Poland. After the war, as a teenager, he immigrated to the U.S. where he built an enduring legacy through his family, various business endeavors, community engagement, and generous philanthropy. Deeply committed to Holocaust memory and education, he was an early leader of the Museum and a very generous supporter. He was a member of the Museum's Founder's Society and served on its governing board. The Museum sends its heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sheila, daughter Rachel, son Howard, who serves on the Museum's Executive Committee, and the entire Konar family. Tom A. Bernstein, Chairman; Joshua B. Bolten, Vice Chairman; Sara J. Bloomfield, Director 1/3

ADAMENKO--Bob. Died peacefully on June 21 after a long battle with dementia, he was 81. Bob was predeceased by his wife Elaine of 42 years, and is survived by three children and six grandchildren. Big Bob was born in Havana but made New York City his home. He was mentored by Alex Rose who brought him into the Liberal Party, through which he was active in organized labor and civil rights causes. Although successful in business with his father-in-law in the Garment District, he used his talents to become the New York Yankees team photographer for many years. He found his true calling working as the Assistant Commissioner for Special Events for the NYC DOT under Mayor Giuliani. His zest for life, his desire to help people whenever possible, and his cooking will be sorely missed. We will be gathering at Bob's favorite restaurant, Da Nico, 164 Mulberry St., to remember him, on Monday, June 29, 12pm- 3pm. Donations can be made in Bob's memory to the Alzheimer's Association: www.alz.org. 1/3

D'AMBRA--Frank N.,78, of Bergenfield, NJ, passed away on June 9. He was born in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his beloved sister Nancy (D'Ambra) Lescher, his niece Elizabeth Chirafisi, and nephews Francis and Fred Lescher. Frank graduated from Holy Trinity High School, St. Francis College and the Catholic University of America. Family and friends are invited Saturday, June 27th from 11:30am-1:30pm at the Frank A. Patti Funeral Home in Fort Lee, NJ to reminisce, grieve and support each other. In lieu of flowers, a tribute donation in honor of Frank may be made to AMFAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, at: www.amfar.org 1/3

PICHARDO--Julie, 57, of Muttontown, New York, passed away on June 20, 2015, with her family at bedside. She was born in Manhattan on August 2, 1957. She was graduated from Queens College and was a recipient of a full academic scholarship from the Albany Law School of Union University where she received her Juris Doctor degree in 1982. She was married to Joseph P. Awad, Jr. on August 26, 1983, at St. Nicholas of Tolentine in Queens, New York. Ms. Pichardo pursued a private practice in real estate and bankruptcy law owning her own practice in Garden City, New York. She had a passion for the New York Yankees, world travel, and Fire Island. She is survived by her two daughters, Alexandria Awad and Ariana Awad, her mother Ana Almanzar, brothers Nelson Pichardo and Robert Pichardo, and sister Annabelle Pichardo, as well as her father-in-law Joseph P. Awad Sr., and brother and sister-in-law James and Maureen Awad; predeceased by her father Julio Pichardo, brother Austin Pichardo, and mother-in-law Theresa Awad. Calling hours will be held at the Frederick Funeral Home in Flushing, New York on Tuesday, June 23rd from 2pm-5pm, and 6pm-9pm. There will be a mass service at St. Nicholas of Tolentine in Queens, New York on Wednesday morning at 10:30am. You may leave condolences at: www.frederick-fh.com. 1/3

REIMERS--Rev. Carl D.,Jr. Passed away peacefully at his home on June 17, 2015. He was born on January 17, 1930 in Richmond, Virginia. He spent his formative years growing up in Fort Worth, Texas with loving parents Charles Dietrich and Ray Saunders Reimers. After graduating from the St. Marks School of Texas he went on to graduate from Northwestern University. Realizing that he desired a career to serve both Man and God, he received a Masters of Divinity from Princeton Theological Seminary and further graduate studies at Harvard Divinity School. After his formal education, he became the Minister at the First Presbyterian Church, Coleman, Texas. Three years later in 1959, he was recruited to become the Assistant Dean of the Chapel, Princeton University serving as minister and professor. In 1970 he went on to become the Chairman of the Religion Department at Princeton Day School where he remained until he retired in 1993. He loved his years at Princeton Day School as a teacher, advisor and later Dean of Students. The "Rev", as his students at PDS affectionately called him, was a beloved teacher, mentor, and friend. Many former students would contact him well after retirement for advice and to officiate at their weddings and children's baptisms. He had an infectious personality with an abundant sense of humor. Carl served on various Boards including Princeton Day School, Historic Morven, Princeton University Art Museum, and the Council for Religion in Independent Schools. He was a member of the Century Association in New York and an honorary member of the Princeton Ivy Club. He is survived by his son Carl D. Reimers III, his son's wife Pamela, and their children Grace Pauline and Charles Damon Reimers of Greenwich, CT. He cherished his two stepsons from his marriage to the late Jane G. Irwin, Watt W. and Thomas B. Reynolds of Fort Worth, Texas. His Memorial Service will be held at the Princeton University Chapel on July 9 at 11am. 1/3

BURNS--Dr. Lois M.,72, of Glendale, passed away June 13, 2015. Dr. Burns was the daughter of Robert J. Burns (deceased) and Florence E. Burns (deceased). Dr. Burns was an academic scholar having graduated Long Island University with a Bachelors in Science and a Masters in Science degree and earning a Doctorate degree in Education from Columbia University Teacher's College. She was a professor, an administrator, a counselor, an author, a caretaker and a friend to many. Most importantly she was a daughter, a sister, a cousin, an aunt and a great aunt. STRAUB--Chester J.,Jr., Of Bronxville, NY, passed away peacefully with his family by his side, on Sunday, June 21, 2015, after fiercely and courageously, but with admirable composure, battling metastatic melanoma. He is lovingly survived by his wife, Jennifer; three stepchildren, Jonathan, Amanda and Mallory, and two step-grandchildren. Born October 4, 1960, Mr. Straub grew up in Brooklyn and Bronxville, NY. He was the eldest son of Chester J. and Patricia Straub, brother of Michael (wife Rachel), Christopher (wife Ann) and Robert (wife Dorothy), and uncle to seven nephews and nieces. Mr. Straub enjoyed some 30 years of progressively responsible executive positions in the public, private and non-profit sectors; with a focus on business, community, economic and real estate development in the states of New York and Florida; numerous urban and rural communities nationwide and in the British Virgin Islands. He had served in the Clinton Administration as Deputy Assistant Secretary, then Acting Assistant Secretary for Economic Development, Washington, DC; Executive Director of Technological Research and Development Authority, Florida; President of Ulster County Development Corporation, New York; Managing Director of Latitude 18 Associates LLC; Chief Executive Officer of Bougainvillea Hospital, British Virgin Islands; Corporate Secretary of Battery Park City Authority, New York; Executive Director, New York State Democratic Party; and various campaign roles for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Governor Mario M. Cuomo, as well as the New York presidential campaigns of Bill Clinton and Walter Mondale. He was educated at Xavier High School, Tufts University and St. John's Law School. Mr. Straub had a deep love for all his family, the centerpiece of his life, and was kind, caring, deeply ethical, and fiercely loyal. He practiced his belief in one's obligation to participate in public and political life, and made the world a better place. He will be sorely missed. Family and friends will gather at Fred H. McGrath & Son, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY on Thursday, June 25, 2015 from 2pm to 4pm and 6pm to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church on Friday, June 26, 2015 at 9:45am, directly across from the McGrath Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. May God have him rest in peace and save his soul. 1/3

IZEN--Marshall, died May 26, 2015, aged 90. Pianist, puppeteer (Emmy 1972), film maker, storyteller, traveler, gadfly to acousticians, fierce letter writer to reviewers, he adored opera, lieder (with nightingales especially), great pianists, conductors, and countless friends in New York, London, Chicago, Los Angeles. Beloved brother and uncle. Memorial Service, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, Sunday, June 28, 2015, 2pm. 1/3

THANHAUSER--Charles. 63, died at home, with his family, on June 22, 2015. The son of Joseph Thanhauser, Jr. and Marion Wolfson, Charles grew up in Philadelphia. Charles earned a B.Arch (1974) from the University of Pennsylvania and an M.Arch. (1977) from Harvard University. Charles moved to New York City where he founded TEK Architects in 1987. Specializing in non-profit and educational projects, TEK Architects won various awards and was featured in the Museum of Modern Art. A voracious reader with a sharp wit, and a deeply loving father and friend, he will be greatly missed. He is survived by his three sons: Bart, Will, and Graham. A memorial service will be held for Charles later this summer. 1/3

OFFENBERG--Ellen, formerly of New York City. Widow of Gerald; mother of Alan and Lori (Wiener); sister of Arthur Koeppel and the late Barbara Papel; grandmother of Gayle Vardakis, Melissa Baron, Michelle Offenberg, and Jessica Wiener; great- grandmother of Reid Vardakis. 1/3

LOHR--Rev. Charles H.,S.J., on June 21, 2015. Survived by his loving siblings William Lohr, Barbara Frey, Andrew Lohr and Joan Anne Sweeney. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Friday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Saturday at 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Northeast Province of the Society of Jesus, 39 E. 83 St., NY, NY 10028. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500. 1/3

OMMANI--Ardeshir. On June 20, 2015, Ardeshir T. Ommani, founder of the American Iranian Friendship Committee died at his Armonk, NY home at the age of 75. Born in Abadan, Iran, he married his beloved wife Eleanor 36 years ago. A dedicated father to his daughter Zheila Ommani and late son Arman, Ardeshir was delighted to be a doting grandfather to his Grandson, Arman Stefano Houghton, in his last year of life. Ardeshir held two Masters: in Mathematics and Political Economy, and taught in NYC Public Schools for 25 years. He dedicated his life to the anti-war, anti-imperialist movement, writing on Politics and Economics in international newspapers, speaking on radio and TV broadcasts. His brilliant ideas and political-economic analysis will be greatly missed; he will be forever remembered by family and friends around the world. 1/3

LANDAU--Edith L. December 28, 1931 - June 22, 2015. Bubbles was a remarkably loving, generous, intelligent, supportive woman who ardently believed in family. We, and our circle of family and friends, mourn the loss of our witty, insightful, resilient matriarch who lived life to the fullest, always happiest in the company of family and friends. Beloved and adoring wife of Billy; proud and cherished mom to Maggi Landau (Bobby Minter) and Debbie Landau; caring sister-in-law to Renee Landau; adoring Nonna to Sarah Furber (Brett), Casey Minter, and Emma Landau; adoring great-Nonna to Abby Furber and Logan Furber. Services will be Thursday, June 25th at 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice. 1/3

MEDINA--Pamela Florio, on June 22, 2015. Beloved mother of Steven and his wife Megan. Loving sister of Aleta and Robert Florio. Devoted niece of Nicoletta and Lucretzia. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St. Whitestone, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Friday St. Luke's RC Church 9:15am. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Thursday 2-5 & 7-10pm. 1/3

SCHULLER--Gunther. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. Composer, conductor, performer, educator, author, publisher, master of Jazz and Classical, his capacious gifts in all realms of music generated an inspiring life--his accomplishments define an era. 1/3

IZEN--Marshall, died May 26, 2015, aged 90. Pianist, puppeteer (Emmy 1972), film maker, storyteller, traveler, gadfly to acousticians, fierce letter writer to reviewers, he adored opera, lieder (with nightingales especially), great pianists, conductors, and countless friends in New York, London, Chicago, Los Angeles. Beloved brother and uncle. Memorial Service, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, Sunday, June 28, 2015, 2pm. 1/3

VOGEL--Margie. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our member Margie Vogel. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Paul Kotcher, President 1/3

CUMMING--Anita H. nee Wolfang (82) on June 20, 2015. Wife of the late Robert D. Mother of Edward and the late Linda Teplan. Mother-in-law of Paola Orsini. Grandmother of lan, Lili, Danny and Emily. Visitation Thursday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. Funeral Service Friday 11am at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to: The Pat Cairo Family Foundation, 40 Parkwold Drive W., North Valley Stream, NY 11580. 1/3

FARLEY--James D. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of James D. Farley. Mr. Farley and his late wife, Mary Kay Farley, an HSS Trustee, were generous supporters of the Hospital's mission and wonderful ambassadors for us on their travels around the world. They leave a lasting legacy, including The James D. Farley Family Laboratory for Connective Tissue Genetics, a primary site for scientific investigations on connective tissue disorders, and the David V. Levine MD Chair dedicated to scoliosis research. We are grateful for the widespread charitable work done by Mr. Farley and we extend our deepest sympathy to his surviving children, grandchildren, brothers and sisters. Kendrick R. Wilson III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, MD, Surgeon- in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

ROLLINS--Jack, 100, of New York, NY, passed away on June 18th, 2015. Born Jacob Rabinowitz, on March 23rd, 1915, in Brooklyn to Sarah and Louis Rabinowitz, he was the oldest of three children. He graduated from Jefferson High in 1933 and The City College of New York in 1937, served in World War II, and in 1948, married the love of his life, Jane Martin (born Pearl Rose Levine, died 2012). Mr. Rollins was personal manager to numerous influential performers including Harry Belafonte, Woody Allen, Robin Williams, Billy Crystal, David Letterman, Robert Klein, Mike Nichols and Elaine May, Dick Cavett and Joan Rivers. With business partner Charles H. Joffe, he executive produced Woody Allen's films, receiving an Oscar for Best Picture for "Annie Hall" in 1977. He was also the executive producer of Late Night with David Letterman. He is survived by his daughters, Susan Rollins of New York, Hillary Rollins of Santa Monica, and Francesca Rollins of Los Angeles, as well as four grandchildren and great nieces, nephews and cousins. "The Gentleman Manager" will be memorialized on Wednesday, June 24th, at 4pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to either St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital or Comic Relief, Inc. 1/3
SAVARICK--Martin "Marty." January 22, 1939-June 24, 2014 Missing You Every Day. Forever In Our Hearts. Sheila 1/3
BRODSKY--Judith. Rememberings are precious and last forever. Love, Grace and Ruth 1/3

PRESSMAN--Marjorie R. Widow of William B. Pressman, mother of Nancy Morgenstern and the late Jack David Pressman, and proud grandmother of Ava, Abe, Sara and Zoe. Retired psychiatric social worker and Local 1199 Union delegate. She will be missed by family and friends to whom she was fiercely devoted and immeasurably loyal throughout her 89 years. Burial private. 1/3
SCHINDLER--Mark E. June 24, 1965 - August 14, 2013 Remembering you today. Sadly missed...always in our hearts, your loving family

THANHAUSER--Charles. The scope and breadth of his wit was only exceeded by his voracious desire for knowledge. My heartfelt condolences go out to Bart, Will and Graham. You will be sorely missed. Saturday's will never be the same. Your best bud Bunky 1/3
SCOTT--Margaret Ann (Simon), passed April 21, 2015 at age 80. Celebration on Saturday, June 27, 1pm, at First Presbyterian Church of NY, 12 West 12th St. at Fifth Ave. 1/3

BAK--Sander. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend and partner, Sander Bak. An accomplished member of the Firm's Litigation Group, Sander joined Milbank as an associate in 2002 and became a partner in 2006. He was highly regarded for his commercial litigation work, with a focus on disputes involving international law, and was honored for his exceptional pro bono service, earning awards from the American Bar Association and Legal Services NYC for his work on civil rights, housing, family law, immigration and criminal law matters. He held degrees from Columbia Law School, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, and Yeshiva University. Sander was much loved at Milbank. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. 1/3
SAN FILIPPO--Gus. 7/27/33 -- 6/23/14. "You are love, here in my heart where you belong, and here you will stay!" Trudy 1/3
ZARLIN--Shelby Fay Greene, died Monday, June 22, after 75 years. Funeral services will be Wednesday, June 24, 11:00am at Millspaugh Funeral Home, 22 Bank St., Walden, NY. 1/3

SALTER--James. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. A master prose stylist, he wrote novels and stories that were exquisitely observed and imbued with restrained passion. 1/3

MARUFFI--Richard B.,on June 13, 2015. Companion of Delores Nelson; Father of Richard (Olga) and grandfather of Gianna and Sophia; Brother of Gina D'Angelo and John Maruffi. Visitation, Friday, June 26, 6-9pm, Fred H. McGrath, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, Saturday, June 27 at 9:45am. 1/3

EVANS--Albert. Peter Martins and the entire New York City Ballet family are heartbroken by the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Albert Evans. An electrifying presence on our stage for more than 20 years, Albert was one of the great artists of his generation, a favorite of both the countless choreographers who wanted to create works with him, and the thousands of fans who cheered his performances night after night. Since retiring from the stage in 2010, Albert continued to share his gifts as a ballet master, passing along his knowledge and love of dance to a new generation of performers. Kind, warm, generous, and always a joy to be with, Albert Evans is quite simply irreplaceable. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. 1/3
SIMON--Jay S. 3/06/37-6/24/06 To the love of my life. I am truly blessed. Jo-Ann 1/3

GLAUBMAN--Dr. Arnold. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our long-time member Dr. Arnold Glaubman. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Beverly and family. Paul Kotcher, President 1/3

BURTON--Frances. Born March 28, 1923 in Omaha to Harry and Elizabeth Rubenstein. Moved to NYC in 1988; lived and loved the New York lifestyle. Fran died peacefully June 19, 2015. Survived by her three children and five grandchildren. 1/3

HICKS--Elizabeth. After a long career helping African-Americans fight for fairness and justice, philanthropic consultant Elizabeth Hicks died in Manhattan on May 14, 2015. She was 92. Ms. Hicks, educated at Hunter College and an early Urban League member, worked for some time as an executive at the notable Harold L. Oram public relations firm, among the major fundraisers for the humanitarian and environmental causes of the time. Her notes to and from Mr. Oram with her ideas for innovative fundraising campaigns have been preserved among the Oram Papers in the Indiana University- Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) library. She went on to raise funds for the United Negro College Fund, especially Meharry Medical College. She was directly responsible, thereby, for giving many minority students the opportunity to get a college education. Before her retirement, she also raised funds for the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. Another of her outstanding accomplishments was helping an interested group form a fundraising LDF branch in Princeton, NJ. Ms. Hicks was born in Harrison, rural Georgia, on October 27, 1922 to the late Thomas Hicks and Lillie Hicks. Her family joined the South-to-North migration of those people of color who had the boldness and the means to avoid the cruelty of segregationist Jim Crow laws and so she grew up in Far Rockaway, Queens, and was educated there. She was a tireless supporter of the formal arts and would never fail to remind friends and associates with similar interests to meet her at performances on Broadway, or at Lincoln Center, the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM), St. Thomas (Episcopalian) Church, or the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and at exhibitions in favorite art galleries. She eventually succumbed to the usual circulatory problems of aging, but kept her ready sense of humor and her charming concern for the well-being of her friends and relatives as she struggled with failing health. She is survived by her cousin Viola Lena Doswell of Babylon, NY, and by the people she mentored, as well as by her close friends and her longtime caregivers. Kevin Rudisel, M.D. and Terry Carter 1/3

KLEIN--Leslie E.,died peacefully in the early morning of June 24th, three months after his 91st birthday. He was born and grew up in the Bronx. After attending DeWitt Clinton High School he answered his country's call and served in the Army during World War II, driving a tank in France. Finishing his education at City College, Les had a successful career in business but found time to serve local civic affairs. After retiring he divided his time among New York City, Long Boat Key, Florida, and Madison, Connecticut. He loved a great mystery novel, a political debate, and to share the hole-by-hole details of his golf game. Far above all he was devoted to his wife Eleanore, his daughters Nancy and Carol and their husbands David and Bill, and his grandchildren Gillian, Hannah, Jack and Kate. In all things his first care was his family. They will ever remember him as he was, that he lived a full and active life and gave them all that a husband and father could provide. 1/3

EVANS--Albert. Peter Martins and the entire New York City Ballet family are heartbroken by the loss of our beloved friend and colleague Albert Evans. An electrifying presence on our stage for more than 20 years, Albert was one of the great artists of his generation, a favorite of both the countless choreographers who wanted to create works with him, and the thousands of fans who cheered his performances night after night. Since retiring from the stage in 2010, Albert continued to share his gifts as a ballet master, passing along his knowledge and love of dance to a new generation of performers. Kind, warm, generous, and always a joy to be with, Albert Evans is quite simply irreplaceable. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. 1/3

The Officers, Directors and Staff of The Leir Charitable Foundations 1/3

STRAUB--Chester J.,Jr., Of Bronxville, NY, passed away peacefully with his family by his side, on Sunday, June 21, 2015, after fiercely and courageously, but with admirable composure, battling metastatic melanoma. He is lovingly survived by his wife, Jennifer; three stepchildren, Jonathan, Amanda and Mallory, and two step-grandchildren. Born October 4, 1960, Mr. Straub grew up in Brooklyn and Bronxville, NY. He was the eldest son of Chester J. and Patricia Straub, brother of Michael (wife Rachel), Christopher (wife Ann) and Robert (wife Dorothy), and uncle to seven nephews and nieces. Mr. Straub enjoyed some 30 years of progressively responsible executive positions in the public, private and non-profit sectors; with a focus on business, community, economic and real estate development in the states of New York and Florida; numerous urban and rural communities nationwide and in the British Virgin Islands. He had served in the Clinton Administration as Deputy Assistant Secretary, then Acting Assistant Secretary for Economic Development, Washington, DC; Executive Director of Technological Research and Development Authority, Florida; President of Ulster County Development Corporation, New York; Managing Director of Latitude 18 Associates LLC; Chief Executive Officer of Bougainvillea Hospital, British Virgin Islands; Corporate Secretary of Battery Park City Authority, New York; Executive Director, New York State Democratic Party; and various campaign roles for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Governor Mario M. Cuomo, as well as the New York presidential campaigns of Bill Clinton and Walter Mondale. He was educated at Xavier High School, Tufts University and St. John's Law School. Mr. Straub had a deep love for all his family, the centerpiece of his life, and was kind, caring, deeply ethical, and fiercely loyal. He practiced his belief in one's obligation to participate in public and political life, and made the world a better place. He will be sorely missed. Family and friends will gather at Fred H. McGrath & Son, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY on Thursday, June 25, 2015 from 2pm to 4pm and 6pm to 8pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church on Friday, June 26, 2015 at 9:45am, directly across from the McGrath Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. May God have him rest in peace and save his soul. 1/3

WRIGHT-MAHARAJ--Elise. Longtime entertainment industry executive and an alumna of Spelman College, passed away on Friday, June 19, 2015 following a brief battle with cancer. Hailing from Illinois, she continued to root for the Chicago Bears even after moving to New York in 1995 to join Motown Records, a division of Universal Music Group. During her tenure with Universal, Wright-Maharaj held various positions until leaving the company as the Senior V.P. of Urban Music for Republic Records in 2012 to establish the strategic marketing firm, Enhance Agency. During her career Wright-Maharaj developed and implemented campaigns for such artists as Stevie Wonder, Nelly, India.Arie, Erykah Badu, Chamillionaire, Akon, Enrique Iglesias, and a host of others. A hallmark of Wright-Maharaj's music business career was her ability to mentor both developing artists and young industry professionals with equal generosity. Beloved wife of Dhanraj Maharaj, she is survived by her parents, Simone Wright; Willard Wright (Yolanda); sister, Rae Allen (Answorth); brother, David Wright (Nicole); sister-in-law, Taurean Brown; step-siblings: Nicole Ricard (Raphael) and Tony Blake, as well as loving cousins, niece, nephews, and a cadre of friends. Services will be held on Friday, June 26, 2015 at 10:00am, St. Paul's Chapel, 1160 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her name to the Neil Pointer Foundation or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center via the following website: https://www.youcaring .com/elisewrightmaharaj 1/3

ADAMS--Laurie M.,died on June 19, 2015 peacefully at home in New York City after a long struggle with cancer, aged 73. The daughter of Dr. Daniel E. and Helen (Nelson) Schneider, she was educated at the Brearley School, Sophie Newcomb College of Tulane University, Columbia University (Ph.D., art history) and Teachers College (M.A., developmental psychology). From 1966 to 2011 she taught at John Jay College (CUNY) and the CUNY Graduate Center. The author of more than two dozen books, including four widely used art history textbooks, she specialized in Italian Renaissance art and the application of psychoanalytic theory to art. For further details see the East Hampton Star website. She leaves her husband of 44 years, John B. Adams; daughters Alexa and Caroline; sons-in-law Eric Shea and Giorgio Caputo; and four grandchildren. Funeral services are private; a memorial event is planned for the fall. Donations to The Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, NY 10028 are suggested. 1/3

LENNON--Jacques E. 92, died of pneumonia, on June 22, 2015. Born in Luxembourg on January 15, 1923, he began a career in business--spanning more than 70 years--at S.A. des Minerais. In 1939 he emigrated to the U.S. and joined Continental Ore Corporation (COC), the North American office of Minerais, making it possible for him to bring his parents and sisters out of harm's way during the war. He served with distinction in the U.S. Army in the Psychological Warfare Branch in North Africa, Italy, and Austria. Following his military service, he rejoined COC in 1946, becoming executive vice president in 1962. COC became one of the most highly respected international marketing companies of industrial raw materials, with over 30 offices and subsidiaries throughout the world. COC was acquired by International Minerals & Chemicals (IMC) in 1968. IMC (now Mosaic), the world's leading independent producer of fertilizers, acquired COC in order to broaden its international presence and diversify into some of COC's areas of expertise. In 1974, together with his two partners, Louis Lipton and Eric Lomnitz, he started Continental Resources Inc. (CRI), serving as president until the present day. Jacques is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Donatella, who took remarkable care of him during his last years; his cherished daughter, Linda, son-in-law Stuart Baskin, granddaughter Rebecca, and nephews Robert and Mark Wolff, and their families. His self-taught appreciation for art resulted in the eclectic collections in his homes in New York and Rome. His generous philanthropic endeavors characterize his diverse interests and humanistic approach to life. He never forgot his Luxembourg roots, serving as chairman of the Luxembourg America Chamber of Commerce for many years, as well as Luxembourg's Honorary Consul, in New York. Jacques was the family patriarch, never too busy to make himself available. His joie de vivre, irrepressible smile, and twinkling blue eyes can never be matched. He made it great for us all. A Memorial Service celebrating Jacques' life will be held at a later time. 1/3

KRAMER-- Meyer, Esq.,Rabbi. The Yeshiva University and RIETS family mourn the passing of Rabbi Meyer Kramer, z"l a revered distinguished alumnus of Yeshiva College '40 and the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) '41, the scion of rabbis in his native Balarus. He pursued a law degree at the Penn Law School where he was a member of the Law Review. He served as a rabbi in Philadelphia for many years while on the faculty of the law school. Upon retiring he became Director of Publications for the American Law Institute -American Bar Association. His son, Rabbi Doniel Z. Kramer, a YU Guardian, established the Rabbi Meyer Kramer Rabbinic Fellowship in honor of his father on the occasion of his 90th birthday six years ago. He is survived by his children: Rabbi Doniel Z. Kramer, Rena (and Chizzy) Loebenberg, Tamar S. (and Yitzchak) Klein and Shira (and Dovid) Danziger. May they and their children and grandchildren be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

PINE--Bessie, on June 22 at age 96, way too soon. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Kurt Pine. Loving mother of Alfred Marc Pine and Annie (Yaakov) Reuveni. Adored grandmother of Kenan (Ronit), Ohad and Li-Shai. Devoted sister of the late Frances Schwartz and the late Dr. Herbert Hadler. Bessie was born in Toronto, Canada where she graduated with honors in psychology from the University of Toronto. At age of 21, she became a branch director at the Toronto Jewish Community Center. After getting her MSW from the University of Pittsburgh she spent the bulk of her career at JCC Association of North America, where she became an institution. Bessie, widowed at age 43, combined her career and brought up her young children at the same time. In 1990 she was awarded the Professional of the Year from the Association of Jewish Center Professionals where she said "the vow I made to myself was to treat people the way I would like to be treated. Maintaining my integrity and credibility has been my ongoing effort and most important accomplishment on the job." The Jewish communal workers in 1993 ran out of awards for Bessie, so they gave her a new one - Tikkun Olam. Our loss, unimaginable, unbelievable, and incredibly painful is heaven's gain where Bessie Pine is already treating people with warmth, generosity, objectivity, compassion, sensitivity and menschlichkeit - and she's just getting started. "Too short time, not enough time, never enough time." Funeral services will be held on Sunday, June 28 at 11:30am at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. 1/3

RABOY--Marc, celebrated photographer to the stars, passed away unexpectedly on June 23, 2015 after an illustrious career creating beautiful pictures of well-known stage, screen, and recording artists. He led a life of vibrant joy shared freely with family, friends, and his beloved dogs Fanny and Mamie. Among the many who shared in Marc's joy was his former partner Jon Giswold, his husband Keith Henry, brothers Edward and the late Joseph. He will be deeply missed and always celebrated. Services at "The Riverside" at 76th Street and Amsterdam on Friday, June 26 at 3pm. Burial private. 1/3

HOWAT--John K.,"Jock," died quietly at home on June 23, 2015. Born in 1937 he attended Exeter, Harvard and the NYU Institute of Fine Arts. The great part of Jock's career was spent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as curator of American Paintings and Sculpture and then as Chairman of the American Wing. He was a scholar, writer, enthusiastic fisherman, traveler and cook, a loving husband and father. Survivors include his wife of 57 years, Anne H. Howat; daughters Karen and Laura; and brother James (Nicole). A memorial service will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main St., Exeter, NH 03833. 1/3
FADEM--Jessica Ann, August 4, 1958 - June 26, 2013 Always Loved. Never Forgotten. 1/3

LENNON--Jacques E. The Board and staff of Public Art Fund note with deep sadness the death of Jacques Lennon, father of Linda Lennon, dedicated Board member and dear friend. We send our sympathy and deepest condolences to Linda, Stuart, and their family. Jill Kraus, Chair; Susan K. Freedman, President; Nicholas Baume, Director 1/3

SEEMAN--Jay. Morrison Cohen LLP mourns the loss of one of our founding partners and dear friend, Jay Seeman. Jay was more than merely a terrific corporate attorney, he was a valued business advisor and strategic thinker. He was also a very decent human being, and left an indelible mark on our firm's culture. He was regularly credited with being an instrumental part of the MoCo fabric and always added life and light to every interaction. He was a very good man and we will all miss him, as we regularly remember his great contributions and leadership. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Seeman family. 1/3

HOWAT--John K. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Jock Howat, who was the Museum's Lawrence A. Fleischman Chairman of the Departments of American Art from 1982 until his retirement in 2001. He served in curatorial positions at the Met for more than 33 years, with his primary focus on the construction and installation of the much-expanded American Wing, completed in 1980, followed by the opening of the Henry R. Luce Center for the Study of American Art in 1988. He was a prolific writer and witty raconteur, a renowned scholar of the work of Frederic Edwin Church, and a lover of New York history and institutions, particularly the Met. In 1982 he established the William Cullen Bryant Fellows, the American Wing support group that continues to underwrite museum scholarship. We extend our condolences to his wife Anne, daughters Laura and Karen, and the entire family. Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO 1/3

HADDA--Janet Ruth. Yiddish professor, psychoanalyst, and biographer, died in Los Angeles on June 23, 2015, of metastatic cancer. She was 69. Born December 23, 1945, the eldest daughter of refugees from Nazi Germany, Dr. George and Annemarie (Kohn) Hadda. With degrees from the University of Vermont, Cornell, and Columbia, she joined the UCLA faculty, where she became the first tenured professor of Yiddish in the US. She published three books, as well as both academic and popular papers in English, Yiddish, German, French, and Hebrew. She also became a Training and Supervising Analyst at the New Center for Psychoanalysis and the Institute of Contemporary Psychoanalysis. Psychological insights permeated her later works, Passionate Women and Passive Men: Suicide in Yiddish Literature and Isaac Bashevis Singer: A Life, as well as her study of Allen Ginsberg. Survivors include her husband, Allan J. Tobin, a neuroscientist, and her sisters, Ceri Hadda (Lloyd Gelwan) and Katherine Hadda (Michael Andrews), her stepsons David Tobin (Ana Maria Xet-Mull) and Adam Tobin (Christine Kelly), and two grandchildren, Gabriel Tobin-Xet and Ursula Cashwan Tobin. Funeral services will be at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles on Friday at 11am. Contributions in her memory may go to the Forward Association: association.forward.com. 1/3

HAFT--Alfred P.,Jr. On June 23, 2015. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Alfred P. and William. Dear brother of Robert. Fond grandfather of Aaron and Eliana. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.) Sunday, June 28 at 11am. 1/3
SIMON--Suzanne. Suzy, my dearest friend since grade school. My loss of you is immeasurable and I will miss you forever. Nancy 1/3

SEEMAN--Jay W.,83 years young, died unexpectedly on Tuesday, June 23rd. He is survived, deeply loved and already painfully missed by his wife Marsha, children Roland and Antonella, Monica and David Zwirner, Claude and Penny and his five cherished grandchildren Lucas, Marlene, Johanna, Noah and Elijah. Also survived by adoring nephews, nieces, and so many others. Jay practiced law for over 60 years giving wise and compassionate counsel to his clients, and was a founding partner of Morrison Cohen. He was a former Chairman of the legal network Mackrell International and served as President of the William Alanson White Institute. When we spoke, you listened well. No more lines at the slopes, Jay. And we promise only serious music wherever you are. Funeral service Friday, June 26th, 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 76th Street, NYC. 1/3
EPHRON--Nora. "WASN'T IT WONDERFUL TO HAVE KNOWN AND LOVED HER--What glory! What fun! What goodness! What loveableness..." Miss you honey xxx Diane 1/3

HANDMAN--Richard A. died unexpectedly on June 22 surrounded by his loving family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Thursday July 2nd at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West, beginning at 6:30pm. 1/3

KELMAN--Laura Kathleen. The employees of Hugo Neu Corporation are deeply saddened by the loss of Laura Kathleen Kelman, mother of Hugo Neu's CEO, Wendy Kelman Neu, and Hugo Neu's Vice President-Business Development, Pete Kelman, and mother-in-law of the late John L. Neu, former CEO of Hugo Neu. Mrs. Kelman's late husband, Captain Peter B. Kelman, acted as Hugo Neu's principal, independent marine surveyor in its extensive export business. Mrs. Kelman was a true lady who raised six unique, caring and intelligent children, who have pursued diverse and meaningful careers. With her husband, she instilled in them a strong work ethic, an egalitarian sense of values, a love of animals and all living things, and an intense desire to contribute to society and preserve our environment. In recent years, Mrs. Kelman courageously dealt with serious health issues but did not allow them to prevent her from enjoying her six children, their spouses, and grandchildren, all of whom will miss her dearly. Our hearts go out to Wendy, Zoe, Sally, Bob, Jackie, Pete and their families at this sad time. 1/3

ROTTENBERG--Jean. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with sorrow the passing of Jean Rottenberg, adored mother of our beloved Cantor Emerita, Lori Corrsin. She was a caring, wonderful woman, adored by all who knew her. Her memory will always be a blessing. 1/3
GLAUBMAN--Arnold. The Rubels and Coplans extend their sincerest condolences. He will be missed. 1/3

HANDMAN--Richard A. died unexpectedly on June 22 surrounded by his loving family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Thursday July 2nd at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West, beginning at 6:30pm. 1/3

POWERS--Robert. We mourn the loss of Robert Powers, beloved husband of Marcia, father of Dawn and Andrew and grandfather of Shelby and Kyle. He is also survived by his sister Ann and his sister-in-law Rene and many beloved relatives and friends. Bob served in the Army during the Korean war, graduated from NYU and was the founder of The Thermo-Tite Window Corp. of Westchester. Funeral Service 10am Sunday at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. Donations can be made in his name to Community Synagogue of Rye, the Bruce Museum of Greenwich or the Alzheimer's Association. For more information; www.zionchapel.com 1/3

KRUGER--Louise Brice, 92, passed away peacefully on June 9 in York, PA. She served in the Cadette Corps of Nursing in WW II. She received her BSN from the University of Pennsylvania and her MA from NYU. She was the Director of Home Care for St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. Louise was a member of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church and a 20-year volunteer for the Central Park Conservancy. She was a devoted mother, grandmother, aunt and friend. Louise is survived by her loving children, Robert Kruger and wife, Monica, and Sherry Lookofsky; and her grandchildren, Maggie and Bryce Kruger, all of York. Louise will be inurned in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Columbarium. Services are pending. Contributions may be made to the FAPC Generation to Generation Campaign, 7 West 55th Street, NYC 10019. Please visit www.HetrickBitner.com to offer condolences. 1/3

ROSS--Barbara S. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of a member from its founding generation, a former trustee and Women of Reform Judaism president, and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor 1/3

ADAMS--Laurie M.,died on June 19, 2015 peacefully at home in New York City after a long struggle with cancer, aged 73. The daughter of Dr. Daniel E. and Helen (Nelson) Schneider, she was educated at the Brearley School, Sophie Newcomb College of Tulane University, Columbia University (Ph.D., art history) and Teachers College (M.A., developmental psychology). From 1966 to 2011 she taught at John Jay College (CUNY) and the CUNY Graduate Center. The author of more than two dozen books, including four widely used art history textbooks, she specialized in Italian Renaissance art and the application of psychoanalytic theory to art. For further details see the East Hampton Star website. She leaves her husband of 44 years, John B. Adams; daughters Alexa and Caroline; sons-in-law Eric Shea and Giorgio Caputo; and four grandchildren. Funeral services are private; a memorial event is planned for the fall. Donations to The Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, NY 10028 are suggested. 1/3

KELMAN--Laura Kathleen, 82, died at home in New York City on June 22nd. She is survived by her beloved children, Wendy Neu, Zoe (Steve) Shinn, Sally (Steve) Osman, Bob (Linda) Kelman, Jackie (Sam) Bisbee, and Peter Kelman. Born in Manchester, England, on May 19th, 1933, Laura grew up during the war, the youngest of eight children. Often she found comfort and security at the local animal shelter where she would share her meager food rations with the homeless dogs. Once married and with the support of her children, she went on to provide that same comfort and security to hundreds of rescued animals. Laura lived a life full of compassion and empathy for the suffering. She will be remembered as a devoted wife who unselfishly cared for her husband of 52- years, the late Captain Peter Kelman, as he battled with Lou Gehrig's disease (died 2005); as a loving and infinitely patient mother who raised six educated children who always pushed the boundaries; as a kind, gentle and loving grandmother to Laura, Eric, Lucie, Zach, Grace and Peter and step-grandmother to Jordan and Kristen. Most importantly she taught her children and grandchildren to confront society's moral and ethical challenges and believe that they can make a difference. She was the inspiration behind the family's foundation "Companion Animal Placement" that rescues animals and supports NY Class and PETA to protect the carriage horses in Central Park, NRDC to protect the environment, and Matheny Children's Hospital. The family is very grateful to the friends who helped out during her lifetime: Melissa, Trineley, Dawa, and especially her beloved Yangchen. The family requests memorial donations to be given to Companion Animal Placement, c/o C.O.S., 120 Fifth Avenue, Suite 600, New York, NY 10011. 1/3

MONTANARI--Marie-Claire, 72, died at her home in New York on June 23, 2015 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Ms. Montanari was born in Paris and came to New York in 1968 to work as an interpreter for the United Nations. She began studying photography seriously in 1973. Her work has been widely exhibited in the United States and France and is part of the permanent collection of the Bibliotheque Nationale de France in Paris. She is survived by her husband, John Ziegler. Services will be held Tuesday June 30th at 11am at the United Nations Chapel at 44th Street and First Ave. 1/3
DESHONG--Edward. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward Deshong, associated with The New York Times from January 1, 1976. 1/3

KELMAN--Laura Kathleen. The employees of Hugo Neu Corporation are deeply saddened by the loss of Laura Kathleen Kelman, mother of Hugo Neu's CEO, Wendy Kelman Neu, and Hugo Neu's Vice President-Business Development, Pete Kelman, and mother-in-law of the late John L. Neu, former CEO of Hugo Neu. Mrs. Kelman's late husband, Captain Peter B. Kelman, acted as Hugo Neu's principal, independent marine surveyor in its extensive export business. Mrs. Kelman was a true lady who raised six unique, caring and intelligent children, who have pursued diverse and meaningful careers. With her husband, she instilled in them a strong work ethic, an egalitarian sense of values, a love of animals and all living things, and an intense desire to contribute to society and preserve our environment. In recent years, Mrs. Kelman courageously dealt with serious health issues but did not allow them to prevent her from enjoying her six children, their spouses, and grandchildren, all of whom will miss her dearly. Our hearts go out to Wendy, Zoe, Sally, Bob, Jackie, Pete and their families at this sad time. 1/3
