YOHALEM--Mark, 92, Roslyn, NY, died June 25, 2015. Educator, mentor, and chairman of Science Deptartment, Bayside High School. Graduated Harvard University, Class of 1943. Served in WWII, seeing action in Normandy and Battle of the Bulge. Choral member of Queens College Choral Society serving as treasurer and president. Recorded text books for the blind; Devoted member and President, Board of Trustees, Bryant Library--Roslyn, NY. He will be sorely missed by his wife Hilda, children Susan and Peter, grandchildren Zach Chaloner and Emily Haan, and great-grandchild, Caleb Haan. Memorial service to be held at a future date. 1/3

MUSHINSKY--Bernard, Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with sorrow the death of Bernard Mushinsky, husband of our devoted docent, Hadassa Mushinsky. May beautiful memories bring comfort to all who mourn his passing. 1/3

MURPHY--John D.,78, on June 25th. Lifelong and well-known resident of Park Slope. Civic activist. Lover of Brooklyn and Ireland. Beloved husband of Louise Tarakan Finney, father of Jennifer Murphy, grandfather of KeithRedzinak and godfather to DeSean Allen. Dear brother of Catherine Hennessey, Mary Murphy, Sarah Doganieri, Mona Carley, Robert and the late Helen and James. Devoted friend to dozens of nieces, nephews, great nieces and nephews and the spouses of his close relations. Waking at Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th St., Brooklyn, Sunday, June 28th, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral mass at St. Thomas Aquinas Church, 9th St. at 4th Ave., Brooklyn, Monday, June 29th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, VNSNY Hospice or the Innocence Project. We shall not look upon his like again. 1/3

SIMON--Suzanne Cohn. June 9, 1940 - June 25, 2015. I have lost my darling Suzy, the light of my life. We had 33 glorious years together. Now they have ended. Her sweetness is gone. Her light has dimmed but it is not gone. That light rests in my heart. The joys we shared, the two loving families we shared -- they are here with her light in their hearts. Oh my darling, you are gone, but as I promised, as you assured me, you are with me forever! David Simon, your husband and your eternal lover 1/3

CONIGLIARO--Michael G.,peacefully passed away on Thursday, June 25th. He was a cherished husband, survived by his wife and sweetie, Laura, and beloved father of Alison Leigh, Andy, and Kimlou, and their spouses Michael, Trina, and Zake. A loving grandfather to Jack, Logan, Nastasja, and Riley, and a caring and loyal friend to so many everywhere he went. He was a big brother to Doris, Chris, Leslie and Lisbeth and their families, and a great pal and brother-in-law to Barbara. He was the President of AMIC Research, a computer services firm, and proud Veteran of the United States Air Force, who had a joy and love for painting during his retirement. In lieu of flowers, it would mean a lot to Michael for any donation to be made to help support the successful lives of Veterans returning from war. The two organizations we have selected are: The Mission Continues (www.themissioncont inues.org) and Team Rubicon (http://www.teamrubicon usa.org). Services to be held at "The Riverside" on 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. On Monday June 29th at 10:30am followed by burial at Menorah Cemetery. 1/3

d'URSO--Senator Mario, died peacefully in Rome on June 5th 2015. He was born in Naples on April 8th 1940 to Sandro d'Urso and Dame Clotilde Serra di Cassano, a direct descendant of George Clymer, a signer of both the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution. Mario came to America to study law at George Washington University and, in 1968, started his career as a banker at Kuhn Loeb, later Lehman Brothers. In 1994, back in Rome, he was appointed Under Secretary of Commerce and, in 1996, he was elected to the Senate of the Republic of Italy. He was unique in combining his civic and corporate responsibilities with mingling in the international jet set. He was generous and compassionate, well-known and well-loved: he will be sorely missed. 1/3

MOORE--Ai. Ai Constance Handa Moore, died at home near Princeton on 13 June, age 90. Born in Seattle, she lived most of her adult life at the intersection of America's problematical racial divides. In 1942 Ai's family was deported to an internment camp for Japanese in Minidoka, Idaho. She left the camp to go East for college, and at war's end finished at University of Washington. Ai did social work in Harlem, at a women's reformatory, and on an Indian reservation. In 1952 Ai moved to Princeton and - crossing another taboo boundary - married James W. Moore. She launched a Princeton catering business and ran the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation dining facility. A memorial service will be held at Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, at 11am 18 July. She asked donations be directed to Mario Laurenti '03 Financial Aid Endowment at Princeton Academy of the Sacred Heart, 1128 Great Rd., Princeton 08540. Her artistic and culinary tastes, lifelong concern for others, and devotion to social justice have marked us both. Yuki Moore and Jeffrey Laurenti. 1/3

SIMON- Suzanne Cohn. Suzy Simon died on June 25th of pancreatic cancer at age 75. As she wished, she passed in her own bed, surrounded by all her loved ones. Her husband of 33 years, David Simon, was by her side throughout the ordeal of pancreatic cancer for 11 months. It was in large part thanks to David's devotion that Suzy was able to fight her disease for as long as she did. At her bedside always were her children, Deb and David Wasser and Deb's wife, Dr Susan Vaughan, whom she loved as her own child. Susan's medical knowledge was hugely helpful throughout. Also ever present were Suzy's doting nieces, Keira and Deirdre Chassman, Deirdre's children Max and Jack Chassman-Silberman, and her grandchildren Savannah and Whittier Vaughan-Wasser. Suzy was the best grandma ever and will be buried with the necklace given her this year: "Just knowing you're my grandma makes me smile." Suzy will be missed by David's sons Michael and Andrew Simon and their families, Michael's wife Alison and their children Lauren, Nathan and Chloe and Andrew's wife Katherina and their children, Jake and Ella, as well as David's sister and her husband, Mimi Forman and John Koller. Suzy was born and spent her whole life in New York, enjoyed New York's culture, most notably serving on the Board of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. She's a graduate of NYU and was a therapist for 40 years. Most recently, Suzy generously supported pancreatic cancer research and asked that any donations be made to The Suzanne Cohn Simon Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund by a check to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (with a notation referencing her Fund), Attn: Amanda Gilstein, 633 3d Ave. 28th Floor, New York, NY10017. Her funeral: Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave on Monday June 29th at 11am. 1/3

BRUSKIN--Richard H.,91, passed away on June 25th surrounded by many family members. He was born in New Brunswick, NJ on February 17th, 1924, the eldest son of Ted and Bess (Elfant) Bruskin. Richard proudly served and was decorated in the Army during World War II. He graduated Rutgers University, class of 1947. After graduation, he became a leader in the field of market research, starting three companies: AdverTest Research; R. H. Bruskin Associates, Inc., which grew to be one of the leading research firms in the country; and ultimately Bruskin Marketing. Richard was an active member of many trade organizations, and a devout supporter and a lifetime fan of Rutgers University Athletics. An avid reader, golfer, and card player, his ultimate pleasure and joy came from spending time with his grandchildren and watching them grow into the people they are today. He lived in Somerset Run, in Somerset, NJ and Hunters Run in Boynton Beach, FL. His loving wife of 66 years, Dorothy Gottleib Bruskin, and his brother Marvin predeceased Richard. He is survived by his brother Stanley and his wife Bobbie; son, David and his wife, Eve; his daughter, Nancy; his daughter, Audrey and her husband, Jeffrey, and his grandchildren, Laura, Julia and her husband Noah, Reed, Rachel, Melissa and Nicole. He will be sadly missed by his family. Any donations in his name can be made to to Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple or Rutgers University. Services today at AEMT, New Brunswick, NJ at 11am. 1/3

SALTER--James. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. A master prose stylist, he wrote novels and stories that were exquisitely observed and imbued with restrained passion. 1/3

NEUMAN--Robert S.,88, of Winchester, MA. and Northeast Harbor, ME passed on peacefully in his sleep, June 20, 2015. American Abstract Artist and recipient of the Fulbright and Guggenheim fellowships. He leaves a devoted wife, Mary Susan "Sunne" Savage. Loving father of Elizabeth Neuman and husband Don Johnson, Ingrid Neuman and fiance James M. Cain, from his first marriage to Patricia Feddersen, of Needham, MA and third daughter, Christina Godfrey and Chad Godfrey, and his four cherished grandchildren, Aliza and Gemma Lurie, Charles and Grant Godfrey. A Memorial Service will be held on September 9th, 2015, on the artist's 89th birthdate at the Church of the Epiphany, Winchester, MA at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, S.D. 57326 www.stjo.org. Services are under the direction of the Lane Funeral Home, Winchester, 781-729-2580. 1/3

d'URSO--Senator Mario, died peacefully in Rome on June 5th 2015. He was born in Naples on April 8th 1940 to Sandro d'Urso and Dame Clotilde Serra di Cassano, a direct descendant of George Clymer, a signer of both the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution. Mario came to America to study law at George Washington University and, in 1968, started his career as a banker at Kuhn Loeb, later Lehman Brothers. In 1994, back in Rome, he was appointed Under Secretary of Commerce and, in 1996, he was elected to the Senate of the Republic of Italy. He was unique in combining his civic and corporate responsibilities with mingling in the international jet set. He was generous and compassionate, well-known and well-loved: he will be sorely missed. 1/3

PRICE--Ethel Rosen. On June 24, 2015 she died peacefully at the age of 94 in her senior living community in Washington, D.C. She was beloved wife of the late Judge Manuel J. Price. She grew up in Brooklyn and got her bachelor's from Vassar and master's from Radcliffe. Her early career was as a buyer for Macy's. She taught elementary school and became Reading Coordinator for the New York City School Volunteer Program now known as Learning Leaders. She is survived by her son Michael and grandchildren Paige and Alexandra of Clifton, Virginia. 1/3

KELMAN--Laura Kathleen. The employees of Hugo Neu Corporation are deeply saddened by the loss of Laura Kathleen Kelman, mother of Hugo Neu's CEO, Wendy Kelman Neu, and Hugo Neu's Vice President-Business Development, Pete Kelman, and mother-in-law of the late John L. Neu, former CEO of Hugo Neu. Mrs. Kelman's late husband, Captain Peter B. Kelman, acted as Hugo Neu's principal, independent marine surveyor in its extensive export business. Mrs. Kelman was a true lady who raised six unique, caring and intelligent children, who have pursued diverse and meaningful careers. With her husband, she instilled in them a strong work ethic, an egalitarian sense of values, a love of animals and all living things, and an intense desire to contribute to society and preserve our environment. In recent years, Mrs. Kelman courageously dealt with serious health issues but did not allow them to prevent her from enjoying her six children, their spouses, and grandchildren, all of whom will miss her dearly. Our hearts go out to Wendy, Zoe, Sally, Bob, Jackie, Pete and their families at this sad time. 1/3

SCHULLER--Gunther. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. Composer, conductor, performer, educator, author, publisher, master of Jazz and Classical, his capacious gifts in all realms of music generated an inspiring life--his accomplishments define an era. 1/3
DREIER--Jacob Leon, died at home on June 17. Memorial service July 1st, 3pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. 1/3

HERIS--Toni, Age 83, died May 9, 2015 at home in hospice care after a short illness. A long-time resident of Manhattan, she was raised in Jackson Heights, Queens, and had a BA in English from Queens College. Beloved wife, Stan Harrison (predeceased, 2001); loving step-mother, Mallory Harrison Gerstein; loving grandmother, Renee and Arielle Gerstein; caring sister, Gloria Brady (predeceased, 2006); cherished aunt to John, Susanne, Steven, Bill, Kathy, Suzy and David, great-aunt to Erin and Caitlin. Toni worked successfully as a copywriter, creative director, and consultant in the advertising world for many years before she and Stan embarked on midlife career changes. Their mutual support during this time of immense challenge and development exemplified the adventurous spirit in which they undertook their life together. Toni and Stan received doctorates in psychology at NYU and began the most exciting and satisfying phase of their work lives as psychotherapists. Toni was a world traveller before she met Stan and she continued those explorations with him and other friends throughout her life. In later years, she was fascinated by her studies in parent/infant attachment. A memorial will be held Sunday, August 16 from 1 pm to 4pm at the Society for Ethical Culture. 1/3
SIMON--Suzanne. Suzy, my dearest friend since grade school. My loss of you is immeasurable and I will miss you forever. Nancy 1/3
MUSHINSKY--Bernard, on June 23, 2015. Beloved husband of Hadassa (Harriet) for 53 years. Devoted father of Nina and Tanya. 1/3

MANETTI--Renald Amadeo, 83, died on June 22, 2015, after an extended illness. He loved his family, God, his country, his work and music. Renald was born in Monessen, PA on January 6, 1932, the eldest child of Andrew and Eleanor Manetti. A graduate of Pittsburgh University and Harvard Law School, Renald married Mary Eunice Gorman of Dorchester, MA in 1955 while they were both attending Harvard Law School. Renald entered the United States Army in 1956 and served the Judge Advocate General until his discharge in 1959. After which he served in the U.S. Army Reserves until he retired at the rank of Major. Renald worked as a corporate attorney for U.S. Steel from 1959 until 1969 and then joined ITT in its New York City headquarters office where he retired from a position as Assistant General Counsel. Renald and Mary settled in Sleepy Hollow, NY in the late sixties and resided there and other Hudson Valley communities for forty- five years raising their six children. During his time as a Mergers & Acquisition attorney, Renald travelled the world visiting Europe, Latin America, Southeast Asia, the Middle East and Australia. After retirement, Renald and his wife, Mary, continued to travel including visits to the Greek Isles, China, and multiple trips with a choir group that sang at renowned churches including The Vatican, Westminster Cathedral in London, and Saint Mark's Basilica in Venice. A life-long musician, Renald was a member of the Transfiguration Church choir for over twenty years and a member of Westchester Choral Society. Renald was also a life- long athlete competing in amateur tennis as a young man and later an avid squash player and devoted New York Yankees fan. Renald is mourned by Mary, his wife of nearly sixty years; his son Renald Jr. (Vanessa) of Quartz Hill, CA; his daughter Ellen (Michael Courts) of Portland, ME; his son Paul (Maureen) of Freeport, ME; his daughter Mary of Ossining, NY; his daughter Maggie (Brad Sousa) of Hastings, NY; and his daughter Carolyn (Paul Broucek) of Los Angeles, CA; his grandchildren, Sarah, Timothy, Joshua, Emily, Jenny, Michael, Christopher and Jason; and his sister Angela (Richard Covert) and his brother Jerry (Carolyn) and many nieces and nephews. Brilliant, compassionate, and generous, Ren lived and died with fearless grace. Visitation was held on Thursday, June 25 at Lindquist Funeral Home, Yarmouth, ME. A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated on Friday, June 26, at Holy Martyrs Church, Falmouth, ME 04105. Please visit www. lindquistfuneralhome.com to view a video collage of Renald's life and to share condolences, memories and tributes with his family. For those who wish, donations may be made in Renald's name to: The Carmelite Friars, 88 Carmelite Drive, Middletown, NY 10940. 1/3
CREAGHAN--George. Dearest, dearest Dad. Oh, how we miss you. Georgina, Dennis & Patricia 1/3

ESSER-- Robert A.,M.D., 96, longtime New York City academic neurologist and psychiatrist, passed away on June 16, 2015, from a sudden illness. Jesuit-educated at Loyola University, he then devoted himself to medicine. He graduated from medical school at Northwestern University in 1945, interning at Cook County Hospital in Chicago, following with a fellowship at Mayo Clinic. He served in the United States Navy and the Naval Reserves, attaining the rank of Commander, then at the State Department in Europe in the 1950s. Moving to NYC in 1962, he served as professor in the departments of neurology and psychiatry at the Neurological Institute of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, EEG expert at the Bronx Veteran's Medical Center and at Saint Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan. He also practiced psychiatry at Saint Vincent's in Rye, NY. Dr. Esser loved travel, European art and history, and genealogical research, documenting his family tree back 300 years to its German roots. Survived by his wife, Maria Ravida Esser; nephews John M. Esser and James M. Esser M.D., and niece Joni M. Esser Fisher. All Saints Cemetery in Chicago, IL, is his final resting place. 1/3

COLYER--Austin T. Of New York, NY, passed away on June 25, 2015. Austin was born on October 29, 1930, in Brooklyn, NY. His long and storied career spanned eight Broadway shows, including "Singin' In the Rain," "I Remember Mama," "Pal Joey," "Desert Song," and "Maggie Flynn." Austin also appeared in countless regional and national productions, including joining the national touring company of "Ragtime" for more than three years. Beyond his illustrious work on the stage, Austin's wit, charm, and encyclopedic knowledge of all things theatrical never failed to make a deep and lasting impression on all who knew him. As recently profiled in The New York Times, Austin was a resident of The Whitby on West 45th Street for more than 50 years, and was a pillar of his community and mentored many young actors. A man of many talents, Austin also served in the United States Army Air Corps. Austin was a fixture in the lives of his family and many friends, and while we truly thought he would be here with us always, he has left each who knew him with the deepest and most joyous memories. A wake will be held on Tuesday, June 30, 2015, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Crestwood Funeral Home at 445 West 43rd Street, between 8th and 9th Avenues. A Funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday morning, July 1, 2015, at 10:30am at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church (the Actor's Church) at 239 West 49th Street, between 8th Avenue and Broadway. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Actors Fund in Austin's memory. 1/3

MASSEY--Laine H. Stearns February 5, 1938 - June 4, 2015. A longtime resident of Manhattan's Greenwich Village and later Washington Heights neighborhoods, Laine was born in May, Oklahoma, daughter of Ruth (nee Lloyd) and William Marshall Harrison. She moved to New York City shortly after graduating from Oklahoma College for Women and never considered leaving. Survived by her daughter Kate, stepson John H. Stearns and his wife Monique Navelet, and a host of family and friends, she will be deeply missed. 1/3

PINE--Bessie, on June 22 at age 96, way too soon. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Kurt Pine. Loving mother of Alfred Marc Pine and Annie (Yaakov) Reuveni. Adored grandmother of Kenan (Ronit), Ohad and Li-Shai. Devoted sister of the late Frances Schwartz and the late Dr. Herbert Hadler. Bessie was born in Toronto, Canada where she graduated with honors in psychology from the University of Toronto. At age of 21, she became a branch director at the Toronto Jewish Community Center. After getting her MSW from the University of Pittsburgh she spent the bulk of her career at JCC Association of North America, where she became an institution. Bessie, widowed at age 43, combined her career and brought up her young children at the same time. In 1990 she was awarded the Professional of the Year from the Association of Jewish Center Professionals where she said "the vow I made to myself was to treat people the way I would like to be treated. Maintaining my integrity and credibility has been my ongoing effort and most important accomplishment on the job." The Jewish communal workers in 1993 ran out of awards for Bessie, so they gave her a new one - Tikkun Olam. Our loss, unimaginable, unbelievable, and incredibly painful is heaven's gain where Bessie Pine is already treating people with warmth, generosity, objectivity, compassion, sensitivity and menschlichkeit - and she's just getting started. "Too short time, not enough time, never enough time." Funeral services will be held on Sunday, June 28 at 11:30am at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. 1/3

HOWAT--John K.,"Jock," died quietly at home on June 23, 2015. Born in 1937 he attended Exeter, Harvard and the NYU Institute of Fine Arts. The great part of Jock's career was spent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as curator of American Paintings and Sculpture and then as Chairman of the American Wing. He was a scholar, writer, enthusiastic fisherman, traveler and cook, a loving husband and father. Survivors include his wife of 57 years, Anne H. Howat; daughters Karen and Laura; and brother James (Nicole). A memorial service will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Phillips Exeter Academy, 20 Main St., Exeter, NH 03833. 1/3

GORDON--Kenny. On your 43rd Birthday. Not a day goes by for us without memories bringing smiles to our faces or tears to our eyes. You are missed every minute of every day. Our aching hearts are always filled with love for you. Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine, Kenya & Chloe. 1/3

HANDMAN--Richard A. died unexpectedly on June 22 surrounded by his loving family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Thursday July 2nd at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West, beginning at 6:30pm. 1/3

VOGEL--Margie, on June 22, 2015. Our Margie was a remarkable, loving, generous, sensitive, supportive and very special woman who was taken from us too soon. Through all of her adversities and afflictions, Margie always focused on her family and closest friends. Margie lived her life to the fullest and was happiest being with all of us. Beloved and adoring wife of Jeff, proud and cherished Mom to Jared and Dara. cherished daughter to Jeanette and Sherman. Loving sister to Isabel, Freddy, Laurie, Stephen, Diane and Jon. Margie, you will always be remembered. May you now rest in peace. We love you. The Vogels and The Schornsteins 1/3

THANHAUSER--Charles. The scope and breadth of his wit was only exceeded by his voracious desire for knowledge. My heartfelt condolences go out to Bart, Will and Graham. You will be sorely missed. Saturday's will never be the same. Your best bud Bunky 1/3

MAY--Isabel Meyer, at the celebrated age of 103. Beloved mother of Linda and Steve Sklar, and Leni and Peter May. Grandmother to Marci (Stu) Bodner, Caryn, Kenneth (Vivian) Sklar, Jon (Juliana) May, Leslie (Andrew) Blauner and great-grandmother of 10. A woman before her time. A pioneer of women's liberation, graduate of Hunter College, M.S. in Social Work from NYU, career woman and dedicated philanthropist. Founder of the Five Towns Welfare League, first woman president of Temple Israel of Lawrence, NY. Active in ADL, Mt. Sinai of Miami Beach, and the Miami Home for the Aged at Douglas Gardens, and many others. She left a large footprint and will be missed by many. Services private. Shiva Monday, June 29, 2-4pm at 146 Lefferts Road, Woodmere, NY and the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St, New York, NY, 5:30-8:00pm 1/3

THANHAUSER--Charles. In memory of Charles Thanhauser, trustee of Housing and Services, Inc. Witty, provocative and insightful, Charles was a driving force in Housing and Services, Inc.'s rebirth. We will strive together to meet the high expectations he set for us. Our deepest condolences to Charles's family. The Board and Staff of Housing and Services, Inc. David Lehmann, Chair James Dill, Executive Director 1/3

HAYES--Jeffrey. Jeffrey Michael Hayes died June 9th, 2015 following a near drowning after a fall at his home near Austin, TX on June 1st. Jeff was born in Los Angeles, CA on August 12, 1965. His mother is Phyllis (Philomena) Zillo Rowlands of Lakeway, TX and his father the late Donald Robert Hayes of East Rockaway, NY. His husband of the past 24 years is Greg Sovey of Lakeway, TX. A Celebration of his life will be held on August 8th at The Hills of Lakeway Country Club, The Hills, TX at 5pm. Contact gregsovey@gmail.com for details. In lieu of flowers, donations to: beardedcollieclub.us/rescue and www.austinpetsalive.org in Jeff's name would be accepted with gratitude. A full obituary is online at: www.wcfish.com 1/3

SMITH--Lillian Reasenberg, passed away at home peacefully on June 25 at the age of 96. Born in Brooklyn, the daughter of Oscar and Frieda Reasenberg, sister of Annette Fisher and Sidney, she was a New York City teacher for over 30 years. Her devoted 70 year marriage to Saul (Smith) produced four children, Judy Gruen, Janet Smith, Karen Smith, and Alan Smith, four grandchildren, Dr. Alison Gruen, Derek Gruen, Daniel Smith, and Kalynn Smith, and two great-grandchildren, Tess and Paige Evans. She was a proud graduate of Hunter College, class of 1940, later earning her M.S. degree. She was dignified, outspoken, strong, and smart. She taught her daughters to be modern women. She will be lovingly missed and forever in our hearts. 1/3

POWELL--Ronnie Ann. With great sadness Bressler, Amery & Ross announces the loss of our partner and friend, Ronnie Ann Powell, who died on June 18, 2015. Ronnie was loved by many and respected by all. She chaired Bressler's Trusts and Estates practice group and served on the firm's Executive Committee. Ronnie was recognized as one of New Jersey's top trusts and estates attorneys. She had more than three decades of experience in all aspects of a trusts and estates law practice, including estate planning, administration and litigation. She was dedicated to working closely and personally with each of her clients, showing care and compassion for helping others. Ronnie cherished her role as a partner, educator and mentor and believed wholeheartedly in serving the communities in which she lived and worked. A long-time resident of Montclair, NJ, she served as a Commissioner of the Township of Montclair Parking Authority and as a Board Member of the Montclair Center Business Improvement Center. Ronnie was recognized for her pro bono work with low-income and abused women in need of legal advice, having received the "Partners in Hope Award" by Partners for Women and Justice, a not-for-profit organization based in Montclair. We extend our deepest sympathies to her entire family with heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband, Matt Powell, and her children, Alexander Louis and Eliza Rose. She will be sorely missed by all of her colleagues at Bressler. 1/3

BENTON--Philip E. Jr. Philip E. Benton Jr.,86, of Orleans MA., passed away peacefully at home on Sunday June 14th, 2015. He was born on New Years Eve 1928 in Charlottesville, VA. He was the first of five children born to Philip E Benton MD. and Orient (Nichols) Benton. Philip went to primary school in Wilton CT. and high school in Westport and Bridgeport, CT. When he was thirteen, during WWII, his mother sent him to boarding school at Tabor Academy, an all 'boys' prep school in Marion, MA. He had not been doing well at Bridgeport High school and tended to get into "trouble as boys do" so his mother saw to it that he went to boarding school. To this day it is clear that Philip appreciates his mother's foresight in sending him to Tabor Academy. With no money left in the family to pay for his college expenses, determined as he was to succeed, Philip joined the Marine Corps which paid for four years of his college tuition. He achieved the rank of corporal and was honorably discharged. He then entered Dartmouth College where he married Bernice Brennan and had his two oldest daughters. They had two more children together. Bernice died in 1975. Philip later married Mary Ann Ward and he adopted her two daughters. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa Magna Cum Laude. He went on to earn a Masters Degree from The Amos Tuck School of Business. Additionally, he was awarded an honorary doctorate by Northwood University in Midland, MI. In 1953 he was hired by the Ford Motor Company as a cost analyst. From there he steadily rose through the ranks until he became the President and COO. He eventually retired in 1992 after nearly 40 years with the company. Philip's love of the water in general and his love of Cape Cod were never far from his heart. While enjoying retirement he could usually be found on or near the water. And you would usually find him with his two closest cousins Pat Patterson and Nick Nichols. Philip was a kind and generous man who touched many lives and is loved by many. He has become associated with the Cape Cod Healthcare Foundation which made great strides in promoting the excellence of Cape Cod Hospital. Additionally, he was involved with the Orleans Conservation Trust which purchases land to be preserved ad infinitum. Philip was preceded in death by his parents, mother Orient (Nichols) Benton and his father Philip E. Benton MD. His sister Carroll Cameron and his brothers Christopher West Benton and Thomas Hart Benton. Philip is survived by His best friend and soul mate, his wife, Mary Ann (Ward) Benton, his sister Ann Benton and his six children: Katharine Harris (David), Deborah Benton, Deborah Ward (Ben Marett), Cynthia Benton, Philip E. Benton III, Paula Benton, as well as 14 grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. A memorial and grave site interment is planned for a future date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Hope Hospice, 508-957-0200. Any condolences or words of love and support for the family at this time can be left at: www.nickersonfunerals.com 1/3

THANHAUSER--Charles. 63, died at home, with his family, on June 22, 2015. The son of Joseph Thanhauser, Jr. and Marion Wolfson, Charles grew up in Philadelphia. Charles earned a B.Arch (1974) from the University of Pennsylvania and an M.Arch. (1977) from Harvard University. Charles moved to New York City where he founded TEK Architects in 1987. Specializing in non-profit and educational projects, TEK Architects won various awards and was featured in the Museum of Modern Art. A voracious reader with a sharp wit, and a deeply loving father and friend, he will be greatly missed. He is survived by his three sons: Bart, Will, and Graham. A memorial service will be held for Charles later this summer. 1/3

KLEIN--Leslie E.,died peacefully in the early morning of June 24th, three months after his 91st birthday. He was born and grew up in the Bronx. After attending DeWitt Clinton High School he answered his country's call and served in the Army during World War II, driving a tank in France. Finishing his education at City College, Les had a successful career in business but found time to serve local civic affairs. After retiring he divided his time among New York City, Long Boat Key, Florida, and Madison, Connecticut. He loved a great mystery novel, a political debate, and to share the hole-by-hole details of his golf game. Far above all he was devoted to his wife Eleanore, his daughters Nancy and Carol and their husbands David and Bill, and his grandchildren Gillian, Hannah, Jack and Kate. In all things his first care was his family. They will ever remember him as he was, that he lived a full and active life and gave them all that a husband and father could provide. 1/3
ZLOTOWITZ--Bernard. Mary McDowell Friends School conveys sincere condolences to the family of Rabbi Bernard M. Zlotowitz, father of Debbie Zlotowitz, Head of School. 1/3

KELMAN--Laura Kathleen, 82, died at home in New York City on June 22nd. She is survived by her beloved children, Wendy Neu, Zoe (Steve) Shinn, Sally (Steve) Osman, Bob (Linda) Kelman, Jackie (Sam) Bisbee, and Peter Kelman. Born in Manchester, England, on May 19th, 1933, Laura grew up during the war, the youngest of eight children. Often she found comfort and security at the local animal shelter where she would share her meager food rations with the homeless dogs. Once married and with the support of her children, she went on to provide that same comfort and security to hundreds of rescued animals. Laura lived a life full of compassion and empathy for the suffering. She will be remembered as a devoted wife who unselfishly cared for her husband of 52- years, the late Captain Peter Kelman, as he battled with Lou Gehrig's disease (died 2005); as a loving and infinitely patient mother who raised six educated children who always pushed the boundaries; as a kind, gentle and loving grandmother to Laura, Eric, Lucie, Zach, Grace and Peter and step-grandmother to Jordan and Kristen. Most importantly she taught her children and grandchildren to confront society's moral and ethical challenges and believe that they can make a difference. She was the inspiration behind the family's foundation "Companion Animal Placement" that rescues animals and supports NY Class and PETA to protect the carriage horses in Central Park, NRDC to protect the environment, and Matheny Children's Hospital. The family is very grateful to the friends who helped out during her lifetime: Melissa, Trineley, Dawa, and especially her beloved Yangchen. The family requests memorial donations to be given to Companion Animal Placement, c/o C.O.S., 120 Fifth Avenue, Suite 600, New York, NY 10011. 1/3

LERNER--Blanche, died peacefully on June 26, 2015 at the age of 97-1/2. She is survived by her loving daughter Sharon (Jeffrey Prager), son Gilbert (Phyllis), granddaughter Dani Mattisinko (Rob) and great-granddaughters Rachel and Perri. Blanche was a loving wife to her departed husband Harry and a devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother whose intelligence and witty sense of humor were maintained throughout her long life. Her greatest pleasures were reading and solving her beloved crossword puzzles, which she continued to do well into her 90s. Shiva will be Monday June 29 and Tuesday June 30 from 6:00 to 8:00pm at the home of her daughter. 1/3

HOROWITZ--Norman, 82, former President/CEO of MGM/UA Telecommunications and one of the most respected, revered, loved and talented executives in Hollywood, passed away of a heart attack at his home in Beverly Hills on Tuesday, June 16, 2015. He was an innovator, a true storyteller and will be remembered for his incredible loyalty and integrity, both in his personal and professional life. He is survived by his son, Steve, daughter-in-law Katie Danziger and their children Jake, Jilly and Josie; his daughter, Eileen Horowitz Bastianelli, and her daughters, Lola and Maya. A memorial is being planned for this summer. Donations can be sent to the March of Dimes, New York City Chapter in his honor. 1/3
WOLF --Marvin. October 28, 1921-June 27, 2014 As long as life and memory last, you will be loved and cherished. Your family, with love 1/3
SCHINDLER--Mark E. June 24, 1965 - August 14, 2013 Remembering you today. Sadly missed...always in our hearts, your loving family

GALLAGHER--Austin (Jack) John. Beloved husband and father died peacefully at home June 26, 2015. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Mark Hal, passed away peacefully on the morning of June 25th at the age of 70. Although Mark lived many complex years, we are extremely proud of his accomplishments in later life. His ability to express love and his sense of humor will be missed by all, especially his long time friend and mentor Ray Peretin who was responsible for changing his life, and the extraordinary Peretin family. Rest in peace Dear Mark. The Goldstein Family. 1/3

MAY--Isabel Meyer, at the celebrated age of 103. Beloved mother of Linda and Steve Sklar, and Leni and Peter May. Grandmother to Marci (Stu) Bodner, Caryn, Kenneth (Vivian) Sklar, Jon (Juliana) May, Leslie (Andrew) Blauner and great-grandmother of 10. A woman before her time. A pioneer of women's liberation, graduate of Hunter College, M.S. in Social Work from NYU, career woman and dedicated philanthropist. Founder of the Five Towns Welfare League, first woman president of Temple Israel of Lawrence, NY. Active in ADL, Mt. Sinai of Miami Beach, and the Miami Home for the Aged at Douglas Gardens, and many others. She left a large footprint and will be missed by many. Services private. Shiva Monday, June 29, 2-4pm at 146 Lefferts Road, Woodmere, NY and the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St, New York, NY, 5:30-8:00pm 1/3

SIMON--Suzanne Cohn. June 9, 1940 - June 25, 2015. I have lost my darling Suzy, the light of my life. We had 33 glorious years together. Now they have ended. Her sweetness is gone. Her light has dimmed but it is not gone. That light rests in my heart. The joys we shared, the two loving families we shared -- they are here with her light in their hearts. Oh my darling, you are gone, but as I promised, as you assured me, you are with me forever! David Simon, your husband and your eternal lover 1/3

COLYER--Austin T. Of New York, NY, passed away on June 25, 2015. Austin was born on October 29, 1930, in Brooklyn, NY. His long and storied career spanned eight Broadway shows, including "Singin' In the Rain," "I Remember Mama," "Pal Joey," "Desert Song," and "Maggie Flynn." Austin also appeared in countless regional and national productions, including joining the national touring company of "Ragtime" for more than three years. Beyond his illustrious work on the stage, Austin's wit, charm, and encyclopedic knowledge of all things theatrical never failed to make a deep and lasting impression on all who knew him. As recently profiled in The New York Times, Austin was a resident of The Whitby on West 45th Street for more than 50 years, and was a pillar of his community and mentored many young actors. A man of many talents, Austin also served in the United States Army Air Corps. Austin was a fixture in the lives of his family and many friends, and while we truly thought he would be here with us always, he has left each who knew him with the deepest and most joyous memories. A wake will be held on Tuesday, June 30, 2015, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Crestwood Funeral Home at 445 West 43rd Street, between 8th and 9th Avenues. A Funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday morning, July 1, 2015, at 10:30am at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church (the Actor's Church) at 239 West 49th Street, between 8th Avenue and Broadway. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Actors Fund in Austin's memory. 1/3

MAY--Isabel. With great sadness, the Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Isabel May, a generous philanthropist and volunteer, and beloved mother of Peter W. May, Chairman of the Mount Sinai Health System Boards of Trustees. We express our condolences to her family and friends, who will dearly remember her and her longstanding volunteerism at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach, Florida. To Peter and to his wife, Leni, their children and all who mourn the loss of this extraordinary, generous woman, we extend our deepest sympathy. Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

d'URSO--Senator Mario, died peacefully in Rome on June 5th 2015. He was born in Naples on April 8th 1940 to Sandro d'Urso and Dame Clotilde Serra di Cassano, a direct descendant of George Clymer, a signer of both the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution. Mario came to America to study law at George Washington University and, in 1968, started his career as a banker at Kuhn Loeb, later Lehman Brothers. In 1994, back in Rome, he was appointed Under Secretary of Commerce and, in 1996, he was elected to the Senate of the Republic of Italy. He was unique in combining his civic and corporate responsibilities with mingling in the international jet set. He was generous and compassionate, well-known and well-loved: he will be sorely missed. 1/3
BOROWIK--Thomas Gabriel. On this day of your birth we remember and wish you were here. 1/3

GOLD--Leonard, of New York City, NY, on June 27, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Phyllis. Loving father of Jane and Louis Azie, Leslie and Jeffrey Brook, Steven and Alisa. Cherished Grandfather of Brooke and Jashar, Michael, Sam and Diana, Evan, Lindsey and Scott, Perry, Corey, Drew, and Tracy. Adored Great Grandfather of Irie, Bodhi, and Willa. Retired Captain of the US Army Air Corps. Contributions to the Alzheimer's association made in Leonard's name is appreciated. 1/3

SIMON- Suzanne Cohn. Suzy Simon died on June 25th of pancreatic cancer at age 75. As she wished, she passed in her own bed, surrounded by all her loved ones. Her husband of 33 years, David Simon, was by her side throughout the ordeal of pancreatic cancer for 11 months. It was in large part thanks to David's devotion that Suzy was able to fight her disease for as long as she did. At her bedside always were her children, Deb and David Wasser and Deb's wife, Dr Susan Vaughan, whom she loved as her own child. Susan's medical knowledge was hugely helpful throughout. Also ever present were Suzy's doting nieces, Keira and Deirdre Chassman, Deirdre's children Max and Jack Chassman-Silberman, and her grandchildren Savannah and Whittier Vaughan-Wasser. Suzy was the best grandma ever and will be buried with the necklace given her this year: "Just knowing you're my grandma makes me smile." Suzy will be missed by David's sons Michael and Andrew Simon and their families, Michael's wife Alison and their children Lauren, Nathan and Chloe and Andrew's wife Katherina and their children, Jake and Ella, as well as David's sister and her husband, Mimi Forman and John Koller, and Milton Bloch, husband of David's late sister Judy. Suzy was born and spent her whole life in New York, enjoyed New York's culture, most notably serving on the Board of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. She's a graduate of NYU and was a therapist for 40 years. Most recently, Suzy generously supported pancreatic cancer research and asked that any donations be made to The Suzanne Cohn Simon Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund by a check to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (with a notation referencing her Fund), Attn: Amanda Gilstein, 633 3d Ave. 28th Floor, New York, NY10017. Her funeral: Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave on Monday June 29th at 11am. 1/3

POWELL--Ronnie Ann. With great sadness Bressler, Amery & Ross announces the loss of our partner and friend, Ronnie Ann Powell, who died on June 18, 2015. Ronnie was loved by many and respected by all. She chaired Bressler's Trusts and Estates practice group and served on the firm's Executive Committee. Ronnie was recognized as one of New Jersey's top trusts and estates attorneys. She had more than three decades of experience in all aspects of a trusts and estates law practice, including estate planning, administration and litigation. She was dedicated to working closely and personally with each of her clients, showing care and compassion for helping others. Ronnie cherished her role as a partner, educator and mentor and believed wholeheartedly in serving the communities in which she lived and worked. A long-time resident of Montclair, NJ, she served as a Commissioner of the Township of Montclair Parking Authority and as a Board Member of the Montclair Center Business Improvement Center. Ronnie was recognized for her pro bono work with low-income and abused women in need of legal advice, having received the "Partners in Hope Award" by Partners for Women and Justice, a not-for-profit organization based in Montclair. We extend our deepest sympathies to her entire family with heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband, Matt Powell, and her children, Alexander Louis and Eliza Rose. She will be sorely missed by all of her colleagues at Bressler. 1/3

THEA--Andi. Andi literally brought the colors of the rainbow into our lives. Her passion for life was matched only by her love for our Alex. Andi's generosity of spirit and her astonishing courage in the face of a cruel fate were equally inspiring. Our family was blessed by Andi's friendship, compassion and kindness. It is with the greatest sense of loss that we note her passing. Andi's memory will serve as a blessing Charline Spektor, Mira J. Spektor Lily Nussbaum, Kiyoshi Matsuyama Elizabeth Wood, Gabriel Nussbaum 1/3

MUSHINSKY--Bernard. The congregation of Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime cherished member. AZENBERG--Elinor Shanbaum, passed away June 15. Mother of Karen Mericola (Augie) and Lisa Hayes (Christopher), grandmother of Christopher, Alexander, Cooper and Emelia. Born in Southbridge, MA April 9, 1936, graduate Mt. Holyoke College 1957 and NYU 1981. Director Reentry Programs at NYU SCPS. Traveler, theatre-lover, mentor, and friend she will live on in our hearts. Donations in her memory may be made to Frances Perkins Tuition Scholarship at Mt. Holyoke or to Etta Kallman Memorial Scholarship at NYU. 1/3

SUTLIFF--Ralph Calvin, 85, died June 12 at his home. He is survived by his beloved wife, Cynthia, by four children, Pete, Jane, Tai and Huong, by two brothers, and by numerous other family members. He was predeceased by his son, Jim. Cal, as he was known, was also a cherished grandfather, uncle, cousin, mentor and friend to many. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Worldwide Orphans Foundation (wwo.org). A memorial service will be held on July 25 at 11:00 a.m. at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn. 1/3

SIMON--Suzanne. The board, artists and staff of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center mourn deeply the passing of our beloved board member Suzanne Simon. A key member of our leadership, she continued to attend every possible board and committee meeting throughout the year that she battled with cancer, lending her elegance, keen mind, and warm heart to every deliberation. Together, Suzy and her husband David were sophisticated, devoted audience members supporting the work they loved with their presence. Suzy embodied music, was full of joy and laughter, and had a core understanding of what matters. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will be forever infused with the light of her gracious, generous, indomitable spirit. She was one of a kind. Jim O'Shaugnessy, Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors Suzanne Davidson, Executive Director 1/3

WATTENBERG--Ben J.,of Washington, DC, died peacefully on Sunday, June 28, 2015 at Sibley Hospital. He was 81 years old. He was the loving father of Ruth Wattenberg (David Kusnet), Daniel Wattenberg (Cindy Balmuth), Sarah Wattenberg and Rachel Wattenberg. He was the cherished brother of Rebecca Schull. Ben was the adored "Pea Pop/Poppy" of Emma Schmidt, Michael Kusnet, Lylah Kusnet and Maisie Wattenberg. He was the former husband of Diane Abelman Wattenberg and the late Marna Hade Wattenberg. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, July 1, 2015, 10:30AM at Temple Micah, 2829 Wisconsin Ave., NW, Washington, DC. Interment will follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Adelphi, MD. Shiva will be observed at the home of Ruth Wattenberg and David Kusnet on Wednesday, Thursday and Sunday from 7-9pm. The family has requested that gifts be made to Enabling the Future: A Global Network of Passionate Volunteers Using 3D Printing to Give The World a "Helping Hand" at: www.enablecommunity foun dation.org/donate/ or Hobart and William Smith Colleges for scholarship support in memory of Ben J. Wattenberg. Checks should be payable to "Hobart and William Smith." Address: 300 Pulteney Street, Geneva, NY 14456. Please indicate "in memory of Ben Wattenberg" in the memo line. Gifts in memory of Ben may also be made to the Colleges online: www.hws.edy/onlinegiving. Services entrusted to Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, 1-800-500-5401. 1/3

MAY--Isabel Meyer. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Isabel May, beloved mother of our longstanding leader and friend, Peter May, Chairman of the Board of Trustees at our beneficiary agency, Mount Sinai Hospital. Peter and his wife Leni, share in Isabel's tradition of tzedakah and tikkun olam. Her legacy of leadership and generosity to countless philanthropies and causes will continue through her beloved family. We extend our condolences to Peter and Leni; to her daughter, Linda, and her husband Steve; to her many grandchildren Marci (Stu) Bodner, Caryn, Kenneth (Vivian) Sklar, Jon (Juliana) May, Leslie (Andrew) Blauner; and to her ten great- grandchildren. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

KAPLAN--Marcia S.,died on June 29 at the age of 86 after a 2 1/2 year struggle with leukemia. Daughter of Rose and Max Schwartz; wife of Bertram Kaplan; mother of Carol Linde, Marilyn Grody, Robin Blum and Sam Kaplan; grandmother of Jessica, Andrea, Brandon, Lisa, Brian and Eric. Sister of Jay and Robert Schwartz, and partner of Willard Schwartz. Born June 3, 1929, in Scranton, PA, she was a 1951 graduate of Syracuse University and became the first woman actuary employed by the Guardian Life Insurance Company. A resident of New Rochelle, NY, and later Roslyn, NY, and Manhattan, she was a longtime member of Glen Oaks Club in Old Westbury, NY. Funeral Services are scheduled for Wednesday July 1st at 11:15am, At "The Riverside" 180 W. 76th St. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name can be made to the Muscular Dystrophy Association www.mda.org. 1/3

UDELL--Natalie. Mrs. Udell died on the evening of June 28, 2015 in Charlotte, NC at age 93. She lived for many years in Great Neck, NY. Mrs. Udell was the beloved wife of the late Bernard "Buddy" Udell; devoted mother of her daughters, the late Iris Stessel, Janice Fisher and Laurie Udell and their husbands, Paul, Lewis and Terry Mond; and loving grandmother to Jay, Daniel and wife Erin, Sarah, Emily and husband Chas, and Allison. A service will be at 1pm, Wednesday, July 1st from the graveside in Mt. Eden Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. Condolences may be offered at: www.HarryandBryant FuneralHome.com. 1/3

SLOANE--David A. The Partners, Attorneys and staff of Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman, LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend and Partner, David. A. Sloane. He was one of the preeminent Real Estate attorneys on Long Island in a career that began in 1963 following earning his JD degree from NYU. David represented many major developers and national home builders and retailers in the areas of commercial real estate, zoning and land use. His firm, Mars, Sloane & Conlon, merged with Certilman Balin 14 years ago, creating an office in Hauppauge which he managed. One of David's more noteworthy accomplishments was his representation of TRITEC Development Group's "The New Village at Patchogue". In appreciation of his work as lead attorney, TRITEC named a street after him, 'Sloane Street'. He was a true gentleman whose clients and colleagues became his friends and admirers. David will be missed by all who came to know him and relied on his legal wisdom and personal relationships. David Sloane was an irreplaceable member of our Firm and an architect of the residential and commercial development of Long Island. Our deep and sincere sympathies go to his wife, Emily, his children and grandchildren. 1/3

MAY--Isabel Meyer, at the celebrated age of 103. Beloved mother of Linda and Steve Sklar, and Leni and Peter May. Grandmother to Marci (Stu) Bodner, Caryn, Kenneth (Vivian) Sklar, Jon (Juliana) May, Leslie (Andrew) Blauner and great-grandmother of 10. A woman before her time. A pioneer of women's liberation, graduate of Hunter College, M.S. in Social Work from NYU, career woman and dedicated philanthropist. Founder of the Five Towns Welfare League, first woman president of Temple Israel of Lawrence, NY. Active in ADL, Mt. Sinai of Miami Beach, and the Miami Home for the Aged at Douglas Gardens, and many others. She left a large footprint and will be missed by many. Services private. Shiva Monday, June 29, 2-4pm at 146 Lefferts Road, Woodmere, NY and the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St, New York, NY, 5:30-8:00pm 1/3

KLEBAN--Carol E.,age 72, passed away suddenly on June 27, 2015. Survived by children Daniel and Matthew, daughters-in-law Janet and Rosa, and grandchildren David, Abigail, Lillian, Esme and Aaron. A graduate of Alfred University, she spent 36 years at Professional Children's School as a teacher, principal and associate head of school, and following retirement, she continued as a part-time alumni liaison. She always said she loved going to work every day and felt fortunate to work with such exceptional staff and students. She was a naturally warm person with a genuine interest in getting to know all people. She was beloved by her lifelong friends and the new friends she continued to make each day. Everyone who knew her spoke of her generosity and her reflexive need to offer solace and support, which she did with an open heart, a warm smile and an understated sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may take the form of donations to Professional Children's School. Services will be held on Tuesday, June 30, 2015 at 11:00am at The Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY. 1/3

TARTER--Fred B.,on June 28, 2015. Beloved husband of Lois. Devoted father of Scott Andrew, Heather Michelle, Megan Elisabeth, Michelle Brooks and Philip Kholos. Father-in-law of Elizabeth, Robert Shortsleeve and Thomas Manco. Cherished grandfather of Natalie, Benjamin, Henry, Allison, Emily, Linus and Jack. Loving brother of Lynne Sterenson and brother-in-law of Robert Sterenson. Step brother of Steven Bartolotto and uncle of Brett and Erin Sterenson and friend to all. Services Thursday 10am at "The Riverside" 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

SCHAPS--Toby, died peacefully June 28 at age 98 after living a life of "doing it her way". FURLAUD--Maxime Jay. My darling Max, Sunday was your birthday: you'd have been 90 years old, if you had lived that long. What an enchanting 90-year-old you'd have been! I miss you every hour of every day. Today I'll put a lovely bouquet on your grave. But you are not in that grave, but in Heaven with your friends, the angels. All my love today and always, Your Ally. 1/3

THEA--Andi. Cherished life-partner of Alex Spektor, beloved sister of DV Hirsch, and Mitchel (Michele) Hirsch, kind aunt to Madeline, Jason, Jeffrey. Andi was also the best Doggie-Mommy of Knowme. Andi passed from this life on Sunday, June 28th. Her profound kindness and joy of life were reflected in her every deed. Words cannot do justice to the radiance of Andi's presence. She lived a life of creativity and fulfillment finding the true secret of happiness in the company of those she loved. She took the time to listen, understand and love. Our lives will be forever enriched for having been in her embrace. Service at The Riverside Memorial Chapel Tuesday, June 30th 9:30am. 1/3

ARBESFELD--Shirley. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Shirley Arbesfeld, PhD, CPA, z"l, a widely admired professor of economics in the Business Graduate School of Rutgers University who also was a CPA and served as a consultant to accounting organizations. She was a highly esteemed longtime member of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York City. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Rabbi Hyman (and Ann) Arbesfeld, her beloved brother, Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) who together with his wife Ann is an active Yeshiva University Benefactor. May the entire Arbesfeld family find comfort among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University/RIETS Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

OBERMAN--Richard "Dick", beloved Husband, Dad, Papa and Uncle, passed away on June 29, 2015. A graduate of both Wagner College and St. John's School of Law, Dick practiced at his own firm, Levidow, Levidow and Oberman, for forty-four years. Dick was a lifelong New Yorker, a voracious reader, and a lover of food and wine. He will be sorely missed, but dearly remembered. The Funeral will be held on Thursday, July 2nd at 12:00pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3
COLYER--Austin. The Council of Actors' Equity Association mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Austin Colyer, a true gentleman of the theater. 1/3

FEINBERG--Lois, 87, formerly of Glen Cove, NY, died on June 27th. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Norman for 46 years. Loving mother of Barney (Tracey), Rob (Ruth), Ellen (Ken Nadel). Grammy to Aaron, Joelle, Phoebe, Sydney, Eric, Lauren and David. Graduate of Oberlin Conservatory, 1949. A classically trained accomplished concert pianist, Lois' greatest passions were family, friends, tennis, music and the arts. Memorial service 11:30 am, Tuesday, June 30th, Temple Sharey Tefilo Israel, 432 Scotland Road, South Orange, NJ. 1/3

COLE--Michael I.,73, died peacefully after a long illness on June 25th surrounded by family members. He was born in Chicago, IL. He is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, Mieke Knoppers Cole, and their children Matthew Cole of Brooklyn, Treska Cole (with Jeff Ferraro) of Waltham, MA, and Daniel Cole (with Marisa Rolish) of Manhattan all well loved and of whom he was deeply proud, his sister Barbara Green of Arizona, sisters-in-law Anneke Knoppers Woodard (with R Craig Woodward), Els Knoppers (with Michael McCormack) and brother-in-law Bas Knoppers (with Alex Faber). Also many nephews and nieces. He was endlessly inquisitive. He loved taking long walks in the city and exploring museums--always with his camera. He enjoyed music, and he was deeply knowledgeable about science, computers, and loved to delve into how everything worked. And he loved to talk, to listen, and to have good, long conversations. A memorial service celebrating his life is planned for late summer. Any donations to honor his memory can be sent to the "Kidney Cancer Research in memory of Michael Cole." at Memorial Sloan Kettering. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Marvin L.,passed away on June 27, 2015 in Weston, MA. Marvin was a resident of Larchmont, NY for over 40 years. He was a loving husband to Gloria, father to Robert M. Schwartz, the late Janet E. Hill, John J. Schwartz and his wife Lynda H. Schwartz, and grandfather to Joshua D. Hill, Jack Schwartz and Laura Schwartz. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn College and NYU Law School, he proudly served in World War II in England, France and Italy as a technical sergeant with the 442nd Troop Carrier Command. After his army service, he practiced law in Manhattan for over 50 years with skill, care and compassion. Marvin was a long-time member of Larchmont Temple and trustee of Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club. He will be fondly remembered for his wit, appreciation of music and sailing. There will be a private interment in Newton, MA. 1/3

MOONEY--James D.,Jr. May 20, 1921-June 23, 2015. Son of the late James D. and Lenore Jane (Watson) Mooney, he was pre-deceased by his two sisters, Mrs. J.K. "Marti" McGrath of London and Mrs. F.S. "Pat" Anderson of Tucson, Arizona, by his three brothers, Michael, John, and Alan, and by his son, James D., III. He is survived by his beloved wife Gloria, his daughter, Mrs. R.A. "Barbara" Wilson, his son Richard A., four grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Oyster Bay, NY, on Thursday, July 2 at 11:00am. 1/3

HEIDT--Jane, age 72, died June 29th in New York City after a brief illness. Jane is survived by Marty Wenglinsky, her devoted husband of 48 years, son and daughter-in-law Harold and Maria Wenglinsky, daughter and son-in-law, Joan and David Platt and three grandchildren, Martin James, Emma and Ben. Jane attended Hunter College High School, Vassar College and then Columbia University, where as a graduate student in sociology, she met Marty. Jane was a working mother before it was fashionable to be one; she had a long and successful career as a developer and evaluator of social programs primarily for underserved populations, with long stints at The Fund for the City of New York and Expeditionary Learning Outward Bound. Jane was a fiercely intelligent woman who lived her life as she wanted: immersed in her work, her family, and her very close friends. 1/3

PILCH--Todd David 7/61 - 1/15/99 Happy Birthday in Heaven. I will never stop thinking about you and wondering if you are okay - that's what big sisters are for. Missed you at the wedding. With all my love, Sue 1/3
BOOKSTAVER--Doug (7/60 -7/23/92) It's the laughter we will remember whenever we remember the way we were. Mumsie, Bobbi, and Julie 1/3
TARTER--Fred. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. 1/3

KOFFMAN--Morley. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Morley Koffman, beloved father of Lori Koffman and father-in-law of Kenneth Ziebelman. We extend our condolences to Morley's wife, Myrna; his children, Lori and Kenneth, Ted (Debby), and Robert (Tara); his grandchildren, Rachel, Alexis, Jamie, Nikki, Lindsey, Anna, Sarah and Ariel; and his entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

TARGOFF--Tillie, of NYC died peacefully in her sleep during her 100th year on June 29. The loved and adored mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and mother-in-law was self-sufficient through the 11th hour of her very full life. Private services are being held today. 1/3

SUTLIFF--Ralph Calvin, 85, died June 12 at his home. He is survived by his beloved wife, Cynthia, by four children, Pete, Jane, Tai and Huong, by two brothers, and by numerous other family members. He was predeceased by his son, Jim. Cal, as he was known, was also a cherished grandfather, uncle, cousin, mentor and friend to many. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Worldwide Orphans Foundation (wwo.org). A memorial service will be held on July 25 at 11:00 a.m. at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn. 1/3

ROSS--Bessie Tolchin. August 27, 1926, died June 28, 2015. Beloved wife of Stanley and mom of Alan Michele and Caryn. Services 1:00pm, Thursday, July 2, 2015. Star of David Chapel, West Babylon, NY. 1/3

SCHAPS--Toby, died peacefully June 28 at age 98 after living a life of "doing it her way". She leaves two children Richard Schaps and Jane Rascoff, Linda (Badish) Schaps and Joseph Rascoff, five grandchildren Spencer Rascoff, Dr. Nanci Rascoff, Hillary Thomas, Brett Thomas, Jordan Schaps, Dr. Jil Schaps, Brooke Rascoff and Jake Rascoff and seven great-grandchildren. Funeral and Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society or the Doe Fund of New York. 1/3

TARTER--Fred B.,on June 28, 2015. Beloved husband of Lois. Devoted father of Scott Andrew, Heather Michelle, Megan Elisabeth, Michelle Brooks and Philip Kholos. Father-in-law of Elizabeth, Robert Shortsleeve and Thomas Manco. Cherished grandfather of Natalie, Benjamin, Henry, Allison, Emily, Linus and Jack. Loving brother of Lynne Sterenson and brother-in-law of Robert Sterenson. Step brother of Steven Bartolotto and uncle of Brett and Erin Sterenson and friend to all. Services Thursday 10am at "The Riverside" 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

MAY--Isabel Meyer. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn with heavy hearts the passing of Isabel Meyer May, beloved mother of our Board member Peter May. Our thoughts and prayers are with Peter and Leni, our dear friend and supporter, Jon and the entire May family. Our community has been deeply blessed by their generosity and dedication. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marc S. Lipschultz, President Stuart J. COLE--Michael I.,73, died peacefully after a long illness on June 25th surrounded by family members. He was born in Chicago, IL. He is survived by his beloved wife of 47 years, Mieke Knoppers Cole, and their children Matthew Cole of Brooklyn, Treska Cole (with Jeff Ferraro) of Waltham, MA, and Daniel Cole (with Marisa Rolish) of Manhattan all well loved and of whom he was deeply proud, his sister Barbara Green of Arizona, sisters-in-law Anneke Knoppers Woodard (with R Craig Woodward), Els Knoppers (with Michael McCormack) and brother-in-law Bas Knoppers (with Alex Faber). Also many nephews and nieces. He was endlessly inquisitive. He loved taking long walks in the city and exploring museums--always with his camera. He enjoyed music, and he was deeply knowledgeable about science, computers, and loved to delve into how everything worked. And he loved to talk, to listen, and to have good, long conversations. A memorial service celebrating his life is planned for late summer. Any donations to honor his memory can be sent to the "Kidney Cancer Research in memory of Michael Cole." at Memorial Sloan Kettering. 1/3

COHEN--Elias A. Although 63 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 97th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President 1/3
COHEN--Elias A. Ever present in our thoughts, we lovingly recall our E.A. Cohen who left us 63 years ago on July 2, 1952. The Cohen Family The Elias A. Cohen Foundation 1/3

COHEN--Dan R. Died suddenly at the age of 79 on Monday afternoon after a short illness. His life brought joy to all he came across including his wife Ann Gael, son Andrew Cohen-Gael, and daughter-in-law Danielle Egic. Dan was an activist committed to human rights and lived to see marriage equality in the US. He is a selfless soul who will live on in the hearts of all who knew him. A memorial will be held in the fall. 1/3

SUTLIFF--Ralph Calvin, 85, died June 12 at his home. He is survived by his beloved wife, Cynthia, by four children, Pete, Jane, Tai and Huong, by two brothers, and by numerous other family members. He was predeceased by his son, Jim. Cal, as he was known, was also a cherished grandfather, uncle, cousin, mentor and friend to many. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Worldwide Orphans Foundation (wwo.org). A memorial service will be held on July 25 at 11:00 a.m. at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn. 1/3

BLAKEMAN--Gloria, 89, died June 30. Adored wife of Dr. Arthur Blakeman, beloved mother of Wendy Brennan and Scott Blakeman, devoted grandmother of Heather, Michael, Cody and Jesse Borden. A respected educator who inspired her students and her family. Services 12 Noon today at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

LEFKOWITZ--Karol, of New York City (Formerly of Scarsdale, NY) on June 30, 2015. Loving wife of Burt, who died in 2011, beloved mother of Ken (Jackie), David (Julie), Bruce (Coco), sister of Irwin, sister-in-law of Rose, grandmother of Andrew, Rebecca, Trent, Kyle, Jenna, Coby, Brady and Kendall. A remarkable woman who loved life, travel, literature, the arts, and, most of all, her family. She was loved and will be missed by many. Funeral service Thursday, 12pm at Congregation Kol-Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. 1/3
POMERANTZ--Carol Stone. Loving wife to Alan, mother to Michael and Kiernan, and adoring grandmother to Quinn and Oona. Died peacefully in her sleep, June 30, 2015, in San Francisco. 1/3

ROSS--Bessie Tolchin. August 27, 1926, died June 28, 2015. Beloved wife of Stanley and mom of Alan Michele and Caryn. Services 1:00pm, Thursday, July 2, 2015. Star of David Chapel, West Babylon, NY. 1/3

MURRAY--Constance B. Connie, died peacefully at her home in New York City on June 30th. Devoted wife of the late Peter Murray. Loving mother to Peter, Billy, Christopher and Gerry. Adored grandmother of Austen, Guarin, Mair, Jessica, Emily, Minna, Arden, Eli, Megan, Dylan and Ryan. Loving big sister to Julie Sykes and Billy Berghold. Connie spent 30 years working for Freedom Institute, most recently as President and Executive Director, where she was dedicated to helping the chemically dependent and their families. She will be sadly missed by all her family and friends who loved her dearly. A Funeral Mass will be held on July 7th at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer at 869 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, New York, New York 10022. 1/3

STRASSMAN--Joseph, 84, died June 30th after a brief illness. Cherished and much-loved father, grandfather, uncle, and our family patriarch and most importantly, loving and devoted husband and best friend of 64 years to Barbara. A proud graduate of Yonkers High School and NYU. He was a trusted and valued tax and financial advisor to many businesses, family and friends. Our wonderful family is his true legacy. Goodbye Joe, we miss you dearly already. Donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY, Bozeman Deaconess Hospital or a charity of choice. Services Friday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

SEEMAN--Jay. The William Alanson White Institute notes sadly the death of Jay Seeman who was, for 15 years, a Trustee of the Institute, serving also as Board President before his retirement. His was a kind, generous and incisive intellect. He will be very much missed. We extend our condolences to his family. Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Christopher N. Young, President, Board of Trustees 1/3
CARTER--Jack. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Member. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. 1/3
MEPPEN--Samuel and Edith. Dear parents, grandparents, and great-grandparents. We cherish their memory. 1/3

SCHAPS--Toby, died peacefully June 28 at age 98 after living a life of "doing it her way". She leaves two children Richard Schaps and Jane Rascoff, Linda (Badish) Schaps and Joseph Rascoff, five grandchildren Spencer Rascoff, Dr. Nanci Rascoff, Hillary Thomas, Brett Thomas, Jordan Schaps, Dr. Jil Schaps, Brooke Rascoff and Jake Rascoff and seven great-grandchildren. Funeral and Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society or the Doe Fund of New York. 1/3

OBERMAN--Richard "Dick", beloved Husband, Dad, Papa and Uncle, passed away on June 29, 2015. A graduate of both Wagner College and St. John's School of Law, Dick practiced at his own firm, Levidow, Levidow and Oberman, for forty-four years. Dick was a lifelong New Yorker, a voracious reader, and a lover of food and wine. He will be sorely missed, but dearly remembered. The Funeral will be held on Thursday, July 2nd at 12:00pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

BARNETT--Mary Jane O'Rourke Wilkinson, was the daughter of Mabel Guerin and John Martin O'Rourke. Jane--as her friends knew her--was from a family of pioneers and builders that settled in White Plains from Ireland in 1853. She is predeceased by husband Peter Carter Wilkinson (army Veteran of the Korean war) and Anthony Barnett. Jane was born on May 22 in 1929 at the beginning of the Great Depression. In 1945 she ventured west to UCLA, eventually becoming an English teacher for the New York State Education system. As an educator, Jane dedicated her life to serving disabled children. As an individual, Jane's personal time was spent as enthusiastically as it was varied. She was a dedicated mother and wife, avid athletic and social supporter, worthy adversary in any card-game, accomplished linguist, passionate follower and commentator of political and world events and a razor-sharp wit. Perhaps most memorably, though, she was a loving family member and friend. She is survived by her family: Peter Hawley Wilkinson (Annette), Paul Christopher Wilkinson (Ellyn), Patricia Catherine Wilkinson, (Annie) deceased, Pamela Wilkinson Vita (Don) and her grandchildren Nicholas Hawley Vita, Jenna Alexandra Wilkinson, Adrienne Carter Vita, Carter James Wilkinson, Haleigh Acton Vita, Sean O'Rourke Wilkinson, James O'Connor Wilkinson and Claire Patrice Wilkinson. In honor of Jane's efforts in life as a volunteer fundraiser for the Special Olympics, the family kindly asks donations be made in Jane's name to the Special Olympic Charity fund in lieu of flowers. Viewing and rosary service will take place at Kane Funeral Home, Ridgefield, CT Thursday, July 2, 2015 from 5:30-7:30pm. Guests are invited after the rosary service to join in celebrating Jane's life at the Cellar Door Restaurant from 8pm-10pm in Ridgefield, CT. The burial will be held at White Plains Rural Cemetery at 12pm on Friday, July 3, 2015. Funeral mass celebration will be at St. Elizabeth Seton Catholic Church also of Ridgefield, CT. 1/3
