SCHAPS--Toby, died peacefully June 28 at age 98 after living a life of "doing it her way". She leaves two children Richard Schaps and Jane Rascoff, Linda (Badish) Schaps and Joseph Rascoff, five grandchildren Spencer Rascoff, Dr. Nanci Rascoff, Hillary Thomas, Brett Thomas, Jordan Schaps, Dr. Jil Schaps, Brooke Rascoff and Jake Rascoff and seven great-grandchildren. Funeral and Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society or the Doe Fund of New York. 1/3
WEILER--Gerald E. 5/8/28-7/3/05 So many cherished memories. Love and gratitude, Helen 1/3

POMERANTZ--Carol Stone. Carol was an extraordinary member of our family, enriching our daily lives and our holiday celebrations, easing our sadness and contributing her unique style and sense of humor to the entire family. Carol had an unusual love of life. She loved and was loved by Alan, her wonderful husband, by Michael and Kiernan, her devoted son and daughter-in-law and by Quinn and Oona, the grandchildren she adored and who adored her. We treasure the memories of the times we shared. Barbara, Valorie, Cara and Larry Iason, Rob Buford 1/3

HELMAN--Gilbert, born in NYC December 29, 1914, died on July 2nd, 2015 in Rye, NY. He was the adored and beloved husband of Joy (nee Ostriker) who lit up his life for over 68 years. Father of Denice H. Rein, Mark Helman and the late Gary Helman. Loving Grandfather of Nicki R. Shalette, Alex Rein, Sarah and Jim Helman. Great-grandfather of Mark and Lucas Shalette. A man of many interests and capabilities, he graduated from Penn in 1936, and Harvard Law in 1939. During WWII he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army, stationed in the Aleutian Islands. After the war he joined his family's commercial Real Estate business which he continued to grow. Moving his young family to Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., he served as mayor for many years. Gil was always dignified and well-respected as a man of fine judgement, intelligence, and character. He was philanthropic and a natural leader, serving on many Boards and committees. He and Joy are on the Rockefeller University Council. His varied interests ranged from world travel and the arts, to piloting his own boat the Joggle II and playing his beloved game of golf both at Inwood Country Club and later at Quaker Ridge. His wisdom, intelligence and sense of humor were enjoyed by everyone who knew him. He and Joy had a wonderful marriage, a true romance that lasted a lifetime. He was an inspiration to his family and will always be remembered with reverence, admiration and love. Funeral service Monday, July 6 at Riverside Chapel 80 West 76th St. at 12:45. The family will receive visitors Monday from 5 to 8:30 at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street. Contributions in his memory should be made to the Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave., NYC. 10065 attn: Marnie Imhoff. 1/3

FAUSER--Helen Langer, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully on June 30, 2015, at age 93 1/2. Her devoted and beloved children were by her side. She is predeceased by parents, Samuel and Celia, brother Stanley and the love of her life, Joseph (2006). They met at LIU, had an incredible marriage of 64 years and no man could have ever loved his wife more. Helen was a beautiful, elegant and selfless woman. She leaves behind her children, Robert and Arlene Fauser, Jill and Richard Israel, grandchildren Chad Fauser (Patti) and Scott Alessandro (Katherine Rosbottom Alessandro) and her cherished great-grand- daughters, Darian, Devan and Jordan Fauser. She was devoted most to her family but was giving and caring to all. We will miss her love and sparkle daily. A graveside service will be July 7, 2015, 11:00am, Pinelawn Memorial Cemetery. Shiva will be at 33 W. 67th. St., NYC on Tuesday, July 7 and Wednesday, July 8 starting at 4:00pm. 1/3

THORPE--Ronald. The Trustees and staff of the New York Hall of Science extend deepest sympathies to Margaret Honey, our President and CEO, at the passing of her husband, Ronald Thorpe. Ron's 40-year career was dedicated to supporting educators and innovating in the space of teacher professional development. As the creative force behind the Celebration of Teaching and Learning, and most recently as President and CEO of the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, Ron created and nurtured a nationwide network of educators committed to attaining the highest standards of practice with the ultimate goal of providing our country's school children with the quality education they deserve and require to be successful in life. He wrote extensively on education, technology and philanthropy, and he was admired and respected by leaders in policy and government, as well as by anyone who had the privilege of knowing him personally. He was kind, supportive and inspiring. He is gone from us far too soon, but his legacy lives on in the dedication and accomplishments evidenced by the thousands of educators who were guided and mentored through Ron's efforts. 1/3

GHOSSEIN--Dr. Nemetallah Amin, died peacefully at his home on Tuesday, June 30th 2015, with his beloved wife of fifty-seven years Mirene by his side. Dr. Ghossein was an individual committed to enhancing the lives of others. He was born June 25, 1931 in Cairo, Egypt to Virginie and Amin Ghossein; the youngest of five children. Dr. Ghossein completed his medical studies at the University of Cairo before settling in the USA in 1958. After a residency in Pittsburgh, PA. He moved to New York City. Dr Ghossein worked as a radiation oncologist at Albert Einstein where he served the better part of 20 years. He gained a reputation as a leader in his field, but, more importantly, he was known for being tremendously generous and caring to his patients. He ended his career as Chairman of Radiation Oncology at Beth Israel Medical Center before retiring in 2000. Dr. Ghossein was equally devoted to his patients as he was to his family. One of the things he enjoyed most was spending weekends at home, surrounded by his wife, children, and friends, sharing great food, vibrant conversation, and laughter. Through his personal and professional experiences, his passion for knowledge, Dr. Ghossein instilled in his children the meaning of selflessness, compassion, and a plural view of the world. Dr Ghossein is survived by his brothers Joseph and Antoine, his sister Odette, his wife Mirene, his children Amin, Cybele and Yara and his grandchildren Alexander, Christopher, Julian, Sadie, Layla, Maya and Naya. His oldest beloved daughter Dominique passed away in 2003. 1/3

STRASSMAN--Joseph, 84, died June 30th after a brief illness. Cherished and much-loved father, grandfather, uncle, and our family patriarch and most importantly, loving and devoted husband and best friend of 64 years to Barbara. A proud graduate of Yonkers High School and NYU. He was a trusted and valued tax and financial advisor to many businesses, family and friends. Our wonderful family is his true legacy. Goodbye Joe, we miss you dearly already. Donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY, Bozeman Deaconess Hospital or a charity of choice. Services Friday, 10am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

KAPLAN--Marcia. The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member Marcia Kaplan and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann, President 1/3

EHRLICH--Florence P. Devoted wife of Fred, mother (mother-in-law) of Richard (Julie) and Jacqueline (Byron), grandmother of Solomon, Margaux, Emily, Hannah, Sage and Bryce. Lived a vibrant life with great concern for family. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, Friday at 1:00pm. 1/3

LEFKOWITZ--Karol, of New York City (Formerly of Scarsdale, NY) on June 30, 2015. Loving wife of Burt, who died in 2011, beloved mother of Ken (Jackie), David (Julie), Bruce (Coco), sister of Irwin, sister-in-law of Rose, grandmother of Andrew, Rebecca, Trent, Kyle, Jenna, Coby, Brady and Kendall. A remarkable woman who loved life, travel, literature, the arts, and, most of all, her family. She was loved and will be missed by many. Funeral service Thursday, 12pm at Congregation Kol-Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

THORPE--Ronald. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of WNET, we are saddened at the passing of Ronald Thorpe, former Vice President of Education. Ron was a passionate advocate for educators and for WNET. His passing is a great loss to all of us who knew him and worked alongside him. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Margaret Honey and his daughter, Katherine Thorpe Kerr. James S. Tisch Chairman Neal Shapiro President and CEO 1/3

THORPE--Ronald. CSA's leadership, staff and members mourn the untimely death of Ronald Thorpe, a friend of the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators and an advocate for quality education for all children. 1/3

HELMAN--Gilbert. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Gilbert Helman. He was an esteemed, longtime member of The Rockefeller University Council and a passionate believer in the importance and value of biomedical research and supporting early career scientists. He and his cherished wife, Joy, became involved with the University in 2003, when they established the Gary R. Helman Endowed Postdoctoral Fellowship Fund in memory of their son. Gilbert and Joy were frequent visitors to campus and took a real interest in the talented young investigators they supported. We will miss Gilbert's avid curiosity about science and his immense personal warmth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joy, his daughter Denice Rein, his son Mark Helman, and his grandchildren. Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Mary Jeanne Kreek, M.D. Bruce S. McEwen, Ph.D. Marnie Imhoff, Senior Vice President 1/3

TUCHMAN--Kenneth (Moe), 87, on July 3, 2015 of New York. Beloved husband of Esther Schrier Tuchman, of Manhattan; cherished father of Paula Weiss (Mitchell) of Annandale, VA; Mark (Michelle) of Brooklyn; Julia of Manhattan; and Robert (Amy) of Manhattan. Loving brother of Irving (Beverly) and Max (Sandy). Adored grandfather of Anna Weiss, Sam, Lily, Ella, Mia and Zoe Tuchman. Son of the late Joseph and Annie Feiler Tuchman. Moe was president of Elect Trimming Co. for 43 years. His passion and talent for sports were well known in his native Bronx. He pitched minor league baseball for the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1948. He was a kind man who was deeply dedicated to his family and always interested in connecting with everyone he met. With deep thanks to his devoted caregivers Orlando James, Romerry Fraser and Jennifer Odia, and to the staff at Bellevue Haven. Service Sunday, July 5th, at 12:45pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice. 1/3

THORPE--Ronald. The Trustees and staff of the New York Hall of Science extend deepest sympathies to Margaret Honey, our President and CEO, at the passing of her husband, Ronald Thorpe. Ron's 40-year career was dedicated to supporting educators and innovating in the space of teacher professional development. As the creative force behind the Celebration of Teaching and Learning, and most recently as President and CEO of the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, Ron created and nurtured a nationwide network of educators committed to attaining the highest standards of practice with the ultimate goal of providing our country's school children with the quality education they deserve and require to be successful in life. He wrote extensively on education, technology and philanthropy, and he was admired and respected by leaders in policy and government, as well as by anyone who had the privilege of knowing him personally. He was kind, supportive and inspiring. He is gone from us far too soon, but his legacy lives on in the dedication and accomplishments evidenced by the thousands of educators who were guided and mentored through Ron's efforts. 1/3

GHOSSEIN--Dr. Nemetallah Amin, died peacefully at his home on Tuesday, June 30th 2015, with his beloved wife of fifty-seven years Mirene by his side. Dr. Ghossein was an individual committed to enhancing the lives of others. He was born June 25, 1931 in Cairo, Egypt to Virginie and Amin Ghossein; the youngest of five children. Dr. Ghossein completed his medical studies at the University of Cairo before settling in the USA in 1958. After a residency in Pittsburgh, PA. He moved to New York City. Dr Ghossein worked as a radiation oncologist at Albert Einstein where he served the better part of 20 years. He gained a reputation as a leader in his field, but, more importantly, he was known for being tremendously generous and caring to his patients. He ended his career as Chairman of Radiation Oncology at Beth Israel Medical Center before retiring in 2000. Dr. Ghossein was equally devoted to his patients as he was to his family. One of the things he enjoyed most was spending weekends at home, surrounded by his wife, children, and friends, sharing great food, vibrant conversation, and laughter. Through his personal and professional experiences, his passion for knowledge, Dr. Ghossein instilled in his children the meaning of selflessness, compassion, and a plural view of the world. Dr Ghossein is survived by his brothers Joseph and Antoine, his sister Odette, his wife Mirene, his children Amin, Cybele and Yara and his grandchildren Alexander, Christopher, Julian, Sadie, Layla, Maya and Naya. His oldest beloved daughter Dominique passed away in 2003. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Marcia Stebbins. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted longtime member and Sisterhood past President, Marcia Stebbins Goldsmith, beloved wife of the late Warren R. Goldsmith, loving mother of Susan Herman, Rachel Katz, and Ilene (David) Rapkin. To them and the entire family our sincere sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President 1/3

WISNIEWSKI--Maria Klonowicz, of Rego Park died peacefully in her sleep on June 26 at age 97. Her long life spanned two continents and several eras. Born in Kiev late in World War I, she grew up in newly independent Poland. She witnessed the occupation and destruction of Warsaw, life behind the iron curtain, and the new world after it fell. She took on challenges of life with courage and resilience. Her intellectual curiosity and love of learning supported her in difficult times and brought pleasure, always. Caring for others included steady support of charities for the blind of Poland. Maria adopted New York as her home late in life and proudly became an American citizen at age 90. Dedicated physician, caring friend, loving daughter, wife, and mother, she touched many lives and will be remembered by many. Maria now rests in peace at Our Lady of Czestochowa Cemetery in Doylestown, PA. 1/3

SARGENT--Malcolm Banks, died on Friday, June 26, at St. Luke's Hospital in New Bedford, Massachusetts, after an extended battle with Pulmonary Fibrosis. Born in St. Louis, Missouri, in 1942 to Margaret Etta Banks and Archer Downing Sargent, Malcolm lived most of his life in Westfield, New Jersey, New York City, and Assonet, Massachusetts. He attended Westfield (New Jersey) High School, Columbia College, and Columbia Business School. Following graduation from business school, Malcolm embarked on a career in finance, joining Chase Manhattan Bank in its Special Development Program and ultimately pursuing private business interests in a number of areas. He was an avid automobile and sports fan and a loyal and steadfast friend to many, including his fellow Phi Gamma Delta fraternity brothers. Malcolm leaves behind his wife of 50 years, Susan Deane Sargent, his brother Bruce Downing Sargent and wife Janet, his beloved nephew Matthew Downing Sargent, and a host of family and friends who will miss him dearly. 1/3

LINDH--Henry Colwell Beadleston, of Narragansett, Rhode Island, died peacefully in New York City on July 3, 2015. Son of the late Alice Lee Beadleston Lindh and Fritz Philip Lindh, Mr. Lindh was born in New York City on August 14, 1930 and attended The Buckley School, St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, and Yale College, receiving his undergraduate degree in economics in 1952. He also received an MBA from Columbia Business School. After service with the United States Army Audit Agency during the Korean War, Mr. Lindh joined Price Waterhouse, becoming a certified public accountant, followed by a distinguished 35 year career on Wall Street, where he was a partner at Faulkner Dawkins & Sullivan and senior vice president, treasurer and chief financial officer of investment firms Wood Gundy & Co. and Richardson Greenshields. For a short time, he was a member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was the breeder and owner of numerous successful thoroughbred race horses including Grade I stakes winner Grecian Flight and was a member of The Thoroughbred Club of America, the Turf & Field Club and the National Steeplechase Association and had been treasurer of the National Horse Show and a trustee of its foundation. Mr. Lindh was very active in charitable organizations, including 50 years on the board of The Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey, where he served as president and treasurer, and 25 years on the board of The New York Genealogical & Biographical Society, serving as chairman, president and treasurer. He had also been a trustee of the Holland Lodge Foundation. He was a life member of the Union Club, ranking number 10 on the seniority list, and serving on the board of governors and as treasurer for a number of years. A descendant through his mother of the very earliest New York families, including Robert Livingston, First Lord of the Manor of Livingston, 1686, John Pell, Second Lord of the Manor of Pelham, 1670, Richard Post of Southampton, Long Island, 1640, and Nicholas Pierre Gouverneur, who came to New Amsterdam in 1663, Mr. Lindh was a member of the New York Society of the Cincinnati, The Huguenot Society of America, where he was president at the time of his death, the Saint Nicholas Society, the Society of Colonial Wars, Holland Society, New England Society and Lords of Manors, as well as Squadron A, the Newport Reading Room, the Clambake Club and the Dunes Club. A kind, thoughtful and generous man, he is survived by his wife Elizabeth Powers Lindh, his son Andrew Seton Post Lindh, his daughter Jennifer Davis Lindh and four grandchildren, Alice Post Lindh Peterson, Phoebe Pell Lindh Peterson, Henry Livingston Post Lindh and William Morgan Pell Lindh. He was predeceased by his first wife Kathleen Davis Lindh and his brother David E. P. Lindh. Services will be held at 11 o'clock on Wednesday, July 15, 2015 at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City. Interment will be private at Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Huguenot Society of America, 20 West 44 St., New York, NY 10036. 1/3

PHILIP--Dr. Chris, an orthodontist, passed away on July 2, 2015 at the age of 86, he was a long time resident of Tenafly, NJ and most recently of Fort Lee. He was a graduate of NYU (University Heights College of Pure Arts & Sciences) and NYU College of Dentistry. He received his degree in Orthodontics at Colombia University. After graduating from Dental school he was commissioned as Captain in the U.S. Air Force Dental Corps. Dr. Philip was a professor of Orthodontics at Fairleigh Dickinson University's graduate department, serving as Director of the Cranio-Facial Anomalies and Cleft Palate Programs and was Chairman of the department of Orthodontics. He also served as president of the Northeastern society of Orthodontists and had private practices in New York and New Jersey. Chris was honored with the title Commander Emeritus of the Order of St Andrew the Apostle and was an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate. He served as President of St. Spyridon parish council. Beloved husband of Irene for 59 years. Devoted father of Katherine and husband Dr. Chris Kojanis and son Chris Philip Jr. Loving Grandfather of Lee, Ellyn and Renee Kojanis and brother of Phyllis Zahos and husband Athan Zahos. Visitation at St John the Theologian Greek Orthodox Cathedral Tenafly, NJ on Tuesday 3pm-9pm. Funeral Service Wednesday 11am at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church, New York City. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to either St Spyridon in NYC or Cathedral of St. John in Tenafly, NJ. Services handled by Barrett Funeral Home, New Jersey. 1/3

SILFEN--Susan. November 15, 1947 - July 3, 2015. Susie passed away suddenly and peacefully in her sleep on Friday morning. She was the beloved daughter of the late Esther and Herman Silfen and sister to David Silfen and Ellen Margolin. Susan was loved by her family and all who cared for her over the years, particularly those at the YAI Riverdale Residence. Despite her profound disabilities, Susie's charisma was felt by all who knew her and she will be missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made in her name to the YAI Riverdale Residence, 281 West 261st St., Bronx, NY 10471. 1/3

HOLMES--Ronald Joseph. June 3, 1937 - July 1, 2015. Ronald Joseph Holmes, 78, of Armonk, New York, passed away July 1, 2015. Born on June 3, 1937, in Brooklyn, New York, he was the son of Edgar George Holmes and Florence Celeste Holmes. Ron attended St. Anselm's College in Manchester, New Hampshire. He was a member of the Whippoorwill Club, Armonk, NY and John's Island Club, Vero Beach, FL. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Barbara McCarthy Holmes and son Gilbert Heath Holmes, son John Breeden Holmes, daughter-in law Torrey Higgins Holmes, son Gregory Galvin Holmes, daughter-in-law Megan Lawson Holmes and grandchildren Olivia Holmes, Heath Holmes, Lawson Pritchett, Marshall Pritchett, Kane Pritchett, and brother Gilbert Harris Holmes. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made payable to Northern Westchester Hospital Foundation and sent to: 400 East Main Street, Mount Kisco, NY 10549, Tax ID 13-4067064. 1/3
LARSON--Esther M.,96, died June 7, 2015. A well known fashion illustrator for more than 50 years, she is survived by her son, Jack E. Larson, Jr, Eastford, CT. 1/3

SCHRERO--Ruth Lieberman. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother died on June 30 at 93. She was a native New Yorker who loved "her city." An extraordinary artist, Ms. Schrero attended Tyler School of Art at Temple University and studied with Oronzio Maldarelli at Columbia, George Grosz and others. She was a life-long member of the Art Students League. She received numerous awards in sculpture, printmaking and drawing including the 2003 Gretchen Richardson Memorial Award for sculpture at the 114th annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Artists and the 1997 Gold Medal of Honor for Sculpture at the Catherine Lorillard Wolfe Art Club's 101st annual exhibition at the National Arts Club of New York. She also worked as a draftsperson for The Manhattan Project during WWII. Ms. Schrero and her late husband, Dr. Elliot M. Schrero, had an unusually loving and mutually supportive marriage of more than 60 years. She is survived by her daughters Elizabeth Schrero Cooper and Maggie D'Arcy, grandchildren Arielle and Daniel Cooper, and sons-in-law Jeffrey Cooper and Keith D'Arcy. Ms. Schrero was a creative spirit who loved all artistic expression. She also loved to laugh and sing and took great joy and pride in her family. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution to the Art Students League of New York or Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts. 1/3
APPLEMAN--Mark J. In the stillness of my life the memories linger and bring back the times of happiness we shared as soulmates. Love you forever, Marguerite 1/3

SIMON--Suzanne Cohn. The board, artists and staff of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center mourn deeply the passing of our beloved board member Suzanne Simon. A key member of our leadership, she continued to attend every possible board and committee meeting throughout the year that she battled with cancer, lending her elegance, keen mind, and warm heart to every deliberation. Together, Suzy and her husband David were sophisticated, devoted audience members supporting the work they loved with their presence. Suzy embodied music, was full of joy and laughter, and had a core understanding of what matters. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will be forever infused with the light of her gracious, generous, indomitable spirit. She was one of a kind. Jim O'Shaugnessy, Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors Suzanne Davidson, Executive Director 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Marcia. Jewish Foundation for Education of Women mourns the passing of Marcia Goldsmith. The first woman to serve as President of the Foundation Board, her commitment to the service of women's education and economic advancement was unwavering for over six decades. We will miss her sharp intellect and elegance, and extend condolences to daughters Susan Herman, Rachel Katz, Ilene Rapkin and their families. Phyllis G. Korff, President; Elizabeth L. Kraiem, Executive Director 1/3

SHAFFER--Dr. Ruth A. of Glen Cove, NY passed away June 25, 2015. Beloved wife of 49 years to Michael. Mother of Sharon Sprung and Stefan. Sister of Ellen Silverman. Grandmother of Jesse, Sara and Julia. Our own Dr. Ruth devoted an entire lifetime to assist the wellbeing of others. She loved her family and friends, her home and community, golf, the Arts and lived life to the fullest. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center or the Melillo Center for Mental Health, Glen Cove, NY. 1/3

ZEMACH--Rita (Dresner), Ph.D. Passed away June 8, 2015 in Deerfield, IL at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Abraham Zemach; loving mother of Brian (Beth) Zemach and Marilyn (Richard) Greene; adored Grandma of Adam, Aaron and Abigail; devoted daughter of the late Samuel and Gertrude Dresner of Paterson, NJ. 1/3

HELMAN--Gilbert, born in NYC December 29, 1914, died on July 2nd, 2015 in Rye, NY. He was the adored and beloved husband of Joy (nee Ostriker) who lit up his life for over 68 years. Father of Denice H. Rein, Mark Helman and the late Gary Helman. Loving Grandfather of Nicki R. Shalette, Alex Rein, Sarah and Jim Helman. Great-grandfather of Mark and Lucas Shalette. A man of many interests and capabilities, he graduated from Penn in 1936, and Harvard Law in 1939. During WWII he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army, stationed in the Aleutian Islands. After the war he joined his family's commercial Real Estate business which he continued to grow. Moving his young family to Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., he served as mayor for many years. Gil was always dignified and well-respected as a man of fine judgement, intelligence, and character. He was philanthropic and a natural leader, serving on many Boards and committees. He and Joy are on the Rockefeller University Council. His varied interests ranged from world travel and the arts, to piloting his own boat the Joggle II and playing his beloved game of golf both at Inwood Country Club and later at Quaker Ridge. His wisdom, intelligence and sense of humor were enjoyed by everyone who knew him. He and Joy had a wonderful marriage, a true romance that lasted a lifetime. He was an inspiration to his family and will always be remembered with reverence, admiration and love. Funeral service Monday, July 6 at Riverside Chapel 180 West 76th St. at 12:45. The family will receive visitors Monday from 5 to 8:30 at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street. Contributions in his memory should be made to the Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave., NYC. 10065 attn: Marnie Imhoff. 1/3

ANDERSON--Max, 87, passed Saturday, May 23, 2015. He was a consultant and lecturer in urban regional planning, economics and design for 60 years, working his whole life to help people, communities and the environment. He will be deeply missed. Online condolences may be left for the family at www.parkerfuneral service.com 1/3

MILLER--Irene D.,of Manhattan, passed peacefully at age 81 on Thursday June 25, 2015 after a long struggle with Parkinson's disease. She is survived by her husband and a large loving and adoring family who, with heavy hearts, will miss her greatly. Funeral services for family only will be held at St. Thomas Church in New York on Monday, July 6, 2015. A larger memorial service in celebration of her life will be held in September 2015. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Marcia Stebbins. Park East Synagogue Sisterhood is heartbroken over the loss of our beloved past President and Board Member, Marcia Stebbins Goldsmith. Marcia was one of our most devoted leaders and will be greatly missed. 1/3

PRINCE-JOSEPH--Dr. Bruce, 89, of Kansas City, MO passed away peacefully Saturday, April 25, 2015 in the comfort of his home in the embrace of close friends. Bruce's legacy as an organist in New York was extensive, having served St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Philharmonic, and Hunter College as Music Department Chair. A Solemn Requiem is planned for Saturday afternoon, July 11th at 3:00pm at St. Mary's Church, 1307 Holmes, Kansas City, MO. Memorial contributions can be made to the American Guild of Organists by sending a check to: AGO New Organist Fund, Bruce Prince-Joseph Scholarship, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 1260, New York, NY 10115. Contribute online at: www.agohq.org/contribute. For more information about Bruce, his career, and accomplishments, visit: mcgilleymidtownchapel.com 1/3

TUCHMAN--Kenneth (Moe), 87, on July 3, 2015 of New York. Beloved husband of Esther Schrier Tuchman, of Manhattan; cherished father of Paula Weiss (Mitchell) of Annandale, VA; Mark (Michelle) of Brooklyn; Julia of Manhattan; and Robert (Amy) of Manhattan. Loving brother of Irving (Beverly) and Max (Sandy). Adored grandfather of Anna Weiss, Sam, Lily, Ella, Mia and Zoe Tuchman. Son of the late Joseph and Annie Feiler Tuchman. Moe was president of Elect Trimming Co. for 43 years. His passion and talent for sports were well known in his native Bronx. He pitched minor league baseball for the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1948. He was a kind man who was deeply dedicated to his family and always interested in connecting with everyone he met. With deep thanks to his devoted caregivers Orlando James, Romerry Fraser and Jennifer Odia, and to the staff at Bellevue Haven. Service Sunday, July 5th, at 12:45pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice. 1/3

FAUSER--Helen Langer, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died peacefully on June 30, 2015, at age 93 1/2. Her devoted and beloved children were by her side. She is predeceased by parents, Samuel and Celia, brother Stanley and the love of her life, Joseph (2006). They met at LIU, had an incredible marriage of 64 years and no man could have ever loved his wife more. Helen was a beautiful, elegant and selfless woman. She leaves behind her children, Robert and Arlene Fauser, Jill and Richard Israel, grandchildren Chad Fauser (Patti) and Scott Alessandro (Katherine Rosbottom Alessandro) and her cherished great-grand- daughters, Darian, Devan and Jordan Fauser. She was devoted most to her family but was giving and caring to all. We will miss her love and sparkle daily. A graveside service will be July 7, 2015, 11:00am, Pinelawn Memorial Cemetery. Shiva will be at 33 W. 67th. St., NYC on Tuesday, July 7 and Wednesday, July 8 starting at 4:00pm. 1/3

PARKAS--Philip P. Judith Parkas, his wife of 51 years, announces the death of Philip P. Parkas. He was born in New York City in 1927. After a tumultuous childhood, he graduated from Forest Hills High School and joined the Army. The GI Bill helped him attend the Wharton School - University of Pennsylvania (Class of 1950) and Columbia University (MBA 1952). He was a successful businessman (bowling centers), a concert promoter (with Erwin Frankel) a Westside activist (Ansonia Independent Democrats), pivotal board member (290 WEA). He loved the music, dancing and food associated with his Greek-American heritage. He was handsome, robust and fun - also well informed and accomplished. He is survived his daughter, Valerie Parkas Kendler, her husband Jason Kendler and their children Stephanie Parkas Kendler and Philip Jack Kendler; also Peter and Dianne Parkas and Arielle, Levi, Josiah and Simone. The last six years were a struggle as Alzheimer's slowly diminished his person and even that he handled with dignity. There will be a memorial service in September. 1/3

WINTERS--Lola. Vibrant, caring and spirited. Lover of all animals and nature. Predeceased by husband Jack and son Mitchell. Loving sister to Penny. Beloved mother to Clifford and Stacy. Grandmother to Nicole. Cherished aunt to Nancy and Kathy. Graveside service. 1/3

SOFAER--Mozelle Ephraim Ezekiel, died in Palo Alto, California, on June 21, 2015, almost 100 years after her birth in Bombay, India on July 3, 1915. She was the 9th of 13 children born to Ephraim Yedidiah Ezekiel from Kirkuk, and his second wife, Lulu Mitana from Baghdad. Her father was a businessman who sold fez hats and other accessories. She was orphaned at the age of 11. Because of her exceptional ability to memorize, Mozelle was recruited by Mrs. Naidu of the Congress Party of India to carry secret messages to and from M.K. Gandhi during his imprisonment by the British in Yerwada around 1930. In 1933, Mozelle married David Meyer Sofaer, a Baghdadi Jew born in Rangoon, Burma. David had a successful career with the E.D. Sassoon Company and later also established his own trading business. In Bombay, Mozelle was active in the charities of the Jewish Women's League, was a superb cook, a mystic and loved music and dancing. The family immigrated to the U.S. in 1952. She is survived by her children, Pearl, Abraham, Isaac, and Shoshanna, 13 grandchildren and 13 great- grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

HELMAN--Gilbert. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Gilbert Helman. He was an esteemed, longtime member of The Rockefeller University Council and a passionate believer in the importance and value of biomedical research and supporting early career scientists. He and his cherished wife, Joy, became involved with the University in 2003, when they established the Gary R. Helman Endowed Postdoctoral Fellowship Fund in memory of their son. Gilbert and Joy were frequent visitors to campus and took a real interest in the talented young investigators they supported. We will miss Gilbert's avid curiosity about science and his immense personal warmth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joy, his daughter Denice Rein, his son Mark Helman, and his grandchildren. Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Mary Jeanne Kreek, M.D. Bruce S. McEwen, Ph.D. Marnie Imhoff, Senior Vice President 1/3

WACHTER--Maxine (Mikki), 80, passed away on June 27th after a valiant battle with emphysema. Loving mother of Richard (Ann) and David (Jiali Chen). Devoted grandmother of Andrew and Danielle. Born in Brooklyn, she graduated from Erasmus Hall High School in 1952, earned her BS in Psychology and certification in teaching from Adelphi University in 1956, and a Master's in Education from Brooklyn College in 1967. She retired in 1999 from George McVey Elementary School in East Meadow. In addition to a 40+ year career in education in which she fostered a commitment of young people to civic duty, Mikki served with the League of Women Voters, and the National Council of Jewish Women. She was an avid bridge player, patron of the arts and passionate about Jewish causes and global suffering. 1/3

HUGHES--Roxanne L.,age 56, of Oakdale, on July 1, 2015. Beloved wife of Camillus. Loving mother of Brian Clark and Kyle Patrick. Cherished daughter of Marion Rahman. Dear sister of Renee Rahman. Reposing Sunday, 7-9:30pm and Monday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30pm at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Main Street, West Sayville. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:00am St. Lawrence R.C. Church, Sayville. Cremation following at Nassau-Suffolk Crematory, Ronkonkoma. In lieu of flowers contributions to: Scleroderma Foundation 300 Rosewood Dr. Suite 105 Danvers, MA 01923 are appreciated by the family. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Marcia Stebbins, peacefully passed away at age 92 with her family at her side on July 3rd 2015. As a board member of The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women. Marcia profoundly improved the lives of those less fortunate than her. She was a graduate of Hunter College. With her adoring and beloved husband Warren of fifty-seven years she shared a life-long appreciation of art, music, nightlife, ballet, theater and especially travel, spanning the globe often with extended family in tow. Her dinner parties and Seders were legendary. While Marcia's spiritual life was her constant compass it was her family that was the foundation of her being. She leaves behind her daughters Susan Herman, Rachel Katz and Ilene Rapkin, grandchildren Zachary Herman and Gabriel Herman, Rebecca Brown, Edward Katz, Kimberly Katz and Asher Rapkin; extended family members David Rapkin, Caitlin Rolls, Tzili Ressler, Jennifer Katz and dear family friend Dr. Garet Gordon. Her cherished great grandchildren are Sabrina Katz and Chelsea Katz. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women, the Sharon Chapter of Hadassah or the Park East Synagogue Day School in memory of Marcia Stebbins Goldsmith. Services will be held at "The Riverside", 180 West 76th Street on Monday, July 6th at 12 Noon. The Interment will be private. 1/3
POMERANTZ--Carol Stone. Loving wife to Alan, mother to Michael and Kiernan, and adoring grandmother to Quinn and Oona. Died peacefully in her sleep, June 30, 2015, in San Francisco. 1/3

BULL--Edith H.,103, died June 25 in Far Rockaway. Born in New York City the second of three daughters of noted orthodontist and anthropologist Dr. Milo Hellman, she grew up in Far Rockaway, graduated from Skidmore College in Zoology and received a Masters in Vertebrate Paleontology from Columbia University. Like her father she worked at the AMNH but in the Vertebrate Paleontology Department. Her husband John Bull worked in the AMNH's Ornithology Department. Edith and John collaborated on many books and co-wrote the popular quick-identification guide "Birds of North America" and co-led many AMNH expeditions around the world. Survivors include daughter Doris Bull Kraus, three grandmdaughters, family and fans. 1/3

FORSTENZER--Peter. The wife and children of Peter Forstenzer sadly announce the passing of this wonderful, generous man, on July 2, at age 93. He was a talented graphic artist who loved drawing and reading. Most of all he loved his family. He will be dearly missed. A memorial service will be held at a later date. 1/3

WHITMAN--John Russell, passed away Thursday July 2nd. John was born and raised in New York City. He graduated from Yale University in 1966 and Harvard Business School in 1971. John loved sailing, golf, tennis, mountain biking, ice hockey and especially dancing. John volunteered and served as a 1st Lieutenant in the US Army in the United States and the Republic of Vietnam. He was awarded two bronze stars, one with a V for valor. John was president and a founder and a managing partner of Sycamore Ventures. He held various positions at Prudential-Bache and Citicorp. John is survived by his spouse of 41 years, former New Jersey Governor Christine Todd Whitman, their two children and their spouses. He is also survived by his six grandsons, his brother Charles S. Whitman III, his sister Jan Whitman Ogden and many nieces and nephews. In lieu, of flowers, please send donations to The New Jersey Vietnam Veteran's Memorial or the Eisenhower Fellows. 1/3

KLEBAN--Carol E.,age 72, passed away suddenly on June 27, 2015. Survived by children Daniel and Matthew, daughters-in-law Janet and Rosa, and grandchildren David, Abigail, Lillian, Esme and Aaron. A graduate of Alfred University, she spent 36 years at Professional Children's School as a teacher, principal and associate head of school, and following retirement, she continued as a part-time alumni liaison. She always said she loved going to work every day and felt fortunate to work with such exceptional staff and students. She was a naturally warm person with a genuine interest in getting to know all people. She was beloved by her lifelong friends and the new friends she continued to make each day. Everyone who knew her spoke of her generosity and her reflexive need to offer solace and support, which she did with an open heart, a warm smile and an understated sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may take the form of donations to Professional Children's School. Services will be held on Tuesday, June 30, 2015 at 11:00am at The Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY. 1/3

LARSON--A. William "Monk", died at the age of 94 in Florida on July 2. A retired Marine Corps Colonel, he was a renaissance man whose myriad talents ranged from poetry to politics. He inspired us all with his unwavering activism for a peaceful planet. He will be deeply missed by friends and beloved family. 1

SOFAER--Mozelle Ephraim Ezekiel, died in Palo Alto, California, on June 21, 2015, almost 100 years after her birth in Bombay, India on July 3, 1915. She was the 9th of 13 children born to Ephraim Yedidiah Ezekiel from Kirkuk, and his second wife, Lulu Mitana from Baghdad. Her father was a businessman who sold fez hats and other accessories. She was orphaned at the age of 11. Because of her exceptional ability to memorize, Mozelle was recruited by Mrs. Naidu of the Congress Party of India to carry secret messages to and from M.K. Gandhi during his imprisonment by the British in Yerwada around 1930. In 1933, Mozelle married David Meyer Sofaer, a Baghdadi Jew born in Rangoon, Burma. David had a successful career with the E.D. Sassoon Company and later also established his own trading business. In Bombay, Mozelle was active in the charities of the Jewish Women's League, was a superb cook, a mystic and loved music and dancing. The family immigrated to the U.S. in 1952. She is survived by her children, Pearl, Abraham, Isaac, and Shoshanna, 13 grandchildren and 13 great- grandchildren. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Marcia. Jewish Foundation for Education of Women mourns the passing of Marcia Goldsmith. The first woman to serve as President of the Foundation Board, her commitment to the service of women's education and economic advancement was unwavering for over six decades. We will miss her sharp intellect and elegance, and extend condolences to daughters Susan Herman, Rachel Katz, Ilene Rapkin and their families. Phyllis G. Korff, President; Elizabeth L. Kraiem, Executive Director 1/3

GOLDSMITH--Marcia Stebbins, peacefully passed away at age 92 with her family at her side on July 3rd 2015. As a board member of The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women. Marcia profoundly improved the lives of those less fortunate than her. She was a graduate of Hunter College. With her adoring and beloved husband Warren of fifty-seven years she shared a life-long appreciation of art, music, nightlife, ballet, theater and especially travel, spanning the globe often with extended family in tow. Her dinner parties and Seders were legendary. While Marcia's spiritual life was her constant compass it was her family that was the foundation of her being. She leaves behind her daughters Susan Herman, Rachel Katz and Ilene Rapkin, grandchildren Zachary Herman and Gabriel Herman, Rebecca Brown, Edward Katz, Kimberly Katz and Asher Rapkin; extended family members David Rapkin, Caitlin Rolls, Tzili Ressler, Jennifer Katz and dear family friend Dr. Garet Gordon. Her cherished great grandchildren are Sabrina Katz and Chelsea Katz. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Jewish Foundation for Education of Women, the Sharon Chapter of Hadassah or the Park East Synagogue Day School in memory of Marcia Stebbins Goldsmith. Services will be held at "The Riverside", 180 West 76th Street on Monday, July 6th at 12 Noon. The Interment will be private. 1/3

SILFEN--Susan. November 15, 1947 - July 3, 2015. Susie passed away suddenly and peacefully in her sleep on Friday morning. She was the beloved daughter of the late Esther and Herman Silfen and sister to David Silfen and Ellen Margolin. Susan was loved by her family and all who cared for her over the years, particularly those at the YAI Riverdale Residence. Despite her profound disabilities, Susie's charisma was felt by all who knew her and she will be missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made in her name to the YAI Riverdale Residence, 281 West 261st St., Bronx, NY 10471. 1/3

LARSON--A. William "Monk", died at the age of 94 in Florida on July 2. A retired Marine Corps Colonel, he was a renaissance man whose myriad talents ranged from poetry to politics. He inspired us all with his unwavering activism for a peaceful planet. He will be deeply missed by friends and beloved family. 1

WOODWORTH--Susan R.,of Murray Hill, NJ, passed away at age 70 on July 3 ,2015, after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Jay, daughter Marian Vonella (Robert) of Freehold, NJ, and son Nicholas (Jillian) of St. Johns, FL, and three grandchildren, Hayley Vonella and Emma and Liam Woodworth. Susan was born in East Orange, NJ, and raised on Shelter Island, NY. She was the daughter of Alice Fiske and step- daughter of Andrew Fiske, who was the 16th Lord of the Manor at Sylvester Manor on Shelter Island. She and her family lived in Summit for 36 years before moving to the Murray Hill section of New Providence in 2010. She graduated from Emma Willard School in Troy, NY, and from Western College in Oxford, OH, now part of the University of Ohio system. She was a member of Calvary Episcopal Church, where she sang in the choir, and the Calvary Chorale. Susan was a sustaining member of several organizations in Summit including the Junior League, College Club, Historical Society, DAR chapter and the Questers. She was also a member and chapter president of P.E.O. International, a philanthropic organization for the advancement of women. Susan was a Patron of Carnegie Hall and a supporter of several public television and classical music radio stations. Susan was an avid rug hooker and a member of two guilds, the Anne Arundel Guild in Maryland and the Hunterdon County Rug Artisans Guild in New Jersey. She loved attending week-long workshops and catching up with friends' projects. When not hooking, Susan could be found curled up with a good book or in the kitchen baking for friends or functions. A Memorial service will be held at a later date at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ 07901. Phone is: 908-277-1814. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in Susan's name be made to Calvary Episcopal Church. 1/3

PARKAS--Philip P. Judith Parkas, his wife of 51 years, announces the death of Philip P. Parkas. He was born in New York City in 1927. After a tumultuous childhood, he graduated from Forest Hills High School and joined the Army. The GI Bill helped him attend the Wharton School - University of Pennsylvania (Class of 1950) and Columbia University (MBA 1952). He was a successful businessman (bowling centers), a concert promoter (with Erwin Frankel) a Westside activist (Ansonia Independent Democrats), pivotal board member (290 WEA). He loved the music, dancing and food associated with his Greek-American heritage. He was handsome, robust and fun - also well informed and accomplished. He is survived his daughter, Valerie Parkas Kendler, her husband Jason Kendler and their children Stephanie Parkas Kendler and Philip Jack Kendler; also Peter and Dianne Parkas and Arielle, Levi, Josiah and Simone. The last six years were a struggle as Alzheimer's slowly diminished his person and even that he handled with dignity. There will be a memorial service in September. 1/3

KRENTZMAN--Farla H. (Blumer), of Chestnut Hill, age 85. Entered into rest on July 5, 2015 at her home. She was the loving wife of the late Harvey "Chet" Krentzman, mother to Mark A. Krentzman and his wife Caroline, of New York and Washington, CT, and to Scott D. Krentzman and his wife Amy of Newton, MA. Devoted "Grammy" to Amanda, Hilary, Robert, Jack, and Samuel, Jennifer, Joshua Krentzman, and to Samuel Gloss. Born in Montreal, Farla was the oldest child of the late Tess and Charlie Blumer and sister to Diane (Blumer) Jackson and the late Ronald Blumer. She was raised in Montreal and graduated from McGill University. On Thanksgiving Day, 1952, Farla married "Chet" and settled in Chestnut Hill, MA where they would remain for the rest of their lives. She and "Chet" were great supporters of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Beth Israel Hospital, Northeastern University, and other Massachusetts institutions but she also cherished her own work at the Boston Ballet, the Hebrew Home for the Aged, and the Silent Spring Institute. Services will be held at Congregation Mishkan Tefila, Chestnut Hill, MA, on Tuesday, July 7, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Silent Spring Institute, 29 Crafts Street, Newton, MA 02458, www.silentspring.org. 1/3

GRUNSPAN--Jack. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of our Executive Vice President. Jack joined Bnai Zion as a member in 1973 and over the years served as a volunteer in numerous capacities including chairman of the Finance Committee and President of the Doctor Harris J. Levine Chapter. In 1998 he was elected National Secretary and joined the staff as Director of Development, using his background in estate planning to lecture and fundraise nationwide and expand the profile of the organization. In 2006 he was named Executive Vice President. His dedication to Bnai Zion and to the people of Israel is an inspiration to us all. He was a real mensch and will be truly missed. Our hearts go out to his wife Judi and his children Rachel and David, and may his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David H. Eisenberg, National President George W. Schaeffer, Chairman of the Board Mel Parness, Exec. Vice President Emeritus Raymond M. Patt, Honorary Chair Cheryl Bier, COO 1/3

MURRAY--Constance B. (Connie) Freedom Institute mourns the loss of Connie Murray, former Executive Director and President who, even after her retirement in 2009, served as a consultant and mentor to many. A dignified and compassionate person, she left her mark on the field of recovery and on all those she helped. She is remembered for her sensitivity, insight and dedication to others, especially to educating adolescents about substance abuse prevention. Freedom Institute would not be what it is today without her. Connie will be dearly missed, but her legacy lives on at Freedom Institute and the memory of her kind smile, sharp wit and intelligent beauty remains in our hearts. 1/3

MIGUEL--Carmen, died in Wellesley, MA on July 2, 2015. Born in Puerto Montt, Chile on September 19, 1932, Carmen was a retired research editor for Life in Espanol and McCalls Magazine, and a long time lover of the opera and the arts in New York City. Carmen was a caring and devoted sister, aunt and friend. She will be profoundly missed by her loving family and friends in the U.S. and Chile. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Ignatius Church, New York, NY. Mass on Wednesday, July 8 at 10:00am St. Paul's Parish, Wellesley, MA. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Jane, 68, born in Pittsburgh, PA, and longtime resident of Larchmont, NY, passed away suddenly on July 2, 2015. She retired as Assistant Head Librarian of The New York Society Library after 40 years. Beloved wife of Kenneth, loving mother of Anne Gerson (Adam) and Ellen Vora (Vimal), and adoring grandmother of Estelle Gerson and baby girl Vora, expected in October. Dear sister of David Hodge and Steven Hodge. Funeral service Wednesday, July 8 at 11am at Larchmont Temple. Private Interment. In lieu of flowers, donations in Jane's name to The New York Society Library. Full obituary at JJFFH.com. 1/3

BROOK--Jonathan Edward. July 3, 2015. Devoted husband of Nicole, loving father of Juliette and Cassie, brother of Adam. Beloved son of Judith and David. A warm, loving, kind young man, who adored his family and cared for others. He made lasting and deep friendships at Amherst College, class of 1992 and beyond. He will be missed by many. 1/3
LISS--Elliott R. 7/6/31-5/18/04. A beloved husband, father, grandfather, and friend. Your joy for living is always with us. Love, Dotty and the kids 1/3

FEUERSTEIN--Charlotte Clein. Beloved and cherished wife of Dr. Sidney Feuerstein for nearly 70 years, treasured mother of Ronnie Heyman (Samuel z"l) and Henry Feuerstein (Elise Meyer). Grandmother of Lazarus Heyman (Kim), Eleanor Heyman Propp, Jennifer Millstone (David) and Elizabeth Heyman Winter; John Feuerstein (Ilana) and Amanda Bushell (Matt). Private service in Palm Beach. Her abiding commitment to Jewish life and family was an inspiration to all and her love made each of us better. 1/3

GELLES--Walter Ralph, passed away at the age of 87 on Saturday, July 4 at Sarah Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck. Devoted husband of the late Carol Schrier Gelles, loving father of Robert and Richard (Susan), nurturing grandfather of Andrew, Danny, Kevin and Thomas, loyal brother of the late Henry (Carol), Edith (Michael) and David (Pam), loving brother-in-law of the late Suzanne Schrier Heimerdinger and John (Marilyn) Heimerdinger, and caring uncle of 12 nephews and nieces. Walter treasured his wife, children and grandchildren. He was not just Carol's husband but also her best friend. During a magical 62 year marriage, he and Carol forged a wonderful partnership that deepened as the years went by. Walter celebrated all of his sons' accomplishments and was always available to provide them with advice and comfort. He got tremendous joy from the time that he spent with his grandchildren. Each grandchild was very precious to him. Walter also valued the friendships that he developed with other people across the many decades of his life. He was always a good and sympathetic listener to his friends, and he took the time to get to know each of them. He had a long and successful career as a real estate attorney. He was quite adept at analyzing legal issues, and he was a persuasive advocate for his clients. He was also a delightful colleague to the other members of his law firm. Walter had a keen interest in politics. He always kept himself well-informed by reading newspapers, magazines and books, and by watching political programs on TV, and he never tired of discussing politics with family and friends. He also enjoyed reading books on history. The history of Israel interested him in particular. Through the many books that he acquired on the subject, he mastered all of the details of the creation of Israel as well as its history since being founded. He got much pleasure from playing bridge, almost always with Carol as his partner. Walter loved classical music. Starting as a teenager, he began to purchase recordings of various symphonies and concertos, and he also developed an interest in opera. Among his favorite composers were Tchaikovsky, Beethoven and Verdi. Walter was an avid golfer and a loyal fan of the New York Jets football team. He also did a lot of traveling. There were two extensive summer trips to the western U.S. and Canada with Carol and the two boys, and many later trips with Carol to Europe. Walter and his family also spent a number of summer and winter vacations in Lake Placid in the Adirondacks. Lake Placid was where Walter had grown up and where he had met Carol. Those of us who knew Walter will miss him very much. He was a very special man. A funeral service is scheduled for Thursday, July 9 at 3pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of James S. Marcus, who was a distinguished member of the Board for more than four decades. Mr. Marcus was elected Managing Director in 1976, served as Chairman of the Board from 1986 to 1993, and Honorary Director since 1997. Jim was a legendary connoisseur of opera and operatic talent and a marvelous advocate for the art form. In addition to his Board leadership duties and the many fundraising activities this service required, Jim also dedicated time, energy, and his personal resources to supporting and advancing the careers of young singers. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Ellen, and to his family and friends. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Judith-Ann Corrente, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager 1/3

NELSON--Stanley, died July 4, 2015. Born in Brooklyn in 1933, Stanley, a prolific writer, was the recipient of the Thomas Wolfe Poetry Award and authored 18 volumes of poetry. His plays have been produced in New York, London, and theaters throughout the US. He is survived by two daughters from his first marriage to Ellen Nelson, Chelly Glancy and Lycette Nelson, his granddaughter Selam, numerous nephews and nieces, and the grandchildren of his second wife who predeceased him, Betty Jean Nelson. The family is grateful to Guy Gauthier for his lifelong friendship with Stanley. Graveside gathering at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, Wednesday, July 8 at 2pm. 1/3

GELLES--Walter R. The partners and staff of Tuchman, Korngold, Weiss, Liebman & Gelles, LLP extend our condolences to the family of our friend, beloved partner and guiding spirit Walter R. Gelles. He will be sorely missed but never replaced. 1/3

LINDH--Henry C.B. We are greatly saddened by the news of the passing of Harry Lindh, our dear friend and colleague of some 35 years. For many of those we worked together on behalf of The National Horse Show and The National Horse Sports Foundation (formerly National Horse Show Foundation) where he served with great distinction as treasurer and board member of both organizations. Our love and deepest sympathy go to his wife Elizabeth and to his son Andrew and his daughter Jennifer and their extended families. He will be sorely missed. Hank and Suzanne Collins 1/3

THOMANN--John, died on July 4, 2015. The people of Turner Construction Company are deeply saddened at the loss of their colleague John Thomann. John, a leader in the construction industry in New York, served as vice president and general manager of Turner's Interiors group in New York for the past ten years. John, who was diagnosed with cancer six years ago, is survived by his wife, Kathleen, daughter Jacqueline and son James. Upon graduation from Manhattan College in 1987, John joined Turner Construction Company in New York. Among his leadership roles at the company were as Superintendent, Purchasing Manager and Project Executive. Under his leadership, the New York Interiors group has long been recognized as one of the leading interiors contractors in New York. A native of Queens, he had a positive impact across New York City as he led the delivery of services to clients in the commercial office, retail, hospitality, sports and entertainment, education, and government sectors. John also made a difference through his leadership and support of community and industry organizations. John received the Victory Award for outstanding commitment to charitable giving from the Saint Dominic's Home, the Francis Award from the St. Francis Food Pantries and Shelters for his outstanding charitable works, and the Progress of Peoples Achievement Award from Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens for outstanding leadership and commitment to creating secure homes in a caring community for low-income seniors and families, the disabled and formerly homeless. John's friendship, leadership, service and mentorship will be missed by all that knew him. Visitation will be held at Connell Funeral Home at 934 New York Ave. in Huntington Station, NY on Wednesday July 8 from 2:00 - 4:00 and 7:00 - 9:00. Mass will be held at St. Elizabeth's Church at 175 Wolf Hill Road in Melville, NY on Thursday at 9:30. All of us at Turner 1/3

We cherish the memory of our dear friend, whose dignity and advice will long be remembered and greatly missed. We extend our condolences to the Whitman family. Paul Hoffman President and CEO William A. Tansey III, MD Chairman of the Board 1

MARCUS--James S. The staff and trustees of Lenox Hill Hospital mourn the loss of Chairman Emeritus James S. Marcus, who led the hospital's board of trustees from 1993-2003. SANTUCCI--Ronald R.,Esq., of New Rochelle, died on July 3, 2015. He was 62. Mr. Santucci was born in Manhattan to John and Eileen Santucci. Mr. Santucci was a partner at the intellectual property firm Frommer, Lawrence & Haug, and served as chair of their patent prosecution group. He was one of the nation's leading experts in patent law with extensive trial experience as well as numerous cases before the International Trade Commission. Ronald is survived by his wife Karen (nee Burbach) and children, John and Julia, siblings: Eileen Hawe, Dennis Santucci, Robert Santucci, Wayne Santucci, Laura Santucci, and Susan Failla. STURM--Rabbi Chaplain Ephraim H. Gentle, gracious, prescient. These were some of the qualities of Ephraim Sturm, as executive Vice President of the National Council of Young Israel, brought a turning point in the 1950's for Jewish university students when Rabbi Sturm championed the idea that students could practice their religion without hindrance and be able to obtain kosher food at universities whose respective dining facilities omitted kosher options. We, today, at Cornell University are early beneficiaries of Rabbi Sturm's initiative and will always be appreciative of his assistance and guidance. Richard J. Bornstein,'62, Chair Endowment Board of Trustees of the Center For Jewish Living at Cornell University 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Metropolitan Opera Guild are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and long-time board member, James S. Marcus. PHILIP--Dr. Chris. an orthodontist, passed away on July 2, 2015 at the age of 86, he was a long time resident of Tenafly, NJ and most recently of Fort Lee. He was a graduate of NYU (University Heights College of Pure Arts & Sciences) and NYU College of Dentistry. He received his degree in Orthodontics at Columbia University. After graduating from Dental school he was commissioned as Captain in the U.S. Air Force Dental Corps. Dr. Philip was a professor of Orthodontics at Fairleigh Dickinson University's graduate department, serving as Director of the Cranio-Facial Anomalies and Cleft Palate Programs and was Chairman of the department of Orthodontics. He also served as president of the Northeastern society of Orthodontists and had private practices in New York and New Jersey. Chris was honored with the title Commander Emeritus of the Order of St Andrew the Apostle and was an Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate. He served as President of St. Spyridon parish council. Beloved husband of Irene for 59 years. Devoted father of Katherine and husband Dr. Chris Kojanis and son Chris Philip Jr. Loving Grandfather of Lee, Ellyn and Renee Kojanis and brother of Phyllis Zahos and husband Athan Zahos. Visitation at St John the Theologian Greek Orthodox Cathedral Tenafly, NJ on Tuesday 3pm-9pm. Funeral Service Wednesday 11am at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church, New York City. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to either St Spyridon in NYC or Cathedral of St. John in Tenafly, NJ. Services handled by Barrett Funeral Home, New Jersey. 1/3

LOOP--Floyd D.,M.D. Floyd D. Loop M.D. Former CEO and chairman of Cleveland Clinic, passed away June 11. Dr. Loop served as chairman and CEO of Cleveland Clinic from 1989 to 2004. He was a pioneering cardiac surgeon and former chairman of the Department of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery. Under his leadership, Cleveland Clinic became an integrated regional healthcare delivery system, with an expanded main campus, hospital and clinic in Florida, and its own medical school program. He launched construction of what would become the Sydell and Arnold Miller Family Pavilion and Glickman Tower, and established a sound foundation for Cleveland Clinic's growth in the current century. "The legacy of Dr. Loop is all around us," says Toby Cosgrove, MD, current president and CEO of Cleveland Clinic. "We can never forget all he's done to make Cleveland Clinic one of the world's great medical centers." Known to friends and colleagues as "Fred", Dr. Loop was the son of a country doctor from Lafayette, Indiana. He graduated from Purdue University, Indiana, and earned his medical degree at The George Washington University, Washington, D.C. After post-graduate training at The George Washington University, the US Air Force at Andrews Air Force Base, and Cleveland Clinic, he joined Cleveland Clinic as a cardiac surgeon in 1970. He performed more than 12,000 cardiac surgeries, and was the author of 350 papers on all aspects of cardiovascular surgery. He refined arterial grafting, improved reoperative techniques, and confirmed the superiority of the internal thoracic artery as a bypass graft to the left anterior descending coronary artery. He led comprehensive follow-up studies of bypass patients, and helped establish the world's first computerized registry of cardiac surgery outcome. In 1975, he was named chairman of the Department of Thoracic and Cardiovascular surgery. Over the next 14 years, he consolidated Cleveland Clinic's worldwide reputation for excellence in cardiac surgery, and assembled a team of expert surgeons who would go on to lead their specialty and set the pace for years to come. Dr. Loop was named CEO in 1989. His challenges included declining reimbursement, potential competition from private hospital systems, and the need to preserve Cleveland Clinic's specialty focus amid a growing demand for primary services. He stabilized finances, centralized authority, and streamlined reporting relationships. His strategy to improve regional access resulted in the construction of family health ambulatory centers across Northeast Ohio, and the acquisition of eight community hospitals through the 1990s. At the same time, he invested heavily in information technology, laying the groundwork for a comprehensive electronic medical records system. With a leadership gift of $100 million from Alfred Lerner and family, he launched a philanthropic campaign that enabled the construction of the Lerner Research Institute, Cole Eye Institute, Taussig Cancer Center, and the Lerner College of Medicine of Case Western Reserve University. He improved access and added new operating rooms through the Maria and Sam Miller Emergency Services building. He reaffirmed commitment to Cleveland Clinic Florida, and built a new integrated medical campus in Weston, Florida. Programs and facilities founded under his leadership include the Sherwin Research Building, Children's Hospital, Cleveland Clinic Innovations, the Surgery Center, Neurological Imaging Center, Cleveland Clinic Sports Health, and the purchase and renovation of Foundation House. In 2001, Dr. Loop announced plans for the current Miller Family Pavilion to consolidate heart and vascular services at a single location. With modifications and the addition of the Glickman Tower, the new facility was completed under the administration of Dr. Cosgrove in 2008. Dr. Loop was married to Bernadine Healy, MD, (1944-2011), who served as chairman of the Research Institute from 1985 to 1995. His awards and honors include the American Heart Association Citation for International Service, the American College of Cardiology Cummings Humanitarian Award, and Cleveland Clinic Lerner Humanitarian Award. Dr. Loop retired as CEO in 2004. He continued to advise and mentor and served on private and public corporate boards. His book, "Leadership and Medicine" was published in 2009. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Bernard G.,of Greenwich, CT passed away suddenly on July 2 at the age of 71. He will be deeply missed by his wife Frances, and children Andrew and Jessica and son-in-law Scott. MARCUS--James S. The Board of the Calamus Foundation of New York City mourn the loss of our colleague James S. Marcus. Jim was a delight to work with, a kind soul who brought wisdom and humor to every conversation. He was an extraordinarily generous donor to many causes. He cared deeply about music, youth education, homelessness, medical care, AIDS/HIV, and so many other worthy causes in his beloved New York City. We send our sincerest condolences to his wife Ellen and to all his friends and beneficiaries of his charity. We loved him dearly. Louis A. Bradbury, President Brian O'Donnell, Executive Director 1/3

MARCUS--James S. Jim's passing is an irremediable loss for all of us who love Pianofest and its purpose of educating gifted young musicians. This is summer, when the music of nature flourishes. Jim's mother was a pianist and he often mentioned hearing her practice "Rustle of Spring" by Christian Sinding, a Norwegian composer. Thus, despite my sadness, I would like my comments about Jim to reflect the ongoing joys of the music he provided for us all. Jim is a classic example of a successful person. He had a wonderful career, he was financially successful, and he invested his considerable intellectual and material resources for the betterment of humanity. He focused on supporting music and musicians to help to ensure that they achieved their greatest potential and then presented their art for the enjoyment and inspiration of their audiences. Jim did what all truly great people do, in that he gained greatly and then gave even more, and in this way, gained in his giving. He often advised me on Pianofest matters, and it pleased me to see how the students enjoyed talking with Ellen and Jim and how they became very close to many Pianofest artists. His passing is a great loss and our condolences are with Ellen and all who knew and loved him. Paul Schenly, Director, Pianofest 1/3

HARRISON--Helen Herre, died in the early morning of July 4, after fighting a mysterious and undiagnosed illness for five years. Helen was the author of The Premature Baby Book, a guide for parents that went through seventeen printings and was known as "The Bible" in neonatal intensive care nurseries. She went on to advocate for parents, insisting that they, rather than doctors, have the right to make life and death decisions in extreme cases. She insisted that doctors give parents a realistic prognosis for survivors of neonatal intensive care. She opposed doctors' tendencies to reassure parents that everything would turn out well, when studies showed the opposite. She was also in the forefront of the movement to ban unanesthetized infant surgery, a common practice until the 1980s, when research showed that it was not only inhumane but harmful to the baby's outcome. Helen was a benign force that changed infant care for the better. She is survived by her beloved children, preemie Edward Harrison and full-term Amy Harrison Sanchez, her son-in-law, Elliot Sanchez, brother Allen Herre of Panama, sister Joan Erwin of North Carolina, and her husband of forty-five years, Alfred Harrison. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Board of Trustees and staff of WNET mourn the loss of our Trustee James S. Marcus. Jim served WNET as a Trustee from 1993 to 2006 and as a Life Trustee beginning in 2006. He was Chairman of the Development Committee, and a member of the Executive, Investment, Planning, and Programming Committees. We are forever grateful for Jim's wisdom and guidance and will miss his warmth, his kindness and his great sense of humor. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Jim's beloved wife, Ellen, longtime Chairman of WNET's Patron Program. Jim's and Ellen's leadership and support of WNET have enriched the lives of millions of people across the country. James S. Tisch, Chairman Neal Shapiro, President and CEO 1/3

PISCIA--Anne J. (Drellich), 55, passed away June 30, 2015 at Rose Monahan Hospice Home in Worcester, MA following complications from ovarian cancer. She leaves her husband of 22 years, David Piscia, her daughters Emma and Rebecca Piscia, her mother Helen Drellich, brothers Steven Drellich, David Drellich and his wife Susan Mayer and Harold "Hal" Drellich and his wife Deborah Berry. Her sister Dr. Sharon Drellich and father Dr. Marvin Drellich predeceased her. She also leaves her nieces and nephews Evan and Elizabeth Drellich, Paul Leoncini, Kiera Joujoute and Sam and Max Piscia, her father and mother-in-law Dr. Peter Piscia and his wife Patricia, brother-in-law Peter Piscia and his wife Melissa, sisters-in-law Melanie Piscia and her husband Richard Dix and Donna McSweeney and her husband David. Anne was born June 10, 1960 in Manhattan, NY. She grew up in Queens and graduated from Queens College in 1982 and then earned her Master's degree at Columbia University in 1984. Her roots in New York were something she treasured throughout her life. After teaching in New York for 10 years, Anne and her husband Dave moved their family to Massachusetts. There she dedicated herself to teaching Spanish at Westborough High School for nearly 20 years. Anne was in many ways defined by the craft in her teaching, her commitment to her current and former students and her unyielding passion toward elevating foreign language education in Westborough. She will be most remembered for her love of family, her advocating for the underdog and against injustice and for her warmth and authenticity. Please honor Anne with donations to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund 14 Pennsylvania Plaza Suite 1710 New York, NY 10122 or online at www.ocrf.org or to the Pan Mass Challenge online at www.pmc.org/DPO214. All are invited to a Celebration of Anne's life July 12th at 1:00pm in the auditorium at Westborough High School 90 West Main St. Westborough, MA 01581. Burial will be private at her family's convenience. Please visit an online guestbook to share a memory of Anne or message of sympathy with her family at: www.RoneyFuneral Home.com 1/3

SOFAER-- Mozelle Ephraim Ezekiel. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Mozelle Ephraim Ezekiel Sofaer, revered matriarch of a distinguished Sephardic family from Bombay, India who led an unusual life in the history of India and Burma. She was actively involved in the charities of the Jewish Women's League and immigrated to the U.S. in 1952. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her children: Pearl; our Yeshiva College alumnus, The Hon. Abraham D. (and Marian) Sofaer who are YU Guardians; Isaac; Shoshana and their families, to her grandchildren and great grandchildren. May the entire family find comfort among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

KENNEDY--Lorraine R.,on July 6, 2015 of Pt. Washington, NY. Beloved wife of Thomas F. Kennedy. Cherished mother of Gail Kennedy (The late James C. Hoar), Glenn Kennedy (Marianne) and the Late Keith Kennedy. Loving grandmother of Patrick, Brian and Melissa. Sister of Maureen Whitaker and the late Richard Lamantia. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Thursday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Friday at 10:30am at St. Peter of Alcantara Church in Pt. Washington. 1/3

BIERER--Sally Erlanger, died on Independence Day peacefully at home after a long illness. Born in 1923, she lived her whole life in New York. A concert pianist and avid equestrienne in her youth, she immersed herself in the arts and thoroughbred racing throughout her adult life. Equally comfortable at the backstretch or the Met, she is remembered for her genuine and generous commitment to her friends and family. She valued honesty in herself and others. She was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, Fred. She leaves her daughter Linda of NY, her daughter Barbara and son-in-law Steve Hyman and their children Emily, Julia and Charles of Newton, MA, and her son Michael and daughter-in-law Elizabeth Peters Bierer and their children, Isaac and Liliana of Cambridge. A memorial service is planned for August. 1/3
