We extend our heartfelt condolences to Charlotte's husband, Dr. Sidney Feuerstein; her children, Ronnie Heyman (Samuel, z"l) and Henry Feuerstein (Elise Meyer); her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

MARCUS--James S. We mourn the passing of James Marcus, whose many decades of service on the Executive Committee of the Guild Hall Board of Trustees, and whose love of art and music shaped our institution. Jim's wisdom, generosity, commitment and wonderful nature will be greatly missed. The Trustees of Guild Hall Ruth Appelhof, Exec. Dir. Martin Cohen, Chairman 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of James S. Marcus. As Juilliard Trustee for 20 years, Jim was an enlightened leader and an enthusiastic supporter of all Juilliard programs and students. His great knowledge of and love for singers led to the establishment of the Ellen and James S. Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts at Juilliard in 2010. Jim's enthusiasm and warmth for all things Juilliard was a special gift to the members of our community and he will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ellen and all his family and friends. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Brian Zeger, Artistic Director of the Ellen and James S. Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts 1/3

HOCHMAN--Jeanette. The family of Jean Hochman sadly announce the passing of this wonderful, beautiful and loving woman, on July 4, 2015, at age 90. Her husband of 36 years, Joseph, and her sons Barry and Robert predeceased her. She is survived by her adoring daughter Debra (Robert Poss) and sister Pearl Zakarin, and many loving nieces and nephews. She radiated happiness and optimism, and lived for her family. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. A funeral service is scheduled for Wednesday, July 8 at noon at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY. 1/3

BARTONE--Richard Charles, 55, of Las Vegas, passed away peacefully Friday, July 3, 2015, after a hard-fought battle with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL.) He was a senior wealth management advisor at Merrill Lynch. Richard was a funny, gregarious, creative, humble and loving singular light that shone brightly in a dark crowded room. He is survived by his wife and son, Alejandra and Lorenzo Bartone, his parents, Donald and Norma Bartone, his sister, Carol Pawuk, and his nephew, Greg Rassen among others. Memorial contributions can be made to The James Cancer Hospital and Solove Research Institute. A check made payable to OSU Foundation may be mailed to P.O. Box 183112, Columbus OH 43218-3112. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The Animal Medical Center (AMC) mourn the loss of fellow board member and friend, James Marcus. An AMC Trustee member since 1988, Jim will be remembered for his incomparable fund- raising skills; as well as his enthusiastic dedication to help shape the Center's commitment to ensure ongoing compassionate patient care and education. During his tenure, Mr. Marcus was an astute advisor on the finance committee and was an honoree in 2005 at the annual Top Dog Gala for his generous support of AMC. Mr. Marcus was an avid animal lover with a passion for the arts and an unwavering supporter of the mission of The Animal Medical Center. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ellen and all those who were touched by the warmth of his friendship. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Board of 720 Park Avenue Corporation deeply regret the loss of James S. Marcus, former President and invaluable member of the board for over thirty years. The board and staff of 720 Park Avenue extend our most sincere condolences to his wife Ellen and the entire Marcus family. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. Lifelong friend of Roy and Barbara Goodman, loving "adopted" father to Claire and Rusty Cloud, Leslie, Randy and Molly Goodman, and "adopted" grandfather to all their kids. Cherished confidant whose warm, inviting smile and deeply resonant voice of reason kept us all on a steady, positive path as our lives evolved. This Earth will never know a kinder and more generous soul! Your spirit and intelligence shall guide us for the rest of our days. Heartfelt sympathies to dear Ellen, devoted wife of 41 years and condolences to the entire Marcus family. 1/3

ROSEN--Marvin. Schechter School of Long Island mourns the passing of Marvin Rosen, former Board President and Chair of the Board. Marvin most recently co-chaired SSLI's NYSAIS Self-Study. His contribution to Jewish Day School education at SSLI was immeasurable. He will be sorely missed. Baruch Dayan Emet. Ira Balsam, President. Cindy Dolgin, Head of School. 1/3
POLEY--Neil M.,husband of Ruth Gerard Poley, father of Philip and Samuel, passed away in Cary, NC on July 4. 1/3

FEUERSTEIN--Charlotte Clein. Beloved and cherished wife of Dr. Sidney Feuerstein for nearly 70 years, treasured mother of Ronnie Heyman (Samuel z"l) and Henry Feuerstein (Elise Meyer). Grandmother of Lazarus Heyman (Kim), Eleanor Heyman Propp, Jennifer Millstone (David) and Elizabeth Heyman Winter; John Feuerstein (Ilana) and Amanda Bushell (Matt). Proud great-grandmother of twelve: Si, Sheldon, and Solomon Heyman, Stella, Juliette, and Clara Propp, Pippa, Francie, Samuelle and Marielle Millstone, Charlie Winter, and Jacob Feuerstein. Private service in Palm Beach. Her abiding commitment to Jewish life and family was an inspiration to all and her love made each of us better. 1/3

ESTIS--Jean Rosenberg & Estis, P.C. founding member Warren Estis' mother, Jean Estis, age 104, of West Palm Beach, FL, passed away at her home on July 5, 2015, of natural causes. She was born in Poland on November 26, 1910. At the age of 12, she arrived with her family in New York City. She became a legal secretary and worked at a law firm where she met her future husband Nathan Estis, an attorney. They wed in 1941 and were married for 61 years. The couple raised two sons, Martin and Warren. Mrs. Estis was a proud grandmother to four grandchildren, Alexander, Danielle, Michelle and Ilene. Mrs. Estis continued to work as legal secretary in addition to raising a family. She later returned to Queens Borough College in New York City to earn a degree, and thereafter became a secretary in the New York City school system. Mrs. Estis was active in various organizations including Cancer Care, B'nai B'rith and Hadassah and attended many charity events. She was also active in the local synagogue. She enjoyed knitting, crocheting and needlepoint and was an avid collector of Lladro, Lalique and Royal Doulton figurines. Mrs. Estis and her husband traveled extensively around the world, and particularly enjoyed cruises and attending Broadway shows. She was very active, and loved dancing and playing mahjong. A private funeral for Mrs. Estis was held on July 7, 2015, at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evening at the home of Warren Estis. 1/3

THOMANN--John, died on July 4, 2015. The people of Turner Construction Company are deeply saddened at the loss of their colleague John Thomann. John, a leader in the construction industry in New York, served as vice president and general manager of Turner's Interiors group in New York for the past ten years. John, who was diagnosed with cancer six years ago, is survived by his wife, Kathleen, daughter Jacqueline and son James. Upon graduation from Manhattan College in 1987, John joined Turner Construction Company in New York. Among his leadership roles at the company were as Superintendent, Purchasing Manager and Project Executive. Under his leadership, the New York Interiors group has long been recognized as one of the leading interiors contractors in New York. A native of Queens, he had a positive impact across New York City as he led the delivery of services to clients in the commercial office, retail, hospitality, sports and entertainment, education, and government sectors. John also made a difference through his leadership and support of community and industry organizations. John received the Victory Award for outstanding commitment to charitable giving from the Saint Dominic's Home, the Francis Award from the St. Francis Food Pantries and Shelters for his outstanding charitable works, and the Progress of Peoples Achievement Award from Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens for outstanding leadership and commitment to creating secure homes in a caring community for low-income seniors and families, the disabled and formerly homeless. John's friendship, leadership, service and mentorship will be missed by all that knew him. Visitation will be held at Connell Funeral Home at 934 New York Ave. in Huntington Station, NY on Wednesday July 8 from 2:00 - 4:00 and 7:00 - 9:00. Mass will be held at St. Elizabeth's Church at 175 Wolf Hill Road in Melville, NY on Thursday at 9:30. All of us at Turner 1/3

ETON--Bella, of Larchmont, passed away July 7, 2015, at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Maxwell, devoted mother of Susan, cherished grandmother of Felicia and Richard, Allison and Alan, Jennifer and Marc, and great-grandmother of Simon, James, Annabel, Maya, Sophia, Lily, and Zoe. For more information, www.zion memorialchapel.com. 1/3

FEUERSTEIN--Charlotte. It is with deep sorrow that we have learned of the passing of Charlotte. Charlotte with her beloved husband Sidney, dear friends for almost 50 years. Charlotte personified infectious friendship, enthusiasm, and uplifting happiness. Whenever we were together she was always beautiful and bright. A pleasure to be with. We recall with pleasure the many occasions we spent together. Especially the Rosh Hashana dinners with the Feuerstein family. Charlotte and Sidney played a major role at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue to the benefit of its members. To Sidney, Ronnie, Henry, the grandchildren and the great- children our heartfelt condolences. May her memory be a blessing. We loved you Charlotte and shall miss you. May you rest in peace. Ingeborg and Ira Leon Rennert Tamara and Randall Nina and Mitchell Ari and Erynne 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Rita and Alex Hillman Foundation mourns the loss of its beloved Board President, James S. Marcus, who helped lead the Foundation for over two decades. An ardent champion of nursing and patient-centered care, he was committed to supporting work that benefited those most in need. His wit, wisdom and deep humanity will be profoundly missed by the entire Hillman community. We extend our love and heartfelt condolences to his wife Ellen and all his family and friends. Ahrin Mishan, Executive Director 1/3

BIERER--Sally Erlanger, died on Independence Day peacefully at home after a long illness. Born in 1923, she lived her whole life in New York. A concert pianist and avid equestrienne in her youth, she immersed herself in the arts and thoroughbred racing throughout her adult life. Equally comfortable at the backstretch or the Met, she is remembered for her genuine and generous commitment to her friends and family. She valued honesty in herself and others. She was predeceased by her husband of 49 years, Fred. She leaves her daughter Linda of NY, her daughter Barbara and son-in-law Steve Hyman and their children Emily, Julia and Charles of Newton, MA, and her son Michael and daughter-in-law Elizabeth Peters Bierer and their children, Isaac and Liliana of Cambridge. A memorial service is planned for August. 1/3

ZEGANS--Dr. Leonard, on July 7, 2015. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Marc and Michael. Dear brother of Natalie. Cherished Papa to his grandchildren. Service: Friday, July 10, 12 noon, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

BACON--Nancy Ellen, born in Bronxville, New York and longtime resident of Manhattan, passed away peacefully on July 3, 2015. Loving daughter of John and Laurel Bacon who predeceased her, sister of John and his wife Margaret, aunt of Matt, Holly, Erin and Allie, companion of Bill Frasca, and good friend to many. Nancy was a talented artist and designer and was devoted to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Miss Hall's School and Kenyon College, among other interests. Her warmth, intellect, wit and courage touched all who knew her and are part of her lasting gift to us. The family is grateful for the compassionate care Nancy received from New York Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell and MJHS Hospice, The Muriel and Harold Block Residence. Nancy, we will miss and remember you. God bless. 1/3

FEUERSTEIN--Charlotte. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Walter J. Molofsky, M.D., Chairman Jacob D. Gold, President 1/3

ESTIS--Jean Rosenberg & Estis, P.C. founding member Warren Estis' mother, Jean Estis, age 104, of West Palm Beach, FL, passed away at her home on July 5, 2015, of natural causes. She was born in Poland on November 26, 1910. At the age of 12, she arrived with her family in New York City. She became a legal secretary and worked at a law firm where she met her future husband Nathan Estis, an attorney. They wed in 1941 and were married for 61 years. The couple raised two sons, Martin and Warren. Mrs. Estis was a proud grandmother to four grandchildren, Alexander, Danielle, Michelle and Ilene. Mrs. Estis continued to work as legal secretary in addition to raising a family. She later returned to Queens Borough College in New York City to earn a degree, and thereafter became a secretary in the New York City school system. Mrs. Estis was active in various organizations including Cancer Care, B'nai B'rith and Hadassah and attended many charity events. She was also active in the local synagogue. She enjoyed knitting, crocheting and needlepoint and was an avid collector of Lladro, Lalique and Royal Doulton figurines. Mrs. Estis and her husband traveled extensively around the world, and particularly enjoyed cruises and attending Broadway shows. She was very active, and loved dancing and playing mahjong. A private funeral for Mrs. Estis was held on July 7, 2015, at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. The family will be sitting Shiva Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evening at the home of Warren Estis. 1/3

LARIC--Roberta Kine. On July 7, 2015. Beloved wife of Dr. Michael Laric. Devoted mother of Shai Laric, Pnina Laric (Eli Glaser), Ari (Brooke) Laric; dear sister of Leah (Ralph) Bernstein; loving daughter of the late Aaron and Miriam Kine; adored grandmother of Zev A. Glaser, Matan E. Glaser, Jackson J. Laric, Maya J. Laric and Samuel J. Laric. Services were held at Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc., Baltimore, MD. (www.sollevinson,com), on Wednesday, July 8. Interment Baltimore, MD. Please omit flowers. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Howard County Conservancy, www.hcconservancy.org. In mourning at 4609 Morning Ride Court, Ellicott City, MD 21042. 1/3
PREISS--Byron. Pioneering Digital Publisher iBooks Mensch Friend Miss Your Smile and Hugs 1/3

MARCUS--James. We lost a wonderful friend. I first met Jimmy Marcus in 1943 when he was a student in the 9th grade at the New Lincoln School. There, he and Roy Goodman began a lifetime friendship that lasted almost 60 years, and I was able to tag along. Over the years, the three of us developed a wonderfully close relationship. Jimmy always had a twinkle in his eye and was almost always the smartest and wittiest person in the room. He was brilliant, humorous, charming, and a man of extraordinary philanthropy and compassion. His sincerity was such that he would always tell it like it was, and he was a man of incredible principle. Dalia and I send a loving embrace to wonderful Ellen, his magnificent wife of so many years. With love and sympathy, DaliaLarry 1/3
LUSBY--Rick. Dear brother, I will never not remember you. Love you deeply, Donna 1/3

FIORAMONTI--Frank R.,died June 27 peacefully at home with his beloved wife, Sheila, at his side. In his 73rd year, Frank was an attorney and administrative law judge. Spending his career in public service, he was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Law and received an LLM from NYU Law. Adored husband of Sheila and father to her children, Brandi and Vance, and grandfather to Juliette and Austin; survived by his sister, Marie. A memorial will be held at a future date. 1/3

KUGLER--Roger, 58, Cross Timbers, MO, formerly of New York City, passed Friday, June 26, 2015. He was named 2009 Top Sommelier at the Copa de Jerez in Spain, a member of Screen Actors Guild, former wine director/ sommelier at The Jefferson, Suba and a consultant for the Gregory White PR firm. Online obituary at www.reserfuneralhome.com. 1/3

BUNCHE--Joan Harris, died unexpectedly and peacefully of natural causes at her home in New York on June 23rd, 2015. She was 83. Joan was the first child of Dr. Ralph Johnson Bunche and Mrs Ruth Harris Bunche. She graduated from The Westtown School, Vassar College and Columbia University where she received a Master's Degree in Sociology. She began her working life in publishing, but soon moved to the United Nations Development Program where she worked for more than two decades as a writer and editor. In her working life she found a unique way to further the goals of her cherished father - equality, human dignity, peace and international understanding. She was most proud of her role as a volunteer for the voter registration movement in Mississippi in 1960 and as a UN Observer for South Africa's first democratic election. Joan had a full life with many friends and many interests in New York and enjoyed travelling the world. She will be fondly remembered by her family and friends for her generosity, charm, warmth and most of all for her indomitable individualism. She is survived by her brother, sisters-in-law and seven nieces and nephews. A celebration of her life will be held in the fall. 1/3

HARRISON--Helen Herre, died in the early morning of July 4, after fighting a mysterious and undiagnosed illness for five years. Helen was the author of The Premature Baby Book, a guide for parents that went through seventeen printings and was known as "The Bible" in neonatal intensive care nurseries. She went on to advocate for parents, insisting that they, rather than doctors, have the right to make life and death decisions in extreme cases. She insisted that doctors give parents a realistic prognosis for survivors of neonatal intensive care. She opposed doctors' tendencies to reassure parents that everything would turn out well, when studies showed the opposite. She was also in the forefront of the movement to ban unanesthetized infant surgery, a common practice until the 1980s, when research showed that it was not only inhumane but harmful to the baby's outcome. Helen was a benign force that changed infant care for the better. She is survived by her beloved children, preemie Edward Harrison and full-term Amy Harrison Sanchez, her son-in-law, Elliot Sanchez, brother Allen Herre of Panama, sister Joan Erwin of North Carolina, and her husband of forty-five years, Alfred Harrison. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. American Composers Orchestra mourns the loss of longtime board member, vice- chairman and cherished friend Jim Marcus. A giant figure on the New York music scene, Jim was the kindest, wittiest, and most generous of supporters of American music. We will miss him dearly. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Ellen and the family. 1/3

FEUERSTEIN-- Charlotte Clein. Yeshiva University and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law extend their heartfelt condolences to Ronnie Heyman, a former member of the YU Board of Trustees and Cardozo and a current honorary member of Cardozo's Board of Overseers, and the entire family on the loss of their matriarch, Charlotte Clein Feuerstein. The beloved wife of Dr. Sidney Feuerstein for almost 70 years, and a devoted mother to Ronnie (and Samuel z"l) and Henry Feuerstein (and Elise Meyer), Charlotte leaves behind a legacy of a beautiful Jewish family, including her grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Her dedication to Jewish life, community and family remains an inspiration for us at Yeshiva and Cardozo. May Ronnie and the entire family find strength and comfort in their memories in the years to come. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

JAKUBEC--Barbara L.,89, February 18, 1926 - June 7, 2015. Devoted mother of Gretchen Garrett (Jeff) and the late John Sloate; grandmother of Timothy and Ian (Justine) Garrett; great- grandmother of Miles. Veteran NYC public school educator; world traveler/art devotee, eternally wearing red, her signature color. Services held privately. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to Scleroderma Foundation, 300 Rosewood Dr., Suite 105, Danvers, MA 01923. 1/3

KEANE--Kerry Colin. Died suddenly June 12 at the age of 46. Kerry grew up in Port Washington, NY, and graduated from Schreiber High School in 1987. He earned a bachelor's degree from Wisconsin (Madison) in 1991, and was a brother of Sigma Alpha Epsilon. He went on to earn a master's degree from NYU in 1995. An early career in real estate banking led to positions at The Bank of Nova Scotia (Syndication and Investment), and at Fitch. He left to form an Internet company, Rush New Media. He held various gaming patents and copyrights. His associates will remember him as an astute banker and innovator; his friends will recall a genial and talented raconteur; and his family will miss him as a loving son, nephew, cousin and a shining light in all their lives. Memorial service 10:30am on July 11th at St. Peter's of Alcantara Church, Port Washington, NY. 1/3

BOURGOIS--Pierre, died peacefully 7 July 2015 in Sagaponack, New York. Born in Paris 13 November 1922, he graduated from Hautes Etudes Commerciales (HEC) in 1946. He was deported to Auschwitz during WWII as a forced laborer. He joined the United Nations in New York in 1949 retiring as Assistant Secretary General in 1984 in Geneva, Switzerland where he resided. He is survived by his children Nicole and Philippe and five grandchildren. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The staff and Board of Directors of Young Concert Artists are deeply saddened by the passing of James S. Marcus. He took such great pleasure in listening to and helping young artists, and we will miss his jovial, knowledgeable and enthusiastic presence. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Ellen, Vice Chairman of the Board of Young Concert Artists. Michael Nash Ambler, Chairman of the Board Susan Wadsworth, Director 1/3

PREISS--Byron. April 11, 1953 - July 9, 2005 A man full of compassion and bold ideas. You are missed every day, but continue to exist in the world you showed to us. Your life teaches us to never be without love, laughter & learning. Love forever and ever, Sandi, Karah & Blaire 1/3

BOYLE--Thomas F.,76, died Sunday in his home in Carlisle, PA. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Jamieson, father of William T. Boyle. English professor at Brooklyn College 1969-2010. Author of five books, including three mystery novels set in Brooklyn. Guggenheim fellow. A lover of good writing, good stories and good times. He will be missed. 1/3

KEANE--Kerry Colin. Died suddenly June 12 at the age of 46. Kerry grew up in Port Washington, NY, and graduated from Schreiber High School in 1987. He earned a bachelor's degree from Wisconsin (Madison) in 1991, and was a brother of Sigma Alpha Epsilon. He went on to earn a master's degree from NYU in 1995. An early career in real estate banking led to positions at The Bank of Nova Scotia (Syndication and Investment), and at Fitch. He left to form an Internet company, Rush New Media. He held various gaming patents and copyrights. His associates will remember him as an astute banker and innovator; his friends will recall a genial and talented raconteur; and his family will miss him as a loving son, nephew, cousin and a shining light in all their lives. Memorial service 10:30am on July 11th at St. Peter's of Alcantara Church, Port Washington, NY. 1/3

His granddaughter Isabella predeceases him. A memorial Mass will be celebrated on July 18, 2015 at 10:00am at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St. 1/3

MARCUS--James. Penn Nursing celebrates the life of James Marcus and extends heartfelt condolences to Ellen Marcus and his family. As president of the Hillman Foundation Board, Jim was a dedicated supporter of Hillman Scholars, Hillman Alumni, and nurses everywhere. 1/3

GAMPERT--Richard, D, PhD, of New York City, NY and Boca Raton, FL, passed away July 6, 2015. Beloved husband of Henry Olivas-Guido of New York City and Boca Raton. A Loving brother to Caryll Greene and her husband Steven of North Easton, MA. Survived by numerous cousins. Doctor Gampert, Assistant Dean of Institutional Research had recently retired from the faculty of Eugenio Maria de Hostos Community College of the City University of New York. Funeral services will be held on Monday July 13, 2015 at 2:00pm at the Frank Campbell funeral home at 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, NYC. Burial will be private. Visiting hours at the funeral home will be held on Sunday July 12, 2015 from 4:00pm to 8:00pm. Friends and family are invited to the home of Richard and Henry on Monday July 13th, 2015 from 5:00pm to 8:00pm. Visiting hours at the home of Caryll and Steve Greene will be held on Wednesday July 15, 2015 from 2:00 to 8:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to MGH Hersch Lab, GM1 Project c/o MGH East, Building #

ARFA--Barbara Gutfruend, passed away peacefully at the age of 68 on July 9, 2015 in her home in Manhattan. Beloved wife of Harvey, devoted mother of Caroline and son-in-law, Morris Massel, and intensely adoring and adored grandmother of Rebecca, Alexander and Michael. She was the daughter of the late Salo and Regina Gutfreund, who were survivors of the Holocaust. Until 2010, she was co-president with her husband of Gruner & Co., Inc., a men's outerwear company established in 1949 by her late father. Over her life, she dedicated herself to many Jewish causes and organizations. She was diligent and tireless in all of her undertakings and relationships. She valiantly fought a long battle with lung cancer. She will be sorely missed. May her memory be a blessing for good. 1/3

WEIL--Gertrude, of Queens, NY passed away on July 3, 2015 in West Orange, NJ. Born in Prague, Czechoslovakia on December 17, 1920, daughter of Joseph and Margaret Keat (deceased) and sister of Paul (deceased). Married to Erwin Weil (deceased). Survived by children Doris and Edward Weil, daughter-in-law Anne Berman, grandsons Gregory and Joseph, first cousins David and Peter Kett, and niece Diana Keat. Graveside service at Knollwood Park Cemetery on Sunday, July 12th at 11am. Please send contributions to: www.barnabashealth.org/ supporthospice. 1/3

KESSEL--George, of Delray Beach, FL, on July 07, 2015, formerly of Bergenfield, NJ. George was born and raised in Bergenfield. He graduated Bergenfield High School and attended Newark College of Engineering. He is survived by his loving wife Joan, nee Piekarsky, of 60 years, his son Jeffrey and his wife, Jacqueline of Woodcliff Lake, and their children Jake and Graham and son Steven and his wife, Stephanie of Old Tappan, and their children Scott and Heather. George had many interests and hobbies. He was an avid bike rider and sailor, skippering a sailboat at the famed Block Island Race Week and winning many trophies. His interests also included motor homing, fishing, traveling, ham radio, and collecting vintage Ford "Model A's," which he drove in many local parades. He was a successful businessman for over 50 years running both his construction company, Bergen County Iron Works, and his real estate development firm, Kessel Associates. Buildings he built can be prominently seen all over northern New Jersey. He was a two-term president of the National Association of Industrial and Office Parks; as well as president of the health club at the YM/YWHA in Hackensack. He served on the Board of Directors of Midlantic Bank, and was a trustee of Englewood Hospital. His greatest business achievement was being elected Developer of the Year by the NAIOP. George was extremely philanthropic giving to charities, too many to count. He founded the George Kessel Charitable Foundation over 40 years ago, which continues to give generously to many worthy causes. Funeral services will take place on Sunday July 12, 2015 at 1:15pm at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ 07647. The period of mourning will take place at the home of Jeffrey and Jacqueline Kessel immediately following the entombment service on Sunday until 9pm with a Minyan service at 8pm and Monday 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm with Minyan services at 8pm. Should friends desire, contributions in George's memory may be made to a charity of your choice. For further information, visit: www. guttermanmusicantwien .com or call 201-489-3800. 1/3

WINSTON--Gary. Our family is deeply saddened to announce that Gary Winston passed away in his sleep while in ICU on Friday, June 19th. As many are aware, Gary has been suffering from several medical conditions over these past many years and yet has been able to surmount these conditions and live with his pain. He was dealt an unexpected setback for which there was no treatment due to his 23 year chronic liver disorder. Thankfully, he learned of this illness only two days prior to his death. We are relieved that his passing was peaceful. He is survived by his daughter Jenny, his sister Miranda, his brother Brad and his sister-in-law Sandra. Gary's memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 16th at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament located at 152 West 71st Street, just east of Broadway, at 4pm. 1/3

SMILOW--Jill. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our member, Jill Smilow, beloved wife of Marc Smilow. We will miss her incredible caring and passionate devotion to family, friends and faith. Our deepest condolences to Marc, their children, Haley and Ethan, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

ROSSMAN--Jerome I.,Jr. Jerome I. Rossman Jr., 88 years old, formerly of Scarsdale and Purchase, New York, passed away peacefully at his home in Jupiter, Florida on Wednesday, July 8, 2015, surrounded by his family. Jerry proudly served his country in the U.S. Marine Corps. He was a truly kind man who had many significant friendships in all aspects of his life, and will be remembered dearly by all for his keen sense of humor, his loyalty and his love of family. Jerry dedicated his life to furthering education and independence for individuals who learn differently. He served as Chairman of the Board of The Maplebrook School in Amenia, NY which focuses on quality academic programs for youngsters with learning differences. Maplebrook provides individualized instruction, where students are assisted in reaching his/her academic, social, vocational and physical potential. Jerry and his wife, Eva, were deeply involved with Maplebrook and the Maplebrook "Parents Association" for many years, which their son, Peter, attended. As Peter was graduating from Maplebrook, Jerry and two other Maplebrook parents founded Chapel Haven, with the vision to establish an independent living facility in New Haven, CT providing lifelong individualized services for people with developmental and social disabilities, empowering them to live independent and self- determined lives. Jerry's devotion and determination paid off. Today, Chapel Haven is an award-winning, nationally accredited school and transitional program serving 250-plus adults with a variety of abilities and needs. Chapel Haven teaches independent living. Jerry is survived by his loving wife of over 60 years, Eva; his adoring children, Peter Rossman, Karen Fleck and Bryan Fleck, husband of Karen. He was predeceased by his parents, Jerome and Alva Rossman and his sisters, Florence Asch and Barbara Engel. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Maplebrook School. Memorial donations in Jerry's name may be made to Maplebrook School: www.maplebrookschool.org or Chapel Haven: www.chapelhaven.org 1/3

KLEIN--Lawrence M. On July 2, 2015 Lawrence M. Klein, passed peacefully. He was born September 20, 1953 in Brooklyn, NY. Jack's dedication to SAB and utmost regard for the well-being of our students always will be remembered. We send our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Ian and family. Max R. Shulman, Chairman of the Board Peter Martins, Chairman of Faculty Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director 1/3

JOSEPH--Stephen H.,Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Stephen Joseph. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. 1/3

SUSSER--Herbert, 93, died July 9, peacefully at home. Devoted husband of the late Doris Susser. Loving father of Mitchell Susser and Loren Palmer (Brandon). Adoring grandfather of Shira and Carly. He will be remembered as a loving brother, uncle, friend, confidant, and adviser. He brought joy to all who knew him. He will be forever in our hearts. Funeral: July 12 at 11am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made to: Hospice Care Network of Long Island or Temple Sinai of Roslyn, NY. 1/3

PARDEE--Aida M. Aida M. Pardee, 73 years old, breathed her last on Monday evening with her husband, Scott E. Pardee, and her son, Alan A. Pardee, holding her hands and with her daughter-in-law, Sally Morris, at her bedside. She was a strong, caring, intelligent, passionate, courageous, hard-working, elegant, and accomplished woman. She was loving and generous to those around her and protective of those in her family circle. She cared deeply about people and wanted the people around her to succeed and be happy in life and to live joyfully in the moment while also preparing carefully for the future. She impressed on all who would listen the importance of family, education, hard work, and active, intellectual involvement in the world around us. She was quieter about discussing her faith, but shared it most with the people closest to her in hopes of guiding them to know the nearness of God. For her, all of these topics were very much intertwined. She was born in the Dominican Republic and moved to her adopted country with her marriage to Scott Pardee on January 29, 1966. They had two children, Alan, who survives her, and Cynthia Lynn Pardee. She was devoted to them and to her family. She was an international economist and worked for a number of years at Bankers Trust (long since merged into Deutsche Bank) and at Marine Midland Bank (which in the end of her time there was acquired by what was then still called Hong Kong Shanghai Bank Corp, now known as HSBC). She represented her firms on four continents over her time working in the field. She became a citizen of the United States. She was a strong-willed woman and a survivor by nature, having lived through a war in her native country, deaths of family members, and the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, diagonally across the street from where she and her husband lived. It is with sadness that her family reports that she did not survive her quiet battle with cancer. She is survived by a loving family here in New York, throughout the US, and in Santo Domingo who miss her and will cherish her memory. 1/3

TATE--James: The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. Absurdly funny or hauntingly tragic, his poems will continue to delight the hearts and minds of his readers. 1

GELBER--Jules May 18, 1941-July 9, 2015. Beloved husband of Carol Rifkind Gelber. Devoted father of Lisa, Shari and her husband Adam Ratner, and Naomi and her husband Jeremy Grunzweig. Adored grandfather of Samantha, Matthew, Sophie, Kevin, and Zahara. Loving brother of Irene Danz. 1/3

HARRIS--Ellen W. July 7, 2015. Ellen's friends loved, admired and respected her She will be sorely missed. Our thoughts are with her family. Alejandra Cicognani, Suzanne Kline Collins, Jeannie Minskoff Grant, Carolina Sterling, Jacqueline Parker Togut 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronnie. There are no words to express our sorrow at the passing of Ronnie. He was a special friend and will be missed by all. Our thoughts are with you and your family. With deepest sympathy and love, Vicki, Eva and Ralph 1/3

GALLIPOLI--Nicholas M.,age 79, of Maywood, NJ, passed away at home surrounded by his wife and children on July 9, 2015. Born in Hoboken, NJ, he graduated in 1954 from A.J. Demarest High School. He worked at U.S. Steel in New York City from 1954 until 1977 and International Tool and Supply from 1977 until he retired. In addition, Nick was president of the National Oil Equipment Manufacturers And Delegates Society (NOMADS) and was recognized with a Senior Regents Service Award in 1997. Nick is survived by his beloved wife of 51 years, Lorraine (Di Angelo) Gallipoli; six children, Frank Gallipoli and his wife Christine of NY, NY, Lisa Sallemi and her husband Ron of Paramus, NJ, Louis Gallipoli and his wife Linda of Wayne, NJ, Nicholas Gallipoli and his wife Toni of Paramus, NJ, Lorraine Palumbo and her husband Ken of Westport, CT, and Steven Gallipoli of Maywood, NJ; and 13 grandchildren. Friends may visit Sunday, July 12 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm at Trinka-Faustini, 439 Maywood Ave, Maywood, NJ. Service on Monday, July 13 at 11:00 am at Madonna Mausoleum, 2070 Hoefley's Ln, Fort Lee, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made in Nick's name to "Trustees of Columbia University". Please specify "for research of Dr. Gary K. Schwartz". 177 Fort Washington Ave, Suite 6GN-435, New York, NY 10032. 1/3
SUGARMAN--Daniel A. PhD, died July 3, 2015. He was a clinical psychologist, author, and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ron. He loved life and it loved him back! He loved and adored his wife, Adrien. She loved him back - they were soul mates. Ron was a man of great strength, generosity, and kindness. Proud of his daughter, Lauren and his grandchildren. Ron did make a difference! Vivian Serota 1/3

TATNALL--Samuel. Samuel Mathew Vauclain Tatnall. February 14, 1939-June 16, 2015. Teacher, scientist, rock climber and lifelong explorer, Sam Tatnall passed away on June 16th with his wife Bitsy and goddaughter Daisy at his side. He is survived by his stepson, Marshall Field, brothers Frank G. Tatnall and David V. Tatnall and sister, Caroline Jopes. Trained at Cornell, Haverford College and Harvard, he taught AP physics and computer science to boys for 22 years at Chestnut Hill Academy, William Penn Charter School and The Haverford School in Philadelphia. He co-founded software development firm, Scherrer Resources and then joined Mobius, developing desktop and web applications. A devotee of the natural world, he was an avid organic gardener at home in Bedford, NY and rock climbed around the world. His mentorship of students and coworkers, generosity of spirit and integrity of character will be remembered dearly. There will be a celebration of Sam's life at the Harvard Club in the fall. Contributions in Sam's name can be made to the music or environmental organization of your choice. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. With deepest sympathy, we mourn the passing of our dear friend, Ron, loving companion and soul mate to Adrien, adoring father to Lauren and doting grandfather to Philip and Ashley. His warmth made everyone feel like family. Lucy, Jeff and Alan 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald M.,age 84, passed away July 9, 2015, at his summer home in Southampton, New York, leaving his beloved wife Adrien, loving daughter Lauren, and devoted grandchildren Ashley and Philip Greenwald, as well as his favorite nephew Robert Gewant. He was a graduate of Bowling Green University and a distinguished naval officer. He went on to a successful career as the owner of Display Creations, a company that he grew from the ground up to cater primarily to Fortune 500 companies across the globe. A resident of Palm Beach, he was a member of the Friars Club, Trump International, the Breakers Golf Club, Mar-a-Logo, and Hampton Hills. He was an extremely charitable man and was loved and respected by his many friends and family. He leaves behind a family that is forever grateful for wisdom, guidance, and love. Services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 St, New York City, Monday, July 13, at 11:00am. 1/3

WATTERS--Jack T.,MD The staff, trustees and Fellows of The New York Academy of Medicine mourn the passing of Dr. Jack T. Watters, a beloved Fellow and Trustee of the Academy since 2013. Jack was a tireless advocate and invaluable supporter, deeply committed to the improvement of public health and health care not only in New York City, but nationally and globally. We will miss his sparkling Scottish wit and charm, his generosity of spirit, his wisdom and the warmth of his friendship. We send our condolences to Jack's loving spouse, Ian Archer-Watters, and to his extended family. Sincerely, Dr. Jo Boufford, President Dr. George Thibault, Chairman 1/3

WATTERS--Dr. Jack The Board and staff of Research!America mourn the loss of Dr. Jack Watters. We are deeply grateful for his years of service as an elected member of our Board of Directors. His insights and energetic commitment to our mission of making research for health a much higher national priority were unmatched. Dr. Watters was a generous man with a warm spirit. His legacy is strong; we will miss him dearly. Hon. John Edward Porter, Chair Mary Woolley, President and CEO Research!America Alexandria, VA 1/3

ASPIAZU de VITERI--Maria Luisa, 1922-2015, died at the age of 93, at the Queens Boulevard Extended Care Facility in Woodside. Her three surviving daughters; Ana Maria, Greta and Magda; and her grandchildren, Michael, Ivan and Chantal: were by her side as she took her last breaths. For the past thirty years Maria Luisa resided in Jackson Heights, Queens. She was born in Juan Montalvo, Los Rios, Ecuador and subsequently took residence in Guayaquil. Maria Luisa was the family trail-blazer for the Viteri's: she moved first by herself, to NYC approximately in 1975, for a better life opportunity for her family. She was followed to NYC by her beloved late husband Hugo Federico; her then four daughters including her beloved late daughter, Bella, and her grandson Michael. Maria Luisa's first line-of- work in NYC was within the garment industry. Whenever anyone would visit with her, they would talk and laugh for hours. They never wanted to leave! She was not a complainer; she influenced her four daughters who all made something of themselves, in this challenging world of ours. She was practical, family and education minded and a proud practicing Roman Catholic! She had a gift to make anyone laugh no matter how difficult the circumstances. She was also a fantastic cook, and mediator, (family squabbles). Maria Luisa had an unmistakable inviting smile and picked up Ivan and Chantal (during their formative years) from St. Joan of Arc on Wednesdays (1/2 days) for memorable lunches. In addition to her daughters and grandchildren; Maria Luisa is survived by her granddaughter, Johanna; great grandsons, Jacob and Isaac; son-in-law, Stephen and numerous family members and friends. Maria Luisa will be in our hearts forever! And now she may rejoin Hugo Federico and Bella! 1/3

WATTERS--Jack. The School of American Ballet mourns the loss of our board member, Jack Watters. For over a decade, Jack served SAB with steadfast loyalty and generosity. His highly refined intellect, graciousness, and joyful appreciation of the School endeared him to all. Jack's dedication to SAB and utmost regard for the well-being of our students always will be remembered. We send our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Ian and family. Max R. Shulman, Chairman of the Board Peter Martins, Chairman of Faculty Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director 1/3

Cherished husband of Wendy Greene Chaikin, beloved father of Seth and Zachary and father-in-law of Stephanie, adored grandfather of Michael, Harley, Bradley and Gavin, loving brother to Robert and Marilyn (deceased), Eric and Stacey (deceased) and Karen and nephews and nieces Reed and Gregg, Shari, Kyle, Lee and Wendy, Shana, Rebecca, Kimberly and Chris, Nikki and Jimmy; passed away suddenly on July 4, 2015. FOLB--Blossom. Blossom Folb was born in Brooklyn, New York on January 10, 1920 and passed away in her sleep on June 14, 2015. Throughout her life and career as a painter, sculptor, jewelry designer and educator she considered herself a New Yorker. This remained true even after she and her husband, artist, playwright and television writer Jay Folb moved to Los Angeles, California in 1974. He passed away in 1997. Blossom was a visionary artist, working in many media, merging her profound spirituality with representational work, while always revealing her unique perspective of life. Blossom designed jewelry for Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels. Her designs were considered to be striking interpretations of wearable sculpture. She was the recipient of The Heydenryk Prize, The Lena Newcastle Prize, The Margaret M. Cooper Prize and The Aileen O. Webb Prize. She is listed in Who's Who of American Women (1974-1975 edition). Blossom was a devoted student of Shri Brahmananda Sarasvati (formerly Dr. Ramamurti Mishra), a respected teacher of Yoga-Vedanta. These studies deeply influenced a significant part of her work. Blossom's boundless energy and joy profoundly affected the lives of everyone she touched and she will remain in the hearts of all who knew her. 1/3

O'GRADY--John J. III "Jack", of Garden City, New York passed away at the age of 82 on July 10, 2015. John was born in Queens, New York on March 21, 1933. He was a graduate of the College of the Holy Cross and Harvard Law School. John spent his entire professional career practicing law with Cadwalader, Wickersham and Taft in New York where he was a partner from 1966 to 1996, and where he maintained senior counsel status until his death. John is survived by his beloved spouse of 57 years, Mary "Molly" O'Grady, his children Glenn O'Grady (Peggy), Ellen Fitzgerald (Peter), Carol Costello (Mark) and Paul O'Grady (Karen), his eight grandchildren Ryan, Colleen, Kevin, Cassie, Stephen, Michael, Emily and Declan, and his sister, Maureen Clancy. A wake will be held at Fairchild Sons, Inc. in Garden City on Monday, July 13, 2015 from 2 to 4pm and 6 to 9pm. A Funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, July 14, 2015 at the Church of St. Anne in Garden City at l0am. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the College of the Holy Cross, 1 College Street, Worcester, MA 01610. 1/3

MARCUS--James S. The Board of Trustees and staff of WNET mourn the loss of our Trustee James S. Marcus. Jim served WNET as a Trustee from 1993 to 2006 and as a Life Trustee beginning in 2006. He was Chairman of the Development Committee, and a member of the Executive, Investment, Planning, and Programming Committees. We are forever grateful for Jim's wisdom and guidance and will miss his warmth, his kindness and his great sense of humor. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Jim's beloved wife, Ellen, longtime Chairman of WNET's Patron Program. Jim's and Ellen's leadership and support of WNET have enriched the lives of millions of people across the country. James S. Tisch, Chairman Neal Shapiro, President and CEO 1/3

AMBROISE--Jennifer Rigsby, of Pembroke Pines, FL, died on July 4th, 2015 after a long battle with complications from Type 1 Diabetes and liver and kidney failure. She is survived by her husband Pierre, sister Vicky and husband Tom, mother-in-law Gisele, four nieces, three nephews, five grand-nieces and nephews and her cat Lexie. Born May 4th, 1956 in New York City to Gordon and Olga Rigsby, she spent half of her early years in Cuba with her grandparents. Jenny went to the Dalton and Calhoun Schools, followed by the University of Pennsylvania. She met the love-of-her-life and husband Pierre while working at The Dalton School as Director of Financial Aid. They moved to Florida in 1999 to be near his family, where she worked in the administrations of Keiser and Broward Colleges. Jenny was passionate, fun-loving, caring and encouraging of everyone around her and absolutely loved children. We will all miss her love, support, youthful exuberance, infectious laugh and smile. A memorial service will be held in Florida in early August. Jenny was diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes as a young child. Donations in her memory should be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF). In addition, the family encourages people to consider becoming organ donors to help people like Jenny in the future. 1/3

HABERMAN--Eve. Hunter College mourns the loss of our beloved 1954 alumna. Eve was a loyal, gracious and wise friend. She loved mentoring our students, and engaging with our faculty at Roosevelt House. We will miss her bright smile. President Jennifer Raab and the Hunter College Foundation 1/3

one family By George Shannon. Illustrated by Blanca Gómez. 32 pp. Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6.)
 
“One” can mean any number of numbers, as in one bunch of bananas (five) or one box of crayons (eight) — and, in this nimble counting book, one clan of any size. Gómez’s adorable digital illustrations of friendly, bobble-headed people in moments of homey togetherness include multiracial families and two men holding hands. It’s a clever way to show the variety between and within families, and Shannon concludes with an apt reminder: We’re all part of “one earth. One world. One family.”

SCHNEIDER--Bernard G.,of Greenwich, CT passed away suddenly on July 2 at the age of 71. He will be deeply missed by his wife Frances, and children Andrew and Jessica and son-in-law Scott. FARR--Muriel Tobin. Elementary school teacher, professor, wife, mother and grandmother, died on June 21st 2015. She was 79 and lived both in Charleston, SC and Flat Rock, NC. Born in New York City in 1935, she graduated at the age of 16 from Sacred Heart of Mary High School in 1952. She attended Ladycliff College where she earned her BA degree in English in 1956. She then attended NYU where she earned her MBA in Education with a focus on Psychology while teaching kindergarten in Highland Falls. She then taught kindergarten at Garrison Union Free School before returning to Ladycliff College as a professor. In 1971 she became the Chairman of the Psychology department at Ladycliff College. She then moved into a hospital administration role where she was the assistant to the President of Saint Luke and Roosevelt Hospitals in New York City. Her last career was assisting her husband Sims with his clients. She was involved in several local community endeavors while she raised her children; serving on the Board of Trustee of the Hamilton Fish Library as well as being on the Phillipstown Community Council. Her first husband, John Edward Byrnes Jr., from Garrison, NY blessed her with four children. Her second marriage to C. Sims Farr lasted for seventeen wonderful years and this marriage ended with his passing in December of 2007. She is survived by her four children, John Byrnes, Michael Byrnes, James Byrnes and Katherine Haney as well as four stepchildren, seven grandchildren and eleven step-grandchildren. Her Memorial Service will be held on August 12th at 11am at St. Bartholomew Church, 325 Park Ave., NYC, NY 10022. 1/3

ARENTS-- John Stephen, teacher, chemist, author, humanist, and Emeritus Professor at CCNY (City College of New York), passed away on July 3, 2015. He was 88 years old. Although he suffered many illnesses throughout his life with dignity and grace, he was dedicated to science and his students. He taught and did graduate work in quantum chemistry at Columbia University from 1950 to 1956 and then became a lecturer and professor at City College until his retirement in 1991. He was co-author through five editions of a general chemistry textbook used at colleges across the United States. When he retired, after 35 years, he was Deputy Chairman of the CCNY Chemistry Department. At age 38, John met and married German-born Gabriele Schatz, a therapeutic dietitian, with whom he enjoyed a happy life for 50 years. Both before and after his retirement, Professor Arents was active with the New York Area Skeptics and the Secular Humanist Society of New York (SHSNY), of which he was Secretary from its inception in 1988, and Treasurer from 1993 to 2004. He was also Editor, from 1998 to 2002, of its newsletter, Pique, a widely respected, although sometimes denounced, mini- journal of diverse opinion that was quoted and reprinted across the US and in other countries. John Arents was a fiercely independent thinker and was critical of liberal and humanist irrationality as well as of any other kind. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. Dear Adrienne, Lauren and Family, it is with a heavy heart that we write this death notice. Ronnie Newman was a gentleman, elegant, handsome, smart and had a great sense of humor. We will miss our wonderful friend, but he will be in our fond memories forever. Adrienne may your lifetime of memories be a comfort to you. Love, Mona and Dan Morello Helene and Al Kaplan 1/3

PARDEE--Aida M. Aida M. Pardee, 73 years old, breathed her last on Monday evening with her husband, Scott E. Pardee, and her son, Alan A. Pardee, holding her hands and with her daughter-in-law, Sally Morris, at her bedside. She was a strong, caring, intelligent, passionate, courageous, hard-working, elegant, and accomplished woman. She was loving and generous to those around her and protective of those in her family circle. She cared deeply about people and wanted the people around her to succeed and be happy in life and to live joyfully in the moment while also preparing carefully for the future. She impressed on all who would listen the importance of family, education, hard work, and active, intellectual involvement in the world around us. She was quieter about discussing her faith, but shared it most with the people closest to her in hopes of guiding them to know the nearness of God. For her, all of these topics were very much intertwined. She was born in the Dominican Republic and moved to her adopted country with her marriage to Scott Pardee on January 29, 1966. They had two children, Alan, who survives her, and Cynthia Lynn Pardee. She was devoted to them and to her family. She was an international economist and worked for a number of years at Bankers Trust (long since merged into Deutsche Bank) and at Marine Midland Bank (which in the end of her time there was acquired by what was then still called Hong Kong Shanghai Bank Corp, now known as HSBC). She represented her firms on four continents over her time working in the field. She became a citizen of the United States. She was a strong-willed woman and a survivor by nature, having lived through a war in her native country, deaths of family members, and the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, diagonally across the street from where she and her husband lived. It is with sadness that her family reports that she did not survive her quiet battle with cancer. She is survived by a loving family here in New York, throughout the US, and in Santo Domingo who miss her and will cherish her memory. 1/3

MARCUS--James. We lost a wonderful friend. I first met Jimmy Marcus in 1943 when he was a student in the 9th grade at the New Lincoln School. There, he and Roy Goodman began a lifetime friendship that lasted almost 60 years, and I was able to tag along. Over the years, the three of us developed a wonderfully close relationship. Jimmy always had a twinkle in his eye and was almost always the smartest and wittiest person in the room. He was brilliant, humorous, charming, and a man of extraordinary philanthropy and compassion. His sincerity was such that he would always tell it like it was, and he was a man of incredible principle. Dalia and I send a loving embrace to wonderful Ellen, his magnificent wife of so many years. With love and sympathy, DaliaLarry 1/3

BRACHFELD--Norman, M.D.,born in Brooklyn, longtime resident of Manhattan and Washington, CT, passed away peacefully on July 9, 2015 with his beloved wife Marlene, brother Daniel, family and loved ones by his side. Dr. Brachfeld was a brilliant cardiologist, professor and author with an illustrious, wide-ranging medical career, and an adoring (and adorable!) grandfather too. He was educated at Columbia College, Washington University, Harvard Medical School, Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, New York Hospital and University College, Oxford as well as a President of the New York Cardiological Society and a Fellow of the American College of Cardiology and American College of Physicians. He proudly served in the U.S. Army Air Force. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, Monday, July 13 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations to GWCJL or VNSNY Hospice. 1/3

BRIMIGION--Mary Jeanne Varney, 81, White Plains, New York died July 1. The beloved and devoted mother, mother-in-law, and grandmother is survived by her three children, Kim of White Plains, Scott (Melissa Bowman) of Valencia, California and Wayne (Kimberly Spell) of Manhattan and three grandchildren Jillian, Sean and Eden Brimigion. She also leaves behind her former husband of 29 years and father of her children, Stephen Brimigion of Brooklyn. Jeanne was born in Rochester, New Hampshire on October 25, 1933 and raised in York, Maine. She was the only daughter of Bertha Darke and Myron Varney. Jeanne's esteemed career in healthcare spanned more than 55 years. A registered nurse, she earned her BS and MSN from Pace University in New York. Serving as Director of Nursing, she ran the Miller Nursing Homes, The Andrus Foundation, and Bayberry Care Center in Westchester County. She also was a highly sought after teacher for Kaplan, where she helped prepare future nurses to take the NYCLEX exam. 1/3

TATNALL--Samuel. Samuel Mathew Vauclain Tatnall. February 14, 1939-June 16, 2015. Teacher, scientist, rock climber and lifelong explorer, Sam Tatnall passed away on June 16th with his wife Bitsy and goddaughter Daisy at his side. He is survived by his stepson, Marshall Field, brothers Frank G. Tatnall and David V. Tatnall and sister, Caroline Jopes. Trained at Cornell, Haverford College and Harvard, he taught AP physics and computer science to boys for 22 years at Chestnut Hill Academy, William Penn Charter School and The Haverford School in Philadelphia. He co-founded software development firm, Scherrer Resources and then joined Mobius, developing desktop and web applications. A devotee of the natural world, he was an avid organic gardener at home in Bedford, NY and rock climbed around the world. His mentorship of students and coworkers, generosity of spirit and integrity of character will be remembered dearly. There will be a celebration of Sam's life at the Harvard Club in the fall. Contributions in Sam's name can be made to the music or environmental organization of your choice. 1/3

In lieu of flowers donations can be made to MGH Hersch Lab, GM1 Project c/o MGH East, Building #

ROZOS--George T. Professor Emeritus of Philosophy, Dies in Greece. Born in 1925, Rozos was a teenager when the Germans invaded Greece. He joined the resistance and was captured by the enemy. Facing execution, young Rozos defended his actions insisting that he was fighting to free his country from foreign invasion. Recognized for bravery and honor he was sent to a prison camp from which he later escaped. Making his way to the USA after the war, Rozos enrolled at Columbia University where he earned his BA, MA and a Ph.D in Philosophy in 1958. He married Virginia Clark and in the early 1960's they had two daughters, Maria and Laura. Sadly, Virginia fell ill and passed away when the girls were still young. Rozos taught at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn until he joined the Integrated Studies Program at Richmond College in 1971, which would later merge into College of Staten Island. He resigned from CSI in 1998, having fought a losing battle against vocationalization but not without leaving a rich academic record. In 1994 he published his life's work, "Dialectic of Action," in which he focused on a central problem in dialectical philosophy. Rozos traveled extensively, loved sailing the Aegean Sea and kept a modest home on the island of Sifnos. In 2003 he married Ellen Looft, his longtime companion, in the seaside town of Voula, near Athens. GTR died in Greece fully appreciating his simple and glorious life. He is deeply missed by those who love him, including his wife, Ellen Looft; daughters, Maria Rozos and Laura Rozos; grandsons, Bairn Rozos Sweeney and Cole Giorgos Horn; sister, Aspasia Loi; sister-in-law, Eva Rozos, and many, many friends and family the world over. 1/3

WOODWORTH--Susan R.,of Murray Hill, NJ, passed away at age 70 on July 3 ,2015, after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Jay, daughter Marian Vonella (Robert) of Freehold, NJ, and son Nicholas (Jillian) of St. Johns, FL, and three grandchildren, Hayley Vonella and Emma and Liam Woodworth. Susan was born in East Orange, NJ, and raised on Shelter Island, NY. She was the daughter of Alice Fiske and step- daughter of Andrew Fiske, who was the 16th Lord of the Manor at Sylvester Manor on Shelter Island. She and her family lived in Summit for 36 years before moving to the Murray Hill section of New Providence in 2010. She graduated from Emma Willard School in Troy, NY, and from Western College in Oxford, OH, now part of the University of Ohio system. She was a member of Calvary Episcopal Church, where she sang in the choir, and the Calvary Chorale. Susan was a sustaining member of several organizations in Summit including the Junior League, College Club, Historical Society, DAR chapter and the Questers. She was also a member and chapter president of P.E.O. International, a philanthropic organization for the advancement of women. Susan was a Patron of Carnegie Hall and a supporter of several public television and classical music radio stations. Susan was an avid rug hooker and a member of two guilds, the Anne Arundel Guild in Maryland and the Hunterdon County Rug Artisans Guild in New Jersey. She loved attending week-long workshops and catching up with friends' projects. When not hooking, Susan could be found curled up with a good book or in the kitchen baking for friends or functions. A Memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, August 8th at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ 07901. Phone is: 908-277-1814. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in Susan's name be made to Calvary Episcopal Church. 1/3

EDELFELT--Roy A.,died on July 7, 2015, at age 94 of medical complications from Parkinson's disease. After graduating from the Crane School of Music, he entered the Navy and served in the invasion of Normandy during World War II, for which he was awarded the Silver Star. He then began a career as a music educator, gradually broadening his interests to teacher education and curriculum and instruction through study at New York University and Teachers College, Columbia University. At the height of his career, he was the Executive Secretary of the National Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards in Washington, D.C. He leaves behind a wife, four children, ten grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ron. We are saddened by the loss of a very special man-a devoted husband, father, grandfather, and friend. There was no one better. We will miss him and all that he brought to us. JOSEPH--Stephen Henry, passed away peacefully at his home in Montclair, NJ. He was 83. A visitation will be held 11:00am - 12:00 noon on Sunday, July 12, 2015 at Ross' Shalom Chapels, 345 Main St., Chatham, NJ. A cryptside service will follow at 2:00pm at Beth El Cemetery in Queens, NY. Born in New York City he moved to Montclair in 1967. He graduated from the Horace Mann School in Manhattan and went on to earn a B.S. from the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, in 1953. He served in the U.S. Naval Reserve at the close of the Korean War, on the USS Oak Hill, and earned the rank of Lt. Commander. He continued his service in the reserves from 1951 to 1976. He was an advertising executive, first working for the Edwin Bird Wilson Agency, in New York City, and then "in-house" for Manufacturer's Hanover Corporation (predecessor of J.P. Morgan Chase) also in New York City. He was a member of the Essex County Country Club in West Orange, NJ, and Temple Emanu-El of New York City. He was also a member of the Society of Antique Modelers and was national champion in 1977 in the Antique Rubber Power Division. He was married to his loving wife Mavis "Van" Ione Joseph for forty years before she passed away in 2000. He is survived by his children, John Nathan Joseph, Esq. (Dale C. Grayson, Esq.) of Bala Cynwyd, PA and Janis Ione Joseph (Dr. Albert W. Ritter) of Chatham, NJ as well as four grandchildren, Michael Leon Joseph, Nathan Joseph Ritter, Sarah Jean Joseph, and Joseph Walter Ritter. 1/3

ROTHSTEIN--Harriet. South Egremont, Ma--Concert pianist and teacher, Harriet Rothstein, who spread music, enthusiasm and love wherever she went, died peacefully at home on Wednesday, July 1. "Her expressive personality spoke directly through the piano as if she and the instrument were one." remembered Evan Rothstein of the Guildhall School of Music in London. Rothstein was born Harriet Elsom in Philadelphia on April 23, 1937 to Dr. Kendall A. Elsom and Dr. Katherine O'Shea Elsom, of Haverford, Pennsylvania. Harriet is survived by daughter Sarah Eustis; son Michael Rothstein; and brother Kendall Elsom Jr. She leaves grandchildren Henry William and Frederick Livingston Eustis. STOCKMAN--Jeanne Monroe. Age 95, died peacefully at home on July 7th in Glen Cove, NY. Wife of Henry C. Stockman, Jr. and sister to Robert Grier Monroe, MD, of Westwood, MA. She was the mother of six children: Helen Stovell, Mina Pell, Jeanne Wullschleger, Henry Stockman, III, Robert Stockman and Mimi Wainwright. She is survived by her loving husband of 70 years and also is survived by fourteen grandchildren and eleven great- grandchildren. Jeanne grew up in New York City and lived on Long Island. She graduated from the Chapin School in New York and the Neighborhood Playhouse. An enthusiastic horseback rider and tennis player, Jeanne was a member of the Meadowbrook Hounds and Piping Rock Club. She will be remembered by her family and many friends for her caring nature, wonderful sense of humor, intelligence and energy. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Rocco's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, LI on Saturday, July 18th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make a gift to The Green Vale School in Glen Head, NY. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald M.,age 84, passed away July 9, 2015, at his summer home in Southampton, New York, leaving his beloved wife Adrien, loving daughter Lauren, and devoted grandchildren Ashley and Philip Greenwald, as well as his favorite nephew Robert Gewant. NEWMAN--Ron. Words cannot express the sorrow we feel at Ron Newman's sudden passing. He was a beloved friend, father, grandfather, and Adrien's true soulmate. He was an avid golfer, dressed to the nines. Always smiling, Ron made time for everyone and had kind words for all who knew him. Ron, you will be truly missed and we will keep you in our hearts forever. Love, Andrea & John Stark, and Florine & Jules Wachter 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. Farewell dear friend. We will always miss you but we are grateful for the privilege of having you in our lives. Our heartfelt sympathy to Adrien, Lauren, Ashley and Phillip. Jeri and Steven Meltzer and Family 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. Our hearts are shattered on the loss of our dearest friend, Ronnie. We know Adrien, Lauren, Ashley, Phillip and Robert are all devastated by his loss, as we are. The world will never be the same without him. We will miss you and always remember you in our hearts. Love, Roberta and Ricky 1/3

CAPPELLI--Virginia M. (nee Delger). Beloved wife of 59 years of Louis J. Cappelli. Chairman of the Boards Sterling National Bank/Sterling Bancorp and treasured mother died after a long illness. Virginia was a lady of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. Virginia will be missed by her husband and children Louis, Craig, Cheryl Craven, Michael and Stephen and their spouses and partners Alicia, Amy and Kevin and 10 grandchildren. She loved her family fiercely and unconditionally, they were her passion, purpose and joy. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between 2-4pm and 7-9pm Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday, July 15 at 9:45am. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. Dearest Adrien and family, Marty, Jane and Rick join me in extending our deepest sympathy. We have been friends forever. My arms are around you now and I will always be here for you. Ellie Wohl 1/3

KIRSHNER--Betty (Berman), B.A.,award-winning Long Island, NY artist and art educator, age 86, died July 6, 2015, in a gallery of her art as prints ICU at Mercy Medical Center Rockville Center, NY. Betty was widow of Samuel J. Kirshner, J.D., co-founder of Zam & Kirshner, Inc. Advertising. He died 14 years ago. Surviving children: Mark G., Karen L., Abby J. Grandchildren: Rachel and Jon Rothschild. Bronx-born to Lily and David Berman, March 14, 1929, she's survived by brother, Sam P. Berman of Reseda, CA. Betty will be remembered for her sweet, kind good nature, and her beauty, brilliance, courage, and lives through her paintings. 1/3

HABERMAN--Eve. You were the light in our lives with your warmth, generosity, and hospitality. No one will be able to replicate your holiday events. We will love and remember you forever. Ruth, Madelaine, Ross and Hillary 1/3

SELINGER--Harry, 90, passed away Friday, July 10. Born to David and Sophie Selinger on September 3, 1924, he was a retail furniture business owner for over 50 years and served as Worshipful Master of both the Three Pillars and Warwick Masonic Lodges. He was also a member of the Board of Directors of PSCH in Queens. He is survived by his wife, Gwynneth, his children, Ross, Mark, Stacy, John, Sean and 10 grandchildren. He will be missed by all. Services at Gutterman's in Woodbury, Tuesday, July 14, 1:00pm. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ron. He loved life and it loved him back! He loved and adored his wife, Adrien. She loved him back - they were soul mates. Ron was a man of great strength, generosity, and kindness. Proud of his daughter, Lauren and his grandchildren. Ron did make a difference! Vivian Serota 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Robert, of New York City and Ocean City, NJ peacefully passed away on July 6th at the age of 76 with Judith, his wife of 54 years, at his side. He is survived by his brother Stephen L Schwartz, Sr and sister Dorris Alexander. He was a marketing research analyst at Ford Motor Company; Vice President of North American operations at American Motors Corporation; President and CEO of Rolls-Royce Motors Cars Inc., and President of Automotive Ventures. A member of the Metropolitan Club and the Ocean City Yacht Club, he served as Treasurer of the Foundation Board of Shore Medical Center. A memorial service will be held at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 2998 Bay Avenue, Ocean City, NJ on Tuesday July 21st at 11 am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to Holy Trinity or to the Cancer Center of Shore Medical Center of Somers Point, NJ. 1/3

BARTFELD--Frederick Francis, died peacefully at home July 10, 2015 at age 92. Decorated WWII airman, scholar of the American Civil War, philosopher, family man. The funeral will be held graveside Friday, July 17, 11:30am at Maplewood Cemetery, Hunter Synagogue section. Son of Felix and Betty, Fred was the beloved husband and caretaker of Rhoda, his wife of over 60 years who predeceased him, devoted father of Jeffrey and Leslie and father-in-law of Suzanne and Bruce, and adored grandfather of Rachel (Tony), Sarah, Emily, Jonathan, Diana, and Mark and great-grandfather to Nathan, Eliza, and Peter. He is survived by sister Helen Wolkow and brother-in-law Rabbi Leo. Born September 10, 1922, he grew up a hardscrabble youth on the Lower East Side, but straightened out after he met Rhoda in Hunter, NY at age 15. After flying over 50 missions over Europe in WWII, he returned and they raised their children in Queens. A brilliant man, he studied Mathematics at MIT and graduated Queens College later in life with honors in philosophy. He spent the last years of his life in Sonoma, California, by Suzanne's vineyards. He was a terrific dancer, a voracious reader, and a wonderful friend. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

SOBEL--Marc Ira, 62, died on July 6 in Hollywood, Florida. Graduate of Scarsdale High School and Princeton. Survived by father, Frank; sons, Chris and Kevin; grandson, Ben; and siblings, Nancy, Ralph, Ricky and John. 1/3

REES--Roger, The Board and staff of The Collegiate Chorale mourn the tragic loss of Roger Rees, our longtime Artistic Associate and dear friend, whose rare gifts were abundant in his many projects with us. He was generous of spirit, intelligent, funny, and, of course, incredibly talented. We will miss him dearly, and send our condolences to his husband, Rick Elice. 1/3

STOCKMAN--Jeanne Monroe. Age 95, died peacefully at home on July 7th in Glen Cove, NY. Wife of Henry C. Stockman, Jr. and sister to Robert Grier Monroe, MD, of Westwood, MA. She was the mother of six children: Helen Stovell, Mina Pell, Jeanne Wullschleger, Henry Stockman, III, Robert Stockman and Mimi Wainwright. She is survived by her loving husband of 70 years and also is survived by fourteen grandchildren and eleven great- grandchildren. Jeanne grew up in New York City and lived on Long Island. She graduated from the Chapin School in New York and the Neighborhood Playhouse. An enthusiastic horseback rider and tennis player, Jeanne was a member of the Meadowbrook Hounds and Piping Rock Club. She will be remembered by her family and many friends for her caring nature, wonderful sense of humor, intelligence and energy. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Rocco's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, LI on Saturday, July 18th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make a gift to The Green Vale School in Glen Head, NY. 1/3
NEWMAN--Ronnie. Our deepest sympathy to Adrien and her family. We will miss our dear Ronnie and always remember the wonderful times we spent together. Carole and Stanley 1/3

VASSILAROS--John A.,July 10, 2015. With grace and in peace, our beautiful and admired Johnny passed this evening in the soulful glowing love of his family at their home in Bridgehampton, NY. Born in Manhattan on July 26, 1945 to Anthony John Vassilaros and Irene Vassilaros, John was a devoted son, brother, adventurer, sailor, and pilot. He delighted in being a deeply loving father; a tender and absolutely wonderful husband; and an extraordinary, one-of-a-kind friend of friends. As a young man, Johnny served in the Green Beret Special Forces. Since 1964, he was President of Vassilaros & Sons, a third generation family coffee-roasting business that is still thriving today. John was an innately keen businessman who was dedicated to producing a consistently excellent cup of NYC coffee. His wife, Alexandra Frangos Gersten Vassilaros, was blessed to be his fourth cousin on her mother's side, and with their family they share an undying passion for the Greek Island of Ikaria, where their respective families were born and where they enjoyed a small home on the Aegean. Ikaria was their simple paradise, and a foundational part of their bond and continuity. Johnny's motto was "Live hard, work hard, play hard, and love hard"--all of which he modeled with gusto, verve, and integrity. For those of us who knew and loved him he was a shining presence. He loved life purely, and that spirit radiated from him so powerfully that one couldn't help but be touched by it. In Greek we might describe him as: "hrisos anthropos"--a selfless person who instinctively puts his loved ones ahead of himself. Vassilaros Coffee actively supports Greek charities, and John served as longtime board member of inner-city youth mentoring program, The 52nd Street Project. He leaves behind a legacy of exquisite love to his wife, Alexandra, and his three adored and big-hearted boys, Tonio John, Luka John, and Stefano John, each of whom adored him to the fullest for his love, generosity of spirit, sense of adventure, and joy. He is also survived by his mother, Irene; his sisters, Sophia, Ann, Irene, and Maria; his nephews and nieces, Stephanie Kasselakis Kyles, John Kasselakis, Zachary Vassilaros, Arianna Peterson, Paul Peterson, Anthony Boyer; and so many beloved cousins and best friends whom he held in his capable heart. A visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1:30pm and 6:30pm on Tuesday, July 14. A service will be held at Cathedral of Holy Trinity (East 74th Street) on Wednesday, July 15 at 11:00am. A memorial of Johnny's extraordinarily well-lived life will be forthcoming.
