GOLDBERG--Eleanor Brown, 88, of New York City and Wellington, FL passed away peacefully on Friday, July 10, 2015, in Wellington, FL with her daughter, Celia and grandchildren, George and Lauren by her side. The funeral service will be held at Palms West Funeral Home, Royal Palm Beach, FL on Wednesday, July 15, 2015 at 10:00am with Stephen H. Pinsky, D.D., Rabbi Emeritus of Temple Beth Torah, Wellington, FL officiating. Interment will follow at The Eternal Light Memorial Gardens in Boynton Beach, FL. The Palms West Funeral Home is handling the services. Eleanor was born in New York City to Celia and Martin Brown on March 18, 1927. She graduated from the Highland Manner School, West Long Branch, NJ in 1943 and from the Russell Sage College, Troy, NY in 1947. She married Eugene Goldberg, who she had met at sleep-a-way camp when she was 14 years old, on June 28, 1947 in the Penthouse Ball Room of the Pierre Hotel, NYC and where they have resided for the past 25 years. Eleanor and Eugene's love and respect for each other evolved into a partnership that enabled them to build an extraordinary life for themselves and their family. Their support of each other, throughout the over 70 years that they were together, enabled them to individually and jointly achieve their goals and experience life to its fullest. Eugene and his brother Robert took a small domestic distributor of chinaware, flatware, and glassware to hotel and restaurant chains and built it into a differentiated multinational firm that serviced leading companies in the foodservice, restaurant, airline and hospitality industries, with Eleanor as a key partner in the endeavor. Later, Eleanor became a trustee of her alma mater, Russell Sage College of Troy, NY. Eleanor was known for her keen mind, sharp wit, beauty and elegant sense of style. She was a very active presence on the New York and Palm Beach social scenes. She and her husband were generous supporters of many causes, including the Central Park Conservancy, the Society of the Four Arts, Palm Beach Symphony, the Frick Museum, the Royal Academy, the United Jewish Federation and the Morikami Museum and Japanese Gardens, among countless others. She was also a devoted long-time member of Sands Point Golf Club, Congregation Emanu-El and the Harmonie Club of New York. Her other passions were traveling, wine, golf, the arts, and her family. She traveled extensively with her husband, golfing in Scotland, shopping in Paris, exploring new vistas in Asia and Africa, seeing all that the world had to offer, completing over thirty trips around the globe. When not traveling, she loved Central Park and spent many hours sitting with her husband on one of the benches she had donated in commemoration of her family, admiring the park's beauty and majesty. Eleanor is preceded in death by her husband, Eugene, her daughter Lauren Kessler, her sisters Joan Roberts and Barbara Brown, her brother-in- law, Robert Goldberg, her nephew James Roberts and her parents Celia and Martin Brown. Eleanor is survived by her daughter Celia Zahringer of Wellington, FL, her nephew Curtis Roberts of Tuxedo Park, NY and Berwyn, PA, her step brother Stephen Brown of NYC, her sister-in-law Joan Goldberg of Delray Beach, FL, her grandchildren James Kessler, M.D. of Great Neck, NY, Major Peter Marks, USMC of 29 Palms, CA, George Zahringer IV, Killian Zahringer and Lauren Zahringer of NYC, her great-grandchildren Benjamin Marks and Jackson Marks of Brandon, VT and her nephews Barry Goldberg of NYC, Ira Goldberg of Newport Beach, CA, James Goldberg of Lake Worth, FL and her niece Ellen Goldberg of Easthampton, NY. 1/3

VICKERS--Jon. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Jon Vickers, the extraordinary dramatic tenor whose passionate performances of some of the most demanding roles in opera thrilled our audience for 27 years. Vickers made his Met debut in 1960 as Canio in Pagliacci and went on to sing 280 performances of 17 roles with the company. Among his many unforgettable roles were Siegmund in Die Walkure, which he first sang in his debut season opposite Birgit Nilsson and continued performing to acclaim through the 1980s; the title roles of Otello and Peter Grimes; Florestan in Fidelio; the title role in Parsifal; and Aeneas in the first-ever Met performances of Berlioz's Les Troyens. We extend our sincerest condolences to all those who loved him, and to his millions of admirers around the world. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

ARFA--Barbara. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Barbara Arfa, beloved wife of Harvey, devoted mother of Executive Board member and Founding Chairperson of our Young Leadership Associates, Caroline Arfa Massel (Morris), grandmother of Rebecca, Alexander, and Michael and daughter of the late Regina and Salo Gutfreund z"l, Survivors of the Holocaust. Barbara dedicated herself to Holocaust remembrance and education. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman Ron Meier, Executive Director 1/3

KAPILOFF--Phyllis P.,78, died Sunday, July 12, 2015, at home in Stamford, CT, where she resided for 50 years. She is survived by her loving husband, Arnold; sons Steven (Erica) and Howard (Merri); adored grandchildren Arielle, Jonathan, Nathan and Jason; and brother, Bernard (Robin) Passes. Phyllis was a co-founder of the Stamford clothing boutique Thru the Garage, which she operated for 20 years. Active in Democratic politics, Phyllis was appointed to the Stamford Zoning Board and served nearly 14 years, her last seven years as Chairwoman. Donations to charities supporting her passion for affordable housing can be made to the Housing Development Fund Inc., 100 Prospect Street, Stamford, CT 06901. Services Tuesday, July 14, at 10am, at Temple Sinai, 458 Lakeside Drive, Stamford. 1/3

BARTFELD--Frederick Francis, died peacefully at home July 10, 2015 at age 92. Decorated WWII airman, scholar of the American Civil War, philosopher, family man. The funeral will be held graveside Friday, July 17, 11:30am at Maplewood Cemetery, Hunter Synagogue section. Son of Felix and Betty, Fred was the beloved husband and caretaker of Rhoda, his wife of over 60 years who predeceased him, devoted father of Jeffrey and Leslie and father-in-law of Suzanne and Bruce, and adored grandfather of Rachel (Tony), Sarah, Emily, Jonathan, Diana, and Mark and great-grandfather to Nathan, Eliza, and Peter. He is survived by sister Helen Wolkow and brother-in-law Rabbi Leo. Born September 10, 1922, he grew up a hardscrabble youth on the Lower East Side, but straightened out after he met Rhoda in Hunter, NY at age 15. After flying over 50 missions over Europe in WWII, he returned and they raised their children in Queens. A brilliant man, he studied Mathematics at MIT and graduated Queens College later in life with honors in philosophy. He spent the last years of his life in Sonoma, California, by Suzanne's vineyards. He was a terrific dancer, a voracious reader, and a wonderful friend. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. Our hearts are broken by the untimely passing of our friend, Ronnie. He loved life, his family and friends. Our deepest love and condolences to his beautiful wife Adrien and his daughter Lauren and his grandchildren Phillip and Ashley. Love, Brenda and Carlin Axelrod 1/3

With much love, Amanda, Neal, Lisa, Michael, Alec, Jake, Evan and Ethan 1/3

KLABOUCH--Francis, on July 11, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Madeline, loving father of Meryn, dear brother of Raymond and brother-in-law of Dolores Morrissey. After his retirement from the Army, he worked as an engineer for AT&T for over fifty years. Visitation will be held today at the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 352 E 87th St, NYC from 2-5 and 7-9pm. BRAMAN--Marjorie died in a state of grace on July 2nd, 2015 at her home in the Hudson Valley, of complications from breast cancer. She was 60 years old. Marjorie began her 26-year career in publishing as an editorial assistant and rose through the ranks to senior vice president and editorial director at Harper-Collins; and editor-in-chief at Henry Holt. Most recently she was an independent editor and member of the independent group 5-E. She was passionate about life, loved her gardens, was a brilliant cook. Whatever she put her hand to she made beautiful, and never worked in half- measures. She was predeceased by her parents, William and Marcia Braman; survived by her two sisters, Holly Braman and Mary Braman; her brother-in-law Lawrence A. Saul; and her adoring husband Jamie M. Saul. A memorial will be held later this year. In lieu of flowers, "be a mensch." 1

Grandchildren: Rachel and Jon Rothschild. Bronx-born to Lily and David Berman, March 14, 1929, she's survived by brother, Sam P. Berman of Reseda, CA. Betty will be remembered for her sweet, kind good nature, and her beauty, brilliance, courage, and lives through her paintings. 1/3

Virginia will be missed by her husband and children Louis, Craig, Cheryl Craven, Michael and Stephen and their spouses and partners Alicia, Amy and Kevin and 10 grandchildren. NEUSTEIN--Charles "Charlie" Benjamin, born September 27, 1935, passed away on Saturday after a lengthy battle with cardiac illness. Charlie graduated from Columbia and went on to a career on Wall St, working at Salomon Brothers, Herzog Heine and Geduld/Merrill Lynch. Charlie and his wife, Jaclyn, raised their children in Scarsdale, where he was always found coaching his children (and referees) on the sports fields. He is remembered as a carefree guy who lived life to the fullest. He is survived by his wife Jaclyn, sister Dr. Mary Genkins, children David and Elizabeth (Ross), their spouses, and grandchildren Ashley and Jared Neustein, and Ezra Ross. Funeral to be held July 15 at 10:30am at Montefiore Cemetery. In memory of Mr. Neustein, the family requests that donations be made to The Mount Sinai Hospital, Office of Development; in memory of Mr. Neustein and in honor of Dr. Valentin Fuster. 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Herbert, 86, of Canton, MA, previously of New York City and Rockville Centre, NY, after a protracted illness. Survived by his cherished wife of 61 years, Marjorie; his three sons, Stephen, Donald and Richard (affectionately known as Um, Strum and Vovchik); his loving daughter-in-law, Marci, and his four cherished grandchildren, Allison, Aaron, Erica and Gil. Herb was a true mensch, who always did the right thing (well, almost always), who was always there when you needed him, who supported you without question when it was right and told you when it wasn't. He was a man of few words whose feelings for those he loved were boundless. A long-time veteran in the home furnishings industry, Herb worked for almost 50 years for just three firms, Grosby Products, Tilbury Fabrics and Richloom Fabrics; and was known to everyone in the trade as a straight shooter. Herb was the original home-body who loved to fix whatever needed fixing and whose idea of heaven was an hour examining the Craftsman tools at Sears. If you look hard, you will see him now with a half-gallon of Breyers, the game on and the dog at least half-way in his lap. 1/3

DOWNING--Michael B.,on July 9, 2015. Age 39. Beloved husband of Tara Downing and father of Emma, son of John M. Downing Sr., brother of Patrick S. Downing (Katalin), Marguerite Peck (Ernest), John Downing (Brenda), and Alison Metzler (William) and uncle of ten. Predeceased by his mother, Catherine S. Downing. Michael was a graduate of Hotchkiss, Tulane, Columbia (M.F.A.), and Cardozo Law School. He was a loving husband, father, brother and son, and an accomplished actor and attorney. He will be greatly missed. Visitation at Greenwich Village Funeral Home on Tuesday, July 14th from 7-9pm. Funeral services will be held at 10am on Wednesday, July 15th at Church of the Ascension, 12 West 11th Street. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to The Actor's Fund. 1/3
GOLDMAN--George M.,86, Science teacher. Mentored students to national competition prizes. Survived by his brother Herbert, nieces, nephew and by his long-term companion. 1/3

KONSKER--Sandra "Sandi", passed away peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, Florida on Sunday, July 12 at the age of 74. Sandra is remembered as a loving mother, adoring grandmother, inspiring mother-in-law, devoted sweetheart and loyal friend. Sandi is survived by her three sons - or as she always referred to them her "best friends" - Mitchell, Steven and Kenneth; her grandchildren Ian, Carly, Samuel, Briella, Eliana, Gabriel, Harrison and Daniel; her daughters-in-law Lori, Charlene and Kim; her beau Mike; her dear SweetPea and so many lifelong friends, all of whom will feel her loss for many years to come. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Morton. For those close to Sandi, a bright light has faded from the landscape. The memories of such a special woman will echo in the minds and hearts of all who loved her. The next time a funny risque story is shared or a shockingly honest statement is made, a smile will appear on the faces of the people that were fortunate enough to know Sandi as they find themselves lost in reverie. The funeral service is scheduled for 10am on Thursday, July 16 at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street in New York. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Murray, Esq.,died peacefully July 12, 2015. Responsible for a number of cases that fundamentally impacted the field of employment law from its inception, including the landmark case of Thoreson v. Penthouse Magazine & Robert Guccione, which held that a claim of sexual harassment can be established based on the victim's testimony alone. He was the lead trial lawyer in the case of McIntyre v. Manhattan Ford, Lincoln Mercury, a sexual harassment, retaliation and intentional infliction of emotional distress suit, where a Manhattan jury awarded the plaintiff $6.6 million, which was then one of the highest awards for sexual harassment in the entire nation. He was also responsible for the appellate decision of Bracker v. Cohen, which confirmed the constitutionality of the NYC Human Rights Law, which has led to countless victims of discrimination finding protection under that statute. He was known as a tireless advocate and a wonderful mentor, whose contribution to the law will be remembered by the many people whose lives he touched. Born in Manhattan, raised in the Bronx and a veteran of WW2, in which he fought heroically in the South Pacific, he is survived by his beloved wife Paula, son Joshua, daughter Davida, and six grandchildren. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

VASSILAROS--John A. The Doctors and Staff of Prosthodontic Associates, NYC, offers our sincere condolences to the Vassilaros Family. John's courage, vitality and heart will always be an inspiration to us. Dr. Harold Litvak and Dr. Michael Litvak 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Stanley D.,Esq. We celebrate the extraordinary life of our father and grandfather, Stanley D. Friedman, Esq., and mourn his passing. He was the most devoted and loving person to his family, friends and colleagues and was truly one of a kind. Our beloved father and grandfather was the kindest, most warm and adoring man, and supported all of us unwaveringly with his strength, passion and of course his wonderful smile. He was our rock. His charm, keen intelligence and extraordinary wit will forever stay in our hearts. Our beloved father founded and was the senior partner of the law firm of McAloon & Friedman, a leading medical malpractice litigation law firm and was a talented and tireless advocate for his clients. He instilled in his partners and staff the values of honesty and integrity he exemplified. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, July 15, 2015 at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY 10552. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to Southampton Hospital. We miss you and love you, Sharon, Chris, Hannah and Addie; Rob, Lori and Jack; Stefanie, John and Jack; and Lynn. 1/3

CAPPELLI--Virginia M. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Sterling Bancorp and Sterling National Bank mourn the passing of Virginia M. Cappelli, beloved wife of our Chairman, Louis J. Cappelli. We extend our sincere sympathy to Mr. Cappelli and the entire Cappelli family. 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. Dearest Adrien and family, we are all so saddened by the loss of Ronnie. Being with the two of you was always such a joy, to share your sole love, to play golf with you was a special lesson. You made everybody feel like family. You made this world a better place. Betsy S. Green and Family 1/3

YORKES--Audree F. Beloved wife of Arthur for over 55 years, mother of Peter and Michael, mother-in-law of Elizabeth. Loving grandmother of Molly and Emma. Sister-in-law of David and Dale. Aunt of Stacy, Jeffrey and Nicole. Her love and generosity showed no bounds. A kind and caring person with a great flare for style and beauty. Her wide circle of friends have nothing but loving and the fondest memories of this unique person whose lives she touched in many ways. Audree was a Lifetime member of Hadassah and served as an administrator for their Rockland county chapter for many years. Funeral services will be held today Tuesday July 14, 2015, 12:00 Noon at Jewish Memorial Chapel of LI, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY 11550. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Memorial contributions in Audree's memory may be made to Orangetown Jewish Center, Hadassah, Jewish Federation of Rockland County or A Charity of One's Choice. 1/3

SWEENEY--Jane Paris, 81, died of a rare neurological disorder at her Cutchogue home on July 12. She was an accomplished pianist, teacher and student of the dance and musical theatre. Widow of George Fenton Sweeney, mother of Michele and Heather Cusack and Patrick Sweeney (Muffie Dunn), grandmother of eight and companion of Frederick Green. Private service 11am, Wednesday at Cutchogue Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to North Fork Community Theater would be appreciated. 1/3

REES--Roger. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Roger Rees, beloved husband of Rick Elice. We will miss his indomitable spirit, his devotion to family and friends and his courage under affliction. Our deepest condolences to Rick and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

PRICE--Gregory S.,age 53, of Morristown, NJ died suddenly and peacefully on June 10, 2015 while on a business trip in Vancouver, Canada. He is survived by his wife, Sabina Holland; his parents, Donald and Dolores Price of Newtown Square, PA; his sister, April Tracy (Daniel) of West Chester, PA and six nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on July 25 at the Brandywine River Museum in Chadds Ford, PA, at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity. 1/3

FUTTERMAN--Jack. We are saddened by the loss of Jack Futterman, a trusted advisor and member of the Board of Directors of The Hain Celestial Group, Inc. for over 18 years. We appreciate Jack's many contributions as a Board member and his work on various committees. Jack brought vast experience from his days as Chief Executive Officer of Pathmark Stores, Inc. as well as extensive industry knowledge and keen insights to our Company. Irwin D. Simon, Founder and Chairman of the Board of Directors 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Stanley D.,Esq. The partners, associates and staff of McAloon & Friedman express their profound sorrow upon the passing of our founding partner, Stanley Friedman. We extend our sympathy to his children and their spouses, Sharon and Chris, Robert and Lori, Stefanie and John and their children as well as to Lynn. Stanley was a lawyer of extraordinary talent and dedication who established a standard of excellence that was long recognized by his clients and colleagues. He was a kind and honorable man, always putting the interests of his clients first and upholding the highest standards of the legal profession. Stanley was a great trial lawyer and legal trailblazer. But above all, he was a person who time and again displayed his devotion to his family, friends, clients and the firm. He will be forever missed. 1/3
ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep abiding interest and love for each of us. Sheila 1/3

NEWMAN--Ronald. We mourn the loss of our dearest friend Ronnie, so special and full of life. So many years, good times, and always laughs along the way. We will miss and never forget you. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his beloved Adrien, Lauren, Ashley and Phillip. Love, Annie and Jeff Mann 1/3

GARTNER--Alan. Died peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family on July 14, 2015 in New York City. Alan is survived by his loving wife, Dorothy Lipsky, his children, Jonathan, Rachel and Daniel, her children, Robin, Nina and Daniel, and their 11 grandchildren. He survived his ex-wife Audrey. Alan Gartner was involved in social justice issues since college at Antioch and Harvard. His career spanned civil and poverty rights, as leader of Boston CORE and Suffolk County OEO; education, as Newton high school teacher and head of Special Education in New York City public schools; academia, as professor at Queens College and director at the Graduate Center at CUNY; publisher of Social Policy magazine and author of more than 25 books, of which those on school inclusion and reform were written with his wife; and politics and government, as director of the City Redistricting Commission and in executive roles throughout the Bloomberg administration. Alan will be greatly missed. 1/3

FUTTERMAN--Jack. We are saddened by the loss of Jack Futterman, a trusted advisor and member of the Board of Directors of The Hain Celestial Group, Inc. for over 18 years. We appreciate Jack's many contributions as a Board member and his work on various committees. Jack brought vast experience from his days as Chief Executive Officer of Pathmark Stores, Inc. as well as extensive industry knowledge and keen insights to our Company. Irwin D. Simon, Founder and Chairman of the Board of Directors 1/3

VASSILAROS--John. Johnny, we celebrate your life and profound friendship! Your kind heart, generosity, humility, talents, laughter and love made all our lives richer. We love you and cherish all our collective and unique memories. May God's loving arms keep you! All your Brothers in Friendship 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Stanley D. The Board of Directors and the Staff of Southhampton Hospital mourn the loss of their friend and Board Member. Always admired for his generosity, integrity, intelligence and wit, he will be missed by many. Robert S. Chaloner, President & CEO Kenneth B. Wright, Board Chair Howard Lorber, Foundation Chair 1/3
HAGADUS--James Matthew, M.D. Nov. 1, 1956--July 15, 1985. Forever in our hearts. Your Sisters 1/3

WATTERS--Dr. John T. The officers and Board of Directors of the American Federation for Aging Research mourn the loss of our colleague, a member since 2010. His service to AFAR and support of our mission and programs were highly valued. William J. Lipton, Chair; Stephanie Lederman, Executive Director 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Stanley D.,Esq. We celebrate the extraordinary life of our father and grandfather, Stanley D. Friedman, Esq., and mourn his passing. He was the most devoted and loving person to his family, friends and colleagues and was truly one of a kind. Our beloved father and grandfather was the kindest, most warm and adoring man, and supported all of us unwaveringly with his strength, passion and of course his wonderful smile. He was our rock. His charm, keen intelligence and extraordinary wit will forever stay in our hearts. Our beloved father founded and was the senior partner of the law firm of McAloon & Friedman, a leading medical malpractice litigation law firm and was a talented and tireless advocate for his clients. He instilled in his partners and staff the values of honesty and integrity he exemplified. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, July 15, 2015 at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY 10552. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to Southampton Hospital. We miss you and love you, Sharon, Chris, Hannah and Addie; Rob, Lori and Jack; Stefanie, John and Jack; and Lynn. 1/3

SHARKEY--William J.,82, died peacefully on July 12th. Beloved husband of Anne, his wife of 59 years, father to John Sharkey, Kevin Sharkey, Michael Sharkey, Anne Larkin and James Sharkey, and grandfather to 12 adored grandchildren. An engineer by training, Bill was a legendary figure within New York City's Office of Management and Budget as an effective and forceful influence for change and progress having served in five different administrations. He consulted for The New York City Council on budget and revenue issues upon retirement. Family will receive friends at the Beaugard Funeral Home, 869 Kinderkamack Rd., River Edge NJ, Wednesday 5-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Our Lady of the Visitation Church, Paramus, NJ on July 16th at 10:00am. 1/3

ROMNEY--Shirley G. (nee Gordon) on Saturday, July 11, 2015 at age 92 in Rye, NY. Beloved wife of the late Seymour L. Loving mother of Ben, Anne and the late Dana Romney. Services at Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Sunday, July 19 at 11am. Burial in Adath Jeshurun Cemetery, 350 Grove St., West Roxbury. See www.levinechapel.com for more information. 1/3

TIFFANY--Thomas Ladd, age 78, passed away on July 12, 2015, of complications of Alzheimer's disease. He is survived by his wife, Carol; sons, Thomas Jr. and Benjamin; daughters-in-law, Sarah and Nancy; grandsons, Thomas III, Zachary, and Tristan; and brothers, Dardenne and Bradford. In lieu of flowers, please make a gift to: Adult Day Club of VNA of Somerset Hills, 200 Mt. Airy Rd., Basking Ridge, NJ 07920 1/3

SWEENEY--Jane Paris, 81, died of a rare neurological disorder at her Cutchogue home on July 12. She was an accomplished pianist, teacher and student of the dance and musical theatre. Widow of George Fenton Sweeney, mother of Michele and Heather Cusack and Patrick Sweeney (Muffie Dunn), grandmother of eight and companion of Frederick Green. Service 11am, Wednesday at Cutchogue Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to North Fork Community Theater would be appreciated. 1/3

SZOR--Irene (91) Born February 5, 1924 in Lwow (Poland), died July 13, 2015 in New York, NY. A survivor of the Holocaust, she spent two years in the forests of eastern Poland hiding with a group of partisans. After the war she immigrated to the USA where she led a highly successful career designing dolls for the Horsman Doll Company. Wife of Leopold Szor and later Michael Lewin. She is survived by her son Daniel, daughter-in-law Katia, grandsons Henry and Alex and granddaughter Emily. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell funeral chapel at 12:00 on Sunday, July 19th followed by a burial at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla. Later in the afternoon there will be a reception for family and friends at Irene's home. 1/3

SOICHER--Lawrence G.,77, died Sunday, July 12, 2015. Beloved uncle who had a great spirit for life and friendship. He leaves behind his nephew, Barry Soicher (Heather) and two great-nephews, along with his niece Lisa Slote (Greg) and two great-nieces. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY at 11:30am on July 15, 2015. 1/3

CAPPELLI--Virginia M. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Sterling Bancorp and Sterling National Bank mourn the passing of Virginia M. Cappelli, beloved wife of our Chairman, Louis J. Cappelli. We extend our sincere sympathy to Mr. Cappelli and the entire Cappelli family. 1/3

DIMELE--Armand F.,Famous Radio Host of "The Positive Mind" on WBAI 99.5 FM in NYC for 35 years, along with being a therapist and director of the successful "DiMele Center", died June 22, 2015. Armand is survived by his sons: Alexander Rivas and Booker Ervin and his sisters: Dr. Bel-Michele DeMille and Mrs. Anita Marie Knochen. Instead of flowers, the family requests donations to WBAI FM in Armand's name. 1/3

WALTON--Dr. Alan The Board and staff of Research!America mourn the death of Dr. Alan Walton. Alan was a visionary who brought intelligence, leadership and passion to every aspect of life, including advocacy for science. We are grateful for his dedicated service as a former member of our Board of Directors. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife EJ and his entire family. Hon. John Edward Porter, Chair Mary Woolley, President and CEO Research!America Alexandria, VA 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Stanley D.,Esq. The partners, associates and staff of McAloon & Friedman express their profound sorrow upon the passing of our founding partner, Stanley Friedman. We extend our sympathy to his children and their spouses, Sharon and Chris, Robert and Lori, Stefanie and John and their children as well as to Lynn. Stanley was a lawyer of extraordinary talent and dedication who established a standard of excellence that was long recognized by his clients and colleagues. He was a kind and honorable man, always putting the interests of his clients first and upholding the highest standards of the legal profession. Stanley was a great trial lawyer and legal trailblazer. But above all, he was a person who time and again displayed his devotion to his family, friends, clients and the firm. He will be forever missed. 1/3

VASSILAROS--John A. The Doctors and Staff of Prosthodontic Associates, NYC, offers our sincere condolences to the Vassilaros Family. John's courage, vitality and heart will always be an inspiration to us. Dr. Harold Litvak and Dr. Michael Litvak 1/3

KONSKER--Sandra "Sandi", passed away peacefully in her home in Boca Raton, Florida on Sunday, July 12 at the age of 74. Sandra is remembered as a loving mother, adoring grandmother, inspiring mother-in-law, devoted sweetheart and loyal friend. Sandi is survived by her three sons - or as she always referred to them her "best friends" - Mitchell, Steven and Kenneth; her grandchildren Ian, Carly, Samuel, Briella, Eliana, Gabriel, Harrison and Daniel; her daughters-in-law Lori, Charlene and Kim; her beau Mike; her dear SweetPea and so many lifelong friends, all of whom will feel her loss for many years to come. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband Morton. For those close to Sandi, a bright light has faded from the landscape. The memories of such a special woman will echo in the minds and hearts of all who loved her. The next time a funny risque story is shared or a shockingly honest statement is made, a smile will appear on the faces of the people that were fortunate enough to know Sandi as they find themselves lost in reverie. The funeral service is scheduled for 10am on Thursday, July 16 at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street in New York. 1/3

WINSTON--Edward Perry, a New York City architect, passed away at New York- Presbyterian Weill Cornell Medical Center on July 11, 2015, two weeks short of his seventieth birthday. Born in Washington, DC, he was educated at Harvard College (1967) and received his graduate degree from Rice University. Uncompromising in his political, social, and ethical values, Perry pursued a career, building housing, schools, and community projects in San Francisco and New York. At the time of his death, he was associated with Magnusson Architecture and Planning. He taught generations of future architects and planners at The New School and Pratt Institute. He is survived by his wife Zeynep Celik of New York City and his son Antonio Ali Winston of Oakland, CA; in addition to his mother Frances Rome of Baltimore, brother Cooper Winston of Norton, MA, and sister Nancy Rome of Baltimore. Donations in his memory may be made to East New York Farms www.eastnewyorkfarms.org. 1/3

FINLEY--John Jordan, MBE, of Hudson, New York, died on July 2, 2015. He was 68. Born September 8, 1946, in Falls Church, Virginia, he was the son of Judge William Thompson Finley and Mary Jordan Finley. He was predeceased by his father, mother, brother, William Thompson Finley, Jr. and sister, Mary Ann Davidson. John attended Harvard College, where he studied Government and graduated cum laude in 1968. He subsequently returned to his native Virginia and received a J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law in 1971. John practiced law in New York City for 44 years. At the time of his death, he was a partner at Stairs Dillenbeck Finley, where he had been in practice for more than 20 years. Throughout his career, he volunteered extensively with the British American Chamber of Commerce, serving as its Chairman from 1995 to 1997 and also Legal Counsel to the British American Business Council for a number of years thereafter. In honor of his devoted service, he was appointed a Member of the Order of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II. John was highly respected as a gentleman and a scholar. He was a voracious reader of the news and literature, particularly spy novels. He loved history, current events, jazz, films, baseball-- he was a life-long fan of the New York Yankees--and golf, and was a gifted writer and musician. He was particularly proud of his Scottish heritage and hosted an annual Robbie Burns Day party for his family and friends. John will always be remembered for his incredible mind, talents, kindness and wit. He will be missed by all who had the pleasure of knowing him. John was an adoring husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his beloved wife Judith; son John Thompson Ambler Finley, daughter-in-law Chase Haynes Finley, and grandson John Thompson Ambler Finley, Jr. of New York City; daughter Jaquelin Cary Finley of Chicago, IL; sister-in-law Julie Hamm Finley of Washington, D.C.; brother-in-law Gary Thomas Potter of Denver, CO; and several nieces and nephews. John was interred in Charlottesville, VA, following a private, family graveside service on July 9, 2015. His memorial service will be held at Christ Church Episcopal, 431 Union Street in Hudson, NY on Friday, July 17, at 4:00 p.m., followed by a gathering of family and friends. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial contributions be made to Columbia- Greene Humane Society, 125 Humane Society Road, Hudson, NY, 12534. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.hillandwood.com. 1/3

ROBINSON--Ruth Leonore, August 12, 1911-July 14, 2015, peacefully at her Home in Pompano Beach, Florida. Formerly of New York City. Much loved Mother of Margot Astrachan, Grandmother of Gregory Astrachan (Jacqueline) and Matthew Astrachan. Beloved Great- Grandmother of Sophie, Chloe, Chelsea, Isabel and Alexandra Astrachan. Fashion writer (Tobe Service Editor), lifelong golfer (achiever of two documented holes in one), and past Chair of The Women's Campaign Board of the American Jewish Committee. Her style, elegance and humor will be greatly missed. A private service will be held on Friday, July 17th, and family will welcome visitors on Thursday, July 16th and Friday, July 17th at the home of Margot Astrachan from 5:00 to 7:30pm. Please contact Plaza Community Chapel- 212-769-4400 for more information. 1/3

SEREBNICK--Seymour, 86, of Jackson Township died Tuesday, July 14, 2015 at his home following a brief illness. He leaves his wife of 52 years, Wendie "Joyce" Serebnick; his son Steven and wife Dale and their three children, Jordyn, Andrew and Ava; and his son Barry and wife Laura and their two children Jacob and Rachel. He is also survived by his sister, Norma Zweifler. Born in Brooklyn, New York in 1929, he was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School. He was a Veteran of the Korean War. Seymour met Wendie at his first job, working for a commercial finance company in New York. His career in the commercial finance industry continued for the next forty years. He was considered an expert in the area of secured transactions, and his advice was sought nationally by other lawyers in the field. 1/3

LO--Eva Lee, on July 14, 2015 at age 100. Beloved wife and soulmate of the late Philip C. F. Lo. Loving mother of Carolyn L. O'Hara. Proud grandmother of Tiffany O'Hara. Adored wife. She lived a charmed life, living in the Far East, Hong Kong, New York City and Washington, DC area. Born and raised in New York City, activist during WWII, managed Far East Division of the Lee Travel Agency family business. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm - with a prayer service to begin at 8pm. Committal Service, Saturday, 11:15am at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to The American Cancer Society. 1/3

JACOBS--Peter L.,80 of New York, NY passed away on Monday, July 13, 2015 of a heart attack at his summer home in Bridgehampton, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane, of 26 years, the love of his life. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on January 1, 1935, the son of Katie and David Jacobs. Peter graduated Brown University and Fordham Law School and upon graduation worked for his father's law firm. Years later, he started his own firm with corporate law and a focus on real estate. Peter worked assiduously on behalf of his clients, intent on giving a voice to the unheard. He will forever be remembered for his quiet determination to support and represent his clients, always putting their needs first and foremost. The funeral is scheduled for Thursday, July 16, 2015 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (630 Amsterdam Ave). Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal. 1/3

SLUTSKY--Lynn. Fun. Funny. Optimistic. Positive. No bull. Our secret weapon with great handwriting analysis skills. Dinner partner. Golf partner. Ski partner. We will miss you in so many ways. Our condolences to Jeff and Vicki and Jason. Love, Dale & Doug Anderson 1/3

GREENEBAUM--Charles L. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of long-time member Charles L. Greenebaum. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi 1/3

STERNLICHT-- Mark Leo. Died peacefully on July 15, 2015. Beloved husband to his wife of 57 years, Harriet, and loving father of Andrew, Barry and Russell Sternlicht. Proud grandfather of Alex, George, Eliza, James, Adrienne, William, Max, Jake, and Lily. He is also survived by his sister, Celina, and her husband, Marvin Zborowski. Mark Sternlicht was born in Krakow, Poland on December 9, 1929, the son of the late Jacob and Lola. He spent the years of World War II in hiding and fighting with the partisans in and around the mountains of the Czech Republic. He was 9 years old when the war broke out and 15 years old when it ended. He traveled from Poland, to the hills of Czechoslovakia, to Hungary, where he was adopted by a Hungarian priest, and back to Czech where he was liberated. As his father, Jacob, was captured by the Russians and sent to a labor camp, Mark became the de facto head of the family during the war years, living in caves and bartering for food and other life necessities. More than a year after the war, Mark was miraculously reunited with his father whom he presumed had passed. Mark went on to complete his education earning an electrical engineering degree from the University of Brussels. Mark, his parents, sister and grandmother immigrated to the United States in 1951 and settled in the Bronx. In 1956, he met the love of his life, Harriet Guiterman, at a wedding in February. They married in August of 1956, first moving to Jackson Heights and then settling in Jericho, Long Island where Mark worked as an engineer for Bechtel. He then moved his young family to Stamford, CT in 1968 and after several careers, founded the United States division of Wonder Corporation serving as its U.S. CEO. The company's success earned him many awards, a seat on the Connecticut Chamber of Commerce and Better Business Bureau and trips to China with Connecticut's then governor, Grasso. In his later years, he worked with the T.V.A. and at age 67, took the Series 7 exam and was offered a position at Smith Barney in Greenwich, where he joined his wife and spent another 10 years. Mark served as President of Congregation Agudath Sholom in his hometown, Stamford, on the Board of Bi-Cultural Day School, and on the Regional Board of the American Jewish Committee. Mark spoke more than eight languages. He loved the United States, its democracy, freedoms and "can do" anything attitude. He loved classical music, every car ever made, the opera, travel, his synagogue, his many friends and most of all, he loved his wife, his children, their families and especially his nine grandchildren with all his heart. Mark had a passion for all life had to offer and never took it for granted. He served as a mentor, consigliere, role model, fighter and a study in great character and resiliency to all who were blessed to know him. The family invites friends to the memorial service at Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Avenue in Stamford, CT on Thursday, July 16th at 10:00 am. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to Congregation Agudath Sholom, where a renovation and expansion are being planned in his honor. Services under the direction of Shippan's Thomas M. Gallagher Funeral Home 453 Shippan Ave, Stamford, CT gallagherfuneralhome. com 1/3

SZOR--Irene (91) Born February 5, 1924 in Lwow (Poland), died July 13, 2015 in New York, NY. A survivor of the Holocaust, she spent two years in the forests of eastern Poland hiding with a group of partisans. After the war she immigrated to the USA where she led a highly successful career designing dolls for the Horsman Doll Company. Wife of Leopold Szor and later Michael Lewin. She is survived by her son Daniel, daughter-in-law Katia, grandsons Henry and Alex and granddaughter Emily. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell funeral chapel at 12:00 on Sunday, July 19th followed by a burial at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla. Later in the afternoon there will be a reception for family and friends at Irene's home. 1/3

MILLER--Justin D. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our longtime, devoted member and Honorary Trustee, Justin Miller. Justin and his beloved wife, Arleen, have been members of the congregation for over fifty years. Our deepest condolences are extended to Arleen, their children, Beth Miller and Leslie and Brad Wagstaff, grandchildren James and Laura, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D. Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

MILLER--Justin. Born in 1918 in Manhattan, he built his life in New York as a loving family man, a proud businessman and veteran, and a lifelong adventurer. His bright spirit grew from Raquette Lake and the inspiration he found so often in the Adirondacks. Rested and calm, Justin passed on July 14th at his home. He leaves behind the love of his life and wife of 69 years, Arleen Miller, his two daughters, Leslie Miller Wagstaff (Brad), and Beth Miller, and two grandchildren, Laura and James. There will be a small, private service. The family will be at the Miller Residence on Thursday, July 16th from 3:00pm - 6:00pm. 1/3
SANDERS--Marlene. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of Marlene Sanders, a long-time member and winner of the Silurians' 1990 Lifetime Achievement Award. 1/3

KONSKER--Sandra. We mourn the untimely loss of Sandi. Beloved wife of the late Morton Konsker. We will miss her one-of-a-kind, uncanny sense of humor and her love of life. Our deepest condolences to her devoted sons, their wives, her loving grandchildren, and adored beau Mike. Rest in peace, we will miss you. Love, Brenda, Carlin, Lisa, Carly, Ian, Kenneth, Marla, Ilana, Hunter, Patti, Dave, and Wilma 1/3

LYNCH--Rose Peabody Parsons, aged 92 and beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother, died at her home in New Canaan, Connecticut this past Saturday, July 11 after a brief illness. Known as Rosie, she was born in New York City on July 1, 1923, the oldest daughter of William Barclay Parsons, Jr. M.D., and Rose Peabody Parsons. Her grandparents were Endicott Peabody, founder of the Groton School, and his wife Fanny Peabody, and William Barclay Parsons, founder of an engineering firm that later became Parsons Brinkerhoff and chief engineer of the first subway in New York City and the Cape Cod Canal, and his wife Anna Reed Parsons. Rosie was passionate about her extended family, the Groton School and, most of all, her grandchildren and great grandchildren. At the time of her death, she was an Honorary Council member of the Women's Prison Association, on whose Board she served for 45 years from 1969-2014 and as President from 1976 to 1979. Later in life, she was equally devoted to Staying Put, serving as an enthusiastic volunteer for this wonderful organization based in New Canaan, which is dedicated to serving the needs of the community's senior citizens helping them to enjoy safer, healthier and more independent lives in their own homes. In everything she did, Rosie brought both a strong hand and an even stronger sense of humor, for which all who knew her will remember as her most endearing quality. She will be deeply missed by her children, Rose Peabody Lynch of Greenwich, CT and New York City, R. Vincent Lynch, Jr. of New York City and his wife Cynthia, and Alexander Parsons Lynch of Greenwich, CT and his wife Sally, as well as her eight grandchildren and six, soon-to-be seven, great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations would be gratefully received by Staying Put, 58 Pine Street, New Canaan, CT 06840. A memorial service will be held in her honor in New Canaan in September. 1/3

BOCK--Patricia (Patti), passed away peacefully on July 15, 2015 with her family at her side. Pre-deceased by her husband, Jerry. They were married for over 60 years and were true partners in life. Survived by her daughter Portia, son George, son-in-law Craig and granddaughter Edie. Her family thanks caregivers Maria, Ewa and Wendy for making Patti's life as good as it could have been. Interment private. 1/3

SANDERS--Marlene. The Community Service Society extends its deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Marlene Sanders who passed away on Tuesday. Marlene was best known as a trailblazing female journalist whose early success as a television correspondent - she was the first woman to anchor a prime time network newscast - helped pave the way for others who would come after her and change the face of television news forever. But she was also a great friend to CSS, having served for more than 20 years as the Chair of the Retired and Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP), the organization's signature volunteer program, and as a former member until 2015 of the CSS Board of Trustees. A three- time Emmy Award winning correspondent, producer, writer, and former news executive, Marlene's illustrious career in journalism spanned more than three decades, including stints at ABC News, CBS News, and PBS. In addition to reporting assignments, she produced and narrated documentaries for HBO, public television, and others. When her journalism career was over Marlene remained active as an advocate for women in the news profession. She also contributed to the development of young journalists as adjunct professor at the NYU Journalism Institute. Marlene will be remembered as a warm, engaging, and undaunted individual who accomplished so much in her groundbreaking career and was incredibly generous with her time and resources. It is with sadness and a profound sense of loss that we mourn her death. 1/3

SZOR--Irene (91) Born February 5, 1924 in Lwow (Poland), died July 13, 2015 in New York, NY. A survivor of the Holocaust, she spent two years in the forests of eastern Poland hiding with a group of partisans. After the war she immigrated to the USA where she led a highly successful career designing dolls for the Horsman Doll Company. Wife of Leopold Szor and later Michael Lewin. She is survived by her son Daniel, daughter-in-law Katia, grandsons Henry and Alex and granddaughter Emily. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell funeral chapel at 12:00 on Sunday, July 19th followed by a burial at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla. Later in the afternoon there will be a reception for family and friends at Irene's home. 1/3

COHEN--Hon. Beverly. We mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague. Her sly wit, compassion and brilliance will be missed. Board of Justices N.Y. Cty. Supreme Court 1/3

NOVICK--Thelma (Tobie). One year has gone by. Her spirit, generosity and passion for life was admired by all who shared time with her. Every day we remain grateful for all that she gave us. As always, Al Parmet 1/3
FELDMAN--Rosalie, of Long Island, wife of Edward and mother of four, died on Tuesday. Shiva is at the home of eldest daughter on Sunday and Monday, Noon until 8pm. 1/3

SEREBNICK--Seymour, 86, of Jackson Township died Tuesday, July 14, 2015 at his home following a brief illness. He leaves his wife of 52 years, Wendie "Joyce" Serebnick; his son Steven and wife Dale and their three children, Jordyn, Andrew and Ava; and his son Barry and wife Laura and their two children Jacob and Rachel. He is also survived by his sister, Norma Zweifler. Born in Brooklyn, New York in 1929, he was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School. He was a Veteran of the Korean War. Seymour met Wendie at his first job, working for a commercial finance company in New York. His career in the commercial finance industry continued for the next forty years. He was considered an expert in the area of secured transactions, and his advice was sought nationally by other lawyers in the field. 1/3
LYNCH--Rose Parsons. The Women's Prison Association (WPA) mourns the passing of our long-time Board member and past president. Her commitment and commentary were legendary. She will be missed. 1/3

WINTERKORN--Jacqueline M. S.,Ph.D., M.D., 68, beloved mother, grandmother, wife, physician, teacher, and friend, died on Saturday, July 11. A resident of Roxbury, Connecticut, Dr. Winterkorn was born and raised in Queens, the youngest of the four children of Louis Schuker and Millicent Milchman Schuker. Dr. Winterkorn earned a B.A. from Barnard College, a Ph.D. in neurobiology from Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences, and a M.D. from Cornell University Medical College. She taught neuroanatomy at Cornell and subsequently practiced and taught neuro-ophthalmology at Cornell for nearly 25 years. Dr. Winterkorn married and later divorced Hans F. Z. Winterkorn III. In 1986, she married Dr. Thomas H. Meikle, Jr., the then Dean of Cornell University Medical College and later President of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation. After Dr. Meikle's death, she married attorney David Lincicome. She is survived by her husband David, her siblings Stephen, Eleanor, and Theodore Schuker, her daughters Elisabeth Winterkorn and Margaret Meyers, and her grandchildren Samuel, Benjamin, and Charlotte Lyczkowski, and Louise Meyers. The memorial service will be on Saturday, July 18th, at 11am at the Roxbury Congregational Church, 24 Church Street Roxbury, CT. Memorial contributions can be made to Weill Cornell Medical College 1300 York Ave. New York, NY 10021. Online condolences can be sent to www.munsonloveterefunera lhome.com. 1/3
SCHECHTER--Lynn. Goodbye to our wonderful friend. We will always remember the happy times we shared and we will miss you forever. Love, Valerie and Bob 1/3
VISCUSI--Mildred. 07/16/29 - 07/17/93. 22 years of missing you. You are in our thoughts and prayers everyday. Love, Stephen & Casey, Laura & Ross 1/3

STERNLICHT--Mark. The LeFrak family deeply mourns the passing of Mark Sternlicht. We extend our profound condolences to his devoted wife, Harriet; their sons, Andrew, Russell, and our friend and partner, Barry; and to the entire Sternlicht family. 1/3

SANDERS--Marlene. Her service to the Foundation in its mission of helping young documentary filmmakers take the next step in their careers was substantial and will be greatly missed. 1/3

SCHNITZER--Murray, 76, of New York City passed away Wednesday, July 15, 2015. He is survived by his family and friends who loved him. He was a teacher for over 35 years in the New York City school system. His warmth, compassion, bright spirit and humor touched us all. Service Sunday, 1pm at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 57-80 Cooper Ave. Ridgewood (Queens), NY. 1/3

BLASI--Beatrice Anna, 89, of NYC, died peacefully at her home on June 13, 2015. Beatrice was born in Medford, MA on May 9, 1926, the daughter of the late Olindo C. and Anna (Gualtieri) Blasi. Beatrice graduated from East Boston High School, and continued her education at CCNY. She studied Spanish and travelled through Spain, taking courses in the language and arts of the regions. In 1960 Beatrice moved to NYC, and made it her home for the past 55 years. She enjoyed all that NYC had to offer, including the Ballet, Opera and Symphony, with the many NYC friends she made over the years. Beatrice retired after a long professional career at Sea- Land Service, Inc., NJ. There will be a memorial celebration of her life in MA for family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the New York City Ballet Education Department, Samuel B. and David Rose Building, 8th Floor, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023 or to a charity of choice. 1/3

ROBINSON--Ruth Leonore, August 12, 1911-July 14, 2015, peacefully at her Home in Pompano Beach, Florida. Formerly of New York City. Much loved Mother of Margot Astrachan, Grandmother of Gregory Astrachan (Jacqueline) and Matthew Astrachan. Beloved Great- Grandmother of Sophie, Chloe, Chelsea, Isabel and Alexandra Astrachan. Fashion writer (Tobe Service Editor), lifelong golfer (achiever of two documented holes in one), and past Chair of The Women's Campaign Board of the American Jewish Committee. Her style, elegance and humor will be greatly missed. A private service will be held on Friday, July 17th, and family will welcome visitors on Thursday, July 16th and Friday, July 17th at the home of Margot Astrachan from 5:00 to 7:30pm. Please contact Plaza Community Chapel- 212-769-4400 for more information. 1/3

GOULD--Eric Witty. Beloved father of Ruby, Benjamin and Spencer, son of Lawrence and Jane, brother of Lance, brother-in-law to Michele, uncle of Samantha and Lucy, nephew of Ken and Eleanor Pearlman -- passed away July 6, 2015. The senior vice president of Valley National Bank had been fighting primary central nervous system lymphoma for two and a half years. He was 47. He graduated from Tulane University, where he was president of the Phi Kappa Sigma fraternity. He also earned an MBA from Pace University. As a son, brother, and friend, Eric lit up the room with his electric smile, quick wit, and good looks. And as a father, there was none finer. He was singularly dedicated to his three children, and took great pride in their achievements. If you asked him what he was most proud of, he would always mention Ruby, Ben and Spencer first. A private memorial service will be held July 26th in Morristown, NJ. 1/3

HOLMES--Russell B.,91, a former CIA specialist on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, died of cancer on December 18, 2014. Mr. Holmes was a career intelligence officer with the Office of Strategic Services and the CIA. He was born on September 20, 1923 in Mystic, CT. Mr. Holmes served as an officer in the Navy during WWII. He then enrolled at Brown University, where he met Fiora, his wife of 64 years. At the CIA, Mr. Holmes worked on foreign and domestic affairs, including counter-intelligence issues in Europe and Southeast Asia. He retired in 1979, but continued working as an archivist of CIA documents related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. These archives came to be known as the "Russell B. Holmes Work File," one of the most cited sources on the Kennedy assassination. Mr. Holmes supported charities, scholarships at various universities, and was a member of the Kennedy Center Circles for the Performing Arts. Mr. Holmes is survived by his wife and daughter, Jennifer Starr Holmes. Interment will take place at the Arlington National Cemetery on Wednesday, July 22, 2015 at 2pm. Memorial donations may be made to The Washington Home and Hospice, 3720 Upton St. NW, Washington, DC 20016. 1/3

SLUTSKY--Lynn. Fun. Funny. Optimistic. Positive. No bull. Our secret weapon with great handwriting analysis skills. Dinner partner. Golf partner. Ski partner. We will miss you in so many ways. Our condolences to Jeff and Vicki and Jason. Love, Dale & Doug Anderson 1/3

SHAPIRO--William Eric, 81, passed away on June 7, 2015. Bill's career in reference-book publishing spanned more than 50 years as author, editor, wordsmith, and encyclopedist. He authored nine nonfiction books for children, was Editor in Chief of The New Book of Knowledge, and wrote hundreds of articles for numerous reference works. A lover of cats, crossword puzzles, maps, flea-market finds, and his family, Bill was appreciated for his warmth, intellect and sharp sense of humor. He will be deeply missed by his two sons with Joan, Jonathan and Scott; daughters-in-law, Catherine and Karen; five grandchildren, Nicole, Daniel, Will, Sam, and Jack; brother and sister-in-law, Phillip and Arlene; long-time companion Fern Mamberg; and many other relatives and friends. 1/3
SCHECHTER--Lynn. Beloved and adored friend who is irreplaceable and will be in our hearts forever. We miss you dearly. Patty and Stephen Sokolow and all of the Sokolow clan 1/3

JACOBS--Peter L.,80 of New York, NY passed away on Monday, July 13, 2015 of a heart attack at his summer home in Bridgehampton, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane, of 26 years, the love of his life. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on January 1, 1935, the son of Katie and David Jacobs. Peter graduated Brown University and Fordham Law School and upon graduation worked for his father's law firm. Years later, he started his own firm with corporate law and a focus on real estate. Peter worked assiduously on behalf of his clients, intent on giving a voice to the unheard. He will forever be remembered for his quiet determination to support and represent his clients, always putting their needs first and foremost. The funeral is scheduled for Thursday, July 16, 2015 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (630 Amsterdam Ave). Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal. 1/3

TUTTLE--Esther. The Board of Trustees, Auxiliary, Volunteers, and Staff of Brooklyn Botanic Garden mourn the passing of our dear friend and past Board Chair Esther (Faity) Leeming Tuttle, who died on July 9 at age 104. Faity's deep involvement with the Garden spanned more than 70 years. She served in a variety of leadership roles, including as Auxiliary President from 1961 to 1963, as a Trustee from 1963 to 2002, and as Board Chair from 1970 to 1977. During her term as Board Chair, she oversaw the Garden's incorporation as a separate entity from its parent institution, the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, a major step in modernizing the Garden's administration. Drawing upon a background in the arts, she also helped produce a series of horticulturally themed films for the Garden. She was honored by BBG in 1988 in recognition of her many contributions. Faity Tuttle's dedication to community, her enthusiasm for life, and her unflagging energy and vibrancy inspired all who knew her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her two surviving children, as well as her ten grandchildren, her 13 great-grandchildren, her 23 great-great-grandchildren. Frederick Bland, Chair Scot Medbury, President Frances Mendlow, Auxiliary President 1/3
STEARNS--Donald A. Don, I will love you life after life... age after age... I will love you forever. Shirley 1/3

COHEN--Beverly Sher, died at home Monday two years after a diagnosis of late-stage ovarian cancer. She was 85. The last two years were her life in microcosm - fiercely independent; thrilled (and at times disappointed) by theater and travel; closely following the news, usually on her beloved iPad; sustained by old friends; still engaged and challenged by legal work. Above all, was her devotion to family - Stuart, her husband of nearly 60 years; her sons, Adam, Harlan and Noam; her daughter-in-law, Aviva Michaelov; and Nuli and Kika, her granddaughters. Even as illness weakened her body, her personality, drive and deep intelligence never flagged. Beverly was born Aug. 29, 1929, in Buffalo, and raised in the Bronx by her father, Julius, a dentist, and mother, Alta, a lawyer who worked for Zionist organizations. Her older sister, Harriett Shapiro, who taught college biology and was a civic leader in Amherst, Mass., died in 2005. Beverly graduated Christopher Columbus High School at 16 and earned a scholarship to Cornell. At NYU Law School, where she met Stuart, her life took shape. In 1976, Beverly was elected Civil Court judge. In nearly 25 years on the bench, much served as a State Supreme Court justice, she championed the rights of New Yorkers, from tenants facing wrongful eviction to homeless people returning bottles for deposits who were turned away by supermarkets. We will forever cherish her memory. Family and friends will gather from 1pm to 5pm Friday, Saturday and Sunday at the home of Stuart Cohen. 1/3

EPSTEIN--Lillian, died at her home on July 11th after a long illness. She was 95. She was born in Brooklyn, the youngest of three children and the only daughter of Samuel and Bessie Scher. She attended and excelled in New York's public schools, but denied herself the opportunity to go on to college out of a sense of responsibility to help support her widowed mother. A keen sense of responsibility and kindness were the dominant traits of her character. She held several jobs before joining the Voice of America, where she was a valued member of the staff during and after World War II. She was the loving and beloved wife of Harold; they were married for 66 years. She was a devoted mother to her four children and their spouses; Susan (Dr. Harold Horowitz), Rachel (Dr. William Breitbart), Lawrence (Elizabeth), and Michael (Margaret). She cherished and enjoyed her seven grandchildren and two step-grandchildren. She was a loyal friend. All who knew her will remember her with love. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, the Multiple Sclerosis Society, or the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

PETRAS--Dorothea A.,on July 17, 2015 of Plandome. Beloved wife of Nicholas for over 57 years. Loving mother of Catherine, Nicholas Jr. (Ruth) and Paul (Laura). Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth, Timothy, Katherine, Rebecca, Nicholas III, Charles and Samson. Devoted sister of the late Ida DePrisco. Graduate of Elmira College Class of 1954. Visitation will be held at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Tuesday, 10am, Archangel Michael Greek Orthodox Church, Port Washington. Donations may be made in her memory to the Friends of the Manhasset Public Library. 1/3
SCHECHTER--Lynn. Beloved and adored friend who is irreplaceable and will be in our hearts forever. We miss you dearly. Patty and Stephen Sokolow and all of the Sokolow clan 1/3

MACE--Jeffrey Howard. The family, friends and colleagues of Jeffrey Mace deeply mourn his loss on July 16, 2015. Valued by his many law partners and clients alike as an extraordinarily wise and trusted advisor, Jeff was a partner in the New York Office and a member of the Executive Committee of Sutherland Asbill & Brennan, where he headed the Lloyd's of London practice. The consummate lawyer, he served as principal counsel to Lloyd's in the U.S. for more than 25 years, and was personally singled out for recognition by then Chairman of Lloyd's Sir David Rowland for shepherding the venerable insurance market through Reconstruction & Renewal in the 1990s. He also represented Lloyd's in high level negotiations with the United States Treasury and matters before other state and federal regulators. Born in Brooklyn in 1956, Jeff graduated from the University of Arizona and Hofstra Law School and began his career as a CPA. He progressed to tax partner at the former LeBoeuf Lamb Greene & MacRae, and ultimately advised many of the leading insurers and reinsurers in the world on their most sensitive and significant tax, regulatory and corporate matters. More important to Jeff than his many triumphs for his clients was his beloved and loving family. He is survived by his devoted wife of 23 years, Rhonda Click Mace, whom he adored, and the children who were his pride and joy: Matthew Lawrence Mace and Leah Meredith Mace; his mother Beatrice Mace Weinberg; his sisters and brothers Barbara Mace Geller (Howard), Scott Mace (Carolyn), Bruce Weinberg (Geri), Mindy Weinberg Becker (Barry) and Richie Weinberg (Marilyn); and his loving nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his father, Donald Mace (d. 1968) and stepfather Morris Weinberg (d. 2009). Jeff played a leadership role in raising awareness and funding for scleroderma, serving as the President of the Board of Directors of The Scleroderma Foundation and a Board member of The Scleroderma Research Foundation, and he lobbied Congress to pass the Scleroderma Research and Awareness Act. In everything he did, including the simplest acts of his daily life, Jeff inspired and led by shining example, with the utmost integrity, grace, compassion, courage, humility and his towering intellect. He was a true hero, greatly respected and much loved. Funeral services will be on Sunday, July 19, at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, in Manhattan. The family encourages donations in Jeff's memory to The Scleroderma Research Foundation and Scleroderma Foundation, Tri-State, Inc. 1/3

We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband Melvin and the entire family in their time of sorrow. Marc Friedman, President 1/3

GELB--Gina. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Walter J. Molofsky, M.D., Chairman Jacob D. Gold, President 1/3

LYNCH--Rose Peabody Parsons, aged 92 and beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother, died at her home in New Canaan, Connecticut this past Saturday, July 11 after a brief illness. Known as Rosie, she was born in New York City on July 1, 1923, the oldest daughter of William Barclay Parsons, Jr. M.D., and Rose Peabody Parsons. Her grandparents were Endicott Peabody, founder of the Groton School, and his wife Fanny Peabody, and William Barclay Parsons, founder of an engineering firm that later became Parsons Brinkerhoff and chief engineer of the first subway in New York City and the Cape Cod Canal, and his wife Anna Reed Parsons. Rosie was passionate about her extended family, the Groton School and, most of all, her grandchildren and great grandchildren. At the time of her death, she was an Honorary Council member of the Women's Prison Association, on whose Board she served for 45 years from 1969-2014 and as President from 1976 to 1979. Later in life, she was equally devoted to Staying Put, serving as an enthusiastic volunteer for this wonderful organization based in New Canaan, which is dedicated to serving the needs of the community's senior citizens helping them to enjoy safer, healthier and more independent lives in their own homes. In everything she did, Rosie brought both a strong hand and an even stronger sense of humor, for which all who knew her will remember as her most endearing quality. She will be deeply missed by her children, Rose Peabody Lynch of Greenwich, CT and New York City, R. Vincent Lynch, Jr. of New York City and his wife Cynthia, and Alexander Parsons Lynch of Greenwich, CT and his wife Sally, as well as her eight grandchildren and six, soon-to-be seven, great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations would be gratefully received by Staying Put, 58 Pine Street, New Canaan, CT 06840. A memorial service will be held in her honor in New Canaan in September. 1/3

SHAPIRO--William Eric, 81, passed away on June 7, 2015. Bill's career in reference-book publishing spanned more than 50 years as author, editor, wordsmith, and encyclopedist. He authored nine nonfiction books for children, was Editor in Chief of The New Book of Knowledge, and wrote hundreds of articles for numerous reference works. A lover of cats, crossword puzzles, maps, flea-market finds, and his family, Bill was appreciated for his warmth, intellect and sharp sense of humor. He will be deeply missed by his two sons with Joan, Jonathan and Scott; daughters-in-law, Catherine and Karen; five grandchildren, Nicole, Daniel, Will, Sam, and Jack; brother and sister-in-law, Phillip and Arlene; long-time companion Fern Mamberg; and many other relatives and friends. 1/3
HAGOUEL--Tzeky. 3/7/52 - 7/18/2010. Tzeky mou: LOVE NEVER FAILS. Nana and our boys 1/3

HESDORFFER--Lotte Karoline (nee Mayer), passed away peacefully at the age of 84 from complications of pancreatic cancer on Thursday July 16th at her home in Annapolis, Maryland. Her only son Charles and daughter-in-law Mary Hesdorffer were at her bedside. Lotte was born in Kaiserslautern, Germany on September 18th 1930. She was an only child and fled from the Nazi regime after Kristallnacht only to be caught up in the mayhem of the Second World War in her adopted Holland. After the war she immigrated to South Africa where she lived with her cousins, the Hess family, and studied sociology at the University of the Witwatersrand. She married in 1954 and worked with her husband in his wholesale jewelry business until they joined their son and his family in New York City in 2002, Lotte subsequently moving with them to Annapolis in 2011. A holocaust survivor who only wanted the best life for her family, she gave it to them in spades. Lotte is survived by her husband of 61 years, Heinz Hesdorffer, who, for health reasons returned to Europe in 2009, and now resides in the Budge Stiftung, Frankfurt, Germany. She is also survived by her only child, Charles and his wife Mary, their two children, Alex and Anna Plitsas, and two grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday 19th July at 11:15am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY 10023 to be followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, any donations should be made in her honor to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation, 1317 Kings ST, Virginia, 22314 or online at www.curemeso.org where she was a stalwart volunteer and supporter even in the dark days of her illness. 1/3

BATES--Eve 1913 - 2015 Passed away peacefully in her sleep July 16 - 102 years old. Eve Bates was born of immigrant parents, grew up in Jazz Age New York, and became a passionate activist for social and labor causes. She joined Harold L. Oram and associates in pioneering the application of ethical fund-raising techniques to liberal and progressive causes. It became her life-long work and helped shape American society into what it is today. In 1942 she married Ralph Bates, English novelist and Spanish Civil War revolutionary who later became an NYU professor (see The New York Times obit 12/2000) They lived in Greenwich Village and on the Greek island of Naxos for decades. Eve Bates died of old age and renal failure. She is survived by her son, Jonathan. There will be a memorial service in mid-September. For further information, contact batesjonathan@yahoo.com. 1/3

GLICKSMAN--Albert, Aly-dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love, Fran 1/3
ZANKEL--Robert Thomas. Always loved, always missed. The WSM Judy 1/3

SHACK--Donald. Died peacefully at home on July 12, 2015, after a short illness, at the age of 86, surrounded by his family. Donald graduated Williams College (Phi Beta Kappa) and Harvard Law School before serving in the Korean War. For more than 60 years he had a distinguished career practicing law in New York City as the managing partner of Golenbock and Barell, a founding partner of Shack, Siegel, Katz & Flaherty, and a partner of Blank Rome. Donald was an indispensable adviser to his clients, many of whom became life-long friends. Actively involved for years in the New York Civil Liberties Union, Donald was a champion of the underdog. Born and raised in Brooklyn, he was heart-broken when his Dodgers moved west but quickly shifted his "wait until next year" brand of fandom to the Mets, who, like the bums before, rarely exceeded his expectations. Donald loved tennis, sailing, and swimming, lively conversation, theater, music, good books, good food, and good Scotch. Yet Donald was most of all devoted to his family. He lost his loving wife of 61 years, Barbara, barely a month ago. Donald was a rock in the lives of his children, David and Laura, a beacon for his grandchildren Nicole, Joseph, and Francesca, to whom he was affectionately known as Papa, and looked forward to providing direction to his great-grand-children, Emma and Olivia. We will miss his penetrating mind, his social conscience, his deep love for his family, and his loyalty to his friends. A memorial service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10024 on Sunday, July 26, 2015 at 4:00pm. The family will be at Donald and Barbara's home at 7 West 81st Street on Sunday, July 26th and Monday, July 27th 6-8pm. Contributions may be made in Donald's memory to The American Civil Liberties Union. 1/3
LYNCH--Rose Parsons. The Women's Prison Association (WPA) mourns the passing of our long-time Board member and past president. Her commitment and commentary were legendary. She will be missed. 1/3

JACOBS--Peter L.,80 of New York, NY passed away on Monday, July 13, 2015 of a heart attack at his summer home in Bridgehampton, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane, of 26 years, the love of his life. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on January 1, 1935, the son of Katie and David Jacobs. Peter graduated Brown University and Fordham Law School and upon graduation worked for his father's law firm. Years later, he started his own firm with corporate law and a focus on real estate. Peter worked assiduously on behalf of his clients, intent on giving a voice to the unheard. He will forever be remembered for his quiet determination to support and represent his clients, always putting their needs first and foremost. The funeral is scheduled for Thursday, July 16, 2015 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (630 Amsterdam Ave). Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal. 1/3
