LANZA--William Michael, 66, of North Bergen, on July 14, 2015. Memorial mass Thursday, July 23rd Historic Church of Madonna at 11am. Memorial July 23rd 4-8pm at The Watermark services at 7pm. For more information (201) 944-0100 or frankpatti.com 1/3

RITCHIE--Jeanie Baldwin, age 77, died peacefully at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, New Hampshire, on Tuesday, July 7, 2015. The cause of death was cancer. Born November 20, 1937, in Boston, Massachusetts she grew up in Wilmington, Delaware and later lived in Summit, New Jersey, and Kenilworth, Illinois while summering in Canaan, New Hampshire. She graduated from Dana Hall School in Wellesley, Massachusetts and completed her studies at Bennett College. Jeanie worked at J. Walter Thompson before becoming a full-time Mom. She was a member of the Garden Club of America and the National Society of The Colonial Dames of America. Survivors include her husband of 53 wonderful years, Tom Ritchie, and her son, Bob (wife Hilary) and daughter, Katherine (husband Ted). Jeanie was preceded in death by her son, Tim. She is also survived by her three grandchildren, Dylan, Morgan and Paige. Jeanie's family is also expecting a fourth grandchild in October. Services will be held at 11am, Saturday, August 8, at the Central Presbyterian Church, 70 Maple Street, Summit, NJ. Relatives and friends are welcome at the service and the reception at Baltusrol Golf Club, 21 Shunpike Road, Springfield Township, NJ, immediately following the service at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions are welcome and should be mailed to Dana Hall School, 45 Dana Road, Wellesley, Massachusetts 02482. 1/3

BEGLEY--George Rollo, 72, died peacefully on July 10th from complications of esophageal cancer. Originally from Holywood, Northern Ireland, George came to the US in 1972 with his beloved wife Sally to work in global capital markets, a field in which he excelled. His incurable wanderlust took him around the world and back again many times over. In his final days, prayer flags were raised for him in Nepal, and prayers were said in mosques in Mali and chapels in Dubai. He is survived by his wife Sally, children Rollo and Tracey, and brothers Richard and Charles. 1/3
SCHECHTER--Lynn. Goodbye to our wonderful friend. We will always remember the happy times we shared and we will miss you forever. Love, Valerie and Bob 1/3

SANDERS--Marlene. The Community Service Society extends its deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Marlene Sanders who passed away on Tuesday. Marlene was best known as a trailblazing female journalist whose early success as a television correspondent - she was the first woman to anchor a prime time network newscast - helped pave the way for others who would come after her and change the face of television news forever. But she was also a great friend to CSS, having served for more than 20 years as the Chair of the Retired and Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP), the organization's signature volunteer program, and as a former member until 2015 of the CSS Board of Trustees. A three- time Emmy Award winning correspondent, producer, writer, and former news executive, Marlene's illustrious career in journalism spanned more than three decades, including stints at ABC News, CBS News, and PBS. In addition to reporting assignments, she produced and narrated documentaries for HBO, public television, and others. When her journalism career was over Marlene remained active as an advocate for women in the news profession. She also contributed to the development of young journalists as adjunct professor at the NYU Journalism Institute. Marlene will be remembered as a warm, engaging, and undaunted individual who accomplished so much in her groundbreaking career and was incredibly generous with her time and resources. It is with sadness and a profound sense of loss that we mourn her death. 1/3

GARFINKEL--Gina, of Glen Head, New York, August 6, 1930 to July 10, 2015. Gina passed away less than 12 weeks after her husband, David Garfinkel, passed away on April 15th. She is survived by her daughter Eva Drabkin, husband Jess Drabkin and grandchildren Michael, Hilary and Brooke, by son James Garfinkel, wife Naomi Garfinkel and granddaughter Maya, and by her brother Arie Rosenbach. Gina and David had a 60-year marriage and a 61-year love affair. Gina was from Pzevorsk, Poland, the daughter of Joseph and Betty Rosenbach. She and her family fled the Nazi invasion of Poland in 1939 and were taken prisoner by the Russians, spending World War II in a slave labor camp in Yakutsk, Siberia. Gina and David built a beautiful family and a beautiful legacy. They built a world of "I love you"; a world where neighbors and friends would come knocking on their door at nine at night for coffee, conversation and maybe even a poker game; a world where people came to their house from Israel and Europe and stayed not for days or weeks, but for months. Gina and David were Queen and King of the beach at Playa Linda in Aruba, holding court at Chickee #

MACE--Jeffrey Howard. The family, friends and colleagues of Jeffrey Mace deeply mourn his loss on July 16, 2015. Valued by his many law partners and clients alike as an extraordinarily wise and trusted advisor, Jeff was a partner in the New York Office and a member of the Executive Committee of Sutherland Asbill & Brennan, where he headed the Lloyd's of London practice. The consummate lawyer, he served as principal counsel to Lloyd's in the U.S. for more than 25 years, and was personally singled out for recognition by then Chairman of Lloyd's Sir David Rowland for shepherding the venerable insurance market through Reconstruction & Renewal in the 1990s. He also represented Lloyd's in high level negotiations with the United States Treasury and matters before other state and federal regulators. Born in Brooklyn in 1956, Jeff graduated from the University of Arizona and Hofstra Law School and began his career as a CPA. He progressed to tax partner at the former LeBoeuf Lamb Greene & MacRae, and ultimately advised many of the leading insurers and reinsurers in the world on their most sensitive and significant tax, regulatory and corporate matters. More important to Jeff than his many triumphs for his clients was his beloved and loving family. He is survived by his devoted wife of 23 years, Rhonda Click Mace, whom he adored, and the children who were his pride and joy: Matthew Lawrence Mace and Leah Meredith Mace; his mother Beatrice Mace Weinberg; his sisters and brothers Barbara Mace Geller (Howard), Scott Mace (Carolyn), Bruce Weinberg (Geri), Mindy Weinberg Becker (Barry) and Richie Weinberg (Marilyn); and his loving nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his father, Donald Mace (d. 1968) and stepfather Morris Weinberg (d. 2009). Jeff played a leadership role in raising awareness and funding for scleroderma, serving as the President of the Board of Directors of The Scleroderma Foundation and a Board member of The Scleroderma Research Foundation, and he lobbied Congress to pass the Scleroderma Research and Awareness Act. In everything he did, including the simplest acts of his daily life, Jeff inspired and led by shining example, with the utmost integrity, grace, compassion, courage, humility and his towering intellect. He was a true hero, greatly respected and much loved. Funeral services will be on Sunday, July 19, at noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, in Manhattan. The family encourages donations in Jeff's memory to The Scleroderma Research Foundation and Scleroderma Foundation, Tri-State, Inc. 1/3

PERTZ--Stuart King, of Rowayton, CT and Park Slope NY, passed away on Wednesday July 8, 2015 at his home. He leaves his beloved wife of 50 years, Jeanette, his two loving daughters, Eliza and Joanna, five devoted grandsons and his caring sister Marion Goodman. Born in Brooklyn, NY he was educated at Brooklyn Tech, UC Berkeley, Ecole des Beaux Arts Fontainebleau and Princeton University where he received his BA and MFA in Architecture. A Fellow of the American Institute of Architects, Mr. Pertz also served as a member of the NYC Planning Commission and as Chairman of the Board of the University Settlement. He was a founding member of the recently resuscitated City Club of New York and an active member of the Century Club. An architect, planner and urban designer, Mr. Pertz designed housing for the New York State Urban Development Corp, developed zoning and urban design plans for Charleston SC, New Britain and Norwalk, CT and for Taiwan, China, Armenia and Kuwait City. As a partner at HLW, he created the strategic planning group for General Motors and projects throughout Europe. He was a Professor of Architecture and Planning and then Chair of the Graduate Program in Urban Design at Pratt Institute. Recently, he had been teaching the Sustainable Communities studio, a seminar on Implementing Advocacy and part of the now established program in Urban Placemaking and Management at Pratt's Graduate Program in Planning, of which he was co-creator. He was an inspiring and passionate teacher and lecturer who loved his students. A unique and creative individual with a great sense of humor, he was dedicated to creating communities that reflect people's needs and values. Stuart was generous of spirit with a driven love of learning, whose interest in how the world works never ceased. During extensive travels with his wife, Jeanette, over the last 25 years, he loved to record the world around him through sketches and watercolors of streets, plazas and architecture. His other love, ceramics - from beautiful simple pots to fantastical figures and animals, are illustrated in a wonderful little book called Creating Friends. Memorial contributions may be made in his honor to his non-profit: the Stuart K. Pertz Center for Urban Placemaking, Inc., c/o McCanliss & Early LLP, Wall St. Plaza, 88 Pine St., NY, NY 10005. For online guestbook: www.Magnerfuneralhome. com 1/3

ROMANI--John H.,age 90, of Ann Arbor, Michigan passed away on July 8 of natural causes. After serving in World War II, he received Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Government from the University of New Hampshire and a Ph.D. in Political Science from the University of Michigan. He held faculty appointments at the University of New Hampshire, Western Michigan University and the University of Pittsburgh prior to serving on the faculty of the University of Michigan School of Public Health, for over 30 years. He was Associate Dean of that School as well as Associate Vice President for Academic Affairs of the University. He also served briefly as Vice Chancellor and Professor of Political Science at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. Throughout his career he worked with a wide variety of governmental and non-governmental agencies on issues associated with the organization and administration of public health activities, both domestically and internationally. Among his professional activities were his service on the National Council of the American Society for Public Administration and as President of the American Public Health Association. A committed classroom teacher he continued, after his formal retirement from the University of Michigan in 1993, to teach at the School of Public Health and in the University of Michigan Program in the Environment. His post-retirement years were also taken up with research on population and health in South Africa where he and his wife, Professor Barbara Anderson of the University of Michigan Department of Sociology, who survives him, have spent time each year since 1999 working with colleagues there. www.muehligannarbor.com 1/3

GIBSON--William B.,Jr., 76, of Cranbury, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family on Thursday, July 16, 2015. Born in Queens to the late William B. Gibson, Sr. and Catherine (nee Curcio), he grew up in Brooklyn near the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He later moved to New Jersey, where he raised his family, most recently residing in Princeton and Cranbury. Mr. Gibson worked for Sudler & Hennessey, Inc., beginning in 1970. He was named President in 1982, and Chairman and CEO in 1984. He retired as CEO in 1996, after 26 years of dedicated work. He also sat on the board of directors for Young & Rubicam, Inc. Mr. Gibson adored his beloved wife of 52 years, Patricia Gibson. He was happiest while at home spending time with his family. He was a wonderful provider, devoted father, and loving grandfather. He enjoyed listening to and playing music, traveling, and he had an incredible sense of humor. He was a dedicated church attendee, with a deep and abiding faith. He will be greatly missed by all of those who had the privilege of knowing him. Mr. Gibson is predeceased by his brother, Rev. Anthony L. Gibson. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Gibson; sons, Chris Gibson, David Gibson and wife, Lee Anne, and Bill Gibson and wife, Anne Marie, as well as 10 grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held on Monday, July 20, 2015, at 11:30am at A.S. Cole Son & Co., 22 N. Main Street, Cranbury NJ 08512. Interment will follow in Brainerd Cemetery, Cranbury. Relatives and friends may call on Saturday, July 18, 2015, from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. and on Sunday, July 19, 2015, from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. at the Funeral Home. Memorial contributions may be made in Mr. Gibson's memory to The Star of Hope Ministries, Inc., 34 Broadway, Paterson, NJ 07505. www.saulfuneralhomes.com 1/3

She was a Vice President of The American Heart Association and a Vice President of the Performing Arts Center at SUNY Purchase, New York. Mimi married Joseph Verner Reed, Jr. on December 19, 1959. They had two daughters, Serena Reed Kusserow of Santa Barbara, California and Electra Reed of Greenwich, Connecticut and four grandchildren. Mimi was a member of the Colony Club of New York, the Gasparilla Inn Beach Club of Boca Grande, Florida, the Round Hill Club of Greenwich, Connecticut and the Harbor Club of Seal Harbor, Maine. Funeral and Memorial Services are to be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mimi's memory may be made to the ASPCA of Hancock County, Maine (141 Bar Harbor Road, Trenton, ME 04605). 1/3

THOMAS--John C, Jr. Born July 27, 1927 in Port Chester, NY died July 9, 2015 in New York City. Long time magazine publishing executive, he attended Columbia earning degrees from the College and the Graduate School of Business. Enlisting in the Navy on his 18th birthday, which occurred one month before VJ Day, he served on active duty less than a year, but was later recalled for two years of sea duty serving in the Korean War. Commencing his publishing career at McCall's Magazine in 1953, he remained there until 1959 when he moved to Time Inc. Serving in various managerial capacities, he was named Director of Time's U.S. sales in 1971. Two years later he joined Clay Felker as Publisher of New York and later founding Publisher of New York's newly launched California magazine, New West. After Rupert Murdoch's purchase of New York, he helped The New York Times introduce their competitor to Time's People called US. In 1978, he and three partners launched A/S/M Communications, which published Adweek, Brandweek, Mediaweek, and other specialized advertising and marketing communications. He served as President and later Chairman. After A/S/M sold to the Boston Globe in 1990, he remained as a consultant, retiring in 2000. Long time resident of Locust Valley, he was active in the Episcopal Church serving as Senior Warden at St. John's of Lattingtown; vice-president of Episcopal Charities of Long Island and a Trustee of the Diocese. He was a Trustee of the Village of Lattingtown and a past President of The Creek Club. Pre-deceased by his wife, Eula Metzger and his son Jeffrey Leonard, he is survived by his Children Mark Gregory Thomas (Ruth), Pamela Cook Thomas and Suzanne Thomas Houghton and his six grandchildren: Leah Thomas (Ryan), Jeffrey Thomas (Cora), Allegra, Jack and Clementine Houghton, and Christine Thomas. Memorial service St. John's of Lattingtown, Lattingtown, New York on July 22nd at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations in John Thomas Jr's name may be made to The Metropolitan Opera. 1/3

LYNCH--Rose Peabody Parsons, aged 92 and beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother, died at her home in New Canaan, Connecticut this past Saturday, July 11 after a brief illness. Known as Rosie, she was born in New York City on July 1, 1923, the oldest daughter of William Barclay Parsons, Jr. M.D., and Rose Peabody Parsons. Her grandparents were Endicott Peabody, founder of the Groton School, and his wife Fanny Peabody, and William Barclay Parsons, founder of an engineering firm that later became Parsons Brinkerhoff and chief engineer of the first subway in New York City and the Cape Cod Canal, and his wife Anna Reed Parsons. Rosie was passionate about her extended family, the Groton School and, most of all, her grandchildren and great grandchildren. At the time of her death, she was an Honorary Council member of the Women's Prison Association, on whose Board she served for 45 years from 1969-2014 and as President from 1976 to 1979. Later in life, she was equally devoted to Staying Put, serving as an enthusiastic volunteer for this wonderful organization based in New Canaan, which is dedicated to serving the needs of the community's senior citizens helping them to enjoy safer, healthier and more independent lives in their own homes. In everything she did, Rosie brought both a strong hand and an even stronger sense of humor, for which all who knew her will remember as her most endearing quality. She will be deeply missed by her children, Rose Peabody Lynch of Greenwich, CT and New York City, R. Vincent Lynch, Jr. of New York City and his wife Cynthia, and Alexander Parsons Lynch of Greenwich, CT and his wife Sally, as well as her eight grandchildren and six, soon-to-be seven, great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations would be gratefully received by Staying Put, 58 Pine Street, New Canaan, CT 06840. A memorial service will be held in her honor in New Canaan in September. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Victor Duzerah, Jr Loving husband of seventy years to Grace (Frysinger), devoted father to Vic, Minta, and Stone, died peacefully July 11th in Greensboro, NC. He is remembered by family and friends for his kindness, generosity, humility and intellect. First and foremost, Victor was a family man, always providing loving care and encouragement. Deflecting attention from himself, he focused on others' pursuits. His introspective shyness and quiet thoughtful nature delighted in Grace's gregarious ways. A classic case of "opposites attract" sustained a long marriage. Known for his dry wit and cluttered desk, Victor was once asked by "neatnik" Grace why he never learned to "clean up after his own mess," an early lesson taught to her kindergarten students. He replied, "I never went to kindergarten." Last year, as Grace's progressive dementia necessitated memory care in separate quarters, Victor visited her three times daily-- his life's purpose. Born on New Year's Day, 1919 to Victor and Annie Phillips, Victor Jr. grew up fourth of six children on a farm near Waxahachie, TX. A child of the Great Depression, he learned early lessons in self- sufficiency, discipline and empathy. Childhood years spent without electricity inspired his lifelong interest in electronics. Early on, Victor built his own crystal radio set, hi-fi stereo, even a television. His gifted mind thrilled at the beauty of calculus and the power of words. He enjoyed classic literature, daily crossword puzzles and e-mailing favorite wordlists to his grandchildren. At 63, he joined the new computer revolution. Well into his 80's, he was the go-to-man for all things cyber for his children and digitally-challenged friends. Following coronary by-pass surgery at age 70, he embraced exercise. He took diurnal walks, undeterred by inclement weather. With increasing age, he switched his daily routine to a NuStep machine, pedaling until the week he died. Victor was also an early champion of psychotherapy, talking openly of its life-enhancing benefits in managing his anxiety, helping to de-stigmatize mental health care for others. An Army Veteran of World War II, Victor sustained a shrapnel injury in the Battle of the Bulge resulting in lifelong paralysis of his right arm. He talked about this significant life change in a 1997 father-son interview on Dateline NBC. In a body cast, he married Grace, June 5th, 1945. Victor attended the University of Texas, Austin, Chemical Engineering, BS, and Chemistry, MA, 1951. He was a Monsanto chemical engineer, 1950-1982. In 1965, the family moved from Texas City, TX to suburban St. Louis, where Victor was a founding member of St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Ellisville, MO. Former rector Howard Park remembers him for his unfailing humor and unwavering gratitude for the gift of divine grace. Rev. Park noted Victor's formulation of a guiding spiritual principle, "Grace is the solution in which faith can grow." Victor is survived by his wife, Grace, three children, Victor D. Phillips, III, PhD of Milwaukee, WI (wife Mai), Minta Phillips, MD of Julian, NC and Stone Phillips of New York, NY, Broadcast Journalist (wife Debra), five grandchildren, Anisa Asakawa (husband Nick), Streeter, Catherine, Ben, Chiara, two cousins, five nieces and three nephews. A memorial service will be held at St. Martin's Church, 11am, August 29th, 2015. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial donations to The Alzheimer's Foundation (www.alzfdn.org) or Fisher House supporting wounded veterans and their families (fisherhouse.org). 1/3

WINSTON--Edward Perry, a New York City architect, passed away at New York- Presbyterian Weill Cornell Medical Center on July 11, 2015, two weeks short of his seventieth birthday. Born in Washington, DC, he was educated at Harvard College (1967) and received his graduate degree from Rice University. Uncompromising in his political, social, and ethical values, Perry pursued a career, building housing, schools, and community projects in San Francisco and New York. At the time of his death, he was associated with Magnusson Architecture and Planning. He taught generations of future architects and planners at The New School and Pratt Institute. He is survived by his wife Zeynep Celik of New York City and his son Antonio Ali Winston of Oakland, CA; in addition to his mother Frances Rome of Baltimore, brother Cooper Winston of Norton, MA, and sister Nancy Rome of Baltimore. Donations in his memory may be made to East New York Farms www.eastnewyorkfarms.org. 1/3

HESDORFFER--Lotte Karoline (nee Mayer), passed away peacefully at the age of 84 from complications of pancreatic cancer on Thursday July 16th at her home in Annapolis, Maryland. Her only son Charles and daughter-in-law Mary Hesdorffer were at her bedside. Lotte was born in Kaiserslautern, Germany on September 18th 1930. She was an only child and fled from the Nazi regime after Kristallnacht only to be caught up in the mayhem of the Second World War in her adopted Holland. After the war she immigrated to South Africa where she lived with her cousins, the Hess family, and studied sociology at the University of the Witwatersrand. She married in 1954 and worked with her husband in his wholesale jewelry business until they joined their son and his family in New York City in 2002, Lotte subsequently moving with them to Annapolis in 2011. A holocaust survivor who only wanted the best life for her family, she gave it to them in spades. Lotte is survived by her husband of 61 years, Heinz Hesdorffer, who, for health reasons returned to Europe in 2009, and now resides in the Budge Stiftung, Frankfurt, Germany. She is also survived by her only child, Charles and his wife Mary, their two children, Alex and Anna Plitsas, and two grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday 19th July at 11:15am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York, NY 10023 to be followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, any donations should be made in her honor to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation, 1317 Kings ST, Virginia, 22314 or online at www.curemeso.org where she was a stalwart volunteer and supporter even in the dark days of her illness. 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Herbert, 86, of Canton, MA, previously of New York City and Rockville Centre, NY, after a protracted illness. Survived by his cherished wife of 61 years, Marjorie; his three sons, Stephen, Donald and Richard (affectionately known as Um, Strum and Vovchik); his loving daughter-in-law, Marci, and his four cherished grandchildren, Allison, Aaron, Erica and Gil. Herb was a true mensch, who always did the right thing (well, almost always), who was always there when you needed him, who supported you without question when it was right and told you when it wasn't. He was a man of few words whose feelings for those he loved were boundless. A long-time veteran in the home furnishings industry, Herb worked for almost 50 years for just three firms, Grosby Products, Tilbury Fabrics and Richloom Fabrics; and was known to everyone in the trade as a straight shooter. Herb was the original home-body who loved to fix whatever needed fixing and whose idea of heaven was an hour examining the Craftsman tools at Sears. If you look hard, you will see him now with a half-gallon of Breyers, the game on and the dog at least half-way in his lap. 1/3

EPSTEIN--Lillian, died at her home on July 11th after a long illness. She was 95. She was born in Brooklyn, the youngest of three children and the only daughter of Samuel and Bessie Scher. She attended and excelled in New York public schools, but denied herself the opportunity to go to on to college out of a sense of responsibility to help support her widowed mother. A keen sense of responsibility and kindness were the dominant traits of her character. She held several jobs before joining the Voice of America, where she was a valued member of the staff during and after World War II. She was the loving and beloved wife of Harold; they were married for 66 years. She was a devoted mother to her four children and their spouses; Susan (Dr. Harold Horowitz), Rachel (Dr. William Breitbart), Lawrence (Elizabeth), and Michael (Margaret). She cherished and enjoyed her seven grandchildren and two step-grandchildren. She was a loyal friend. All who knew her will remember with love. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, the Multiple Sclerosis Society, or the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

STEIN--Gilbert "Gil", aka Gilbert Irwin Stein passed away peacefully at Cleveland Clinic Hospital in Florida on June 20, 2015 at the age of 88. After Florida and New York memorials, he was buried in the family plot in Elmont, NY. He was born in the Bronx on June 15, 1927 to Frances and Louis Stein. Gil happily lived for more than 50 years in his infamous walk-up on West 56th Street. In 2011, he moved to Tamarac, FL, which he called "paradise." Gil graduated from Forest Hills High School and was active in MENSA, the Forest Hills Jewish Center and UJA. After graduation, he enlisted in the US Merchant Marines, serving as a Radio Operator Officer during WWII. He returned to New York City and joined the family printing business, GraphicCraft. Gil spent his career as a printing and marketing executive. He enjoyed reading, square dancing and Broadway music. Gil spent his summers on Long Island where he was famous for his gourmet cooking skills. He was also an active Track and Field Official with the New York Runners Club. Gil's enthusiasm for life and "gab" was well known. Gil leaves behind his brothers Jack and Peter, his partner Diana and also nieces and nephews Rachel, Lee and Zachary, and others. May his name always be remembered with blessing. Condolences for Gilbert Irwin Stein may be expressed at: www.starofdavid funeralchapel.com 1/3

KRAUS--Dorothy. Dorothy Kraus. 1927-2015. My witty, pretty mother died after a long run on planet earth. Born in Brooklyn, New York to Natalie and Stanley Stern, my mom was and always will be the adored baby sister of Beatrice Kahn. As a young woman, my mother modeled, graduated from Queens College and married my dad, comedy writing dentist Jack Kraus. While married, my mom was a licensed New York public school teacher, studied acting under Uta Hagen and attended Brooklyn Law School. For many years my stylish mom wrote fashion catalogues for major department stores, including Gertz, Gimble's, I. Magnin and Bergdorf Goodman, to name a few. If you've read a clothes ad in the last 50 years, chances are you've read my mother's prose. My mother was a proficient seamstress and a visiting instructor at The Fashion Institute of Technology. Widowed at a young age, my mother moved to San Francisco where she was a long time member of the Metropolitan Club, emceeing many of their events. My mom started the club's annual Hat Day, a tradition which carries on. My mom was the owner of The Arts Made Lively and spoke on the life and fashion of Coco Chanel. As a deputized San Francisco Commissioner, my mom officiated numerous weddings, including same sex marriages, long before the Supreme Court spoke. My mom was a fun, feisty lady who made silly faces and called pudding pudgin, for no particular reason. My mother is survived by me, daughter Amy-Hannah Broersma, her precious grandson Jack Kraus Broersma and former son-in-law Dirk Broersma, who she loved. My mom is also survived by her sister's wonderful children, niece Frances Rice and husband Maury; nephew Robert Kahn and wife Rebecca, and their extended families. Robert and Fran did their mom proud, carrying on their mother's legacy of looking out for their beloved Aunt Dot. Long time San Francisco neighbor Jeri Ospital, who extended my mom many kindnesses and friend Elaine Ozarow, who my mom met at a bus stop on the way to Bayside High School seven decades ago also survive my mom. Dear friend Alma Sohmer of New York, where are you? Thank you to Silverado Beverly Place, Los Angeles. 1/3

GODFREY--Raymond Raymond Hoagland Godfrey, Jr. of East Setauket, NY passed away July 5, 2015. He was 71. Raised in Tarrytown, NY; graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University and Harvard Business School. Began his career as a writer for Time Inc. and worked in the administration of NYC Mayor John Lindsay. Part of the Merrill Lynch strategic team that developed the financial industry's first cash management product. Introduced marketing/ business development concepts to investment banking at The First Boston Corporation; co-founded Needham & Company, Inc. from which he retired in 2010. Ray was passionate about sports, music and history. Began a lifetime love of squash at Exeter, captained the Yale squash team and later competed nationally, including a famous win over the 5-time U.S. champion. Never missed a New York Giants game in 60 years, relished the intricacies of baseball and was gratified by spurts of natural talent on the golf links. Ray had an encyclopedic knowledge of rock and roll. In the 1990's he co-produced the last album of blues icon Paul Butterfield and was thrilled with this year's induction of the Butterfield band into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. A history and political affairs buff, Ray loved to analyze issues and engage in debate. In retirement, he overcame impatience with technology to roam the web. More than anything, he loved a good laugh. Ray is survived by his wife, Susan Schoch; children, Katherine Godfrey Beede, Jessica Godfrey Meehan, Raymond Hoagland Godfrey, III ("Terry"), and Eliza Jayne Godfrey; brother, Joseph Fallon Godfrey; sister, Deborah Godfrey Farrell; and five grandchildren. A memorial is planned for October in NYC. The family welcomes donations to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, http://pulmonaryfibrosis. donorpages.com/Tribute/ RaymondGodfrey. 1/3

SHACK--Donald. Died peacefully at home on July 12, 2015, after a short illness, at the age of 86, surrounded by his family. Donald graduated Williams College (Phi Beta Kappa) and Harvard Law School before serving in the Korean War. For more than 60 years he had a distinguished career practicing law in New York City as the managing partner of Golenbock and Barell, a founding partner of Shack, Siegel, Katz & Flaherty, and a partner of Blank Rome. Donald was an indispensable adviser to his clients, many of whom became life-long friends. Actively involved for years in the New York Civil Liberties Union, Donald was a champion of the underdog. Born and raised in Brooklyn, he was heart-broken when his Dodgers moved west but quickly shifted his "wait until next year" brand of fandom to the Mets, who, like the bums before, rarely exceeded his expectations. Donald loved tennis, sailing, and swimming, lively conversation, theater, music, good books, good food, and good Scotch. Yet Donald was most of all devoted to his family. He lost his loving wife of 61 years, Barbara, barely a month ago. Donald was a rock in the lives of his children, David and Laura, a beacon for his grandchildren Nicole, Joseph, and Francesca, to whom he was affectionately known as Papa, and looked forward to providing direction to his great-grand-children, Emma and Olivia. We will miss his penetrating mind, his social conscience, his deep love for his family, and his loyalty to his friends. A memorial service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10024 on Sunday, July 26, 2015 at 4:00pm. The family will be at Donald and Barbara's home at 7 West 81st Street on Sunday, July 26th and Monday, July 27th 6-8pm. Contributions may be made in Donald's memory to The American Civil Liberties Union. 1/3

BEREZIN--Judith Ann "Judy," an early childhood education expert with a lifelong commitment to peace and social justice, died unexpectedly July 7th. She was born to Irving and Dorothy Berezin in New York City, 1948. She attended the Little Red Schoolhouse, Music and Art, SUNY Old Westbury, Empire State College and Bank Street College of Education, where in 1984 she received an M.S. in Early Childhood Education. Her career included roles at Head Start, Sesame Workshop, The Center for Children's Initiatives, and the LYFE Program (NYC Department of Education). In 1990 she authored The Complete Guide to Choosing Childcare (Random House 1990). After joining The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) as a high school student, she would go on to become a leader in the Civil Rights, Anti-War and Women's Movements. In protest, she stood up against the wars in Iraq, and joined the resistance movement against the occupation of Palestine, which she visited in 2004. She considered motherhood to be her greatest accomplishment. She leaves behind her loving children, Joya and Cody, their father Gary, her sister Joan, of Berkeley, CA, her husband Michael, and their pets, Honeybear and Charlotte. 1/3

GOULD--Eric Witty. Beloved father of Ruby, Benjamin and Spencer, son of Lawrence and Jane, brother of Lance, brother-in-law to Michele, uncle of Samantha and Lucy, nephew of Ken and Eleanor Pearlman -- passed away July 6, 2015. The senior vice president of Valley National Bank had been fighting primary central nervous system lymphoma for two and a half years. He was 47. He graduated from Tulane University, where he was president of the Phi Kappa Sigma fraternity. He also earned an MBA from Pace University. As a son, brother, and friend, Eric lit up the room with his electric smile, quick wit, and good looks. And as a father, there was none finer. He was singularly dedicated to his three children, and took great pride in their achievements. If you asked him what he was most proud of, he would always mention Ruby, Ben and Spencer first. A private memorial service will be held July 26th in Morristown, NJ. 1/3
MARKS--Lionel, lawyer, died July 12, 2015 four days before his 84th birthday. He was loved and respected by both his family and his clients. He will be missed greatly by his loving sister. 1/3

MALIN--Clement Biddle, "Clem," passed away on July 6, 2015 in Redding, CT after a courageous battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was born on April 4, 1934 in Drexel Hill, PA and was a graduate of Swarthmore (PA) High School, Dartmouth College, and the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University. Clem joined Mobil Oil in 1960 and spent the rest of his career in the energy sector. After 13 years at Mobil he joined the Federal Energy Administration, and received a presidential appointment as Assistant Administrator for International Energy Affairs. In 1978 he joined Texaco where he spent the balance of his career traveling the world to represent both his company and his country, becoming an industry expert in global warming. He retired as Vice President of International Relations in 1998. In retirement, Clem taught at the University of Bridgeport, was a founding member of the Weston (CT) Lacrosse Club, served in community organizations, and performed in church choirs and theatrical groups. Clem was married to Dorothy Ann Fleet for 56 years. She predeceased him in 2013. Survivors include sons Henry and Thomas, grandchildren Andrew, Patrick, Madison, and Brandon, and brothers Robert Malin and Randall Malin. Donations can be made in Clem's memory to Dartmouth College or a charity of the donor's choice. 1/3

BATES--Eve 1913 - 2015 Passed away peacefully in her sleep July 16 - 102 years old. Eve Bates was born of immigrant parents, grew up in Jazz Age New York, and became a passionate activist for social and labor causes. She joined Harold L. Oram and associates in pioneering the application of ethical fund-raising techniques to liberal and progressive causes. It became her life-long work and helped shape American society into what it is today. In 1942 she married Ralph Bates, English novelist and Spanish Civil War revolutionary who later became an NYU professor (see The New York Times obit 12/2000) They lived in Greenwich Village and on the Greek island of Naxos for decades. Eve Bates died of old age and renal failure. She is survived by her son, Jonathan. There will be a memorial service in mid-September. For further information, contact batesjonathan@yahoo.com. 1/3
SHACK--Donald. NYCLU honors the life and memory of Donald Shack. Donna Lieberman, Director Jonathan Horn, President 1/3
FISHMAN--Anna Mae. Please watch over us during this difficult time. We miss you. Love, your children, grandchildren & great- grandchildren 1/3

SHABER--Gary S.,MD, on July 13, 2015 at the age of 81 in Philadelphia. Compassionate physician and world traveler, Gary was exceptionally creative with his hands - reconstructing antique sports cars, music boxes, vintage pinball machines and model airplanes throughout his lifetime. He was a celebrated and highly respected radiologist at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. But he was most passionate about being the beloved husband of the late Sandra Shaber, father of Ruth Shaber and the late Steven Shaber, father-in-law of Lisa Shaber, grandfather of Allison, Madeline and Hannah, and uncle of Samantha and Remy Shaber. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Goldsteins' Rosenbergs' Raphael-Sacks www.goldsteinsfuneral.com 1/3

PERTZ--Stuart King. The students, staff and faculty of Pratt Institutes Programs for Sustainable Planning and Development are deeply saddened by the loss of Stuart K.Pertz. His contributions to architecture, urban design and community planning are monuments to his sense of social, economic and environmental justice. His contribution to PSPDs new program in placemaking and to fostering an exchange with Cuba are part of a long list of contributions that he has made to making places and cities better for the people that inhabit them. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Stuart K. Pertz Center for Urban Placemaking, c/o McCanliss & Early LLP, Wall St. Plaza, 88 Pine Street, NY, NY10005. 1/3

JOHNS--Clara, MD, July 18, 1916 - May 18, 2015. Umpqua, Oregon. Dr. Clara Johns, born July 18, 1916 on a family farm in Rockford, Illinois, died May 18, 2015 in Umpqua, Oregon. She was 98. She received her Bachelor's degree from Rockford College, and graduated from the University of Chicago as a medical doctor in 1941, one of the first three women to get medical degrees from the university. She entered the Public Health Service, and served during WWII in Washington, DC and Kansas. Later, Dr. Johns was the first woman to graduate with a Masters of Public Health from Harvard. She married Dr. William A. Hall (deceased) and raised five children. The family moved to the west coast where she pursued her career in medicine. She led a life of service and accomplishment, always aspiring to improve public health. Her interest in progressive politics informed her work to help those in need. During her career in California, she worked as a pediatrician at UCLA at the Santa Clara County Health Department with migrant populations providing preventive health and maternal and child healthcare; with the mentally ill at Agnews State Hospital; as a volunteer at the United Farmworkers clinics in Salinas; and with the Flying Samaritans treating Native Americans on remote tribal lands. She retired from her position as Medical Director of the Home Care program at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center, Santa Clara, CA in 1982, where she also had served as Chief of Staff. Upon retirement she received a commendation from the State of California for her service to the community. After her retirement she enjoyed many years living among the redwoods near Watsonville, CA, and ultimately placed a conservation easement on her beloved property with the Santa Cruz Land Trust for preservation. She loved dogs and flowers, and enjoyed reading, collecting stamps, and music, remembering the songs of her childhood into old age. She spent the last 9 years of her life living with her daughter Marcia along the Umpqua River in Umpqua, OR. We will miss her sense of humor and her amazing memory for songs, poetry recitations, and all other items 'great and small' that she learned in her childhood. She is survived by daughters Diana Hall, (Tim) Mt. View, CA, Dr. Linda Hall (Quentin) Walnut Creek, CA, Dr. Marcia Hall, (Donald) Umpqua, OR, son Jeffrey Hall, JD of Santa Cruz, niece Dr. Sandra Drake (Ray) Menlo Park, CA, nephew Karl Drake, (Carol) Palo Alto, grandchildren Nicholas Noble, (Melia) of Umpqua, OR, Ian and Sara Hall of Santa Cruz, CA, Elise Hall, of New Zealand, their mother, Wendy Molin, of Santa Cruz, CA and great-grandchildren Ariana and Lincoln Noble of Umpqua. Her son Dr. Raney Hall preceded her in death. As Dr. St. Claire Drake, her brother-in-law once inscribed "Dr. Clara - whose lively interest in public affairs and social extensions of the Hippocratic Oath I admire." Her great presence in our lives and the lives of all she served will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions can be made in her name to Doctors without Borders or the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Memorial Services pending. marciah@jeffnet.org 1/3

WILLIAMSON--Susan Kettering, 78, died July 11, 2015. Memorial services are planned for the end of August. A full obituary and condolences may be expressed in an online guestbook at knightfuneralhomes.com. 1/3

STERNKLAR--Jack, February 5, 1922- July 5, 2015. Born to Sabina and Zacharia Sternklar in Vienna, Austria, Jack arrived in New York alone on July 4, 1938 at the age of 16, his education cut short by the Nazis. Jack served in the U.S. Army in World War II. Before embarking on a successful career as an owner of real estate, Jack opened the first Sabbath-observant grocery store in Boro Park, Brooklyn with his father, who survived Dachau and Buchenwald. A beloved Father, Grandfather, Great- Grandfather, Brother and Uncle, Jack is survived by his wife of 64 years, Lila; daughter Cindy Sternklar Worenklein, son-in-law Jacob Worenklein; daughter Sarah Sternklar, son-in-law Marvin Davis; and son Mark Sternklar, daughter in law, Nora Tammam; his grandchildren Sabrina, Ari, Etan, Benjamin, Sabina, Shira, Rena and Yigal; and his great grandchildren Charlotte, Oliver, Ayla, Lev, Noah, Eli, Be'eri, Raanan, Uriya, Dvash, Naaveh, Tiferet, Adi, and Tehila; his sister, Rosa (Ronnie) Gorden; and his nieces and nephews Caryn and Larry Malitzky and Zachary and Elana Gorden. He loved Jewish history, current events, his work, and most of all, his family. He was a generous supporter of education, Jewish causes and Israel. He was a voracious reader and self educated to a high standard of intellectual achievement. He was known for his integrity, his powerful mind, and his remarkable wit until the day he died. He was the most generous, humble, kind and gentle of all men. He will be missed by all who ever met him. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Stanley D. The Nat Sherman family celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Stanley D. Friedman; a beloved friend, an extraordinary attorney, an invaluable mentor and an esteemed advisor for more than five decades. We offer our heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathies to Stanley Friedman's family and to all those whose lives he graced. Stanley will never be far from our thoughts and forever in our hearts. The Nat Sherman Family 1/3

WING--John Brian. On July 6, 2015, John Brian Wing passed away of natural causes at his home in The Woodlands, Texas. He was 68 years old. John was born in the town of Potsdam, New York on July 20, 1946 and was the son of the late Martha Virta and Ivan Frank Wing. His siblings Steve and Christine Wing survive John. John is also survived by his daughter Christina Wing O'Donnell, her husband Tad O'Donnell and their three children: Jack, Julia and Blake; his son Brian Wing, his wife Shannon Wing and their three sons: Patrick, Henry and Charlie; Karen Milanese Wing, mother of Christina and Brian, and many Wing, Milanese and O'Donnell relatives. John is also survived by many friends that he considered brothers and sisters including his beloved Veterans. John grew up on a farm in Norfolk, New York, a natural athlete with a love for baseball, hockey, skiing, golf and fishing. He took great delight in teaching these sports to his grandchildren, who called him Papa. Papa was truly one of a kind and made each grandchild feel special, they were the apple of his eye. He wanted them to make their own path but be aware of the hard work and sacrifice that it takes to succeed. He treated them as friends and they will forever miss his Papa hugs and great Papa stories. John attended Norfolk High School where his mother, an English teacher, nurtured his core skills in math and English. John's communication and numbers acumen were key elements of his academic and entrepreneurial success. He cherished his ties to Norfolk and supported many of its charitable organizations. John loved returning to his hometown and provided scholarships for the local children. John attended the United States Military Academy at West Point, graduating in 1968. He was a member of the varsity hockey team. His active duty service was in The United States, Germany and the Republic of Vietnam from 1968 through 1973. His principal duties were as a pilot and aviation commander. He was recalled to active duty in 1982 for classified operations in Central America. Throughout his life, he valued individuals who attended West Point and served in the military, as he respected their character and leadership. Many of his closest friends were fellow West Point graduates. In his business endeavors, individuals with military backgrounds filled key positions. John received an M.B.A. from Harvard University in 1980 and graduated with high distinction as a Baker Scholar. John formed another group of lifelong friends from business school. He was an investor and director with Jim Koch of the Boston Beer Company. In addition, John was involved with several corporations with his Harvard classmates related to international infrastructure, domestic oil and gas investments, and the alternative asset industry. After graduation, John worked for General Electric and was the principal architect for Enron's power development business. He is recognized as a leader of the independent power industry. John was the chairman and founder of the Wing Group and led the development of multi-billion dollar power projects worldwide. These projects include the Teesside project in England and the first privatized power project in the Middle East. He was also a pioneer of China's independent power industry. In addition to John's business endeavors, he was passionate about democracy and civil rights. John worked closely with Representative Charlie Wilson on global issues and they were a dynamic force in Afghanistan as well as other regions. After selling the Wing Group, John founded Wing Aviation with his son Brian. Wing Aviation, a full service aviation company serving the corporate and commercial market, was a source of great pride. His love of aviation lasted his lifetime. He encouraged new pilots and served as a director and Vice Chairman of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. John was passionate about his country, family and community. He mentored many people with the message of positive social and economic impact. John expected his mentees to demonstrate good judgment, community involvement, philanthropy and love of country. He lived the motto, "pay it forward" and encouraged others to as well. John founded Operation Grateful Nation, which raised and donated money for Veterans, and most importantly provided mentoring and compassion to our warriors. John will be deeply missed by his family and friends. He was a positive force to all. John was an excellent son, brother, father, Papa, friend and Patriot. He was one of a kind. Duty. Honor. Country. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Operation Grateful Nation. Operation Grateful Nation, P.O. Box 132858, The Woodlands, Texas 77393. A private celebration of his life was held on July 10th for family and friends. John will be laid to rest at West Point. 1/3

SPITZ--Hyman "Hy" , 72 Beloved husband to Edith. Loving Dad to Stu (Prisca) and Ruth. Adoring Poppy to Molly, Lindsay, Rahim, Freya, Caleb, SharonRose, Noah, and Selah. Devoted brother to Richard (Jill) and the late Jerry (Lauren). A wonderful uncle and friend to many. You will be missed. 1/3

STERNKLAR--Jack, February 5, 1922- July 5, 2015. Born to Sabina and Zacharia Sternklar in Vienna, Austria, Jack arrived in New York alone on July 4, 1938 at the age of 16, his education cut short by the Nazis. Jack served in the U.S. Army in World War II. Before embarking on a successful career as an owner of real estate, Jack opened the first Sabbath-observant grocery store in Boro Park, Brooklyn with his father, who survived Dachau and Buchenwald. A beloved Father, Grandfather, Great- Grandfather, Brother and Uncle, Jack is survived by his wife of 64 years, Lila; daughter Cindy Sternklar Worenklein, son-in-law Jacob Worenklein; daughter Sarah Sternklar, son-in-law Marvin Davis; and son Mark Sternklar, daughter in law, Nora Tammam; his grandchildren Sabrina, Ari, Etan, Benjamin, Sabina, Shira, Rena and Yigal; and his great grandchildren Charlotte, Oliver, Ayla, Lev, Noah, Eli, Be'eri, Raanan, Uriya, Dvash, Naaveh, Tiferet, Adi, and Tehila; his sister, Rosa (Ronnie) Gorden; and his nieces and nephews Caryn and Larry Malitzky and Zachary and Elana Gorden. He loved Jewish history, current events, his work, and most of all, his family. He was a generous supporter of education, Jewish causes and Israel. He was a voracious reader and self educated to a high standard of intellectual achievement. He was known for his integrity, his powerful mind, and his remarkable wit until the day he died. He was the most generous, humble, kind and gentle of all men. He will be missed by all who ever met him. 1/3
GREENBERG--Saul N. 6/20/23-7/20/09 His spirit will live on through us. Love, SMSJ 1/3

WESTCOTT--Patricia D. (Doherty), of Attleboro, MA died July 18, 2015. Born 1925 Chicago, IL; Graduated High School Bronxville, New York, 1943. Graduated Simmons College, Boston, 1947. She leaves behind her beloved husband of 68 years, Frank Thomas Westcott, and children Peter T Westcott, Deborah Auliya Westcott, and Nancy Westcott Pocock. Lifelong member of P.E.O. Boundlessly charitable to and an active volunteer with many civic organizations in the community including the Florence Sweet Building Association, Anderson House, North Purchase Club, Girl Scout Cookie Regional Chairwoman, the United Way, Sturdy Hospital, Community VNA Hospice, Salvation Army Bridges of Hope, Attleboro Arts Museum, Celebrity Nights of the Attleboros and the Episcopal Church. A valued member of the Simmons College Alumnae Association Executive Board, where she served as an active volunteer and as their President from 1975-1977, the Class of 1947 class officer from 1996-2007 and a member of the Planned Giving Committee from 1999-2009. A member of the Museum of Fine Arts (MFA Boston) Ladies Committee, an active member of the Eastward Ho Ladies Golf Committee until 2010, and a superb, award winning salt fisherman in Cape Cod, Palm Beach and the Caribbean. A life force and dedicated friend to all who knew her, she will be sorely missed and often remembered. Calling hours at Sperry & McHoul Funeral Home, 15 Grove Street, North Attleboro, MA on Thursday, July 23, from 4pm to 7pm. Funeral at All Saints Episcopal Church, 121 North Main Street, Attleboro, MA on Friday, July 24 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to at All Saints Episcopal Church, 121 North Main Street, Attleboro, MA 02703. 1/3

PINCUS--Rosalyn. The Workmen's Circle mourns the loss of an extraordinary activist and dear friend Rosalyn Pincus. A lifelong member and leader she served on the National Executive Board and numerous Committees. Together with husband Milt, she coordinated the Jewish Cultural Experience in our Circle Lodge. A founder of our East Meadow Shule, she remained actively involved in their programs through this Passover. The Workmen's Circle community extends its deepest sympathies to Milton, Jessica, Alice, and the entire Pincus family. Peter Pepper, President Ann Toback, Executive Director 1/3

CHRISTIE--Constantino, age 95, passed away in the comfort of his home, surrounded by family on July 17, 2015 after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Constantino was born in Kastoria, Greece and immigrated to America in 1940, where he and his brothers founded Christie Brothers Furs, his pride and joy. At leisure, he thoroughly enjoyed playing backgammon and pinochle, loved his tennis matches, and always looked forward to spending time with his family and friends. Constantino is survived by the love of his life and wife of 54 years, Aliki, as well as children Dean & Athena, son-in-law Eric, daughter-in-law Aarti, grandchildren Nicole, Alexander, & Steven, and sister Nina with daughters Christine & Lydia. Funeral services will be held on July 21, 2015 at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 337 E 74th St. Visitation 10:30; funeral 11:00. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that those wishing to contribute donate to The Cathedral. 1/3

COLBY--Barbara Heinzen, died peacefully Thursday, July 16 at the age of 94. She served with her husband and their family during his long CIA career in Sweden, Italy, Vietnam, and Washington, D.C., culminating in his service as Director of Central Intelligence from 1973-1976. She served on the Agency's Family Advisory Board, and played an important role in the passage of legislation guaranteeing a share of lifetime benefits to former spouses of Agency employees. She received the CIA Director's Award in 2002 for her "untiring efforts on the part of former Agency spouses" and her "constant concern for the welfare of Agency families," Mrs. Colby was born Barbara Ann Heinzen in Springfield, Ohio on December 25, 1920. Her father, Karl, was a journalist, businessman, and president of the Bayer Aspirin Company in the mid-1930s. Her mother Annette was a fashion coordinator for the Montgomery Ward Company. Barbara received a B.A. in History from Barnard College in 1942 and was an advertising copywriter before marrying William Egan Colby in 1945. Their marriage ended in divorce. In 1992 she received an M.A. in the Humanities from Georgetown University. She was a Dame of the Order of Malta. A beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, she is survived by four children, eight grandchildren and three great- grandchildren: her son Jonathan and Susan Colby of Jupiter Island, FL, her son Carl Colby of Washington, D.C., her son Paul and Amie Colby of Alexandria, VA, and her daughter Christine Colby Giraudo and John Giraudo of Washington, D.C.; her grandchildren Emily and Scott McLellan, Elbridge Colby and Susana Cordeiro Guerra, George Colby, 1st Lt. Arthur Colby, USMC, Peter and Sabrina Giraudo, and Charles and Elizabeth Colby. A daughter, Catherine Ann Colby, predeceased her in 1973. The funeral will be held at Holy Trinity Church in Washington, D.C., at 10:30am on Thursday, July 23. 1/3

PERTZ--Stuart King. The students, staff and faculty of Pratt Institutes Programs for Sustainable Planning and Development are deeply saddened by the loss of Stuart K.Pertz. His contributions to architecture, urban design and community planning are monuments to his sense of social, economic and environmental justice. His contribution to PSPDs new program in placemaking and to fostering an exchange with Cuba are part of a long list of contributions that he has made to making places and cities better for the people that inhabit them. Contributions in his honor may be made to the Stuart K. Pertz Center for Urban Placemaking, c/o McCanliss & Early LLP, Wall St. Plaza, 88 Pine Street, NY, NY10005. 1/3

RACHLEFF--Lillian Shames, passed away peacefully at St. Barnabas Hospital on July 19, 2015. A native New Yorker, she was philanthropically active and a lover of all things elegant and refined. Fiercely independent and effortlessly stylish, she lived on her own in the house she shared with her beloved husband Jack and remained resolutely and lovingly by his side during his struggle with Parkinson's. Lillian is survived by her son Andy, daughter-in-law Debbie, and her two grandchildren Jake and Shelby. A chapel service is scheduled for Monday, July 20, 2015, 1:00pm at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union (Vauxhall) New Jersey. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, New Jersey. 1/3

GROSSINGER--Tania, age 78, died peacefully in hospice on Sunday, July 19th after a short illness. She leaves behind a cadre of loving cousins and friends and was predeceased by her long term companion. Tania was a resident of Greenwich Village for over 50 years and known as a raconteur, author of both fiction and non-fiction books and as a public relations consultant. She will best be remembered for recounting her life in "Growing Up at Grossinger's" and her most recent book "Memoir of An Independent Woman." A memorial service will be announced at a later date. With special memories and much love, Mary Ann Grossinger, Pat Strongin. 1/3

SUGARMAN--Katherine Mandell, died untimely on July 17 at the age of 29. She will be profoundly missed by her parents, Mark Sugarman and Margery Mandell Sugarman, her siblings Jacob and Alix, her sister-in-law Mariela Pacchioli and her beloved niece, Julia. Despite crippling physical disabilities, Katie fought to have a meaningful life, managing to earn her bachelor's degree from Edinboro University in Pennsylvania. Her humor, strength, compassion and healthy appetite for good food were beloved and appreciated by all who knew her. Contributions in her name can be made to Southampton Fresh Air Home. 1/3

MURRAY--Mozelle Menefee, 95, passed away at her home in New York City on July 3, 2015. Affectionately known as Moque, Mozelle was born on June 8, 1920 in Tuskegee, Alabama, where she grew up. She graduated from Tuskegee Institute, where she met her husband, the distinguished writer, Albert Murray, who passed away in 2013. They were married 72 years and were blessed with one child, Michele, who lives in New York City. Mozelle was a devoted wife and mother who had a distinguished 20-year career as an elementary school teacher in the New York City public schools from which she retired in 1987. Mozelle was a dedicated Tuskegee graduate whose commitment to the school continued throughout her life. As an active member of the New York Chapter Tuskegee Alumni Club, Mozelle served as its secretary for many years. Mozelle was a world-class cook and conscientious hostess who loved to entertain. With her warm and infectious smile, Mozelle possessed the innate ability to put even the most casual of acquaintances at ease and make them feel welcome in her home. She will be missed by her many friends and members of her extended family. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 23 at 11am at the First AME Church: Bethel, 60 West 132nd Street, New York, NY 10037. Contributions may be made in Mozelle's memory to the Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, The United Federation of Teachers Disaster Relief Fund and Tuskegee University. 1/3

WALDMAN--Robert. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of long- time member Robert Waldman. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi 1/3
