GROSSINGER--Tania, age 78, died peacefully in hospice on Sunday, July 19th after a short illness. She leaves behind a cadre of loving cousins and friends and was predeceased by her long term companion. Tania was a resident of Greenwich Village for over 50 years and known as a raconteur, author of both fiction and non-fiction books and as a public relations consultant. She will best be remembered for recounting her life in "Growing Up at Grossinger's" and her most recent book "Memoir of An Independent Woman." A memorial service will be announced at a later date. With special memories and much love, Mary Ann Grossinger, Pat Strongin. 1/3

GABEL--Gertrude (Ribakove). Died July 18, 2015 in El Cerrito, CA, age 97. Born and raised in Brooklyn; longtime resident of Usonia Homes near Pleasantville; art teacher in New York City high schools. Married 1941-1976 to Murry Gabel (1912-1981). Beloved sister of the late Lionel Ribakove and mother of the late Laura Gabel. Survivors include her sister, Florence Bar-Ilan, Rehovot, Israel; sons Jonathan (Ligaya Yadao), Oakland, CA, Michael (Irene Amy Scheinbaum), El Cerrito, CA, Matthew (Jane), Oakland, CA; grandchildren Andrew Gabel and Sophie Gabel- Scheinbaum; and many nieces and nephews. Funeral service 11am, Friday, July 24, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York City, followed by burial at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. 1/3

NEALON--Stephanie, passed away peacefully at home on July 11, 2015 at the age of 55 after succumbing to metastatic breast cancer. She was born in New Haven, Connecticut, the daughter of Delores Nealon, nee Smolenski, and James Nealon. She worked with computers, most recently as data base administrator for Covenant House, a charitable organization protecting the rights of homeless kids. Stephanie appreciated art and creative pursuits of all kinds. She loved to travel and enjoyed nothing more than hiking in national and state parks. She had a wry sense of humor coupled with a formidable character and generous personality. She is survived by her husband, Todd Herman, and sons, Woody Herman and Zach Herman. Stephanie's family, friends and acquaintances will miss her dearly and remember her fondly. 1/3

FEINBERG--Shirley R.,Age 89, died at home on July 20, 2015 of cancer. Devoted wife of Judge Wilfred Feinberg, who died in July of last year. She was born in Valley Cottage, NY of Jewish immigrants from Poland and Russia, who named their humble Mount Vernon dress shop Shirley's in honor of their daughter. For many years Shirley had her own business as a personal fashion shopper, assisting style-challenged executives and judges in the New York metropolitan area and beyond. Doting mother, gourmet cook, energetic tennis player, and perfect companion for 68 years to her more reserved husband, Shirley was a beautiful, vivacious, always stylish woman who loved art, music, good food and wine. She was also an avid gardener; she planted and maintained a small but exuberant plot in Liberty Community Garden, which she helped to found. She served as a docent at the Brooklyn Museum for the past 10 years, and she maintained her boundless energy to the very end. (Traipsing through her favorite art museums, she could easily outlast any of her offspring.) She was devoted to and is survived by her daughter, Susan Stelk, her husband Wayne and their children, Sam and Dasha of Marblehead, MA; her son Jack, his wife Pam McKniff and their children Rebecca, Andrew, and Eliza of Manhattan Beach, CA, her daughter, Jessica Twedt and daughter, Kayla of Garrett Park, MD, and her brother Frank Marcus, of Tucson, AZ. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, July 22, at 11:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. (at Amsterdam Ave.), New York. A reception will be held at Shirley's apartment from 5pm to 8pm the same day. Memorial donations can be made to the Hudson River Park. 1/3
GLENN--Thomas E. Gone 2 years yet still alive in our hearts. 1/3

SALTER--James. A memorial service for the acclaimed and beloved writer James Salter will be held on Tuesday, July 28th at 5:00pm at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th St. Mr. Salter died in June at the age of 90. 1/3

CRUZ--Edward, P.E.,entrepreneur and philanthropist, passed away at home in Bay Head, NJ on July 14, 2015 with his wife and four children by his side. Born in Portugal in 1941, he immigrated to the U.S. in 1950, initially settling in the Ironbound section of Newark. He graduated from Newark College of Engineering (now NJIT) in 1963, with a BS in Civil Engineering, earning his New Jersey Professional Engineer's license in 1968. In 2013, Mr. Cruz received a Doctor of Science, honoris causa from NJIT. After graduation in 1963, Mr. Cruz joined his father at Cruz Construction Company in New Jersey, heading the firm as President from 1974 to 1984. In 1984, he and his cousin Evaristo G. Cruz founded E.E. Cruz & Company Inc., a heavy civil contractor in New York and New Jersey. EE Cruz became an ENR Top 400 Construction Firm in the U.S. Mr. Cruz was a philanthropic leader with a particular interest in education and the Portuguese community. He endowed numerous scholarships and underwrote the Monmouth County Concours d'Elegance to benefit children's charities in New Jersey. Mr. Cruz recently completed his memoir, A Bold Journey, eagerly anticipated and enthusiastically received by his family, friends and colleagues with proceeds going to St. John's Soup Kitchen in Newark. Mr. Cruz is survived by Sharon, his wife of 51 years; his four children, Robin McClearn, Jeffrey Cruz, Kelly McCullers, and Susan Barkey and their spouses; his grandchildren, Michelle, her husband Dan, Connor, Taylor, Kate, Caroline, Henry, Olivia, Peter, Hilary and Liam; his mother Lidia; and his four siblings. The memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 22nd at 4pm at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, NJ. Complimentary parking will be available in lots A, B, and C. Donations in lieu of flowers: The Trust For Public Land attn: Tracy Terry, Lafayette Street School Project, 20 Community Place #

LEONE--Richard C. The trustees and staff of The Century Foundation are deeply saddened by the passing of Richard C. Leone. Dick served as president of The Century Foundation from 1989 to 2011, working tirelessly to help reduce inequality, strengthen social insurance, enhance voting rights and improve our education and health care systems. For Dick, public policy wasn't a job - it was a mission. TCF extends its deepest sympathies to Dick's family and friends. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

WALLACE--Joanne C.,unexpectedly passed away, in her sleep, on July 19, 2015 at age 69. Born September 6, 1945 in New York City, Joanne was the only child of Joseph and Sophie Czechlewski. She was raised in Manhattan, and had an intense love for New York City her whole life. After attending Marymount School of New York on 5th Avenue, Marymount College, Tarrytown and Teachers College, Columbia University, Joanne taught music for many years in the New York City public schools. Joanne was loved by all who knew her, because she was smart, talented, witty, fun loving and extraordinary generous to her friends. Joanne loved being with people and people loved to be with her because she took a great interest in life. Joanne was devoted to her Catholic faith, friends and her family, especially her husband William (Bill), with whom she recently celebrated their 47th wedding anniversary. Joanne and Bill were each other's best friend, closest companion and biggest supporter. Rarely apart, they loved spending time with each other and everything they undertook was enhanced by being together. Joanne was a great advocate for her two children, working tirelessly to instill in them the values and morals needed to navigate life, teaching them through example unconditional love. Music was Joanne's passion. Blessed with a powerful mezzo-soprano voice, Joanne studied and sang opera professionally with Musica Reservata in New York, and later sang for many years with The Grace Notes in Greenwich, CT, and other groups, but most fun was when she could be coaxed into singing for family and friends, where she would light up the room. Joanne and Bill regularly attended the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and myriad cultural offerings in New York City, a city she truly loved. Beyond music, Joanne loved her gardens, enjoyed golf and bridge, and was a good sport about her family's love of sailing and being on the water, no matter how bad the weather. Joanne lived in Greenwich, Connecticut, Watermill, New York and Hobe Sound, Florida and was a member of the Colony Club in New York City, The Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, Connecticut and Loblolly in Hobe Sound, Florida. She will be missed desperately by her family and all the people she had contact with throughout her life. And they are certain that Joanne will be singing a heartfelt rendition of Sto lat as she is welcomed into heaven. Joanne is survived by her husband William, her daughter Joan, her son Andrew and her daughter-in-law Wistar. A wake will be held on Tuesday, July 21 and Wednesday, July 22 from 5pm to 8pm in Joanne's home. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Thursday, July 23 at 10:30am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola located at 980 Park Avenue in New York City, followed by interment at Saint Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx and a reception at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, CT. Please contact Gallagher Funeral Home at 203-869-1513 for more information. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Joanne's memory to Marymount 5th Avenue. 1/3

LEONE--Richard C. Dick was one of a kind. His titanic intellect, wit, and insights into the human condition and uncomfortable truths of life were enduring gifts to those he befriended and inspired. In government service and devotion to the public interest, he defined the gold standard. His legacy of integrity and compassion will forever guide those he knew and loved. Our deepest condolences to Meg (his rock), Kate (Will), Max, granddaughter Lucy, and sister Sandra. Ellen & Lew Kaden Hilary Ballon & Orin Kramer 1/3

BYRNES--Dennis Patrick, of Bonita Springs, FL, passed away on July 11, 2015. Born in Jersey City, NJ, on January 18, 1943, Dennis attended St. Peter's Preparatory School and St. Peter's College in Jersey City. He then served in the United States Marine Corps Reserves. Dennis lived in Manhattan for many years where he embarked on a thirty-year career in advertising, working as Executive Vice-President at DDB Needham Worldwide, following which he was Executive Vice President, Worldwide Account Director at Foote, Cone & Belding. In 2004, Dennis married Mary Naylor and lived in Darien, CT, before moving to Bonita Springs. Dennis loved to travel both for business and for pleasure and to relax on the beautiful beaches of the Hamptons and Cape Cod. He enjoyed cooking, entertaining family and friends, and buckling down on Sundays to tackle the New York Times crossword puzzle. In addition to his devoted wife Mary, Dennis is survived by his stepsons Jack Naylor (Meghan) and Brian Naylor, grandson Jackie Naylor, loving sister Eileen O'Rourke (Emmett), nephews Brian O'Rourke (Isabel), Patrick O'Rourke (Jennifer), Michael O'Rourke (Debra), niece Kerry Hershberger (Mike) and great-uncle to Molly, Luke, Gracie, Kate, Megan, Clare, Kristen and Kayla. A beloved family man and a loyal friend to many, he will be missed dearly. 1/3

LEONE--Richard C. Former president of the Century Foundation and a past chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died on Thursday, July 16. He was 75 years old. He was being treated for Parkinson's disease and was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. Born in Webster, New York in 1940, Dick Leone spent the bulk of his career in public service. A graduate of the University of Rochester, he earned a Masters degree and a PhD at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. A pragmatic progressive whose views were forged during the Kennedy era, Leone worked on many local and national campaigns. One of his proudest moments was working as an advance man on Robert Kennedy's presidential campaign in Oregon. He also worked on presidential campaigns for George McGovern, Walter Mondale, Michael Dukakis and Bill Bradley. In the '60s, he was executive director of the White House Task Force on The Cities. In addition, Leone managed Brendan Byrne's two successful campaigns for Governor of New Jersey, in 1973 and 1977. From 1974 to 1977, Leone was state treasurer of New Jersey. In 2005, he served as chairman of Governor Jon Corzine's transition committee. Leone served as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and was chairman of the Port Authority from 1990 to 1994. From 1989 to 2011, he was president of the Century Foundation (formerly Twentieth Century Fund), a public policy think tank. Leone steered the foundation to concentrate on such issues as inequality and civil liberties and he fought against attempts at privatizing Social Security. Leone's private sector jobs included working as President of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a managing director at Dillon Read & Co. He has long been a director/trustee of multiple funds at Dreyfus Corp. and serves on the board of the Center for American Progress. Burial is private, but a memorial service will take place in Princeton, New Jersey in September. He is survived by his wife, Meg Cox Leone; his children Kate Leone and Max Leone, and his granddaughter Lucy Kirschner, as well as his sister Sandra Leone Thomas Brooks and first wife, Anita Leone. As well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Those wishing to honor his memory can consider donations to New Jersey Policy Perspective or the Michael J. Fox Foundation. 1/3

PINCUS--Rosalyn. The Workmen's Circle mourns the loss of an extraordinary activist and dear friend Rosalyn Pincus. A lifelong member and leader she served on the National Executive Board and numerous Committees. Together with husband Milt, she coordinated the Jewish Cultural Experience in our Circle Lodge. A founder of our East Meadow Shule, she remained actively involved in their programs through this Passover. The Workmen's Circle community extends its deepest sympathies to Milton, Jessica, Alice, and the entire Pincus family. Peter Pepper, President Ann Toback, Executive Director 1/3

LUDMAN--Joan (Hurwitz). February 1, 1932 - July 19, 2015. Born in Brooklyn, graduated from Tilden High School and BA from Barnard College, Masters degree from CW Post College of Long Island University. Author and co-author, editor and co-editor, and contributor to numerous art reference books. Leaves her beloved husband of 62 years, Harold Ludman, M.D.; devoted children Mark (Batya), Neil (Terrence King), and Evette (Dennis Birch); grandson Benjamin (Danielle), grandson Aaron (Einat), granddaughter Shayna. Sister Elaine Greenstone and late husband James Greenstone, sister Carol and husband Josef Sirefman, brother-in-law Nathan Ludman and family and sister-in-law Norma Cohen and family. Also leaves many beloved nieces, grandnieces, nephews and grandnephew, and a vast number of adored and adoring friends. Lived in Westbury, Long Island for almost 50 years, then lived in Boynton Beach, Florida. Loved travel, visiting art museums all over the world, painted, sculpted, researched and wrote art books, was a voracious reader, loved books, music, theater, film and all animals, especially dogs. Loved being with her adored and devoted family and friends. 1/3

JOSEPHSON--Barry. Died peacefully in his sleep Monday. He was a clinical psychologist and entrepreneur. He is survived by his devoted wife and partner of 50 years, Dixie Roberts Josephson and his loving sons and their spouses, Dr. Braden Josephson and his wife Dr. Sarah Church, Mark Josephson and his wife Megan and his sister Harriet Josephson. He was the proud grandfather of Henry, Eliza, Theodore and Oliver Josephson. He will remain a model for those that knew him. After a private burial, a funeral service will be held Wednesday, July 22 at 3 PM at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam, New York. A memorial service will be held Friday, July 24 at noon at Temple Beth-El, 70 Orchard Street, Providence, RI. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 E. 70th Street, 5th Floor, New York, NY 10021 and VNSNY.org. 1/3

REED--Marie "Mimi" Byers. Our beloved Marie "Mimi" Byers Reed passed away peacefully on July 17, surrounded by the family who loved her, after a prolonged illness. Mimi was born in Pittsburgh January 11, 1939, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederic Byers. Mimi graduated from Sewickley Academy, The Foxcroft School and Briar Cliff Manor College. She was a Vice President of The American Heart Association and a Vice President of the Performing Arts Center at SUNY Purchase, New York. Mimi married Joseph Verner Reed, Jr. on December 19, 1959. They had two daughters, Serena Reed Kusserow of Santa Barbara, California and Electra Reed of Greenwich, Connecticut and four grandchildren. Mimi was a member of the Colony Club of New York, the Gasparilla Inn Beach Club of Boca Grande, Florida, the Round Hill Club of Greenwich, Connecticut and the Harbor Club of Seal Harbor, Maine. Funeral and Memorial Services are to be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mimi's memory may be made to the ASPCA of Hancock County, Maine (141 Bar Harbor Road, Trenton, ME 04605). 1/3

COHEN --Josef B. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed Trustee and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Walter J. Molofsky, M.D., Chairman Jacob D. Gold, President 1/3

MURRAY--Mozelle Menefee, 95, passed away at her home in New York City on July 3, 2015. Affectionately known as Moque, Mozelle was born on June 8, 1920 in Tuskegee, Alabama, where she grew up. She graduated from Tuskegee Institute, where she met her husband, the distinguished writer, Albert Murray, who passed away in 2013. They were married 72 years and were blessed with one child, Michele, who lives in New York City. Mozelle was a devoted wife and mother who had a distinguished 20-year career as an elementary school teacher in the New York City public schools from which she retired in 1987. Mozelle was a dedicated Tuskegee graduate whose commitment to the school continued throughout her life. As an active member of the New York Chapter Tuskegee Alumni Club, Mozelle served as its secretary for many years. Mozelle was a world-class cook and conscientious hostess who loved to entertain. With her warm and infectious smile, Mozelle possessed the innate ability to put even the most casual of acquaintances at ease and make them feel welcome in her home. She will be missed by her many friends and members of her extended family. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 23 at 11am at the First AME Church: Bethel, 60 West 132nd Street, New York, NY 10037. Contributions may be made in Mozelle's memory to the Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, The United Federation of Teachers Disaster Relief Fund and Tuskegee University. 1/3

COMAS--George Andrew, was surrounded by family when he passed away peacefully on July 18, 2015, the day of his 77th birthday. Born in the Bronx to Frank Komatsulakis and Alexia Valakis, George demonstrated a keen intelligence early on at Stuyvesant High School. He graduated Manhattan College in 1958 then later served stateside in the Army during the Korean War. George began his career as a financial advisor at White Weld, which later was purchased by Merrill Lynch in 1978. At Merrill, he was a member of the Circle of Champions, an elite group of high-producing financial advisors. George's long and distinguished career spanned more than three decades before he retired from Merrill Lynch in 2003. For all his professional successes, what defined George was the joyous way in which he lived life. He treated each day as a celebration, something to be enjoyed and savored until well after sunset. While his gracious nature and good humor were shared with everyone he met, it was his beloved family and friends who were most precious to him. A passionate fitness enthusiast, George never let injury hold him back or dampen his spirit. No matter the challenges he faced, George's motto was that he was "Livin' the dream." From Miami to Manhattan to Southampton, George espoused this positive view, serving as an inspiration to everyone he met. The legacy George leaves behind bears the indelible imprint of the life he lived. He taught everyone that happiness is a choice, and life should always be lived to the fullest. He was the beloved father of Frank, Claire, Iris and John, and adored grandfather, or Geeg, to Lily, Caroline and Charlie. He is survived by his sister, Marie, niece, Christina, and nephews, Andrew, Peter and Dan. He is predeceased by his brother, Gus, and nephew, Gregory. George will be forever missed, and always loved. He indeed lived the dream. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 22, 2015 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10028. Friends and family are welcome to pay their respects anytime between 1 and 6pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in George's honor to http://braintumor.org. Kindly direct gifts to: Defeat GBM Research Collaborative. 1/3

JOHANNESSEN--John E.,Ft Myers, FL prior Tenafly, NJ, Grantham, NH died June 6. Born November 12, 1920 in Denmark. WWII, US B17 pilot. RAVOSA--Carmino, one of the most popular songwriters for children and foremost musical composer on historical subjects, died on July 19th at age 85. Born in Springfield, MA, he graduated from Hartt School of Music and Columbia University; was a music teacher at Fox Meadow School in Scarsdale, NY; then Faculty Fellow and Composer-In-Residence at The Dalton School and subsequently for Edison Schools. At the invitation of President Jimmy Carter, Ravosa performed his musical "Ghosts in the White House" at the White House in 1978. He also performed at the inaugurations of President George H.W. Bush in 1989 and President George W. Bush in 2001. His musical "Scarecrow" won awards in 1975 at the International Light Opera Festival in Ireland, and his musical "Seneca Falls" was performed in 1976 at Carnegie Hall. He also performed at the gala reopening of the Ellis Island Immigration Museum in 2001. He was an author for Silver Burdett's music textbook series and for CBS's "Captain Kangaroo", "Romper Room" and PBS's "Shining Time Station". He is survived by his wife Claire; children Carine, Gina and Dean; eight grandchildren; and sister Corena. Visiting hours are July 23rd from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Beecher Flooks Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY. A Memorial Service will be held August 8th at 11am at Emanuel Lutheran Church in Pleasantville, NY. 1/3

RACHLEFF--Lillian. The Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain at Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of our friend Lillian Rachleff. Her support of our research, in memory of her late husband, Jack, has been truly extraordinary. We offer our condolences to her son, daughter-in-law, grandchildren, and the extended Rachleff family. Richard Mayeux, M.D., M.Sc. Chair, Department of Neurology, Co-Director, Taub Institute Michael L. Shelanski, M.D. Ph.D. Chair, Department of Pathology, Co-Director, Taub Institute Lucien J. Cote, M.D. Professor Emeritus of Neurology, Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

BRIGATI--Jane, passed away at Elderwood Nursing Home in Liverpool July 16 at the age of 85. She is survived by her brother, Spike (Patti) Brigati and many nephews and nieces. Jane was predeceased by her parents George and Elizabeth, her sisters Barbara and Pat, and brother Joe. After graduation from Emerson College, Jane immediately went to work in Manhattan. She finished an illustrious career in advertising at BBDO where she was elevated to Vice President breaking through the then glass ceiling. She was an excellent role model for her three nieces and twelve nephews. There will be no calling hours and services will be private for the family only. Donations may be made in Jane's memory to the charity of your choice. Whelan Bros. & Hulchanski Funeral Home, 5854 Belle Isle Road, Syracuse, NY 13209. 1/3

BURTON--Bernard H.,loving husband, father and grandfather, Holocaust survivor and author of "A Letter to My Grandchildren and Other Correspondences" died peacefully on July 21 in the comfort of his family. He was married 55 years to his late wife Helga Burton. In 2009 he married Janis Weissman. Bernie was beloved by his three daughters; Vivian (Bill Eldridge), Monica and Mimi, (Michael Zuckman) and grandchildren, Rachel, Nicole, Daniel, Jake and David, step-children Rick (Tricia), Nancy and Carol (Larry) and step-grandchildren Jeffrey (deceased), Connor, Sarah and Jeremy. Services Thursday, 10:30am, Temple Sinai, Roslyn Heights, NY. 1/3

SHILS--Maurice Edward, M.D. FACP, ScD. December 31, 1914 - June 29, 2015. Husband of Betty Bell Shils of Mobile, Alabama; father of Jonathan Shils of Atlanta, Georgia; and Loraine Shils (David) Hammack of Shaker Heights, Ohio; with his wife of almost 50 years, Cylia Finkel Shils (deceased); grandfather of Elizabeth (Michael Ulchak) Hammack, Peter (Beth) Hammack and Sarah (Bret) Kovacs and great grandfather of four. Professor Emeritus of Medicine, Cornell Medical College, retired Attending Physician and Director of Clinical Nutrition, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital; retired Executive Secretary, Committee on Public Health of New York Academy of Medicine; retired Adjunct Professor, Wake Forest School of Medicine; senior editor of Modern Nutrition in Health and Disease, 7-10th editions. 1/3

PITT--Gloria M. Gloria M. Pitt, a long-time resident of Port Washington, New York, died peacefully at the home of her daughter in McLean, Virginia on July 16, 2015. She was 90 years old. Gloria was born on November 19, 1924 in Bayside, New York. She was married for 46 years to William Ray Pitt III, and they were the most graceful of dance partners until his death in 1992. She was also predeceased by her mother, Katherine Murphy Igoe, her father, Herbert "Hype" Igoe, (celebrated illustrator and sports writer for the New York American), her sister Jaunita Coon, her brother Jack Igoe, and her son William Ray Pitt IV. Gloria is survived by her son, David Pitt (Fred Goldstein) of Hollywood, California, her daughter, Janice Pitt Fitzgibbon (Timothy) of McLean, Virginia, and her grandchildren, Colin William Fitzgibbon and Cathryn Gloria Fitzgibbon. Gloria took great pride in her volunteer work at St. Francis Heart Hospital in Roslyn, New York. Over a period of more than 25 years, she logged nearly 13,000 volunteer hours and was fondly referred to as "The General," due in large part to the 26 gold "Volunteer Award Bars" she wore pinned to her uniform. Even after her eyesight was diminished by macular degeneration, Gloria adeptly maneuvered the halls of the hospital guided by the different colors of the floor tiles, and she put thousands of patients at ease in the process. As the daughter of a sports writer, Gloria loved language in all of its forms, including political debates, the daily crossword puzzle, conversations with patients, and stories that improved in humor and detail with each retelling. She also loved to dance, which she continued to do regularly until shortly before her death. She never met a stranger, as could be attested by many of the fellow Amtrak passengers she encountered during her regular trips from New York to see her grandchildren before she moved from Port Washington to the Chesterbrook Residences in McLean, Virginia two years ago. There will be a graveside service at 11 a.m. on Friday, July 24, 2015 at Nassau Knolls Cemetery in Port Washington. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her memory to St. Francis Heart Hospital at www.stfrancisheartcenter. com. 1/3

GERLA--Marvin. Died peacefully Monday, July 20th with his family at his side. He was 93 years young. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was the son of Rose and Bernard Gerla, brother to Stanley, husband to his beloved Cecily for 62 years, father to Jamie Dee Kline, Bradley, Kathy Gold, and Michael, father-in-law to Suzanne and Jennifer Gerla, and Alan Gold. Dedicated grandfather to Stephanie, Bradley, Lindsay, Brittany, Genna, Bryan, Anna, A.J., Garrett, Julia, and Caroline. He had an incredible passion for life, his friends and his family, and a successful career as a Long Island real estate developer. Strong-minded with remarkable wit, integrity, and impeccable style, he will be sorely missed by everyone he touched. 1/3

ARMIGER--George Dobler. On July 13, 2015, George Dobler Armiger of White Hall, MD; beloved father of M. Danielle Armiger and loving grandfather of Camden Grace; dear brother of Elizabeth A. Bryant and her husband, Barry and William B. Armiger and his wife, Linda. A Memorial Service will be held in the Govans Presbyterian Church, 5828 York Road, Baltimore, MD 21212 on Sunday, July 26, 2015 at 3pm. A reception will follow at Woodberry Crossing. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made out to the Camden Grace College Fund and sent to the church. 1/3

WALLACE--Joanne C.,unexpectedly passed away, in her sleep, on July 19, 2015 at age 69. Born September 6, 1945 in New York City, Joanne was the only child of Joseph and Sophie Czechlewski. She was raised in Manhattan, and had an intense love for New York City her whole life. After attending Marymount School of New York on 5th Avenue, Marymount College, Tarrytown and Teachers College, Columbia University, Joanne taught music for many years in the New York City public schools. Joanne was loved by all who knew her, because she was smart, talented, witty, fun loving and extraordinary generous to her friends. Joanne loved being with people and people loved to be with her because she took a great interest in life. Joanne was devoted to her Catholic faith, friends and her family, especially her husband William (Bill), with whom she recently celebrated their 47th wedding anniversary. Joanne and Bill were each other's best friend, closest companion and biggest supporter. Rarely apart, they loved spending time with each other and everything they undertook was enhanced by being together. Joanne was a great advocate for her two children, working tirelessly to instill in them the values and morals needed to navigate life, teaching them through example unconditional love. Music was Joanne's passion. Blessed with a powerful mezzo-soprano voice, Joanne studied and sang opera professionally with Musica Reservata in New York, and later sang for many years with The Grace Notes in Greenwich, CT, and other groups, but most fun was when she could be coaxed into singing for family and friends, where she would light up the room. Joanne and Bill regularly attended the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and myriad cultural offerings in New York City, a city she truly loved. Beyond music, Joanne loved her gardens, enjoyed golf and bridge, and was a good sport about her family's love of sailing and being on the water, no matter how bad the weather. Joanne lived in Greenwich, Connecticut, Watermill, New York and Hobe Sound, Florida and was a member of the Colony Club in New York City, The Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, Connecticut and Loblolly in Hobe Sound, Florida. She will be missed desperately by her family and all the people she had contact with throughout her life. And they are certain that Joanne will be singing a heartfelt rendition of Sto lat as she is welcomed into heaven. Joanne is survived by her husband William, her daughter Joan, her son Andrew and her daughter-in-law Wistar. A wake will be held on Tuesday, July 21 and Wednesday, July 22 from 5pm to 8pm in Joanne's home. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Thursday, July 23 at 10:30am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola located at 980 Park Avenue in New York City, followed by interment at Saint Raymond's Cemetery in the Bronx and a reception at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich, CT. Please contact Gallagher Funeral Home at 203-869-1513 for more information. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Joanne's memory to Marymount 5th Avenue. 1/3

TENEV--George, 95, of Princeton, New Jersey, died Sunday, February 22, 2015. Born in Aitos, Bulgaria, he was a resident of Princeton for many years. He attended schools in Aitos and Kotel, and Sofia University St. Kliment Ohridski, Bulgaria, the University of Vienna, and the New School for Social Research in New York. During World War II, he served as a medical corpsman in a Bulgarian Red Cross sanitary train operating across Europe; he was wounded twice and witnessed the firebombing of Dresden. During the war, in Poland, he met the late Helena Marzec. He returned to find her as hostilities were ending and in 1945, in Prague, they married and lived together for 70 years. After the war, he returned to Bulgaria with his wife. An opponent of the communist regime, he was imprisoned periodically and tortured; his family was persecuted; his father was executed in 1955. In 1957, he illegally left Bulgaria with his wife and children, a crime punishable by death. The family lived in a displaced persons camp in Vienna, Austria, and eventually came to the United States. They settled in Yonkers, New York. He worked for Radio Free Europe for many years and, after its New York offices were wound down, for financial institutions in Manhattan. He was a frequent visitor to New Suffolk, New York and Westerly, Rhode Island and, in retirement, to Menton, France and Cambridge, England. He traveled extensively throughout Europe and the Americas. He enjoyed reading, gardening, music, art, nature, swimming and skiing, and was a keen student of the political scene. He played an active role in raising his grandchildren. He was devoted to family and friends. Son of the late Jovi and Paraskeva Tenev, he is survived by a daughter Marie Pepper of Cambridge, England; a son Jovi Tenev and daughter-in- law Nancy Hingston of Princeton Junction, New Jersey; a granddaughter Tara Pepper Goldsmith and her husband Charles Goldsmith of Cambridge, England; a grandson Sean Pepper of New York; a grandson Liam Pepper and his wife Bic Hoang Leu of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; a grandson Nicholas Tenev of Madison, Wisconsin; grandchildren Christopher and Helena Tenev of Princeton Junction; and great grandsons Charles, Thomas, and Jonathan Goldsmith of Cambridge, England. A choral funeral Mass will be celebrated 4:30pm, July 25, 2015 at Miller Chapel, Princeton Theological Seminary, with interment at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested donations to the Red Cross, Trinity Church, Princeton, or St. Dimitri of Thessaloniki Church in Aitos. 1/3

DUKESS--A. Carleton, 85, died at home in Larchmont, New York, on July 20, 2015 with his adored wife of 60 years, Mona Dukess, and his beloved daughters, Linda, Laura and Karen Dukess, at his side. The most loveable of men, he was treasured by his six grandchildren: Joanna and Sam Bernstein, Ben and Stephen Schwed, and Joseph and Johnny Liesman, and was a cherished father-in-law to Jody DiPerna, Roger Schwed and Steve Liesman. He loved his nieces and nephews, rejoiced in his friendships with people young and old, and was known as a great raconteur and a wise listener. Carleton was pre-deceased by his older brother, Joseph Dukess. A graduate of Syracuse University and Columbia University School of Law, Carleton had a distinguished career as a real estate attorney and developer. He drafted the documentation for the nation's first condominium development and lectured extensively on the then-novel form of ownership. His interest in the restoration of urban buildings for low and moderate income housing led to his co-founding of Continental Wingate Company, Inc., a housing and rehabilitation company. He was a president of the National Housing and Rehabilitation Association and served on the Citizens Housing & Planning Council of New York. He later was a partner in Castle Properties Co. and a director of Apple Bank for Savings in New York. Appreciative of his good fortune, Carleton devoted significant time and attention to charitable endeavors. He was a trustee of Barnard College, and a member of the boards of the New York Foundation, Community Resource Exchange, Castle Hill Center for the Arts and the Provincetown Art Association and Museum. Carleton loved Italian opera, the music of Benny Goodman, fishing, boating, single-malt Scotch and reading, but loved nothing more than spending time with his friends and family, especially in his favorite place, his home in Truro, Massachusetts. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, July 24 at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Cancer Support Team of Purchase, New York, or the Provincetown Art Association and Museum. 1

REED--Marie "Mimi" Byers. Our beloved Marie "Mimi" Byers Reed passed away peacefully on July 17, surrounded by the family who loved her, after a prolonged illness. Mimi was born in Pittsburgh January 11, 1939, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederic Byers. Mimi graduated from Sewickley Academy, The Foxcroft School and Briar Cliff Manor College. She was a Vice President of The American Heart Association and a Vice President of the Performing Arts Center at SUNY Purchase, New York. Mimi married Joseph Verner Reed, Jr. on December 19, 1959. They had two daughters, Serena Reed Kusserow of Santa Barbara, California and Electra Reed of Greenwich, Connecticut and four grandchildren. Mimi was a member of the Colony Club of New York, the Gasparilla Inn Beach Club of Boca Grande, Florida, the Round Hill Club of Greenwich, Connecticut and the Harbor Club of Seal Harbor, Maine. Funeral and Memorial Services are to be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mimi's memory may be made to the ASPCA of Hancock County, Maine (141 Bar Harbor Road, Trenton, ME 04605). 1/3

MILLIMET--Erwin, 89, of New York City and Massachusetts, left us on July 20, 2015. Erwin was born in New York City, the son of Henrietta and Maurice Millimet, a well-known New York City lawyer and brother of Beatrice. He spent his young years on a dairy farm in Fitchville, Connecticut. He served in World War II in combat operations in Europe and the Philippine Islands. He escaped from a German prisoner of war camp to rejoin his regiment. Erwin was a graduate of Amherst College, Phi Beta Kappa, and of Harvard Law School C.L. He was the recipient of post graduate fellowship in political science and foreign relations. He worked with Dr. Karl Lowenstein on the drafting of the new constitution for West Germany. Erwin's prime interests after family were the law, education and national politics. His 40 year legal career was with the national law firm, Stroock and Stroock and Lavan for which he retired as the Chairman of the Executive Committee. He was known as an expert in corporate law, and represented major corporations and financial institutions and charities, with service on the boards of directors and trustees. He acted as special master for federal judges in New York and Massachusetts. On behalf of the National Venture Capital Association he was the co-author of the plan assets regulations of the Department of Labor which were essential for the development of venture capital. On specific assignments he represented the post-revolution government of Haiti and the government of Malaysia. He was a member of the corporate division of the senior lawyers committee of the American Bar Association, an arbitrator with the Arbitration Association and a consultant to the local offices of the district attorney and attorney general. Erwin's love of education led him to invitations for speaking and teaching at several post graduate schools on the east and west coast. He participated in the establishment of a paralegal program at UCLA and Elms College in Chicopee, MA. Erwin was active in national republican politics from the Eisenhower years, the Regan Administration, and the Administrations of George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush. He was a member of the Presidential Task Force. He was a co-founder of President Reagan's "Citizens for America" and Jack Kemp's "Stand Up America". He was a member of the United Nations Commission on African Development Strategies, and a member of the African National Support Group. He is survived by his wife Dr. Sharon Christie, his daughters Rachel and Sarah of Springfield, MA, their mother Mary, and his grandson, Lucas, of San Diego, CA. His sons, Robert and James, predeceased him in 2012 and 2010, and their mother, Renee predeceased him in 1988. Erwin was a religious man who believed in close family relationships and the one God of all people, regardless of culture, denomination or background. His departure leaves a large gap for all who loved him. Donations to celebrate Erwin's life may be made of any personal choice to an organization helping needy children receive education. A gathering to celebrate Erwin's life will be held Thursday, July 23rd, beginning at 4:00pm in Forastiere Smith Family Funeral Home, 220 North Main St., East Longmeadow, MA (413) 525-2800. A funeral home service will commence at 6:00pm. Erwin will be laid to rest in a private ceremony and military honors in the Massachusetts Veterans' Memorial Cemetery, Agawam. www.forastiere.com. 1/3
PLAUT--Harry, 94. Born Frankfurt, Germany. Traveling salesman 50+ years, volunteer, great-grandfather. Sinai Chapels, Wednesday. 1/3

TENEV--Helena, 90, of Princeton, New Jersey, died Wednesday, February 25, 2015. Born in Jedrzejow, Poland, she was a resident of Princeton for many years. She attended schools in Jedrzejow and Warsaw and, during the period of Nazi occupation when Poland ceased to exist, secret schools organized by the Polish Underground. After the war, she attended the Hochschule fur Welthandel (now Wirtschaftsuniversitat Wien) in Vienna, Austria. During World War II, she became separated from her family and was conscripted into labor in Warsaw. A Polish patriot, she supported the Home Army, the Armija Krajowa; she survived the Warsaw Uprising in 1944 and escaped deportation. In Poland, during the war, she met the late George Tenev, a medical corpsman serving in a Bulgarian Red Cross sanitary train. He returned to find her as hostilities were ending and in 1945, in Prague, they married and lived together for 70 years. After the war, she moved to her husband's native Bulgaria. An opponent of the communist regime, her husband was imprisoned periodically and tortured; her family was persecuted; her father-in-law was executed in 1955. In 1957, the couple illegally left Bulgaria with their children, a crime punishable by death. The family lived in a displaced persons camp in Vienna, Austria, and eventually came to the United States. They settled in Yonkers, New York. She worked as a medical technician and became supervisor of the electrocardiogram department at Misericordia Hospital (now Our Lady of Mercy) in New York City. She worked closely with AIDS patients for many years. She was a frequent visitor to New Suffolk, New York and Westerly, Rhode Island and, in retirement, to Menton, France and Cambridge, England. She traveled extensively throughout Europe and the Americas. She enjoyed music, art, nature, and reading, especially poetry; she was deeply religious. She played an active role in raising her grandchildren. She was devoted to friends and family. Daughter of the late Jozef and Marianna Marzec, she is survived by a daughter Marie Pepper of Cambridge, England; a son Jovi Tenev and daughter-in-law Nancy Hingston of Princeton Junction, New Jersey; a granddaughter Tara Pepper Goldsmith and her husband Charles Goldsmith of Cambridge, England; a grandson Sean Pepper of New York; a grandson Liam Pepper and his wife Bic Hoang Leu of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; a grandson Nicholas Tenev of Madison, Wisconsin; grandchildren Christopher and Helena Tenev of Princeton Junction; great grandsons Charles, Thomas, and Jonathan Goldsmith of Cambridge, England; and sisters Janina Wachsberger Witkowski of Washington, D.C. and Danuta Wernik of Oceanside, California. A choral funeral Mass will be celebrated 4:30pm, July 25, 2015 at Miller Chapel, Princeton Theological Seminary, with interment at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested donations to the Red Cross, Trinity Church, Princeton, or the Church of the Holiest Saviour (Kosciol Najswietszego Zbawiciela) in Warsaw. 1/3

NATHAN--Robert Clark, passed away on July 20, 2015 at the age of 96. Bob was a WWII Navy Veteran. Loving husband of the late Miriam and brother of the late Alan. He is survived by his three children, Artie, Mindy and Paul and his four grandchildren, Ezra, Jarret, Zady and Marlee. FEINBERG--Shirley R.,Age 89, died at home on July 20, 2015 of cancer. Devoted wife of Judge Wilfred Feinberg, who died in July of last year. She was born in Valley Cottage, NY of Jewish immigrants from Poland and Russia, who named their humble Mount Vernon dress shop Shirley's in honor of their daughter. For many years Shirley had her own business as a personal fashion shopper, assisting style-challenged executives and judges in the New York metropolitan area and beyond. Doting mother, gourmet cook, energetic tennis player, and perfect companion for 68 years to her more reserved husband, Shirley was a beautiful, vivacious, always stylish woman who loved art, music, good food and wine. She was also an avid gardener; she planted and maintained a small but exuberant plot in Liberty Community Garden, which she helped to found. She served as a docent at the Brooklyn Museum for the past 10 years, and she maintained her boundless energy to the very end. (Traipsing through her favorite art museums, she could easily outlast any of her offspring.) She was devoted to and is survived by her daughter, Susan Stelk, her husband Wayne and their children, Sam and Dasha of Marblehead, MA; her son Jack, his wife Pam McKniff and their children Rebecca, Andrew, and Eliza of Manhattan Beach, CA, her daughter, Jessica Twedt and daughter, Kayla of Garrett Park, MD, and her brother Frank Marcus, of Tucson, AZ. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, July 22, at 11:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. (at Amsterdam Ave.), New York. A reception will be held at Shirley's apartment from 5pm to 8pm the same day. Memorial donations can be made to the Hudson River Park. 1/3

CRUZ--Edward, P.E.,entrepreneur and philanthropist, passed away at home in Bay Head, NJ on July 14, 2015 with his wife and four children by his side. Born in Portugal in 1941, he immigrated to the U.S. in 1950, initially settling in the Ironbound section of Newark. He graduated from Newark College of Engineering (now NJIT) in 1963, with a BS in Civil Engineering, earning his New Jersey Professional Engineer's license in 1968. In 2013, Mr. Cruz received a Doctor of Science, honoris causa from NJIT. After graduation in 1963, Mr. Cruz joined his father at Cruz Construction Company in New Jersey, heading the firm as President from 1974 to 1984. In 1984, he and his cousin Evaristo G. Cruz founded E.E. Cruz & Company Inc., a heavy civil contractor in New York and New Jersey. EE Cruz became an ENR Top 400 Construction Firm in the U.S. Mr. Cruz was a philanthropic leader with a particular interest in education and the Portuguese community. He endowed numerous scholarships and underwrote the Monmouth County Concours d'Elegance to benefit children's charities in New Jersey. Mr. Cruz recently completed his memoir, A Bold Journey, eagerly anticipated and enthusiastically received by his family, friends and colleagues with proceeds going to St. John's Soup Kitchen in Newark. Mr. Cruz is survived by Sharon, his wife of 51 years; his four children, Robin McClearn, Jeffrey Cruz, Kelly McCullers, and Susan Barkey and their spouses; his grandchildren, Michelle, her husband Dan, Connor, Taylor, Kate, Caroline, Henry, Olivia, Peter, Hilary and Liam; his mother Lidia; and his four siblings. The memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 22nd at 4pm at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, NJ. Complimentary parking will be available in lots A, B, and C. Donations in lieu of flowers: The Trust For Public Land attn: Tracy Terry, Lafayette Street School Project, 20 Community Place #

KANDELL--Brian J. "Yank", passed away on July 10, 2015. Loving husband, father, and grandfather. An Army Veteran and devoted member of the Order of the Arrow of the Boy Scouts. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, Brian practiced law in New York and Pennsylvania. Beloved and respected by his many friends and colleagues; he will be dearly missed. Brian will be interred following a family graveside service on July 26th at Mt. Hebron cemetery in Flushing, NY. A memorial service will be held on Sunday August 2, 2015 at 2 PM at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, followed by a gathering of family and friends. The family requests that memorial contributions be made out to the Ten Mile River Scout Museum and mailed to Hal Rosenfeld, Trustee, 46 Henry Street, Merrick, NY 11566. 1/3

PARSONS--James P.,Jr., formerly of New York City, passed away on June 30, 2015. Jim worked as a comptroller with AKA Advertising until his retirement. Jim is survived by his sisters, Margaret Malandra of Langhorne, PA, and Marilyn J. Powers of Levittown, PA. Services and interment were held privately. 1/3
LITTMAN--Madelyn C. Jan. 24, 1952--July 23, 2010. You would be so proud of Emily & Molly. We miss you every day. Love you forever -- Frank, Emily and Molly Wagner 1/3
BARNETT--Bill. I was lucky to "feel myself beloved on this earth." It has been a year; I will love you forever. Amy. 1/3

STERN--Vera. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our beloved friend and champion, Vera Stern. Vera, along with her husband of 43 years, Isaac Stern, worked tirelessly and passionately to save the Hall from destruction in 1960. In saving the Hall, Vera and Isaac created the Carnegie Hall family, of which all New Yorkers - and many beyond - are part. Vera remained actively involved with the Hall in the decades that followed, always eager and willing to lend a helping hand wherever it was needed most, and providing a reminder of the values that drive this institution. Vera will be dearly missed but has left a lasting legacy in preserving Carnegie Hall for future generations. All of us who have and will be transformed by their experiences at Carnegie Hall owe Vera a debt of gratitude. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Michael, Shira, David, and the entire Stern family. Sanford I. Weill, President; Ronald O. Perelman, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3
HAYWOOD--Nancy A. (July 12, 1927 - July 9, 2015) Nancy was the most elegant and treasured friend who is greatly missed. Jo Hallingby 1/3

GROSS--Sally. Performer, choreographer, teacher, Sally died on July 20, 2015. She is the mother of Rachel and Sidonia, grandmother of Giaco, Tessa and Tejo, and sister of Edythe Green. A memorial will be announced. 1/3

STERN--Vera. The George London Foundation for Singers mourns the passing of our founding Board Member Vera Stern. She was an enthusiastic supporter of our mission, keenly interested in working to promote the careers of young opera singers. We will miss her advice, wise counsel and friendship. Our deepest condolences to Shira, David, Michael and all her family. George London Foundation for Singers Nora London, President 1/3
SIMON--Robert. Forever in our hearts. Love always, Mimi, Eileen, Valerie, Jim and Rebecca 1/3

STERN--Vera. Devoted herself to AICF, with love and great success, and saving Carnegie Hall, causes dear to her and to her husband. Beloved by family and friends, she will never be forgotten.--JFW 1/3

HOCHHAUSER--Stanley (97), of NYC passed away peacefully at his home. After graduating from N.Y.U. he took graduate courses at Yale University, and then he joined the U.S. Army Air Force where he achieved the rank of Captain during WWII. His family was at the center of everything. He was married to his darling Rita for 65 years before her passing and had two sons Richard (Carole) Ken who predeceased him (Kathy). He talked lovingly about his grandchildren Jonathan (Amy), Jennifer (Jamie), Ellen, Gwen (Rich). He is also survived by his four great grandchildren Jackson, Charlie, Weston and Lucy, each of whom brought a sparkle to his eyes. Funeral services will be held on Thursday July 23, at 2pm at the Cedar Park Cemetery Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, N.J. Memorial donations can be made to the World Assistance for Cambodia which will support the Rita Hochhauser School, c/o Richard and Carole Hochhauser. Funeral services by Louis Suburban Chapel Fair Lawn N.J. 201-791-0015. 1/3

STERN--Vera. Lifelong volunteer, arts benefactor, mentor to young musicians, died peacefully at her home in NYC on July 21, 2015, at age 88. A Holocaust survivor, her indomitable spirit was a force felt by all who knew her. She was married for 43 years to violinist Isaac Stern, with whom she co-spearheaded the successful fight to save Carnegie Hall from destruction in 1960. Past President and Chair of the Board of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation for many years, member of the Board of the Musicians' Foundation, a devoted champion of Israel, and active in many other causes. She is survived by her daughter, Rabbi Shira Stern and her two sons, both conductors, Michael Stern and David Stern; her son-in-law Rabbi Donald Weber and her daughters-in-law Shelly Cryer and Katharina Wolff; her niece Mika Hornyak Hale and her nephew Gregor Hornyak; and her grandchildren, Noah and Ronni Jane, Ari, Eytan, Hannon, Nora, Sophia, and Talia. Services to be held at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68th Street, on Thursday, July 23, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The New York String Seminar at the New School. 1/3

BIKEL--Theodore. Actors' Equity Association mourns the passing of our dear friend, our brother and President Emeritus, Theo Bikel. He was a tireless advocate for Equity members and his extraordinary achievements paved the way for so many. No one loved theater more, his union better or cherished actors like Theo did. He has left an indelible mark on generations of members past and generations of members to come. We thank you, Theo, for all you have done. 1/3

SHILS--Maurice Edward, M.D. FACP, ScD. December 31, 1914 - June 29, 2015. Husband of Betty Bell Shils of Mobile, Alabama; father of Jonathan Shils of Atlanta, Georgia; and Loraine Shils (David) Hammack of Shaker Heights, Ohio; with his wife of almost 50 years, Cylia Finkel Shils (deceased); grandfather of Elizabeth (Michael Ulchak) Hammack, Peter (Beth) Hammack and Sarah (Bret) Kovacs and great grandfather of four. Professor Emeritus of Medicine, Cornell Medical College, retired Attending Physician and Director of Clinical Nutrition, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital; retired Executive Secretary, Committee on Public Health of New York Academy of Medicine; retired Adjunct Professor, Wake Forest School of Medicine; senior editor of Modern Nutrition in Health and Disease, 7-10th editions. 1/3

EPSTEIN--William. Age 68 of New York City. Survived by sons Charles and Nathaniel and wife Patricia. His passion for history, politics, literature, art, music and sports enriched his life and ours, but what we will miss most is his love. 1/3

MERCADO--Luis G.,died at his home on July 20, 2015, age 80 years. A loving father of Deborah, grandfather of Ashley and Stephan and super great-granddad for Dionte. He was deeply grateful to his sister Sequi for her devoted care of their mother during her later years. He had the greatest respect and admiration for his cherished daughter Deborah who with love, courage and determination brought two wonderful children to adulthood. Gil was my special friend and companion for over 46 years; as kind and generous a partner one could hope for. Dearest Gil, we spent the young and long years well. Thanks for everything you have meant to me. Donald Fredrickson 1/3

STARK--Leslie, J.,a beloved Renaissance Man died July 17, 2015 at the age of 76 at his home on Martha's Vineyard. The cause of death was Myelodysplasia. He was a graduate of Poly Prep and Hobart & William Smith Colleges where he served on the board for many years. Upon graduation from college he attended the Yale School of Drama. He acted in New York in theatre and on T.V. He was the International Marketing Director of a subsidiary of Revlon and was based in Brussels and Hong Kong. After meeting his wife of 49 years Myra, a PHD in English Literature he entered the world of advertising, working at Benton and Bowles which became DMB& B. He became a successful producer of TV commercials and inspired all who worked with him. He had boundless energy and curiosity and fully embraced everything he did. But he will be remembered most for his numerous quiet acts of kindness. When he retired to Martha's Vineyard he continued to pursue his many passions including jazz, which he taught. He produced, directed and starred in countless plays at the Vineyard Playhouse and Island Theatre Workshop; was a member of the Peter Luce Play Readers Group. He enjoyed ballroom dancing, was a superb cook; learned and performed the ukelele after being told his fingers were not dexterous enough for the cello. He was a member of The Chamber Music Society. He was on the board and a major supporter of the Cancer Society Support Group and devoted to the Vineyard House. He worked on the Martha's Vineyard Gazette the oldest newspaper on the island. He is survived by his adored wife Myra, daughter Victoria Stark, son Brian Stark and his wife Julie Ramos M.D., granddaughter Eliana, sisters, Renee Stark, Cheryl Stark, sisters-in-law, Margery Meltzer, and Ruth Waldbaum, M.D., brother-in- law, Robert Waldbaum M.D., nieces Karen Andrade, Jennifer Marcus, Nicole Moser, Alexandra Kinnie and Hillary Waldbaum. We all adored Leslie and will miss him dearly. Donations can be made to the Martha's Vineyard Cancer Support Group, PO Box 2214, Martha's Vineyard, MA 02568. 1/3

GERLA--Marvin. Died peacefully Monday, July 20th with his family at his side. He was 93 years young. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was the son of Rose and Bernard Gerla, brother to Stanley, husband to his beloved Cecily for 62 years, father to Jamie Dee Kline, Bradley, Kathy Gold, and Michael, father-in-law to Suzanne and Jennifer Gerla, and Alan Gold. Dedicated grandfather to Stephanie, Bradley, Lindsay, Brittany, Genna, Bryan, Anna, A.J., Garrett, Julia, and Caroline. He had an incredible passion for life, his friends and his family, and a successful career as a Long Island real estate developer. Strong-minded with remarkable wit, integrity, and impeccable style, he will be sorely missed by everyone he touched. 1/3

HARRIS--Ellen. Passed away on July 7 after a long battle with pancreatic cancer. A magnetic, compelling woman, Ellen attracted a broad and deep range of smart and wise people throughout her life. She brought people together. Her extraordinary immediate and extended family, remarkably strong circles of friends from different walks of life, political associates from her work for Senator Jacob Javits in Washington D.C. in the '70s, and legal colleagues in New Jersey and New York energized her life. To all of them she was an anchor, ally, advisor, and unwavering friend. Practicing lawyer for 37 years, Ellen was a Counsel of Securities Law at Sidley Austin LLP in Manhattan, where she specialized in funds and investments. With a 1969 B.A. from University of Rochester, 1970 M.A. in history from Stanford University, and a 1977 J.D. from New York University School of Law, she recognized the importance of education and served on the Board of Trustees at The Pingry School in Martinsville, NJ, where her two loving sons, Michael and David, graduated. An exemplary mother, she showed unwavering devotion to them and pride in their accomplishments. In addition to her loving family, she became an honorary mother and aunt to innumerable others, with kindness, class, and intelligent guidance. Ellen's parents, Mimi West (driving force behind the Los Angeles Free Clinic for three decades, and founder of Friends of the Los Angeles Free Clinic) and Bernie West (Emmy-winning writer of All in the Family, and producer of Three's Company) instilled in Ellen and in her sister, Isabel, both a love of culture and fine arts and the importance of giving back to society. She was a patron of The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey and on the Board of the Rioult Dance New York, and she hosted fundraising events to champion the causes and cultural celebrations in which she believed. Donations in her name can be made to some of her favorite arts charities Rioult Dance, New York City Ballet, or the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey. She will be deeply missed. 1/3

VAVRUSKA--Mary A.,passed away peacefully at her residence in Jackson Heights, NY on July 22, 2015. She was a lifelong resident of Queens. She was very active in Cooperative and Community Affairs serving as President of Brulene Cooperative and Chairman of Community Board 3. She received a Bachelor's Degree in Economics from NYU. She retired from Equitable Life as a Vice President of Internal Auditing. She was President of the family owned business TCE Systems. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Charles and his wife Susan. Cherished grandma of Mary. Also survived by her sister Gloria Carroll and her husband Arthur, her brother in law Ronald Vavruska and his wife Jeanne. Reposing Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, NY, Thursday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 945am Blessed Sacrament RC Church, Jackson Heights. Interment Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, New York. 1/3

NATHAN--Robert Clark, passed away on July 20, 2015 at the age of 96. Bob was a WWII Navy Veteran. Loving husband of the late Miriam and brother of the late Alan. He is survived by his three children, Artie, Mindy and Paul and his four grandchildren, Ezra, Jarret, Zady and Marlee. Funeral services will be held Friday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

MESSINGER--Martin P.,age 66, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, passed away unexpectedly on Sunday, July 19, 2015 at his home in East Hampton, New York. Marty was born in the Bronx, New York to Roslyn Cohen and Hyman Messinger. He grew up in Bayside, Queens along with his brother, Joel Messinger, and attended Bayside High School before earning his bachelor's degree from the University of Bridgeport and his juris doctorate from St. John's University School of Law. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1975. Marty began his remarkable 36-year career with Westinghouse Broadcasting and CBS in 1978. Prior to retiring in December 2014, he had served as Senior Vice President and Deputy General Counsel for CBS since 1996; and chief legal officer for the CBS Television Stations group since the division was formed in 2000. Marty also served as CBS Corporation's first Chief Compliance Officer for four years, following the company's separation from Viacom in December 2005. He joined the CBS Law Department in 1996, following the merger of CBS and Westinghouse. Prior to that, he was Vice President and General Counsel of Westinghouse Broadcasting (Group W). He played a key role in the merger of CBS and Group W, the merger of CBS with Infinity Broadcasting and numerous other significant transactions. Prior to joining Group W in 1978, Marty practiced corporate law at the Wall Street law firm Sullivan & Cromwell. The counseling and representation CBS's stations received under Marty's leadership was the best in the business. As much as his commitment to professional excellence, Marty was also revered for his deep commitment to being a friend and mentor to those around him and taking a genuine interest in the lives and careers of colleagues throughout the company. Marty's greatest pride and joy was his family. He was a devoted, involved and incredibly proud father to his children Nicole, Christopher and John, and a beaming grandfather to Nicole and her husband Bryn Harder's three daughters, Madelyn, Ruby and Layla. He is also survived by his lifelong friend, and the mother of his three children, Lupe Abuchaibe. Marty was a brilliant, intellectually curious and deeply funny man. His passion for books was evident to anyone who ever entered his home and his love for movies was also well known. He was a lifelong fan of the Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers, the New York Giants, the Rangers and Knicks, and all things sports. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Saturday, July 25 at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or Save the Children, two charities that were favorites of Marty. 1/3

STERN--Vera. The America-Israel Cultural Foundation mourns the passing of Vera Stern. From the late '60s until 2007 Vera served in many roles with the organization, including as its president, and was known as the heart and soul of AICF. She tirelessly dedicated herself to the organization and passionately supported its artists for over four decades. Some of the world's top artists can trace the beginning of their careers and early development to investments made by AICF and Vera. Vera's love for Israel and her passion for the arts will leave a long legacy of creative excellence through AICF and demonstrate Tikkun Olam in its most universal language. 1/3

STERN--Vera. On behalf of the Board of Directors of the Musicians Foundation we express our condolences and deepest sympathies to her extensive family. She served on the Board for over forty years with devotion and a deep sense of caring for the musicians who are our clients. She will be sorely missed. Hans E. Tausig, President 1/3
APPLEMAN--Mark J. Still miss you after all these years. Marguerite please contact me I'm in Washington, DC. Larry Ravitz 1/3
BENENSON--Edward H. Always in our thoughts. Forever in our hearts. Gladys, Lisa, and Amy 1/3

BIKEL--Theodore. Actors' Equity Association mourns the passing of our dear friend, our brother and President Emeritus, Theo Bikel. He was a tireless advocate for Equity members and his extraordinary achievements paved the way for so many. No one loved theater more, his union better or cherished actors like Theo did. He has left an indelible mark on generations of members past and generations of members to come. We thank you, Theo, for all you have done. 1/3
DUNTON--Patricia Hall, 84, of Marietta, GA, passed away July, 21, 2015 surrounded by family. Survived by six children and twenty two grandchildren. 1/3

DOCTOROW--Edgar L. With deep sadness we note the passing of Edgar L. Doctorow. He was a cherished friend of NYU Libraries and we are honored to hold his literary papers. His wit, brilliance, and grace will be sorely missed and well remembered here. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Helen and his family. Carol A. Mandel, Dean of Libraries, NYU 1/3

BIKEL--Theodore. Partners for Progressive Israel mourn the passing of Theodore Bikel, Board Chairman (2005-present) and inspiration for peace and human rights in the Middle East. All knew Theo as a great performing artist; we knew him as a dynamic social activist and a powerful voice for justice, dignity and peace for Israel, its neighbors and the world. His deep love for Israel was firmly rooted in the Zionist movement. No one was a more articulate advocate for a two-state solution. Theo will continue to light our way with his example of tikun olam, healing the world. We remember his great warmth, humor and vibrant presence. Partners for Progressive Israel has established the Theodore Bikel Fund for Peace and Social Justice to continue his dedicated activism for a secure, democratic Israel and a better world. 1/3

MESSINGER--Martin P.,age 66, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, passed away unexpectedly on Sunday, July 19, 2015 at his home in East Hampton, New York. Marty was born in the Bronx, New York to Roslyn Cohen and Hyman Messinger. He grew up in Bayside, Queens along with his brother, Joel Messinger, and attended Bayside High School before earning his bachelor's degree from the University of Bridgeport and his juris doctorate from St. John's University School of Law. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1975. Marty began his remarkable 36-year career with Westinghouse Broadcasting and CBS in 1978. Prior to retiring in December 2014, he had served as Senior Vice President and Deputy General Counsel for CBS since 1996; and chief legal officer for the CBS Television Stations group since the division was formed in 2000. Marty also served as CBS Corporation's first Chief Compliance Officer for four years, following the company's separation from Viacom in December 2005. He joined the CBS Law Department in 1996, following the merger of CBS and Westinghouse. Prior to that, he was Vice President and General Counsel of Westinghouse Broadcasting (Group W). He played a key role in the merger of CBS and Group W, the merger of CBS with Infinity Broadcasting and numerous other significant transactions. Prior to joining Group W in 1978, Marty practiced corporate law at the Wall Street law firm Sullivan & Cromwell. The counseling and representation CBS's stations received under Marty's leadership was the best in the business. As much as his commitment to professional excellence, Marty was also revered for his deep commitment to being a friend and mentor to those around him and taking a genuine interest in the lives and careers of colleagues throughout the company. Marty's greatest pride and joy was his family. He was a devoted, involved and incredibly proud father to his children Nicole, Christopher and John, and a beaming grandfather to Nicole and her husband Bryn Harder's three daughters, Madelyn, Ruby and Layla. He is also survived by his lifelong friend, and the mother of his three children, Lupe Abuchaibe. Marty was a brilliant, intellectually curious and deeply funny man. His passion for books was evident to anyone who ever entered his home and his love for movies was also well known. He was a lifelong fan of the Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers, the New York Giants, the Rangers and Knicks, and all things sports. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Saturday, July 25 at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or Save the Children, two charities that were favorites of Marty. 1/3
GRABOSKI--Teddy. "Unable are the loved to die, for love is immortality." -E.D. Forever in our hearts, Benny, Nancy, Diane, Jennifer, Carol, & family 1/3

RIPPE--William Cisler. Formerly of Westfield, NJ passed away peacefully at his home in Westport, CT on Tuesday, July 21, 2015 after a long struggle with lung cancer. He was surrounded by his loving family. Bill was born in Summit, NJ in 1959 and was raised in Westfield, NJ. He graduated from Westfield High School and attended Cornell University, where he received his Bachelors Degree in Chemical Engineering. After two years at the Texaco Refinery in Port Arthur, TX as a process engineer, he returned to The Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, where he received his MBA Degree. Following graduation, Bill joined Drexel Burnham Lambert in the investment banking sector, working on mergers and acquisitions. With the demise of Drexel Burnham, Bill joined AIG Financial Products, responsible for trading and finance in the energy field. He then took his talents to the Louis Dreyfus Group where he was instrumental in creating Louis Dreyfus Energy Services, advancing to the position of Executive Vice President. He also served on the boards of Louis Dreyfus and the Lung Cancer Research Foundation. Bill led a full and active life. He played football and wrestled in high school and later became an accomplished tennis and paddle tennis player, winning club championships. He belonged to both The Patterson Club in Fairfield and The Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport. In addition to his athletic achievements, he had a green thumb, spending many hours perfecting his gardens, including a wild flower garden in a large vacant field. His last project was converting an old shed into a new barn, overlooking this field. Bill is survived by his loving wife Laure Sudreau-Rippe, his parents Marianne and Dick, his brother Paul, his sister Ann Beard, his children Brad, Amy and Chloe and his step-children Lucas and Juliette. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lung Cancer Research Foundation, 155 East 55th St., New York, NY 10022. 1/3

ROSE--Alan, aged 67, died at home in New York City on July 7 from lung cancer. He was born on April 27, 1948 in Regensberg, Germany to Herbert and Marjorie (Murrell) Rose. Alan's early years were spent living in Germany, Japan, Colorado and Mississippi. The family moved to Baltimore in Alan's teenage years and he became an ardent fan of both the city and its people. After three years at the Maryland Institute of Art Mr. Rose worked as an independent graphic designer for Harry, an underground newspaper and on John Waters' films. For a brief period he lived in San Francisco collaborating on artwork for albums put out by various bands including The Quicksilver Messenger Service. Moving to New York in the early 70's he joined the National Lampoon. Alan Rose earned acclaim with his 1980's World At Your Feet Books, a series of such landmarks as the Empire State Building. He married Anne (Spaulding) Rose in 1981 and moved to Springfield, Massachusetts. During the summers he transformed a simple Adirondack cabin into a magical mountaintop masterpiece, complete with birch bark wallpaper and a tree in the living room. No typical father figure he coached his stepdaughters on junk store shopping, culinary risk-taking as well as dirt bike riding on Cuttyhunk Island. Alan's unconventional, selfgoverning and thrifty nature generated countless adventures for himself and those around him. His ideas were as innovative as his humor was keen. He is survived by his wife, Anne, his brother Michael B. Rose (Jenny) of Plymouth, Massachusetts, his stepdaughters Hilary Diebold of West Springfield, Massachusetts, Anne Diebold (Dan Szenda) of Southwick, Massachusetts and two step-grandchildren. In addition he leaves an aunt, five cousins, three step-nieces, one step- nephew and one great step- nephew. There will be a private service at the Adirondack lake he loved and a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Alan Rose's name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) and sent to the Office of Development, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Lauren Kelly, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

DONOVAN--Eileen. Mrs. Eileen Frances Donovan, nee McAllister, born and raised in Brooklyn, daughter of Anthony and Marjorie McAllister of NYC's family run 150 year old McAllister Towing (Tugboat) Company. For 51 years wife of the late Dr. J. Timothy Donovan, survived by her siblings Patrice Guiney, Marjorie (Jack Toner) Brian (Rosemary), Bruce (Susan) and Michael (Patti) McAllister, her children Tim, Anthony, Sean, Moira, Eileen and Tate Donovan, daughters-in-law Karen and Mary J, grandchildren Ari, Marnika, Kyrie Weiss and Lia Allee, and myriads of cousins. Graduate of Fontbonne Academy and St. Elizabeth's College, NJ, Class of 1949, and received her Master of Education from Columbia University in 1970, from which she proceeded to tutor remedial reading. She ran numerous charity events. An early volunteer in the HIV crisis during the 1980's. In 1988 she became a devoted hospice volunteer and continued until recently to partner with Sr. Rosalie O'Connor of St. Francis Missionary Convent, to visit the sick and shut ins in Bergen County. She remained an active Eucharistic Minister serving daily mass at her parish St. Therese of Liseux, Cresskill, NJ, and a leading member of the Third Order of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel of Engelwood. Wake at Barrett's Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ. (Sunday, July 26th, 2-6pm). Funeral Mass at St. Therese Parish, Cresskill, NY (July 27, 10am). In lieu of flowers, send donations to Hope House Ministries, PO Box 358, Port Jefferson, NY 11777. 1/3

POLLACK--Shirley, of NYC died peacefully on Thursday, July 23, 2015 at home. She was 95. Beloved mother, grandmother, great- grandmother, sister and aunt. She is survived by two daughters, Marilyn (Merv) Balsam of Stamford, CT and Ellen Pollack-Patrisso of NYC. Funeral Services to be held Sunday, July 26, 2015, 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Burial will follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. STERN--Vera. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our beloved friend and champion, Vera Stern. Vera, along with her husband of 43 years, Isaac Stern, worked tirelessly and passionately to save the Hall from destruction in 1960. In saving the Hall, Vera and Isaac created the Carnegie Hall family, of which all New Yorkers - and many beyond - are part. Vera remained actively involved with the Hall in the decades that followed, always eager and willing to lend a helping hand wherever it was needed most, and providing a reminder of the values that drive this institution. Vera will be dearly missed but has left a lasting legacy in preserving Carnegie Hall for future generations. All of us who have and will be transformed by their experiences at Carnegie Hall owe Vera a debt of gratitude. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Michael, Shira, David, and the entire Stern family. Sanford I. Weill, President; Ronald O. Perelman, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

VANCE--Geraldine "Gerry", on July 23, 2015. Loving wife of the late James J. Vance Sr. (N.Y.P.D-1961). Devoted mother of Valerie Vance Belcher (deceased) (Taylor Michael), Victoria Vance Weiskopf (Daniel-deceased), James Vance (Diane). Beloved grandmother of nine, Elizabeth Santos Zelus, James Santos, Taylor Edward Belcher, James, Jonathan, Jesse and Jordan Vance, Whitney Vance Weiskopf and Brandon Weiskopf. Blessed with two great-grandchildren, Kaden and Callie Zelus. Survived by one brother Raymond Newman (Beverly) and many nieces and nephews. Gerry was a long time member of the Screen Actors Guild and for 45 years was the Police Anchor Club's Widows Liaison Officer. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to the New York City Police Anchor Club, Chaplains Unit 130 Ave C, Room 409 NY,NY 10009. Visiting Sunday 6-9pm and Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm at McLaughlin Funeral Home 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday at 10am St. Patricks Church, 9511 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3
