MILLER--Douglas Howard. After a long illness, Douglas Howard Miller passed away on July 21, 2015 at his home in Naples, Florida -- just days after he celebrated his one hundredth birthday. Mr Miller is survived by his wife of eighteen years, Grace Lurton Miller of New York and Connecticut. He also leaves daughters Leslie Taylor and Sara Miller of Massachusetts and five grandchildren of his 57-year marriage to the late Barbara Miller. Mr. Miller's long career was highlighted by many years as comptroller of the General Foods Corporation here and prospector of business development abroad. Mr. Miller took special pride in his career-capping ten years in New Jersey where he introduced public financing and business development to the still-growing campus of Montclair State University. The family expects to have a private memorial service on Tuesday, July 28th at the First Congregational Church in former hometown Madison, Connecticut. 1/3

LICHTENSTEIN--Dorothy. 96, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died July 23, 2015 in Carlsbad, CA, of complications of Alzheimer's disease. She was born in Manhattan on June 27, 1919, to Zachara and Molly Ehrlich Ger. For 60 years the beloved wife of Milton Julian Lichtenstein until his death in 2005. Loving mother of Todd (Mimi Bowling) and Gregg (Janel Jacob) and adoring grandmother of Brian (Allegra Conway) and David, all of whom survive her. PS 11, Julia Richman High School, NYU (BA and MA). Teacher, traveler, foodie, dancer, reluctant sailor, indefatigable shopper, consummate hostess, devotee of all the arts, and above all a steadfast friend to so many. Graveside services Sunday, July 26, 11:00 a.m. at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, with a gathering to follow at the home of Todd and Mimi. For information, contact Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, (212) 769-4400. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to a liberal or humanitarian cause or an arts organization. 1/3

STONE--Dr. Leonard, beloved father of Barbara A. MacAdam and Brook Myra Stone, died on July 23rd at the age of 98 of complications of pneumonia. Cardiologist and internist, Dr. Stone was affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital his entire career, beginning as an intern in 1942 soon after serving during World War II in the Army Medical Corps where he rose to the rank of Major. Born in Staten Island, NY, where he attended Curtis High School, and went on to graduate from City College and from the University of Illinois at Chicago Medical School. He was married for 55 years to the late June Bernstein. Surviving him are his second wife, Delia Friedman, his daughters, his grandchildren, Elise and Geoffrey, and four greatgrandsons. Funeral services will be held Sunday, July 26 at 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Mount Sinai Medical School. 1/3

POLLAK--Shirley, of NYC died peacefully on Thursday, July 23, 2015 at home. She was 95. Beloved mother, grandmother, great- grandmother, sister and aunt. She is survived by two daughters, Marilyn (Merv) Balsam of Stamford, CT and Ellen Pollak-Patrisso of NYC. Funeral Services to be held Sunday, July 26, 2015, 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Burial will follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Shiva will be observed at the Hope Hershey residence Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. 1/3
PATSNER--Neva. Feb. 18, 1953 - July 25, 2009 Remembered with love. Your Husband Bruce 1/3

LESCH--Judith Willis, died peacefully, surrounded by her family, on July 23, 2015 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. She had heroically battled pancreatic cancer for three years. She was much beloved and is survived by her loving husband, Michael, a lawyer, daughter Sara Lesch (Gabriel Mesa), a lawyer, and son Ben Lesch (Ali), a teacher, and grandchildren Ana and Amalia Mesa, and Charlie, Daniel and Willa Lesch. Services will be Monday, July 27, 2015 at 11am at the Larchmont Temple, 74 Larchmont Ave., Larchmont, NY. Shiva will be observed starting at 6pm Monday and 3pm on Tuesday. For full obit, see her page at: www.JJFFH.com 1/3

DONOVAN--Eileen. Mrs. Eileen Frances Donovan, nee McAllister, born and raised in Brooklyn, daughter of Anthony and Marjorie McAllister of NYC's family run 150 year old McAllister Towing (Tugboat) Company. For 51 years wife of the late Dr. J. Timothy Donovan, survived by her siblings Patrice Guiney, Marjorie (Jack Toner) Brian (Rosemary), Bruce (Susan) and Michael (Patti) McAllister, her children Tim, Anthony, Sean, Moira, Eileen and Tate Donovan, daughters-in-law Karen and Mary J, grandchildren Ari, Marnika, Kyrie Weiss and Lia Allee, and myriads of cousins. Graduate of Fontbonne Academy and St. Elizabeth's College, NJ, Class of 1949, and received her Master of Education from Columbia University in 1970, from which she proceeded to tutor remedial reading. She ran numerous charity events. An early volunteer in the HIV crisis during the 1980's. In 1988 she became a devoted hospice volunteer and continued until recently to partner with Sr. Rosalie O'Connor of St. Francis Missionary Convent, to visit the sick and shut ins in Bergen County. She remained an active Eucharistic Minister serving daily mass at her parish St. Therese of Liseux, Cresskill, NJ, and a leading member of the Third Order of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel of Engelwood. Wake at Barrett's Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ. (Sunday, July 26th, 2-6pm). Funeral Mass at St. Therese Parish, Cresskill, NY (July 27, 10am). In lieu of flowers, send donations to Hope House Ministries, PO Box 358, Port Jefferson, NY 11777. 1/3

KOSSOFF--Irwin Ira, passed peacefully on July 23 at age 93. He is survived by his wife Edith and his sister Laine Rudd; his children Alan Kossoff, Evan Don Kossoff, Tom Kossoff, Mitzi Gilbert, Hank Steinberg and Steve Steinberg, and his 11 grandchildren. Ira was a recipient of a Purple Heart medal from WWII and was a paper box manufacturer. The funeral will be Monday, July 27 at 11:15am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, his family asks that donations be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Association. 1/3

HEPBURN--Mildred Joanne Smith, 94, a Broadway and film actress, and teacher, died on July 19. She is survived by her daughter, Vanessa, son, David, stepdaughter, Valerie, and six grandchildren. Her funeral will take place, Monday, July 27, at Grace Episcopal Church, White Plains, NY. 1/3

SISCHY--Ingrid. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation is profoundly saddened by the passing of Ingrid Sischy, whose commitment to and tireless support of our mission to rid the world of breast cancer was a source of strength, wisdom and dedication. As a brilliant and prolific writer, editor, speaker, advisor and friend she was a motive force in all of the arts and an irreplaceable central figure in contemporary culture. We join with the world in offering our deepest condolences to her beloved wife, Sandra Brant, and all of Ingrid's family. Leonard A. Lauder, Co-Chairman Kinga Lampert, Co-Chairman Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director Myra J. Biblowit, President 1/3

It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. 1/3

WOLLMAN--Anne Carolyn, died at the age of 82 on June 5, 2015. She was a prominent and discriminating collector of art works including ceramics, prints, and paintings; and was known for her impeccable taste in the clothing and jewelry she wore. The Vermont home that she and her husband designed was filled with works of art and antiques. Some of the ceramics and prints constituted the material for a show called Cross Currents in 20th Century Art, at the Currier Museum in Manchester, New Hampshire, during the summer of 2010. As an enthusiastic supporter of the arts and the artists who created them, she curated a number of ceramic shows on compelling intellectual and artistic themes, such as Vanitas and After Palissy. She served as a trustee of many organizations, including The Clay Studio of Philadelphia; Watershed Center for the Ceramic Arts, Newcastle, Maine; and The Vermont Arts Council. She is remembered by those who knew her for her comprehensive knowledge of the field of art, her unerring eye, and the gently mischievous teasing which was reserved for certain special friends. She was a graduate of Radcliffe College in 1954, and of the Harvard-Radcliffe Graduate Program in Business Administration in 1955. Her three daughters also graduated from Harvard College and are pursuing careers: Julie as President of Edinboro University of Pennsylvania; Emily as a Senior Director of Med Assets, a hospital management and consulting firm; and Diana in tax law as a partner in Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton. The older of her two grandchildren, Sara, is starting a career in art therapy; and the younger, Rosa, is currently attending Harvard College. Anne Carolyn Wollman is survived by her husband of 58 years, Harry, who was a former Medical School Dean, and is now a partner in Alexander, Wollman and Stark, where he serves as an advisor to executives and developer of talent for academic medical centers. Memorial services will be held in Woodstock, VT on September 20, and in Philadelphia on October 17. Donations may be sent to the Anne and Harry Wollman Scholarship Fund at Edinboro University, 210 Meadville St., Edinboro, PA, 16444. 1/3
LITTMAN--Madelyn C. Jan. 24, 1952--July 23, 2010. You would be so proud of Emily & Molly. We miss you every day. Love you forever -- Frank, Emily and Molly Wagner 1/3

SURAWICZ--Borys MD. Born 1917 Moscow, Russia, died 2015 in Palm Coast FL. Cardiologist, researcher, clinician, teacher and mentor. Full obituary online at: www.nytimes.com 1/3

SPIELMAN--Arthur. Art was born on March 6, 1947, to Jerry and Sunny, and grew up in Forest Hills, Queens. He was a pioneering figure in sleep research. Art worked at the first sleep center in the United States, his development of Sleep Restriction Therapy is a core component of insomnia treatment, and what became known as the Spielman 3P Model of Insomnia remains a cornerstone of the field. Art had a long association with Cornell, most recently as Co-Director of the Weill Cornell Center for Sleep Medicine. As a professor at CUNY for more than thirty years, he mentored graduate students and co-authored more than fifty scholarly articles and book chapters. In June of this year, he was honored with the Outstanding Scientific Achievement Award from the Society for Sleep Research. Art was a caring man who loved life. He treasured his friends, and meant so much to so many people. He was a love to his wife, Marlene, an inspiration to his children, Evan and David, a light to his daughter-in-law Melissa, an adored brother to his sister Eileen, and a joy to his grandchildren, Emma, Jason, and Hayley. He will be an eternal presence to his entire family. Services will be held on Sunday, July 26, 2015 at 4pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street. In lieu of flowers, his family asks that donations be made to the Art Spielman Memorial Fund at the Weill Cornell Center for Sleep Medicine. 1

SISCHY--Ingrid. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation is profoundly saddened by the passing of Ingrid Sischy, whose commitment to and tireless support of our mission to rid the world of breast cancer was a source of strength, wisdom and dedication. As a brilliant and prolific writer, editor, speaker, advisor and friend she was a motive force in all of the arts and an irreplaceable central figure in contemporary culture. We join with the world in offering our deepest condolences to her beloved wife, Sandra Brant, and all of Ingrid's family. Leonard A. Lauder, Co-Chairman Kinga Lampert, Co-Chairman Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director Myra J. Biblowit, President 1/3

LEONE--Richard C. Former president of the Century Foundation and a past chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died on Thursday, July 16. He was 75 years old. He was being treated for Parkinson's disease and was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. Born in Webster, New York in 1940, Dick Leone spent the bulk of his career in public service. A graduate of the University of Rochester, he earned a Masters degree and a PhD at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. A pragmatic progressive whose views were forged during the Kennedy era, Leone worked on many local and national campaigns. One of his proudest moments was working as an advance man on Robert Kennedy's presidential campaign in Oregon. He also worked on presidential campaigns for George McGovern, Walter Mondale, Michael Dukakis and Bill Bradley. In the '60s, he was executive director of the White House Task Force on The Cities. In addition, Leone managed Brendan Byrne's two successful campaigns for Governor of New Jersey, in 1973 and 1977. From 1974 to 1977, Leone was state treasurer of New Jersey. In 2005, he served as chairman of Governor Jon Corzine's transition committee. Leone served as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and was chairman of the Port Authority from 1990 to 1994. From 1989 to 2011, he was president of the Century Foundation (formerly Twentieth Century Fund), a public policy think tank. Leone steered the foundation to concentrate on such issues as inequality and civil liberties and he fought against attempts at privatizing Social Security. Leone's private sector jobs included working as President of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a managing director at Dillon Read & Co. He has long been a director/trustee of multiple funds at Dreyfus Corp. and serves on the board of the Center for American Progress. Burial is private, but a memorial service will take place in Princeton, New Jersey in September. He is survived by his wife, Meg Cox Leone; his children Kate Leone and Max Leone, and his granddaughter Lucy Kirschner, as well as his sister Sandra Leone Thomas Brooks and first wife, Anita Leone. As well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Those wishing to honor his memory can consider donations to New Jersey Policy Perspective or the Michael J. Fox Foundation. 1/3

Survived by his close former wife, Anne Cooling, and his children William Jr (Billy), Andrew, Sarah and Melissa. Memorial Service was held at Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien on Saturday, July 25. Memorial contributions may be made to the Stamford Hospital Foundation, 1351 Washington Blvd, Suite 202, Stamford, CT 06902. www.lawrencefuneral home.com 1/3

LEONE--Richard C. Dick was one of a kind. His titanic intellect, wit, and insights into the human condition and uncomfortable truths of life were enduring gifts to those he befriended and inspired. In government service and devotion to the public interest, he defined the gold standard. His legacy of integrity and compassion will forever guide those he knew and loved. Our deepest condolences to Meg (his rock), Kate (Will), Max, granddaughter Lucy, and sister Sandra. Ellen & Lew Kaden Hilary Ballon & Orin Kramer 1/3

COLBY--Barbara Heinzen, died peacefully Thursday, July 16 at the age of 94. She served with her husband and their family during his long CIA career in Sweden, Italy, Vietnam, and Washington, D.C., culminating in his service as Director of Central Intelligence from 1973-1976. She served on the Agency's Family Advisory Board, and played an important role in the passage of legislation guaranteeing a share of lifetime benefits to former spouses of Agency employees. She received the CIA Director's Award in 2002 for her "untiring efforts on the part of former Agency spouses" and her "constant concern for the welfare of Agency families," Mrs. Colby was born Barbara Ann Heinzen in Springfield, Ohio on December 25, 1920. Her father, Karl, was a journalist, businessman, and president of the Bayer Aspirin Company in the mid-1930s. Her mother Annette was a fashion coordinator for the Montgomery Ward Company. Barbara received a B.A. in History from Barnard College in 1942 and was an advertising copywriter before marrying William Egan Colby in 1945. Their marriage ended in divorce. In 1992 she received an M.A. in the Humanities from Georgetown University. She was a Dame of the Order of Malta. A beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, she is survived by four children, eight grandchildren and three great- grandchildren: her son Jonathan and Susan Colby of Jupiter Island, FL, her son Carl Colby of Washington, D.C., her son Paul and Amie Colby of Alexandria, VA, and her daughter Christine Colby Giraudo and John Giraudo of Washington, D.C.; her grandchildren Emily and Scott McLellan, Elbridge Colby and Susana Cordeiro Guerra, George Colby, 1st Lt. Arthur Colby, USMC, Peter and Sabrina Giraudo, and Charles and Elizabeth Colby. A daughter, Catherine Ann Colby, predeceased her in 1973. The funeral will be held at Holy Trinity Church in Washington, D.C., at 10:30am on Thursday, July 23. 1/3

We extend our condolences to Michael, Shira, David, and their families. 1/3

DONOVAN--Eileen. Mrs. Eileen Frances Donovan, nee McAllister, born and raised in Brooklyn, daughter of Anthony and Marjorie McAllister of NYC's family run 150 year old McAllister Towing (Tugboat) Company. For 51 years wife of the late Dr. J. Timothy Donovan, survived by her siblings Patrice Guiney, Marjorie (Jack Toner) Brian (Rosemary), Bruce (Susan) and Michael (Patti) McAllister, her children Tim, Anthony, Sean, Moira, Eileen and Tate Donovan, daughters-in-law Karen and Mary J, grandchildren Ari, Marnika, Kyrie Weiss and Lia Allee, and myriads of cousins. Graduate of Fontbonne Academy and St. Elizabeth's College, NJ, Class of 1949, and received her Master of Education from Columbia University in 1970, from which she proceeded to tutor remedial reading. She ran numerous charity events. An early volunteer in the HIV crisis during the 1980's. In 1988 she became a devoted hospice volunteer and continued until recently to partner with Sr. Rosalie O'Connor of St. Francis Missionary Convent, to visit the sick and shut ins in Bergen County. She remained an active Eucharistic Minister serving daily mass at her parish St. Therese of Liseux, Cresskill, NJ, and a leading member of the Third Order of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel of Engelwood. Wake at Barrett's Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ. (Sunday, July 26th, 2-6pm). Funeral Mass at St. Therese Parish, Cresskill, NY (July 27, 10am). In lieu of flowers, send donations to Hope House Ministries, PO Box 358, Port Jefferson, NY 11777. 1/3

MILLER--Douglas Howard. After a long illness, Douglas Howard Miller passed away on July 21, 2015 at his home in Naples, Florida -- just days after he celebrated his one hundredth birthday. Mr Miller is survived by his wife of eighteen years, Grace Lurton Miller of New York and Connecticut. He also leaves daughters Leslie Taylor and Sara Miller of Massachusetts and five grandchildren of his 57-year marriage to the late Barbara Miller. Mr. Miller's long career was highlighted by many years as comptroller of the General Foods Corporation here and prospector of business development abroad. Mr. Miller took special pride in his career-capping ten years in New Jersey where he introduced public financing and business development to the still-growing campus of Montclair State University. The family expects to have a private memorial service on Tuesday, July 28th at the First Congregational Church in former hometown Madison, Connecticut. 1/3

CAMUS--Jacques Pierre. Passed away July 20, 2015 at his Laguna Beach, CA home after battling cancer. Born July 5, 1931 to a farming family in Nollevaux, Belgium, Camus graduated from the prestigious Namur Hotel School. He then embarked on a career that spanned decades as a world class hotelier. He was employed as a Senior Executive by Loews Hotels in New York City at The Drake, The Summit and the famed Regency Hotel on Park Avenue, among others. He ended his illustrious career as General Manager of the Westwood Marquis in Los Angeles. Camus will be missed by his long term partner, Fernand Poitras, by the Poitras Family, by Thomas Crijns, who was like a son to Jacques, by his cousin Chantal Bellevaux and her husband Jules Martin, as well as by scores of friends from around the world. A Mass and reception will be held in celebration of Jacques' life at 4:30pm on August 15 at The Sherman Library and Gardens, 2647 East Coast Highway, Corona Del Mar, CA. The family requests that donations be made to a charity of your choice, in lieu of flowers. 1/3

CARPENTER--Anthony. Died on July 12 in Vero Beach, FL. Born in Texas in 1932, he was the son of Dean Carpenter and Rosemary Hilton Carpenter. He leaves his loving wife of 60 years Lilan, children Dean, Hilary and Tracey and four grandchildren. He rose to Vice President of Hilton International, which took the family all over the world, including St. Thomas, Istanbul and Sydney. Lilan and Tony met at The Hotel School in Lausanne, Switzerland, where they embarked on a remarkable life. They returned to the United States from Sydney in 1982 to open the Vista International division of Hilton International, settling in Greenwich, CT until retirement when they moved permanently to Vero Beach, FL. The family will celebrate his life with a private gathering in the near future when his ashes will be spread. Tony will be deeply missed. 1/3

ADKINS--Winthrop R. Winthrop R. Adkins, Ph.D.,age 82, a quintessential "teacher of life" passed away on July 17, 2015 from complications following lung surgery. He was a Professor Emeritus of Psychology and Education at Columbia University, Teachers College where he taught masters and doctoral students in psychology, counseling and education. Dr. Adkins was born in Beirut, Syria (now Lebanon) on October 25, 1932 to Dr. Leslie John Adkins and Mrs. Edith Sanderson who were missionaries serving in Turkey and Syria. He was a graduate of Phillips Andover Academy and of Princeton University, Class of 1955. He received his doctorate in Counseling Psychology from Columbia University, Teachers College in 1963 where he worked on the groundbreaking Career Pattern Study. This was followed by a year at Harvard University at the Center for Personality. He was associated with the US Navy for over twelve years, first as a member of the NROTC at Princeton and then as a Naval Officer on the USS Salem, from 1955 to 1958, the flagship of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean. During that time he received training at the Naval Justice School. He became involved with the War on Poverty where he worked with the YMCA of Greater New York in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Project TRY, to develop a large training center for educationally and economically disadvantaged youth. In 1966 he became a founding faculty member of York College, City CUNY where he helped design the Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge (SEEK) program, directed at helping low income students achieve college success. His work at Teachers College and at the Institute for Life Coping Skills for over thirty years, reflected his passionate interest in developing new methods for helping people learn the complex attitudes and behaviors they needed to cope with the predictable life tasks of career, marriage, parenting, dealing with family dynamics, confronting loss and other psychological issues. His design of multi-media counseling systems to reach larger numbers of people was a major focus of his work. He trained thousands of graduate students on how to develop psychological, behaviorally based interventions, using his methods and theory, for a variety of populations and problems. Dr. Adkins numerous professional research and writing focused on these issues and he was in the process of writing a book which summarized his theoretical models and ways to apply them in all these areas. The Adkins Life Skills Career Development Program (ALSP) was his most successful and nationally known program. The ALSP was originally published by The Psychological Corporation, a division of Harcourt, Brace, and Jovanovich. The program helped people learn to make short-term and long-term job and career choices, become self-directing and learn to navigate occupational systems. Most importantly it helped people learn about and believe in themselves. The ALSP was used in over 2,000 agencies including prisons, homeless shelters, drug rehabilitation centers, welfare-to-work programs, economic opportunity centers and community colleges, in 45 states. The Institute trained over 5000 staff members as Life Skills Educators who delivered the program in their own agencies. Over 1 million people graduated from this program. The impact of the program was well documented in numerous academic research studies. There is Spanish and an Italian version of the program. A Life Coping Skills curriculum, based on Dr. Adkin's theory and methods, was instituted in over 200 community colleges in India to help students from small villages learn how to psychologically navigate larger urban life. Over the years, Dr. Adkins served on many non-profit boards of directors, including the YMCA of Greater New York, the HOPE Program for the homeless, the NYS Advisory Group on Adult Education, the Greenwich Adult and Continuing Program and the Center for Insurance Research. He was also a founding board member of Princeton Project '55 Center for Civic Leadership, inspired by Ralph Nader, a classmate, which helped Princeton undergraduates become involved with the work of non-profit and non-governmental organizations nationwide. In recent years, together with his wife Dr. Caroline Manuele Adkins, he continued to direct the Institute for Life Coping Skills, revising its 3rd and international editions. In semi- retirement, Win as he was affectionately known became an enthusiastic member of the Retired Men's Association of Greenwich, CT where he served on the Program Committee and was a Co-Director of the Melody Men, a singing group that entertained in nursing homes throughout the local area. He was predeceased by his parents and his sister Beverly Wells. He is survived by his loving wife Dr. Caroline Manuele Adkins, a Professor Emerita in Psychology and Counseling from Hunter College, City University of New York, his son Jason, and his wife Karen Kraut, his daughter Jennifer, and her husband David Ernst and five grandchildren, Benjamin, Julia, Daniel, Oakes and Locke. He is also survived by his sister Sally Wilbur and his brother Dr. Douglas Adkins and his wife Dr. Rapee Adkins, his former wife Susan Fisher and many nieces and nephews. Winthrop Adkins was an inspired and passionate teacher. He was concerned always with social and economic justice and with making a real difference in the world. He spent countless hours personally counseling people who were going through crises and transitions in living. He was a "force of life" who dignified everyone he met and made them feel special, no matter who they were. He was a loving husband, father, brother and uncle to all his family. He was always so much fun to be with. Our hearts are heavy and sad and we will miss him forever. There will be a Memorial Service at 11am on August 1st at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Rd, and Greenwich, CT 06831. 1/3

DUKESS--A. Carleton. For our entire lives, Carleton was a beloved member of our extended family. He will live in our hearts forever. Sending our deepest love and sympathy to Mona and the entire Dukess family. The Zankel Brothers 1

MERCADO--Luis G.,died at his home on July 20, 2015, age 80 years. A loving father of Deborah, grandfather of Ashley and Stephan and super great-granddad for Dionte. He was deeply grateful to his sister Sequi for her devoted care of their mother during her later years. He had the greatest respect and admiration for his cherished daughter Deborah who with love, courage and determination brought two wonderful children to adulthood. Gil was my special friend and companion for over 46 years; as kind and generous a partner one could hope for. Dearest Gil, we spent the young and long years well. Thanks for everything you have meant to me. Donald Fredrickson 1/3

LAPIDUS--Dorothy Frances (Farris), 92. Born in Wilkes- Barre, PA. Long time resident of Brooklyn Heights and proud City College graduate, died in her home on July 20. A teacher, author, and dear friend and neighbor. At her direction, there will be no service. 1/3

KOLLISCH--Peter, 87, died July 16, 2015. Born in Austria, escaped WWII - Holocaust on the Kindertransport. Devoted family man, dedicated school social worker, and friendly Upper West Side neighbor; remembered for lively story- telling, generosity, and good humor. Peter is survived by wife Annie, children David and Lisa, four grandchildren and beloved sister Eva. A memorial service will be held in fall 2015 in New York City. 1/3

FAISON--Marilyn Mazza, Portland, Maine - Marilyn Mazza Faison, of Peaks Island, Maine and New York City died on July 22, 2015. She is survived by her husband John Faison, sister Joann Weston, brother John Mazza, sister-in-law Susan Faison, and several nieces and nephews. There will be a private, family gathering to commemorate her life. To see her full obituary, please go to www.athutchins.com. 1/3

HARRIS--Ellen. Passed away on July 7 after a long battle with pancreatic cancer. A magnetic, compelling woman, Ellen attracted a broad and deep range of smart and wise people throughout her life. She brought people together. Her extraordinary immediate and extended family, remarkably strong circles of friends from different walks of life, political associates from her work for Senator Jacob Javits in Washington D.C. in the '70s, and legal colleagues in New Jersey and New York energized her life. To all of them she was an anchor, ally, advisor, and unwavering friend. Practicing lawyer for 37 years, Ellen was a Counsel of Securities Law at Sidley Austin LLP in Manhattan, where she specialized in funds and investments. With a 1969 B.A. from University of Rochester, 1970 M.A. in history from Stanford University, and a 1977 J.D. from New York University School of Law, she recognized the importance of education and served on the Board of Trustees at The Pingry School in Martinsville, NJ, where her two loving sons, Michael and David, graduated. An exemplary mother, she showed unwavering devotion to them and pride in their accomplishments. In addition to her loving family, she became an honorary mother and aunt to innumerable others, with kindness, class, and intelligent guidance. Ellen's parents, Mimi West (driving force behind the Los Angeles Free Clinic for three decades, and founder of Friends of the Los Angeles Free Clinic) and Bernie West (Emmy-winning writer of All in the Family, and producer of Three's Company) instilled in Ellen and in her sister, Isabel, both a love of culture and fine arts and the importance of giving back to society. She was a patron of The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey and on the Board of the Rioult Dance New York, and she hosted fundraising events to champion the causes and cultural celebrations in which she believed. Donations in her name can be made to some of her favorite arts charities Rioult Dance, New York City Ballet, or the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey. She will be deeply missed. 1/3

BUNZEL--Peter D. His family mourns the passing of journalist Peter D. Bunzel, aged 88, on July 20, 2015 in Los Angeles, CA. Peter began his professional career at the (Martha's) Vineyard Gazette, and was later a staff writer at the New Yorker, Entertainment Editor at Life Magazine, Co-Founder, Editor and Publisher of Seattle Magazine (1963 to 1970), Editor of West Magazine and of the Opinion section of the Los Angeles Times (1971 to 1978), and a television critic at the Los Angeles Herald-Examiner where in 1986 he won a major victory for free speech in the California Supreme Court, 42 Cal. 3d 254. Born in 1927 in New York, NY to Harriet Harvey and Ernest Everett Bunzel, Peter attended Allen-Stevenson, the Kent School and Princeton University where he was Editor and Chairman of the Daily Princetonian. In 1952, he married Jane Cole (deceased) and had four children: Cole Bunzel (deceased), Robert H. Bunzel of Oakland, CA, Jeffrey H. Bunzel of New York, NY and John D. Bunzel of Los Angeles, CA. In 1982, Peter married Suzanne Belcher Platt in Los Angeles, CA. Peter was devoted to books, movies, theatre, martinis, politics, freighter trips and family. He is survived by his wife Suzanne, his brother John H. Bunzel of Belmont, CA, his three sons, eight grandchildren and two great-grandsons. A celebration of his life for family and friends will be held in September in Los Angeles. 1/3

DAVIS--Ruth Kalaidjian, of New York City, passed away peacefully at her home on Thursday, July 16, 2015. She was born on September 7, 1913. Beloved mother of Sarah and John Davis and grandmother of Nicholas and Elisabeth, she was the daughter of Mihran Tatios Kalaidjian and Aimee Gillies Kalaidjian. She is preceded in death by her brothers Robert and William, and survived by her brother Edward and sister Marjorie Gottwik, as well as, numerous beloved nieces and nephews. She was an alumna of Barnard College (1934), and subsequently earned an M.S. in Social Work from Columbia University (1943) and a PhD from New York University (1971), focusing her research on college choices among highly gifted girls. Her active career in teaching and counseling, was motivated by a lifelong commitment to education. She specialized in teaching the understanding of the development of children from infancy through adolescence. In addition to the private practice of psychotherapy, she was also the director of guidance programs at The Madeira School and Hunter High School. She taught at Sarah Lawrence College and Hunter College, from which she retired as a full, tenured professor. Age did not diminish her sharp mind. She was reading and discussing world events until the day she died. In the tradition of honoring her milestone birthdays, her 102nd birthday will be celebrated with a gathering by all who loved her. 1/3

DOCTOROW--E.L. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. A masterful story teller, wonderfully imaginative, he ranged over one hundred fifty years of American history making it come alive in his novels and short stories to the delight of his devoted readers. 1

KOSSOFF--Irwin Ira, passed peacefully on July 23 at age 93. He is survived by his wife Edith and his sister Laine Rudd; his children Alan Kossoff, Evan Don Kossoff, Tom Kossoff, Mitzi Gilbert, Hank Steinberg and Steve Steinberg, and his 11 grandchildren. Ira was a recipient of a Purple Heart medal from WWII and was a paper box manufacturer. The funeral will be Monday, July 27 at 11:15am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St. in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, his family asks that donations be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Association. 1/3

RIPPE--William C.,The Lung Cancer Research Foundation (LCRF) mourns the loss of Board member William "Bill" C. Rippe. Bill passed away on July 21st after a long and courageous battle with lung cancer. A committed member of the LCRF Board of Directors, Bill believed firmly in the mission of the Foundation-to improve and save lives by funding groundbreaking research for the prevention, diagnosis, treatment and cure of lung cancer. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife Laure Sudreau - Rippe, parents Marianne and Dick, children Brad, Amy and Chloe and his step-children Lucas and Juliette. We have lost a dear friend and valued colleague. Pippa Gerard Chairman, LCRF Board of Directors Nancy Sanford Executive Director, LCRF 1/3

PORCELLI--Adele Marie (Piazza), born April 12, 1921 in Brooklyn, New York, where she lived all of her 94 years until she passed away. Wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, she was a feminist before the word was invented. Avid reader, cleaner, watcher of Jeopardy and kibitzer in Cobble Hill park, she died as she had lived, independent and opinionated. May she rest in peace. Wake Sunday, July 26, 2-7pm, Cobble Hill Funeral Home, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, New York. 1/3

STARK--Leslie, J.,a beloved Renaissance Man died July 17, 2015 at the age of 76 at his home on Martha's Vineyard. The cause of death was Myelodysplasia. He was a graduate of Poly Prep and Hobart & William Smith Colleges where he served on the board for many years. Upon graduation from college he attended the Yale School of Drama. He acted in New York in theatre and on T.V. He was the International Marketing Director of a subsidiary of Revlon and was based in Brussels and Hong Kong. After meeting his wife of 49 years Myra, a PHD in English Literature he entered the world of advertising, working at Benton and Bowles which became DMB& B. He became a successful producer of TV commercials and inspired all who worked with him. He had boundless energy and curiosity and fully embraced everything he did. But he will be remembered most for his numerous quiet acts of kindness. When he retired to Martha's Vineyard he continued to pursue his many passions including jazz, which he taught. He produced, directed and starred in countless plays at the Vineyard Playhouse and Island Theatre Workshop; was a member of the Peter Luce Play Readers Group. He enjoyed ballroom dancing, was a superb cook; learned and performed the ukelele after being told his fingers were not dexterous enough for the cello. He was a member of The Chamber Music Society. He was on the board and a major supporter of the Cancer Society Support Group and devoted to the Vineyard House. He worked on the Martha's Vineyard Gazette the oldest newspaper on the island. He is survived by his adored wife Myra, daughter Victoria Stark, son Brian Stark and his wife Julie Ramos M.D., granddaughter Eliana, sisters, Renee Stark, Cheryl Stark, sisters-in-law, Margery Meltzer, and Ruth Waldbaum, M.D., brother-in- law, Robert Waldbaum M.D., nieces Karen Andrade, Jennifer Marcus, Nicole Moser, Alexandra Kinnie and Hillary Waldbaum. We all adored Leslie and will miss him dearly. Donations can be made to the Martha's Vineyard Cancer Support Group, PO Box 2214, Martha's Vineyard, MA 02568. 1/3

STERNKLAR--Jack, February 5, 1922- July 5, 2015. Born to Sabina and Zacharia Sternklar in Vienna, Austria, Jack arrived in New York alone on July 4, 1938 at the age of 16, his education cut short by the Nazis. Jack served in the U.S. Army in World War II. Before embarking on a successful career as an owner of real estate, Jack opened the first Sabbath-observant grocery store in Boro Park, Brooklyn with his father, who survived Dachau and Buchenwald. A beloved Father, Grandfather, Great- Grandfather, Brother and Uncle, Jack is survived by his wife of 64 years, Lila; daughter Cindy Sternklar Worenklein, son-in-law Jacob Worenklein; daughter Sarah Sternklar, son-in-law Marvin Davis; and son Mark Sternklar, daughter in law, Nora Tammam; his grandchildren Sabrina, Ari, Etan, Sasha, Benjamin, Sabina, Shira, Rena and Yigal; and his great grandchildren Charlotte, Oliver, Ayla, Lev, Noah, Eli, Be'eri, Raanan, Uriya, Dvash, Naaveh, Tiferet, Adi, and Tehila; his sister, Rosa (Ronnie) Gorden; and his nieces and nephews Caryn and Larry Malitzky and Zachary and Elana Gorden. He loved Jewish history, current events, his work, and most of all, his family. He was a generous supporter of education, Jewish causes and Israel. He was a voracious reader and self educated to a high standard of intellectual achievement. He was known for his integrity, his powerful mind, and his remarkable wit until the day he died. He was the most generous, humble, kind and gentle of all men. He will be missed by all who ever met him. 1/3

KAPPEL--Barbara, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of NYC; beloved wife of the late Joseph and dear mother of Maxine and James Portnof and Dr. Bruce and Elyse Kappel; sister of the late Robert Worth and cherished grandmother of Rachel and Harry Portnof and Joshua and Brandon Kappel. Funeral Services held privately at the convenience of the family. 1/3

SISCHY--Ingrid. The board and staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem deeply mourn the passing of Ingrid Sischy. Ingrid was a fierce and committed champion of art and culture. Her sharp intellect, voracious curiosity, and unbridled passion will be profoundly missed. We send our sincerest condolences to Sandra Brandt and Ingrid's entire family and many friends. Raymond J. McGuire, Chairman, Thelma Golden, Director, The Studio Museum in Harlem 1/3
ZINAMAN--Dick. Happy Birthday! We miss your great smile and contagious laugh. 1/3

ROSE--Alan, aged 67, died at home in New York City on July 7 from lung cancer. He was born on April 27, 1948 in Regensberg, Germany to Herbert and Marjorie (Murrell) Rose. Alan's early years were spent living in Germany, Japan, Colorado and Mississippi. The family moved to Baltimore in Alan's teenage years and he became an ardent fan of both the city and its people. After three years at the Maryland Institute of Art Mr. Rose worked as an independent graphic designer for Harry, an underground newspaper and on John Waters' films. For a brief period he lived in San Francisco collaborating on artwork for albums put out by various bands including The Quicksilver Messenger Service. Moving to New York in the early 70's he joined the National Lampoon. Alan Rose earned acclaim with his 1980's World At Your Feet Books, a series of such landmarks as the Empire State Building. He married Anne (Spaulding) Rose in 1981 and moved to Springfield, Massachusetts. During the summers he transformed a simple Adirondack cabin into a magical mountaintop masterpiece, complete with birch bark wallpaper and a tree in the living room. No typical father figure he coached his stepdaughters on junk store shopping, culinary risk-taking as well as dirt bike riding on Cuttyhunk Island. Alan's unconventional, selfgoverning and thrifty nature generated countless adventures for himself and those around him. His ideas were as innovative as his humor was keen. He is survived by his wife, Anne, his brother Michael B. Rose (Jenny) of Plymouth, Massachusetts, his stepdaughters Hilary Diebold of West Springfield, Massachusetts, Anne Diebold (Dan Szenda) of Southwick, Massachusetts and two step-grandchildren. In addition he leaves an aunt, five cousins, three step-nieces, one step- nephew and one great step- nephew. There will be a private service at the Adirondack lake he loved and a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Alan Rose's name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) and sent to the Office of Development, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Lauren Kelly, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

STERN--Vera. On behalf of the Board of Directors of the Musicians Foundation we express our condolences and deepest sympathies to her extensive family. She served on the Board for over forty years with devotion and a deep sense of caring for the musicians who are our clients. She will be sorely missed. Hans E. Tausig, President 1/3
TURNER--Barry. The Marks family extend our condolences on the passing of our dear friend Barry. 1/3

GRAY--Walter Evans, 66, passed away July, 20, 2015 at Hogar Isla Verde Nursing Home, San Juan, Puerto Rico. Mr. Gray is the son of Frank Biddle Gray of Montevideo, Uruguay, and Blanche Fleming Gray of Memphis, Tennessee, both deceased. Mr. Gray attended Woodberry Forest in Virginia and was graduated from Vassar Collage. Mr. Gray began his career at Young @ Rubicam, New York, and became Media Director at Y@R, San Juan, Puerto Rico. Mr Gray was founder and President of ADSERVE L.A. Inc, a media research firm in San Juan. Mr Gray is survived by this brother, Frank Biddle Gray, Jr., of Charlottesville, VA. 1/3

DUKESS--A. Carleton, 85, died at home in Larchmont, New York, on July 20, 2015 with his adored wife of 60 years, Mona Dukess, and his beloved daughters, Linda, Laura and Karen Dukess, at his side. The most loveable of men, he was treasured by his six grandchildren: Joanna and Sam Bernstein, Ben and Stephen Schwed, and Joseph and Johnny Liesman, and was a cherished father-in-law to Jody DiPerna, Roger Schwed and Steve Liesman. He loved his nieces and nephews, rejoiced in his friendships with people young and old, and was known as a great raconteur and a wise listener. Carleton was pre-deceased by his older brother, Joseph Dukess. A graduate of Syracuse University and Columbia University School of Law, Carleton had a distinguished career as a real estate attorney and developer. He drafted the documentation for the nation's first condominium development and lectured extensively on the then-novel form of ownership. His interest in the restoration of urban buildings for low and moderate income housing led to his co-founding of Continental Wingate Company, Inc., a housing and rehabilitation company. He was a president of the National Housing and Rehabilitation Association and served on the Citizens Housing & Planning Council of New York. He later was a partner in Castle Properties Co. and a director of Apple Bank for Savings in New York. Appreciative of his good fortune, Carleton devoted significant time and attention to charitable endeavors. He was a trustee of Barnard College, and a member of the boards of the New York Foundation, Community Resource Exchange, Castle Hill Center for the Arts and the Provincetown Art Association and Museum. Carleton loved Italian opera, the music of Benny Goodman, fishing, boating, single-malt Scotch and reading, but loved nothing more than spending time with his friends and family, especially in his favorite place, his home in Truro, Massachusetts. A memorial service was held at 11am on Friday, July 24 at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Cancer Support Team of Purchase, New York, or the Provincetown Art Association and Museum. 1

LICHTENSTEIN--Dorothy. 96, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died July 23, 2015 in Carlsbad, CA, of complications of Alzheimer's disease. She was born in Manhattan on June 27, 1919, to Zachara and Molly Ehrlich Ger. For 60 years the beloved wife of Milton Julian Lichtenstein until his death in 2005. Loving mother of Todd (Mimi Bowling) and Gregg (Janel Jacob) and adoring grandmother of Brian (Allegra Conway) and David, all of whom survive her. PS 11, Julia Richman High School, NYU (BA and MA). Teacher, traveler, foodie, dancer, reluctant sailor, indefatigable shopper, consummate hostess, devotee of all the arts, and above all a steadfast friend to so many. Graveside services Sunday, July 26, 11:00 a.m. at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, with a gathering to follow at the home of Todd and Mimi. For information, contact Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, (212) 769-4400. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to a liberal or humanitarian cause or an arts organization. 1/3

SULLIVAN--James T.,86, passed away on July 17, 2015 in Boca Raton FL. James worked with the New York City Police Department from 1953 to 1984, being promoted to the rank of Chief of Detectives in 1978; and was Chief of Police of the Waterfront Commision of New York Harbor from 1986 to 1992. He served his country in the US Army during the Korean Conflict and he belonged to the Local 10-13 Club of Broward County. He is survived by his beloved wife of 22 years Angela Sullivan, and his children Kathleen, Eileen, Timothy, James Jr, Maureen and Thomas. He is also survived by six grandchildren and his sister Mary Alice Meyer. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in James memory to the Michael J Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research www.michaeljfox.org Funeral services are private and entrusted to Babione- Kraeer Funeral Home and Cremation Center, Boca Raton FL. 1/3

SILVERSTEIN--Maurice, died on Tuesday at the age of 84 after a prolonged illness which he battled with dignity, grace, and humor. He was a graduate of Tilden High and City College. After proudly serving as a Lieutenant in the Navy, he graduated Columbia Law on the GI bill in '58, a Stone Scholar. Thus, a provincial Brooklyn boy become an international licensing lawyer for the pharmaceutical industry. He is survived by his beloved wife Lenore, his daughters Leila Thomas and Laura Colban, and his grandchildren, Caleb, Danie, and Owen Thomas and Andreas, Kaia, and Amelia Colban. Please send donations to Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. 1/3

SKOPIN--Caroline. November 14, 1927 - July 23, 2015 of Manhattan, NY. Caroline Skopin was one of the reasons this world was a better place to live. She was as beautiful on the inside as was her natural beauty on the outside. Honored in her lifetime by associations including In Touch Networks and The Jewish Guild For The Blind, she, as did her husband Murray Skopin (deceased), gave of herself asking nothing in return but the satisfaction that she was able to be there to enhance the lives of others. Caroline loved words and books (especially mysteries). Her daily reading of The New York Times was essential to her lifestyle. Caroline is survived by her sister Ellen Schefler, brother Arthur Schefler, nephews Raymond and Jeffery Skopin and too many dear friends to list (including Barbara Danziger, Jim Schnars, Gloria Briggs, Steve and Jean Zorn and Shirly Thaler). 1/3

VARGA--Vera (nee Szekeres), died at 87 after a brief illness. She was born in Gyor, Hungary, and lived in Chicago. She was a Holocaust survivor, adored wife, mother and grandmother. Graduating Summa cum Laude from medical school, she became a pediatrician. Escaping from Hungary in 1968, she settled first in Nyack, NY and later in Princeton, NJ. Her kindness, wisdom and joie de vivre touched all who knew her. She is survived by Ervin, her husband of 67 years; sons Peter and John; daughters-in- law Linda Piccinini and Julie Varga, and grandchildren Adrian, Danielle, Peter and Andrew. 1/3

BERKOWITZ--Lori (Lax), 87, of New York, NY and Loon Lake, NY. Beloved wife of Peter Lax, (and the late Jerome Berkowitz), passed away July 19, 2015. Lori lived and breathed music as principal violist for the American Symphony Orchestra and teacher at Manhattan School of Music, Children's Orchestra Society, and Princeton Chamber Week. She co-founded Loon Lake Live! and was an active viola coach and chamber musician. An avid hiker, berry picker and stargazer, Lori savored the outdoors. She was an original and a welcoming, gentle soul, who loved her family. Survivors include Peter Lax, children David Berkowitz (Susan) and Susan Berkowitz (Robin), and grandchildren Jeffrey and Dana. Contributions may be made to: Children's Orchestra Society, Inc. or Loon Lake Live! 1/3

GONZALEZ--Nicholas James, MD, died unexpectedly at his home on July 21, 2015. He was 67. He was born on December 28, 1947 in Flushing, NY, and was the son of Marie and William Gonzalez. He graduated from Brown University and Cornell Medical College. Dr. Gonzalez was a pioneer in cancer treatment offering intensive nutritional therapy treatment in the treatment of advanced cancer and other incurable diseases, as well as for prevention. Dr. Gonzalez has been the recipient of numerous nationally and internationally recognized medical awards. Survivors include his cherished wife, Mary Beth Gonzalez (nee Pryor); his beloved mother and siblings, Marie Franzese Gonzalez, Dana (John) Segretto and William Gonzalez and a host of heartbroken nieces, nephews, in-laws and friends. The Funeral Service will be held at 2pm on Tuesday, July 28, 2015 at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, 382 Cantitoe Street, Bedford, NY. Interment will follow at St. Matthew's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be kindly directed to Nick's foundation, Nutritional Research and Educational Foundation http://www.nutritional research.info/ 1/3

HORVITZ--Lois Unger, wife of the late Harry R. Mother of Michael (Jane) Horvitz, Pam (Tony) Schneider and Peter (Margaret O'Meara) Horvitz. Grandmother and great-grandmother. Services held in Cleveland, OH. 1/3
KANE--Tina. December 21, 1942. Died on July 25, 2015. Conservator in Textile Conservation at Metropolitan Museum of Art, she was beloved by many in the U.S. and Australia. 1/3

MITTLER--Gerald A. Jerry passed away on July 18, 2015. Beloved husband to Roberta. Loving dad to Kara Segal, Cheryl Eldredge and Mitchel Mittler. Loving father-in-law to Bart, Matt and Susan. Adoring grandfather to Jeremy, Ilana, Tori, Zoe, Olivia, Adi and Benjamin. Loving brother to Rochelle Sicklick. His warmth, compassion and humor touched us all. He will be missed. Donations can be made to the following: Long Island State Vets Home at Stonybrook, Wounded Warriors, Smithtown Hadassah, Breast Cancer Foundation, Colon/ Rectal Cancer Foundation. 1/3

ENTENMAN--Robert J.,Jr. 57, Global Head eCommerce, Uni-Credit died May 28th, 2015 in London of complications from surgery. Survived by wife Athina, children Chloe and Alexander and extended family and is sadly missed. 1/3

SISCHY--Ingrid. The Board of Trustees and staff of Dia Art Foundation mourn the loss of Ingrid Sischy and extend our deepest condolences to our longtime friend and Trustee, Sandra Brant and her family. Ingrid's contributions to the world of art and fashion are immense. We will greatly miss her enthusiasm, counsel, and generosity. 1/3
APPLEMAN--Mark J. Still miss you after all these years. Marguerite please contact me I'm in Washington, DC. Larry Ravitz 1/3

SMALL--Robert D.,MD. The Board of Directors, management, physicians, and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn the sudden passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague, Robert D. Small, MD. A well-known and beloved orthopedic surgeon in Westchester for the past three decades, Dr. Small joined the staff of White Plains Hospital in 1983, after completing his residency at the Hospital for Joint Diseases and fellowship at the Hospital for Special Surgery. He became part of the White Plains Hospital Physician Associates Orthopedic Specialists Group in 2011. Earlier this year, Dr. Small was elected President of the Medical and Dental Staff at White Plains Hospital. He was Chief Emeritus of orthopedic surgery as well as the Director of the Westchester Orthopedics Institute at the Hospital and a founder of Bone and Joint Associates. Bob's kind heart, boundless energy and generous spirit will be greatly missed, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. 1/3

STERN--Vera. All of us at Opus 3 Artists join musicians everywhere in mourning the death of Vera Stern. She was a source of strength to the international musical community, and an important inspiration to us in our days as ICM Artists. BENARDO--Joseph, 95, on July 23. Son of Sam and Allegra, husband of predeceased Lillian, father of Steven (Leslie) and Sheldon (Carole), grandfather of Ian, brother of Leo (Helene) and predeceased Jack (Lina and Babe). After suffering extensive wounds on D-Day, June 6, 1944, Joe went on to a full and productive life of family, work and activities: handball, dancing, listening to the swing bands of the 30s and 40s were all part of a life that brought smiles to all who knew him. Joe worked for the Corps of Engineers for 35 years where he received numerous citations from the Department of Defense for superior service. The family is most grateful for the dedication, professionalism and sensitivity shown to Joe for the 65 years he received services from the staff of the Bronx VA. Joe's wit and wisdom will be missed. Funeral was private. 1/3

SISCHY--Ingrid. The board and staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem deeply mourn the passing of Ingrid Sischy. Ingrid was a fierce and committed champion of art and culture. Her sharp intellect, voracious curiosity, and unbridled passion will be profoundly missed. We send our sincerest condolences to Sandra Brandt and Ingrid's entire family and many friends. Raymond J. McGuire, Chairman, Thelma Golden, Director, The Studio Museum in Harlem 1/3

KRANZ--Frances Sanders, 94, died on July 23, 2015 in West Palm Beach, FL. Known by those who loved her dearly as Francy, she was born on June 1, 1921 in Brooklyn, NY to Max and Lucille. Francy married her devoted husband, Frederick Kranz, on April 29, 1942 and shared 70 wonderful years of marriage with him. They shared a home in New York City where they had two children and retired to Florida later in life. The couple went dancing every Saturday night together and those who knew them fondly remember them dancing through life. She was preceded in death by her loving husband, Frederick Kranz, in 2012. Francy is survived by her two daughters, Dr. Virginia Kranz Myerson (Dr. Mark Myerson) and Marjorie Brooke; grandchildren, Rachel, Lucas, Charlie and Olivia; and great grandchild, Macie. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Alzheimers Association. 1/3

WEINBERGER--Gerald J.,passed away on July 26, 2015 at the age of 72 years old. He is survived by his beloved wife of almost 50 years, Irene, devoted sons Greg with Diane and Jeff with Patti; adoring grandchildren Jack David, Alex Simon, Nick Damon, Brian Scott and Katie Elizabeth and loving sister Susan with Michael Stein. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association in his memory. 1/3

CECIL--Jane. The Board and staff of the Center for Educational Innovation extends its deepest sympathies to our dear Board member, Donald Cecil and family at the passing of his extraordinary wife, Jane. KAYE--Walter, 96, New York City, passed on July 26th surrounded by friends and family. Born in New York City and raised in the Bronx. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of over 60 years, Selma Berger Kaye and his parents, Jacob and Annie Kalmanowitz, his sisters Alice Kaye Peerce and Maye Oldin, and his brother Sidney Kaye. Survived by his children, Joan Kaye Cauthorn; Howard (Wilma) Kaye, Nancy (Sylvester) Karagis; grandchildren, Jennifer (Steve) Marsden, Jill (Randy) Kohl, Darren (Shara) Bialo, Caralyn Bialo, Jacquelyn Bialo, Ross (Beth) Kaye and Robin (Carl) Amorosino; and great-grandchildren, Ayla Marsden, Siena and Jeremy Kohl, Alex and Gabrielle Amorocino and Semantha and Gabriel Kaye. Walter started in the insurance business at the age 17. At 33, Walter Kaye Associates was formed. He was joined by Howard in 1967. The company grew into one of the premier brokerage firms in the private sector. When the business was eventually sold, it was a public company with over 500 employees in cities across the country. Walter was considered a legend in his industry. Well respected by all his peers. In 1995, Walter was appointed Civilian Aide to the Secretary of the Army for New York South and held that position as Emeritus until his death. During this time, Walter dedicated numerous hours assisting our military in charitable ways. Walter was also quite active in a number of philanthropic organizations. He will be missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Walter Kaye's honor to: Wounded Warrior Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, Kansas 66675. support.wounded warriorproject.org/default. aspx?tsid=676&campaign Source=ONLINE& source=BS15047P 1/3

AMRON--Howard C. Passed away peacefully at home on July 26, 2015 just short of his 90th birthday. Beloved husband of Joan, father of Arthur, Alison and Susan, father-in-law of Sara Pearl and Mary Ellen Manning, grandfather of Zachary and Adam. Born in Rockaway Beach in 1925 to Samuel and Rose, Howard lost his older brother Arthur in combat on Bataan, the Philippines, in the first months of World War II. Howard graduated from the New York State Maritime Academy at Ft. Schuyler toward the end of the War and then served in the Merchant Marines. He graduated from NYU Law School in 1950. Howard met his future wife Joan Goldberg on a ski trip in 1953 when they ended up spending most of the weekend together after Joan came down with food poisoning. Married the next year, they spent 61 wonderful years together. Howard enjoyed practicing real estate law in Manhattan for more than six decades. He was a founding member of "The Wednesday Ten", a long-time district leader of the New Democratic Club, and a board member and ardent supporter of both Urban Pathways and The Northside Center for Child Development. Among his many ventures, Howard was an owner of the Chelsea Place restaurant, one of the first businesses in the now- booming Chelsea area, as well as an investor in a silver mine in Colorado. A passionate sailor, he captained his family's numerous sailing trips in the Caribbean. He was also an adventurous traveler and a collector of fine French wines. His easy-going manner and sense of humor will be missed. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell--The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. on Tuesday, July 28, at 11:30am. Donations in his honor may be made to Urban Pathways or the Northside Center for Child Development. 1/3

ALBERT--Jack N. The Directors of the Bennie and Martha Benjamin Foundation note with profound sadness the death of our esteemed President, Jack N. Albert, on July 25, 2015 in Boca Raton, Florida. The Foundation was formed under his guidance as the executor of the estate of Bennie Benjamin, the songwriter he represented for many years. Jack also represented other songwriters such as George David Weiss and MAD Magazine founder William Gaines. Through his dedication and commitment to Bennie's vision, the Benjamin Foundation was created in 1991 to promote improved health care in the U.S. Virgin Islands, fulfilling Bennie's dream. As a result of this vision, many doctors and other health professionals have been given scholarships and hospitals have received grants for needed equipment. Our sincere condolences are extended to Jack's widow, Evelyn, and his daughters Susan and Wendy. David A. Beale, Executive Director, Seymour Braun, Treasurer 1/3
GLASS--Jean Ann, 77, devoted and beloved wife. A woman for all seasons. I will love you forever. Lester 1/3

Love and miss you more than words can ever describe. Mark, Susan, Maura and Andrew Zankel 1/3

ZANKEL--Arthur. Best friend, confidante, supporter, guide, advisor, Dad, Father-in-law. Loving, giving, funny, brilliant, strong, sweet, a wonderful man. Dearly missed but felt every day. Kenny and Anna 1/3

CROHN--Frank T. Died at home on July 26, 2015 at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Helene, devoted father of Frank Crohn, Jr., Carole Davis, Alex Crohn, Adrienne Crohn, Laurie Jannelli and David Crohn. He is also survived by ten grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. In addition to the pride and pleasure he took in his family, he spent decades in the business world. Frank founded and built two insurance companies, served on the boards of several financial institutions and insurance companies as well as philanthropic organizations. He affected the lives of everyone who knew him and will be missed and remembered with affection and admiration. Funeral to be held at Temple Emanuel of Kingston, NY on July 29, 2015 at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to waynebartonstudycenter.org or to templeemanuelkingston.org. 1/3

BRODERICK--Edward F.,Jr. Edward F. Broderick, Jr., 81, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, July 22, 2015. He was a life long resident of Morristown and graduated from Delbarton School in 1950. He continued his education at the University of Notre Dame, where he graduated from the undergraduate college in 1954 and from the law school in 1956. Mr. Broderick had a long and distinguished legal career that began by joining his father in private practice in 1959. He was a senior managing partner of Broderick, Newmark and Grather P.C. for over five decades, providing legal counsel in the areas of commercial and corporate law, employment law and civil rights litigation. He was a Certified Civil Trial Attorney, and tried hundreds of civil and criminal cases before juries and as bench trials, with consistently successful outcomes. He had recently joined the national firm of Wilson Elser, LLP where he continued his legal career Of Counsel. It was his love of the law and his passion for justice that kept him actively working until days before his passing. Before entering the private practice of law, he served for three years in the U.S. Air Force. In 1985, he received the Air Force's Commendation Medal, followed by the Meritorious Service Medal in 1987. He continued to serve in the Air Force Reserve, retiring as a full Colonel in 1987. He is survived by his cherished wife, Faith (Gallo), to whom he was married for 58 years; his daughters Karen Broderick Tourville (David), Cynthia Broderick Beck (Michael), his sons Edward F. Broderick III (Lenore) and Mark P. Broderick (Kimberly), his nine grandchildren, Justin Frye (Valerie), Edward F. Broderick IV, Alison Tourville, Brian Broderick, Elyse Broderick, Grace Tourville, Matthew Broderick, Michael Beck, and Timothy Broderick, his two great-grandchildren Stella Frye and Filomena Frye. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, July 29 between 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue in Morristown. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Mary's Abbey, Delbarton School in the Abbey Church in Morristown at 10:00 am on Thursday, July 30. Private interment will follow at Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Foundation for Morristown Medical Center, 475 South Street, Morristown, New Jersey, 07960. 1/3

MALONIS--Edward J.,85, died Sunday, July 26th, 2015 at home surrounded by his family. Ed was born in Lynn, Massachusetts to Adam and Malania Malonis. He graduated from Lynn Classical High School and went on to Dartmouth College, graduating in 1952. Immediately after college, he got his MA at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. Ed then entered the Navy. He was a Lieutenant and served in the Navy for three years as a Legal/Operations officer in Japan and the Mediterranean. After the Navy, he joined the US Foreign Service in Washington. He married Mary Huggins Malonis in 1960 and they moved to Milan, Italy where he worked in the Bureau of Economic Affairs. In 1963, they returned to the US where Ed worked for Esso in government affairs. After Esso he was Managing Editor at Petroleum Intelligence Weekly. In 1970 Ed moved to CONOCO where he was Director of International Government Affairs working mostly in the Middle East. Ed retired from CONOCO after 19 years based in New York, Connecticut, Delaware and Houston. The Malonis' returned to the New York area in 1987 where Ed worked at Agip Petroleum as Director of Government and Industry Affairs until his retirement in 1999. Upon retirement, Ed and Mary moved to Cape Cod where he died after a short illness. Ed is survived by his loving wife of 55 years Mary Huggins Malonis, his daughter Tracy Malonis Stephen and his grandchildren Jack, Charlie, Molly, Kate and Bridget whom he adored. He was predeceased by his son, Dr. John A. Malonis, M.D. In accordance with Ed's wishes there will be no calling hours or funeral. A celebration of Ed's life will be arranged at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Dr. John Malonis scholarship fund at Harrison High School, 255 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY 10528. Attn: District Treasurer. 914-630-3012. 1/3

GOODMAN--Barbara S. Devoted wife and mother, died July 24, 2015, 87 years old, resident of Rye, NY and Mill River, MA. A graduate of Oberlin College class of 1949. Survived by Peter Goodman, husband of 63 years, son Mark, son Geoffrey and daughter Elizabeth and five grand children. Barbara was an artist by profession whose paintings hang in many corporate headquarters and private residences. Her landscapes are deeply expressive, influenced by the natural beauty of The Berkshires and Monhegan Island. She was a member of the Pindar Gallery in New York City, and in 2005, was presented with an Honorary Lifetime Membership with the Silvermine Guild of Artists. Barbara had a passion for competitive bridge and classical music, attending concerts throughout her life. Barbara was an inspiration to her family and will be sorely missed. 1/3

CECIL--Jane. Purchase College and the Purchase College Foundation Board of Trustees extend their heartfelt sympathy to Trustee Donald Cecil and the family of Jane Cecil. Jane Cecil, a recipient of the college's Nelson A. Rockefeller Award, is remembered for her dedication to education and the arts. Her support and presence at college lectures, performances, and events will be deeply missed. The legacy of the many students she supported and encouraged continues. Thomas J. Schwarz, President Lucille Werlinich, Chair 1/3

SEIDLER--Ann Ganong, died peacefully at her home in Northampton on July 24th, surrounded by her family. Born in Northampton on September 8th, 1925, she graduated from Smith College as a Theatre Major in 1946 and taught theater in Honolulu. Professionally, Dr. Seidler (Ph.D., New York University), was a speech therapist and author of many children's books as well a Professor of Speech and Theatre at Montclair State University in New Jersey. She was a member of the Author's Guild, the Metropolitan Opera Club, and was active in the Institute for Retired Professionals at the New School. She resided in Manhattan. Ann is survived by her four children, Dr. Jan Seidler Ramirez, Karen Seidler Gross (Robert), Bayard Seidler, and Dr. Christopher Seidler (Cheryl Hersperger), nine grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. She was predeceased by her husband William Dickson Seidler. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Montclair State University Foundation, Speech /Theatre Scholarship, 1 Normal Avenue, Montclair, NJ 07043, or the Botanic Gardens of Smith College, 16 College Lane, Northampton, MA 01063. 1/3

COOPER--David, 91, died peacefully at home in Pittsburgh on July 25, 2015. David was a loving husband, father, grandfather, father-in-law and uncle, as well as a teacher, historian, author, Democrat, questioner of authority and the status quo, world traveler, supporter of the underdog (both people and baseball teams), and devoted reader of the print edition of The New York Times. He will be missed by his wife and consummate life-partner of 67 years, Joan; his sons, Daniel and Matthew; his grandson, Sam; his daughter-in-law, Melissa, and granddaughter-in-law, Julie; all of whom will strive each day to keep his memory alive in the way they lead their lives. David also leaves behind the scores of students he inspired, his many nephews and nieces who regarded him as a parent, and a wide array of friends who relished his sense of humor, intellect and humanity. He can be remembered by contributions to Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

WERNER--Vera Stein, 92, died peacefully at home Friday, July 24th. Predeceased by her loving husband Jack, Vera is survived by her children Ken (Noreen), Karen (Ken), Andrea (Brad), and grandchildren. Funeral services at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY, Thursday, July 30th, 11am. Family and friends invited to gather at the family home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Nazi Victim Services Program of Self Help Community Services, Inc., 520 8th Ave, NY, NY 10018. 1/3

AMRON--Howard. The board of Goddard Riverside Community Center mourns the passing of Howard Amron, husband of board member Joan Amron. A leader in the field of real estate law, he was also a dedicated philanthropist who helped make New York City a better place for all. We extend our condolences to his family. Betsy Newell, President, Board of Directors and Stephan Russo, Executive Director, Goddard Riverside Community Center 1/3

DANFORTH--Theodore, Passed away July 26, 2015 of a heart attack in Southampton, NY. He is survived by his loving wife of 40 years Laura, and his five children Theodore Danforth Jr., Alexandra Danforth, Bryan Danforth, Laura Danforth, and Florence Danforth-Meyer; and two grandchildren Isabelle and Nicholas. He was born in Boston, Massachusetts to William H. Danforth and Hilma L. Nelson. He graduated from The Hill School, Amherst College, and attended Harvard Business School. He served on the boards of the J. Craig Venter Institute, North Shore LIJ-- North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, NY; Jupiter Island Medical Center in Jupiter, FL; and the Library Museum of the U.S. Golf Association. He served as trustee of the Village of Matinecock from 1970-1995. He was a member of St. Andrews Royal and Ancient, Augusta National Golf Club, Piping Rock Club, Jupiter Island Club, Medalist Golf Club, The Meadow Club, Racquet Club of New York, Seminole Golf Club, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Somerset Club, The Southampton Bathing Corporation, The Southampton Club. The service will be held at the St. Andrew's Dune Church on Gin Lane in Southampton, NY at 4pm on Friday, August 7th. Please honor his memory with an act of kindness. 1/3
THOMPSON--Selina. July 28, 2013. Missing and thinking of you every day. Stephen and Casey 1/3

CECIL--Jane Grossman, Died July 25 following a short illness. Loving wife and devoted partner to Donald Cecil, her surviving husband of 62 years. Beloved mother of Leslie (Creighton Michael) and Alec (Diane Zultowsky), and grandmother to Balin, Jake, Eli and Loren. She was the only child of Alexander Grossman and Helen Tuck Grossman. Jane attended Scarsdale High School and was a graduate and active alumna of Smith College. Known for her intelligence, elegance and being the consummate hostess, she enjoyed a full life and traveled the world with her husband and family. A lifelong resident of Westchester County, she devoted herself to supporting many local organizations and programs, particularly those focusing on education for children from families with limited means and opportunity. She was a leader in philanthropy and served on boards for a number of non- profits, including Student Advocacy, the White Plains YWCA and Todays Students, Tomorrows Teachers. She and Donald shepherded an I Have a Dream program in Mt. Vernon in the 1980s and established the Jandon Scholars Program in 1999, which has, to date, assisted over 200 students from the county in attending college. They have also been active supporters of Purchase College, including establishing the Writing through the Arts program. Her personal involvement, wisdom and leadership were so valued by many who sought her advice and assistance, and she was honored by multiple organizations over the years. The family will have a private interment. A memorial service will be held at a later date. The family will receive visitors from 5 to 9 p.m. on Tuesday (July 28) and Thursday (July 30) at the home of Alec Cecil, Pelham, NY, and on Wednesday (July29 ) at the home of Leslie Cecil, Mt. Kisco, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Student Advocacy, 3 West Main Street, Suite 212, Elmsford, NY 10523 or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

CECIL--Jane. The YWCA White Plains & Central Westchester is saddened by the passing of our dear friend, former board member and long-time supporter, Jane Cecil. She inspired and ignited our flame for justice. 1/3

ALBERT--Jack, N.,92, of Boca Raton, died July 25th. A Navy Veteran and graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he represented clients including Mad Magazine. Jack was a lifelong New York and San Francisco Giants baseball fan, a Bridge Life Master, a voracious reader, a lover of movies, classical music and opera. Most importantly, he was a loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. A Memorial Service will be held at the South Florida National Cemetery, 6501 S State Road 7, Lake Worth, FL on Tuesday, July 28 at 10:30am. Donations to the charity of your choice. 1/3

CECIL--Jane, Student Advocacy mourns the passing of our Board member Jane Cecil. She was a great lady and a life-long advocate for children. She made a difference in this world. The Board and Staff of Student Advocacy 1/3
ZANKEL--Arthur. I can't believe it's ten years. In my heart and my thoughts every day. Love always, Judy 1/3

LITT--Alvin, 82 years young. Beloved husband of Abby, big brother of Len and Mona, father of Sarah and Elan, Eli and Lisa, grandpa to Elsie, Violet and Max. Born November 4, 1932, he left us too soon on Tish B'Av July 26, 2015. Services 12:30pm, Tuesday, July 28, 2015, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at West 91st Street, NYC, 212.769.4400. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center will be warmly appreciated. 1/3
AMRON--Howard C. The members of the Wednesday Ten, formed over 55 years ago, mourn the passing of one of our founding members. Wednesday Ten 1/3

ROTHENBERG--Selma. SAR mourns the loss of Selma Rothenberg, beloved mother of SAR Honorary Trustee Susan (and Scott) Shay, grandmother of Benjamin and SAR Alumnae, Ariel, Alison and Abigail. May the Shay/Rothenberg family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President 1/3

HILLMAN--Kathleen, (nee Powers) of Stewart Manor, NY died peacefully in her sleep on Monday, July 27, 2015. Beloved wife of the late George C. Hillman who died in 1987, and survived by her children George C. (Anne), Maryellen, James (Ellen), Kathleen Simmons (the late Bruce), Margaret Buonomo (Joseph), Virginia, and Patricia Pender (Michael). She is also survived by her loving grandchildren George Courtland (Court), Katherine, Conor, Meghan, Jennifer, Jack, Maggie, Emma, Siobhan and Erin. Kathleen was a long-time employee of Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre and volunteered at both St. Clare's Church in Rosedale and St. Ann's Church (Garden City). Visitation will be held at Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave., Williston Park, N.Y. on Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:00am at St Clare's RC Church, Rosedale, N.Y. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations be made to a memorial scholarship created in her behalf. Inquiries about donations can be sent to kphfund@gmail.com. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Marc. With profound sadness, the family of Marc Rosenberg announces his death on July 26th after a valiant battle with cancer. Founder and Executive Producer of Lost Highway Films, emerging novelist and wine lover, Marc was known for his maverick creativity, kind and nurturing spirit, and for his joyful embrace of life. He is survived by his partner, Susie Lodise of New York City, his son Brandon Rosenberg of New York City, his mother Frieda Rosenberg Baron of Boynton Beach, FL, his sister Ellen Rosenberg of Winston-Salem, NC, his brother Jamie Rosenberg of New York City, and his niece Blake Kovner of Seattle, WA. Beloved by his family and cherished by his friends, he will be deeply missed. Services will be held Tuesday evening, July 28th, at 6pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to cancer research. 1/3
